column1: List of All CSCW 2014 Papers Submissions

column3: Title
column9: Author list
column100: Keywords
column101: Abstract
column102: Eligibility for Best Student Paper Award

column3: Social Networking Site Use by Recent Mothers
column9: Meredith Morris
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: In this paper, we present the first formal study of how recent mothers (of children aged three and under) use social networking sites, particularly Facebook and Twitter, including mothers’ perceptions of which SNSes are appropriate for sharing information about their children, changes in post style and frequency after birth, and the volume and nature of child-related content shared in these venues. Our findings have implications for improving the utility and usability of SNS tools for recent mothers, as well as for creating and improving sociotechnical systems related to maternal and child health.

column3: Socio-technical Trajectories: A Structural Framework for Analyzing Event Log Data
column9: Brian Keegan, Darren Gergle
column100: Social network analysis; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Socio-technical systems like Wikipedia and GitHub encode a variety of implicit relationships within the digital traces of their user contributions. While prevailing social network analysis approaches can capture explicitly declared relationships, they ignore contextual and time-dependent interactions pervasive in social computing systems. We propose a method to recover these more implicit relationships from these archived event log data to identify the ``trajectories'' of both users and artifacts as they progress through the system over time.  This socio-technical trajectory framework provides an intermediate structural representation by reducing melding large quantitative analyses of digital trace data into more parsimonious representations. In particular, these structural signatures reveal regularities in action as well as anomalies in the behavior of users and artifacts that can motivate follow-on qualitative investigations of social roles, communities of practice, and institutional repertoires of action. We evaluate the mixed method potential of this approach with case studies of user and project activity on two large and noisy socio-technical systems, GitHub and Wikipedia.

column3: Social Media Supporting Political Deliberation Across Multiple Public Spheres: Towards Depolarization
column9: Bryan Semaan, Scott Robertson, Sara Douglas, Misa Maruyama
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: This paper reports on a qualitative study of social media use by 21 US citizens. In observing people’s interactions in the “sprawling public” sphere across multiple social media tools (in both political and non-political spaces), we found that social media supported the interactional dimensions of deliberative democracy—the interaction with media and the interaction between people. Social media supported people’s interaction with media as people used multiple tools through which they: were serendipitously exposed to diverse political information, constructed diverse information feeds, and disseminated information. Social media also supported people’s interactions with others, as people used multiple tools to engage in respectful and reasoned political discussions with diverse audiences. When one tool was lacking people often adopted or re-appropriated another tool. On a deeper level, we discuss how these interactions can have a depolarizing effect on the political beliefs and attitudes in the public sphere.

column3: The Documentscape of Global Software Development
column9: Lars Rune Christensen, Pernille Bjorn
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: On the basis of a field study this article introduces the concept of documentscape to the analysis of document-centric work practices. The field study is of global software development that entails or rests on the creation of a multitude of specialized documents taking their meaning from their position in an ensemble of documents, used or produced serially or in parallel, and usually by many people working together. The concept of documentscape refers to the entire ensemble of documents, in their mutual intertextual interlocking. We will argue that the effect of the intertextual relations between the documents constituting the documentscape is to draw the globally distributed activities of working with the documents together. In introducing the concept of documentscape, this paper outlines an approach to the investigation and conception of ensembles of documents in highly distributed cooperative work practices.

column3: Navigating Imagined Audiences: ‘Outward’ and ‘Inward’ Motivations for Participating in the Online Public Sphere
column9: Bryan Semaan, Scott Robertson, Heather Faucett, Misa Maruyama, Sara Douglas
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: This paper reports on a qualitative interview study of social media use for political participation. We interviewed 27 residents of the state of Hawaii who had integrated one or more social media tools into their daily lives so as to participate in the online public sphere by disseminating information and engaging with others. We found that users were utilizing social media to satisfy outward and inward motivations. On the one hand, people chose media so as to satisfy the needs of others (outward motivations) through the dissemination of information, and by calling people to action. On the other hand, people chose social media to satisfy their own needs (inward motivations) for social connectedness, sensemaking, catharsis and entertainment. Media choice and satisfaction were tied to people’s perception of the audiences within any particular media.

column3: Critical Reflection: A Visualization of Computer Use in K-12 Education
column9: Rona Sagi
column100: User experience/interaction design; Workflow management; Other domain-specific support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Education researchers are identifying discrepancies between designers intentions, or technological capability, and the practical implementation of computers in the classroom. Studies in k-12 education show that teachers often use computers in traditional pedagogical practices, far from the powerful learning environment envisioned by so many. This work addresses the concern of the education community by proposing a new, sustainable and time effective solution that reduces the reliance on traditional training. Inspired by sociocultural approaches and value-centred HCI principals, a new digital artefact has been designed for the professional development of teachers. The Reflective Computing Interface (RCI) is a customisable visualisation of personal computing analytics. The visualisation applies an inclusive approach to technology design by providing access to information that has traditionally marginalised the common personal computer user.

column3: Inferring the Origin Locations of Tweets with Quantitative Confidence
column9: Reid Priedhorsky, Aron Culotta, Sara Del Valle
column100: Social network analysis; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Privacy/access control/trust; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: Social Internet content plays an increasingly critical role in many domains, including public health, disaster management, and politics. However, its utility is limited by lack of geographic information; for example, fewer than 1.6% of Twitter messages (tweets) contain a geotag. We propose a scalable, content-based approach to estimate the location of tweets using a novel yet simple variant of gaussian mixture models tuned for this task. Further, given that real-world applications depend on quantified uncertainty of such estimates, we propose novel metrics of accuracy, precision, and calibration, and we evaluate our approach accordingly. Experiments on 13 million global, comprehensively multi-lingual tweets show that our approach yields reliable, well-calibrated results competitive with previous computationally intensive methods. Our results also show that a relatively small number of training data are required for good estimates (roughly 30,000 tweets), and trained models are quite time-invariant (effective on tweets many weeks newer than the training set). Finally, we offer an analysis of which content types provide the best location signals.

column3: Understanding Individuals’ Personal Values from Social Media Word Use
column9: Jilin Chen, Gary Hsieh, Jalal Mahmud, Jeffrey Nichols
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: The theory of values posits that each person has a set of values, or desirable, trans-situational goals that motivate one's actions. The Basic Human Values, a motivational construct that captures people's values, have been shown to influence a wide range of human behaviors. In this work, we analyze people's values and their word use on Reddit, an online social news sharing community. Through conducting surveys and analyzing text contributions of 799 Reddit users, we identify and interpret categories of words that are indicative of user’s value-orientations. Using the same data we further report a preliminary exploration on word-based prediction of Basic Human Values.

column3: By Source or By Issue? How Content Aggregation Method Impacts Perceptions of Political Issues
column9: Eric Baumer, Mitchell Davis, Geri Gay
column100: Other domain-specific support; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Significant research has explored integrating various types of computational analysis into interactive tools for readers of political content. However, relatively little attention has been paid to exactly how that content is aggregated for analysis. This paper explores this question by comparing two alternatives: aggregating content based on the source in which it is published, and aggregated content based on the issue to which it pertains. Here, we focus on how these two different aggregation methods support frame reflection, the ability to consider alternative framings of a given political issue, in the context of healthcare. The results suggest that issue-based aggregation significantly impacts participants’ demonstrated capacity for frame reflection, but they provide little evidence that source-based aggregation is helpful. These results not only contribute the literature on framing and on supporting frame reflection, but they also provide valuable implications and future directions for the design of interactive tools applying computational analysis to political content.

column3: Why Are You More Engaged? Personality as Predictor of Social Engagement Behavior
column9: Jalal Mahmud, Jilin Chen, Jeffrey Nichols
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: We present a study to analyze the role of personality as predictor of social engagement behaviors. We particularly investigated how people with different personality exhibited different reply and retweet behaviors on Twitter. Our analysis considered scenarios when such social engagements involve friends or strangers in social network.  We also found personality attributes that show significant correlations with such social engagement behaviors. In addition, we have built predictive models of responses and retweets based on such personality attributes. Our experiments using two real world datasets validate our findings.

column3: Topical Selectivity and Friending Behavior on Facebook
column9: Lilian Weng, Thomas Lento
column100: Social network analysis; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: Social network sites empower people to easily communicate online, generating an unprecedented amount of data for studying human interaction and social behavior. Here we explore two major research questions using Facebook data: Do conversion topics influence the friending behavior? Do people talk to friends differently? The principle of homophily suggests that people tend to befriend others with shared characteristics, such as similar interests or social circles. We present an analysis from an egocentric viewpoint, revealing that friends who favor similar conversation topics form dense, growing, and isolated clusters. The selection of content about which one communicates with another is related with not only the individual interests but also the strength of social tie in-between. Our finding hints at many potential applications in modern social network sites, including content recommendation, news ranking, friends grouping, and social circle detection. As a demonstration of prospective uses, we succeed to infer individual topical preference with a good accuracy using content popularity, structure of local neighborhood, and social tie strengths.

column3: Collaboration in Education: Can Learning Designers Work Collaboratively in Creating Adaptive Learning Materials?
column9: Dade Nurjanah
column100: E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: There is a classic issue in learning and teaching where many students register in the course that learners’ characteristics are differs. To accommodate the diversity, recent developments in the field of learning systems have led to adaptive-personalised learning which considers learner models when performing pedagogical-related decisions. As a consequence, learning designers are required to create learning content, pedagogical knowledge, adaptation rules, learner model, and interfaces to support adaptation and personalisation. Hence, collaboration among learning designers is important. A challenge emerges as learning designers view learning from various pedagogical dimensions, which make it potentially fall into a fail when they can not find a concensus. This paper discusses our study on authors’ collaboration in authoring adaptive-learning resources. The study was specifically focused on how learning designers approach collaborative authoring of pedagogical knowledge and learner models and in which level of granularity learning designers can work collaboratively.

column3: Shifting the Focus from Private to Public: Considerations for the Design of Interactive Digital Bulletin Boards
column9: Claude Fortin, Carman Neustaedter, Kate Hennessy
column32: School of Interactive Arts and Technology
column100: Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: The next decade is likely to see a shift in digital public displays moving from non-interactive to interactive content thereby creating forms of digital bulletin boards.  With this shift comes a need to understand how such displays should best be designed to encourage community members to engage and interact with the displays. We examine this by exploring prominent non-digital interactive displays in society, namely community bulletin boards, as cultural artifacts “in the wild.” Our results highlight the ways in which bulletin boards are used for content of local relevance and how cultures of participation, architecture, location, and personalization affect community members’ interactions with the boards.  This suggests key design considerations, each intrinsically linked to the users’ sense of agency within a delineated physical space. We discuss them in relation to geographic relevance, contextual relevance, and entry points for action and participation.

column3: How Social Cues Regulate Task Coordination and Communication
column9: Allison Sauppé, Bilge Mutlu
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing
column101: To design computer-supported collaborative work (CSCW) systems that effectively support remote collaboration, designers need a better understanding of how people collaborate face-to-face and the mechanisms that they use to coordinate their actions. While research in CSCW has studied how specific social cues might facilitate collaboration in specific tasks, such as the role of gestures in video instruction, how a range of communicative cues might facilitate activities across many collaborative settings is unknown. In this paper, we model the predictive relationships between facial, gestural, and vocal cues and collaborative outcomes in three different tasks, drawing conclusions on how each cue might contribute to these outcomes in a given task and how such relationships generalize across tasks. The results highlight differences in \ how collaborators use gaze, the importance of shared context for some tasks, and how different gestures (particularly deictic gestures) facilitate collaborative outcomes. Our findings offer key theoretical and design insights.

column3: Giving is Caring: Understanding Donation Behavior through Email
column9: Yelena Mejova, Venkata Garimella, Ingmar Weber
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Every day, thousands of people make donations to humanitarian, political, environmental, and other causes, a large amount of which occur on the Internet. In this paper, we describe a comprehensive large-scale data-driven study of donation behavior. We analyze a two-month anonymized email log from several perspectives motivated by past studies on charitable giving: demographics, user interest, external time-related factors and social network influence. We show that email captures the demographic peculiarities of different interest groups, for instance, predicting demographic distributions found in US 2012 Presidential Election exit polls. Furthermore, we find that people respond to major national events, as well as to solicitations with special promotions, and that social connections are the most important factor in predicting donation behavior. Specifically, we identify trends not only for individual charities and campaigns, but also for high-level categories such as political campaigns, medical illnesses, and humanitarian relief. Thus, we show the extent to which large-scale email datasets reveal human donation behavior, and explore the limitations of such analysis.

column3: Ubiquitous, Connecting, Interrupting: How Push Notifications Affect our Daily Lives
column9: Martin Pielot, Rodrigo de Oliveira, Karen Church
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: Push notifications on smartphones notify users of a wide range of events, such as the arrival of a new email or a new comment on a post in a social network, when the respective applications are not in foreground. Given that they are at the core of many applications, push notifications frequently compete for the user’s attention. The goal of this work is to gain an understanding of how notifications affect our daily lives.  \ In this paper, we report the results of a one-week, in-situ study, where we collected real-world log data and daily diaries from 15 information workers.  \ We found that notifications are frequent and a source of interruption and social pressure. Reasons are that mobile phones travel between private and work domain, and connect us with the people we care as well as with our work emails. However, our results indicate that rather than reducing the number of notifications, there are opportunities in delivering messages through the right channels at the right time.

column3: Tinkering around healthcare infrastructures. Nursing practices and junction work
column9: Enrico Piras, Alberto Zanutto, Claudio Eccher
column23: Dipartimento di Sociologia e Ricerca Sociale
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Collaboration architectures; Medical and health support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Introduction of healthcare infrastructures is often accompanied by workarounds, persistence of paper-based documents and of technologies that the innovation was intended to replace, raising the question as to whether they are by-products or intrinsic to infrastructure innovation processes. \  \ This work, through a longitudinal case study of a hospital information system long in use, investigates  their origin, their role in enabling the system’s affirmation, and the difficulty of eliminating them. Through a qualitative methodology (semi-structured interviews and ethnography) we reconstruct the history of the system and the information management practices around it. \  \ Our analysis reveals that the effectiveness of the tool implemented derived largely from 'junction work' performed by the nurses, and which ensured the flow of data among different electronic and paper-based information systems. Moreover, in carrying out their junction work the nurses intervened to modify, enrich and complete the information contained in the different systems.

column3: Travelling with Digital Media:  Keeping Kids Busy in the Car
column9: Chandrika Cycil, Mark Perry, Eric Laurier
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: Keeping children adequately occupied in the car can be challenging for parents, and it is not surprising that digital media have become an entrenched tool for keeping them busy. However, as we have seen in our data, electronic devices such as phones, tablets and portable games require more active collaboration from parents than merely handing over these technologies to children and expecting them to occupy themselves. Drawing on video extracts and observations from field visits collecting over a period of seven months, this paper explores how parents and children engage collaboratively with media during car journeys. We discuss the difficulties around keeping children occupied in the car while examining the interactions and media appropriations that take place within this context. We conclude with a discussion of how technology design could be enriched by better attending to the social interactions and family practices around media use in the car.

column3: With a Little Help from my Friends:  Resisting Temptation with Social Media Primes
column9: Jamie Guillory, Jeff Hancock
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Medical and health support
column101: Mobile Apps and online communities offer opportunities to help people make healthier choices (i.e., controlling weight).  Social features in these venues are important for users’ success in making healthy behavioral changes. One reason for this is that even minimal social support can provide psychosocial resources that help people cope with challenging circumstances. An experiment tested this idea in a social media context by priming a person to think about social support by sending a text message to a friend before being tempted to eat unhealthy food. Findings show that participants who sent a content-neutral text message to a friend ate less unhealthy food compared to participants who saved the message in their phone. The social support effect was bounded by a participant’s stress level, suggesting that although a text message prime can influence eating, the effect is limited. Implications for research in computer-mediated communication, social support, and design are discussed.

column3: Mobile Campaign Designer: An End-User Programming Toolkit for Creating Crowdsensing Applications
column9: Scott Heggen, Amul Adagale, Jamie Payton
column15: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column24: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column33: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column100: Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Mobile and embedded devices; Crowdsourcing; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Crowdsensing has the potential to support human-driven sensing and data collection at an unprecedented scale. While many organizers of data collection campaigns have extensive domain knowledge, they do not necessarily have the skills required to develop robust software for crowdsensing. In this paper, we present Mobile Campaign Designer, a tool supporting end-user programming of mobile crowdsensing applications. Using Mobile Campaign Designer, organizers are able to define parameters about their crowdsensing campaign, and the tool generates the source code and an executable for a tailored mobile application. This mobile application embodies the current best practices in crowdsensing and is freely distributable by the campaign organizer. A user study was conducted to evalute Mobile Campaign Designer, and the results show that users at all levels of technical expertise are capable of creating a crowdsensing application in an average of five minutes, and the generated applications are comparable in quality to existing crowdsensing applications.

column3: Understanding the Communication Ecosystem Formed by Caregivers of Children with Type 1 Diabetes
column9: Yi Han, Gregory Abowd, Rosa Arriaga
column100: Medical and health support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Type 1 diabetes is a serious chronic condition that is difficult to manage for children. Their bodies are changing rapidly due to growth so their treatment plans need to change frequently. As these changes occur, communications need to take place to keep all the caregivers informed. We conducted interviews to investigate the needs and communications that occur between the caregivers at home, at school and at the clinic for children with diabetes as a first step in modeling the roles of communication in this ecosystem. We found that the current system is acceptable but substantial improvements can be made.

column3: Beyond Selective Exposure in Social Media: Concrete Evidence for Partisan Sharing
column9: Jisun An, Daniele Quercia, Jon Crowcroft
column100: Social network analysis; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: The idea behind selective exposure is that people crave like-minded information and eschew conflicting information, and that has negative consequences on political discourse. Hitherto this hypothesis remains empirically difficult to test. Based on the political science literature on selective exposure, we derive a set of hypotheses on what we call partisan sharing-the tendency for users to predominantly share like-minded news articles. We test these hypotheses upon both news articles shared on Facebook, and opinions shared on a political website we built. We find concrete evidence for partisan sharing, which, however, does not apply to every single user all the time. It  applies to specific individuals, as it is high for those who are knowledgeable about or simply interested in politics. It changes over time, as it tends to decrease during US primary elections. We also find that it impacts whether one will vote in a general election or not. \

column3: Aesthetic Capital: What Makes London Look Beautiful, Quiet, and Happy?
column9: Daniele Quercia, Neil O'Hare, Henriette Cramer
column23: Yahoo! Research, Yahoo! Lab, Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Location-based and context-aware computing; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: In the 1960s, Kevin Lynch's "The Image of the City" explored what impression US city neighborhoods  left on its inhabitants.  Till now, however, the scale of urban perception studies has been considerably constrained by the quantity of experimental subjects used. That is why we have been working on a crowdsourcing project that can help us find out what it is about the look of a particular neighborhood that makes it appear to be beautiful, quiet, and happy. We collect votes from more than 3K individuals and translate them into quantitative measures of urban perception (i.e., of aesthetic capital). By then using state-of-the-art image processing techniques,  we determine the visual cues that make a place appear beautiful, quiet, and happy. The amount of greenery is the most positively associated visual cue with each of three qualities; by contrast, broad streets,  fortress-like buildings, and council houses tend to be negatively associated.

column3: Strategies for Targeted Sharing: A Qualitative Study and Supporting Tool
column9: Saiph Savage, Leif Singer, Angus Forbes, Carlos Toxtli, Grant McKenzie, Tobias Hollerer
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Social network analysis; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Some users of social network sites such as Facebook participate in them to promote a certain cause — be it a political \ group, an art project, or a business. These users mention and \ tag other users in their posts to improve their content’s visibility: they conduct targeted sharing. However, choosing the right users to target is not an easy task. In a qualitative study, we explore the motivations, strategies, and challenges in targeted sharing. \  \ The results from this study inform the design of a search and \ exploration tool that supports users in finding people who are \ most relevant for a topic. Participants in a first evaluation of \ our tool felt that finding an audience for targeted sharing is \ easier than it is with list-based interfaces.

column3: “On Second Thought”: Sampling Location-Sharing Decisions to Analyze Mismatches With Access Preferences
column9: Sameer Patil, Roman Schlegel, Apu Kapadia, Adam Lee
column14: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology HIIT
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: Given the increasing popularity of location-sharing systems and the ever-expanding size of individuals' social networks, it is becoming  cumbersome for people to specify their information-sharing preferences a priori, or even anticipate the types of situations that may lead to privacy violations. To this end, researchers have recently proposed `exposure-aware' systems that convey feedback about accesses to location so that people can adjust or react to undesirable exposure. Yet,  little is known about how or why one's stated preferences conflict with one's actual preferences. Our goal is to inform the design of exposure-aware systems by studying (1)~the extent to which people's pre-specified sharing settings diverge from their in situ sharing decisions; (2)~the level of comfort or disagreement with automated system decisions based on stated preferences; and (3)~various contextual factors that contribute to such divergence. We report our findings based on a 15-day ESM study (N=35). \

column3: Privacy Impacts of Long Term Ubiquitous Surveillance and Its Removal
column9: Sameer Patil, Antti Oulasvirta, Aurora Pihlajamaa
column14: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology HIIT
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: A rich understanding of how people experience surveillance characteristics of sensor rich systems is essential for mitigating their inherent privacy threats. Toward this end we extend earlier findings on a naturalistic investigation long term ubiquitous surveillance with a particular focus on termination of surveillance. We monitored 12 participants from 10 households using a sensor rich surveillance system and report on semi-structured individual interviews conducted after the system was uninstalled from the household. Participants \ responses to the removal range from relative indifference to euphoria. We examine diversity in participant experiences by applying a six dimensional theory of privacy. Results indicated that such a breakdown can be more illuminating compared to a monolithic treatment of privacy.

column3: Ad hoc Participation in Situation Assessment: Mobile Collaboration Practices in Emergencies
column9: Christian Reuter, Thomas Ludwig, Volkmar Pipek
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Distributed/virtual teams; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Emergencies are characterized by a high complexity and unpredictability. In order to assess and manage them successfully, improvisation work and informal communication, even beyond local and organizational boundaries, is needed. Such informal practices can facilitate ad hoc participation of involved units in situation assessment, but may lack overall situation awareness. This paper presents a study on how emergent ‘collaboration needs’ in current work of response teams, who are located on-site and in the control center, could be supported by mobile geo-collaboration systems. First, we present the results of an empirical study about informal work and mobile collaboration practices of emergency services. Then we will describe the concept of a mobile geo-collaboration system that addresses the aspects detected in the empirical study and was implemented as an Android application using web sockets, a technology enabling full-duplex ad hoc communication. Finally we outline the findings of its evaluation in practice.

column3: Collaborative metaphor for haptic designation in complex 3D environments
column9: Adrien Girard, Mehdi Ammi, Malika Auvray
column100: User experience/interaction design; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies
column101: Designating targets, such as elementary primitives (e.g., vertices, edges and faces) or complex objects (e.g., 3D objects and structures), to a partner in Collaborative Virtual Environments is a real challenge in different applications. In fact, the communication constraints in such environments limit the understanding of the partner's actions, which lead to wrong selections and thus to conflicting actions. \ Beyond these limitations, applications providing complex data to manipulate, such as molecular environments, introduce additional constraints which limit the perception and access to the partner's working space. \ This paper proposes a remote designation procedure linked with an haptic attraction model for molecular deformation tasks, we propose to guide physically the partner to the designated atom. \ Experimental results showed a significant improvement in performance and efficiency for the different steps of collaborative tasks (i.e., designation/selection of atoms and deformation of structures). Moreover, this haptic guidance method enables more accurate selections of atoms for the partner.

column3: Sent From: A Field Experiment Exploring Location Sharing and Butler Lying in Text Messaging
column9: Madeline Smith, Jeremy Birnholtz, Lindsay Reynolds, Jeff Hancock
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: While cell phones allow us to stay constantly connected, there are times when people wish to avoid interaction. People often use deception in these situations in order to manage their unavailability while preserving their rela- tionships. These deceptions, called butler lies, are plausible because contextual information, such as where the sender is located, is ambiguous in text messages. New services threaten this ambiguity and people’s abilities to tell plausible butler lies. To test this claim, we built a text-messaging app that manipulated location ambiguity by allowing users to share their locations. Our participants shared their location less often when telling butler lies, suggesting that location ambiguity is important for unavailability management. Our app also provides a methodological contribution for gathering and analyzing message-level data.

column3: Email Inbox Dynamics in an Information Overloaded Environment
column9: Yoram Kalman, Gilad Ravid
column24: Ben Gurion University of the Negev
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; B2B / information systems; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Information overload is a hallmark of the daily challenges faced by knowledge workers who use collaborative technologies to carry out their work. This study focuses on the most ubiquitous of these technologies, email, and unobtrusively explores the inbox management activities of thousands of users worldwide. The study reveals a diverse set of strategies for dealing with the constant inflow of messages: reading them, classifying them, responding to them in a timely manner, and archiving them for future reference. Based on the observed characteristics and behaviors, we propose a quantitative index that can be used to classify those management strategies, and propose that this index is a refinement and improvement of Whittaker and Sidner's [18] widely cited trichotomous classification of users into 'frequent filers', 'spring cleaners' and 'no-filers'. Our findings and the proposed index suggest tools to better understand different strategies for coping with email information overload, and to study the fit between these strategies and users' needs.

column3: Supporting Trust in Globally Distributed Software Teams
column9: Erik Trainer, David Redmiles
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Collaborative software development
column101: A significant obstacle to the development of trust in distributed teams is that distributed team members are more likely than collocated team members to erroneously interpret the reasons for their colleagues' negative behavior. So-called "attribution errors" can erode trust among collaborators. In a laboratory study of 40 subjects, we sought to investigate whether a software engineering awareness tool called Theseus could engender trust among distributed software developers by supporting accurate attribution. The results show that Theseus directly affects the kinds of attributions subjects make and the perceived trustworthiness they have toward their collaborators. In particular, subjects make more accurate attributions with Theseus and their perceived trustworthiness of their collaborators more accurately reflects actual circumstances. Our results shed new light on the role that awareness tools can play in distributed software developers' interpersonal relationships.

column3: Practices of craft in building software
column9: Jessica Lingel, Tim Regan
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; User experience/interaction design
column101: Drawing on interviews with 12 software engineers, we investigate the relationship between developers and the tools they use to build code through the lens of craft. We conceptualize the tools identified by participants as necessary for building code in terms of producing software (such as IDEs) and those used for externalizing thought processes (such as whiteboards and notebooks). We also analyze the ways in which developers talk about selecting one tool over another for building code, revealing tensions of perceiving code as, on the one hand, highly rational, and on the other, deeply personal and embodied. In working through these tensions of code as abstract and concrete, cerebral and intuitive, we note implications for craft, both as a theory relevant to computer human interaction, and for paradigms of education in computer science.

column3: Learning from Failure or Failing to Learn: Experiencing Public Failure Online Through Crowdfunding
column9: Michael Greenberg, Elizabeth Gerber
column100: Crowdsourcing; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: We investigate the consequences of and reactions to public online failure through the lens of crowdfunding. Through a mixed-methods study of Kickstarter.com we wish to address the following broad question in an exploratory manner: What are the reactions to failure in crowdfunding online? Online crowdfunding is gaining attention among novice entrepreneurs as an effective platform for funding their ventures. However, a focus on the quantity of financial exchange and several wildly successful projects has obscured the fact that over 58% of crowdfunding projects fail to achieve their funding goals. Drawing inspiration from literature on failure in entrepreneurial ventures and social motivation, we explain the reactions to and coping mechanisms for failure in online crowdfunding. Results indicate that relaunched projects succeed roughly half the time. We also find that project creators find failure to be a largely positive experience. This has implications for designing creative platforms online where failure, both public and private are considered.

column3: A Partial Replication Approach for Anywhere Anytime Mobile Commenting
column9: Huanhuan Xia, Tun LU, Bin Shao, Guo Li, Xianghua Ding, Ning Gu
column100: Concurrency control
column101: Commenting systems play increasingly important roles in the interactive web applications. Meanwhile, more and more web applications are visited on mobile devices. However, most existing commenting systems are not mobile ready. The intermittent connection of mobile networks poses great challenges to both smooth interaction and data consistency. On the one hand, smooth user interaction requires non-blocking commenting and high responsiveness. On the other hand, data consistency must be guaranteed due to the simultaneous commenting actions on the same thread. As an optimistic replication technique that achieves high responsiveness while maintaining consistency, group editing technique can well meet the system requirements of mobile commenting. In this paper, we propose a novel partial replication approach specially designed to provide smooth commenting experience on mobile devices. Users are allowed to freely comment anywhere anytime. The comment thread can be incrementally updated and automatically synchronized with strong data consistency guarantees. We implemented a system prototype called Hydra and evaluated it on a real data set.

column3: CO-SI Card method: how to refine and validate concepts through a scenario generator framework.
column9: Cedric Mivielle, Cedric Mivielle, ANNIE GENTES, Maxence Mauduit
column100: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; User experience/interaction design; Collaborative software development
column101: This paper describes a design method named “CO-SI Card” that was created and used in a collaborative project with a multidisciplinary team for the design of crossmedia services. This method allows the creation of a tangible and visual tool that generates intermediate representations of situations of communication. These representations optimize the collaboration between members in engaging and playful ways. The purpose of this method is to refine and validate concept(s) by confronting them to random scenarios built with cards but also to explore the potential of the project. We argue first that it is necessary to create tools that allow collaborative team to both diverge and converge in the design process. Then we consider how creating intermediate objects that support a semiotic system where transformations can be operated helps this divergent/convergent process. We present the method, communication situations cards stack that is a scenario generator framework and how to replicate it. We analyze the case of a project. Finally, we discuss possible improvements and limitations.

column3: Freedom To Tweet or Tweet To Freedom: The Relationship Between Freedom Status and Tweets During Elections
column9: Zahra Ashktorab, Jennifer Golbeck
column100: Social network analysis; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: Social media platforms have become widely used on a global scale. Twitter has emerged as a global Internet venue for expressing opinions and has played an instrumental role in elections, governmental policy changes and even contributing to entire regime changes. For example, Egypt’s revolution was highly influenced by social media (Eltantawy & Wiest, 2011). In this paper, we conduct an exploratory study of the relationship between a country's freedom status, which indicates a country’s civil liberties and political rights, and Twitter activity during elections. We utilize global Twitter use to compare the relationship between tweets, freedom status of a country, and election outcome. Using a combination of network analysis and text analysis, we explore the trends that emerge among nine different countries with different freedom statuses during their respective elections, and present our observations and hypotheses for future work.

column3: Beyond “Bieber Fever”: Exploring Teens’ Engagement with Online Video and YouTube
column9: Alexander Thayer, Melanie Kellar
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Social Networking Site Design and Use; User experience/interaction design
column101: This study expands the current understanding of how teens augment their lives with online video. We conducted a video diary study and in-person interviews with teens across the US to understand their daily media habits and practices, their educational uses of online video, and their specific experiences with YouTube. We observed that video plays an instrumental role in building intimacy with both friends and parents, understanding personally meaningful topics (potentially while also building intimacy with others), and supporting formal learning endeavours. Our findings enhance the currently slim literature base regarding teens’ engagement with online video.

column3: Competing or Aiming to be Average? Normification as a means of engaging digital volunteers
column9: Chris Preist, Elaine Massung, David Coyle
column100: Crowdsourcing; Other domain-specific support
column101: Engagement, motivation and active contribution by digital volunteers are key requirements for crowdsourcing and citizen science projects. Many systems use competitive elements, for example point scoring and leaderboards, to achieve these ends. However, while competition may motivate some people, psychological theories of norm conduct suggest that it can have a neutral or demotivating effect on many. In this paper we explore theories of personal and social norms and investigate normification as an alternative approach to engagement, to be used alongside or instead of competitive strategies. We provide a systematic review of existing crowdsourcing and citizen science literature and categorise the ways that theories of norms have been incorporated to date. We then present qualitative interview data from a pro-environmental crowdsourcing study, Close The Doors, which reveals normalising attitudes in certain participants. We assess how this links with competitive behaviour and participant performance. Based on our findings, and our analysis of norm theories, we propose guidelines for the use of normification in crowdsourcing and citizen science.

column3: The Reader-to-Leader Framework: An Empirical Evaluation
column9: Ofer Arazy, Lisa Yeo, Oded Nov, Felipe Ortega
column33: Polytechnic Institute of New York University
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Crowdsourcing
column101: Participants in open collaboration initiatives, such as open source software development or Wikipedia, can play different roles: from peripheral members to core contributors who take part in the project’s administration. In a widely influential paper, Preece and Shneiderman proposed the ‘Reader to Leader’ (R2L) framework: a conceptualization of successive participation stages and the transitions between roles. The objective of this study is to empirically validate the R2L framework, and based on the study’s results offer directions for refinement of theory in the area. Focusing on the three stages closest to the core – contributor, collaborator, and leader - our research examines the frequency and duration of transitions between these stages. A large scale analysis of Wikipedia contributors reveals intricate patterns of stage transitions. In particular, our findings suggest that the collaborator stage is not an important stepping stone towards administrative leadership, hinting that there may be dual, orthogonal paths to community leadership.

column3: Reconstructing normality: The use of infrastructure leftovers in crisis situations as inspiration for the design of resilient technology
column9: Amro Al-Akkad, Leonardo Ramirez, Sebastian Denef
column15: Fraunhofer Institute for Applied Information Technology (FIT)
column24: Fraunhofer Institute for Applied Information Technology (FIT)
column33: Fraunhofer Institute for Applied Information Technology (FIT)
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Other domain-specific support
column101: In this paper, we examine challenges people face in situations of disrupted infrastructures and how people use surviving portions of technology to cope with these challenges. We show how an important aspect in crises is the disturbance of services caused by disruptions in underlying technological structures. In such situations, people resort to all possible means to create a new normality. Mechanisms arise where people use the remains of the technological landscape. Building on the analysis of interviews with crises witnesses and first responders, external reports and scientific literature, we propose and describe three categories of mechanisms involving the creative use of surviving technology in crisis situations. We argue that studying these mechanisms can provide a key source of inspiration to define qualities of resilient architectures, and use these mechanisms as creative input to propose architectural qualities that can potentially make communication infrastructures more resilient in the face of crises.

column3: The Effects of Consistency Maintenance Methods on Player Experience and Performance in Networked Games
column9: Cheryl Savery, Nick Graham, Carl Gutwin, Michelle Brown
column41: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column100: Entertainment/games; User experience/interaction design; Concurrency control
column101: Network lag is a fact of life for networked games and can cause game states to diverge at different nodes in the network, making it difficult to maintain the illusion of a single shared space. Lag compensation techniques have been proposed to try and maintain consistency. However, these techniques do not address all of the issues that arise due to diverging states. In particular, current understanding of consistency maintenance does not indicate how to make game-critical decisions when there are divergent views, nor does it indicate how to repair inconsistencies. These two issues – decision-making and error repair – can have substantial effects on how players view the game, but there is little information about these effects. To address this shortcoming, we carried out an experiment to test the effects of different choices. Our study confirms that decision-making and error repair can have significant effects on player experience and performance, and shows that that simple consistency is often not as important as these other factors.

column3: Distributed Affect as a Theoretical Framework For Analyzing Text-Based Communication
column9: Taylor Scott, Sean Mitchell, Megan Torkildson, Cecilia Aragon
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Historically, the study of affect has been intimately tied to theories of cognition, and there are still unexplored connections between these phenomena. In this paper, we propose an expanded formulation of distributed affect as a theoretical framework for analyzing the text-based communication of a distributed group that relies on chat to coordinate their work. We specifically elaborate parallels between theories of cognition that extend beyond the individual as the unit of analysis and the communication of affect between the members of the distributed group. We describe the methods used to code, sample, and analyze these chat logs, and validate our formulation of distributed affect through an examination of specific events in the group’s history. These examples highlight the unique ways affect is communicated via this medium, and provide support for our position that the analysis of affect must also extend beyond the individual.

column3: Toward Agent-Supported Situational Awareness in Disaster Response
column9: Stuart Moran, Nadia Pantidi, Tom Rodden
column100: Other domain-specific support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Recommender and Filtering Systems
column101: In Disaster Response situational awareness is critical; efficient and effective decision making depends on dynamic information being shared and considered among many stakeholders such as the responders on the ground, the local authorities, governmental advisors etc. The bigger the disaster the harder it gets to manage, communicate and share information. \ In this paper, we examine existing practices and the current technological state of the art of how information is shared and communicated across in three levels of command (operational, tactical, strategic) of urban search and rescue as observed in an international training exercise. We identify a set of challenges and propose that information management in urban search and rescue can benefit greatly from the integration of intelligent software systems. \

column3: Understanding and Improving Software Build Teams
column9: Shaun Phillips, Thomas Zimmermann, Christian Bird
column100: Collaborative software development; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Other domain-specific support
column101: Build, creating software from source code, is a fundamental activity in software development. Build teams manage this process to ensure builds are produced reliably and efficiently. However, despite their critical role, build teams have been largely unstudied. To address this deficiency, this paper presents an exploration into the nature of build teams--how they form, work, and relate to other teams--through three multi-method studies conducted at Microsoft. We also consider build team effectiveness and find that many challenges are social, not technical: role ambiguity, knowledge sharing, communication, trust, and conflict. Our findings validate theories from group dynamics and organization science, and using a cross-discipline approach, we apply learnings from these fields to inform the design of engineering tools and practices to improve build team effectiveness. Further, we discuss how our findings can be useful to organizations outside of the software engineering context.

column3: T-echo: Calendar-based Virtual Mentoring System
column9: Yuki Nagai, Atsushi Hiyama, Takahiro Miura, Michitaka Hirose
column14: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology
column23: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology
column32: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology
column41: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Privacy/access control/trust; Home/family/intimacy support; Crowdsourcing
column101: This paper proposes a context-aware social mentoring system, t-echo. Conventional e-mentoring systems have expanded to social mentoring, including computer-mediated mentoring systems based on the power of crowd-sourcing and social media, although the most suitable types of interactions for achieving good communication during mentoring have not been addressed. In previous studies, we discovered that social mentoring requires a moderate psychological distance between the mentor and mentee. Thus, we developed t-echo, which is a calendar-based mentoring system that facilitates mentorship based on the requirements of the mentee, what they have done previously, and what they have time to do. Our final aim is to achieve an intergenerational mentoring system based on t-echo. As a preliminary step, we conducted a field study using laboratory members. In this paper, we answer the following questions. 1) Does t-echo facilitate intergenerational mentoring? 2) Is SNS like communication necessary for calendar-based mentoring? 3) How much should we be concerned about privacy during calendar-based mentoring?

column3: Glaucus: Exploiting the Wisdom of Crowds for Location-Based Queries in Mobile Environments
column9: Minsoo Choy, Jae-Gil Lee, Gahgene Gweon, Daehoon Kim
column100: Location-based and context-aware computing; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Social network analysis
column101: In this paper, we build a social search engine named Glaucus for location-based queries. They compose a significant portion of mobile searches, thus becoming more popular with the prevalence of mobile devices. However, most of existing social search engines are not designed for location-based queries and thus often produce poor-quality results for such queries. Glaucus is inherently designed to support location-based queries. It collects the check-in information, which pinpoints the places where each user visited, from location-based social networking services such as Foursquare. Then, it calculates the expertise of each user for a query by using our new probabilistic model called the location aspect model. We conducted two types of evaluation to prove the effectiveness of our engine. The results showed that Glaucus selected the users supported by stronger evidence for the required expertise than an existing social search engine. In addition, the answers from the experts selected by Glaucus were highly rated by our human judges in terms of answer satisfaction.

column3: Rethinking Third Places: Contemporary Design With Technology
column9: Nemanja Memarovic, Sidney Fels, Roberto Calderon, Junia Anacleto, Federico Gobbo, John Carroll
column50: DISIM - Dep. of Inf. Eng., Comp. Science and Math.
column59: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Third places are defined by Oldenburg as “neutral, democratic, public, conversational, mundane, emotional, diverse, and novel”. These characteristics were established prior to the introduction of some current digital communication technologies, such as personal devices and social networking services, as well as consolidated changes in society, e.g., changes in the structure of work, race, and gender issues. In order to understand how technology changed the concept of third places (and how it changes the society) we looked at affordances and practices in nine third places in Paris. Through our field study we have reconsidered and reemphasized the relevance of the original Oldenburg’s characteristics of third places and added additional ones based on the changes in the society and technology. Our goal is to revisit third places concept in the current pervasive and ubiquitous technology era, informing how we can provide technology to support third places.

column3: Making IT “Pay a Bit Better”- Design Challenges for Micro Rural Enterprise
column9: Andy Crabtree, Alan Chamberlain
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Other domain-specific support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: This paper reports on a field study of small market in Wales undertaken as part of broader research project aimed at developing IT solutions to support rural enterprise. The project is predicated on the assumption that the primary challenge facing rural enterprise is that of scale and that IT solutions could and should add value by enabling growth. The study suggests that many rural enterprises are micro in character, that they are not driven by the need to grow, and that value is and can be added in different ways that reflect the social values oriented to and employed by micro businesses and their consumers. The paper elaborates vernacular understandings of supply chains and their coordination, along with business and consumer motivations to consider alternative possibilities for design that place emphasis on making micro rural enterprise ‘pay a bit better’ rather than scaling it up.

column3: (Stable) Virtual landmarks: Can it help to design the futuristic apps?
column9: Swadhin Pradhan, Ananth Balashankar, Niloy Ganguly, Bivas Mitra
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Mobile and embedded devices; Location-based and context-aware computing; Crowdsourcing
column101: Landmarks are signatures of our surroundings which help \ us to uniquely identify a location. Recent studies show \ that interestingly like us humans, it may be possible by the \ sensors on mobile devices to identify landmarks. This can \ open up the possibility of a lot of intelligent context-aware applications. However, to make \ such applications a reality, a particular landmark need to be \ stable across mobile phones, persons carrying the mobile \ phones etc. This paper speciﬁcally builds up a framework to \ discover such stable landmarks. \  \ The major challenge to build such a system lies in its \ enormous heterogeneity across the agents. In order to achieve this goal, we employ a clustering algorithm to explore the possibility of identifying landmarks from non-intuitive feature combination of sensors like accelerometer, gyroscope, magnetometer etc. We rigorously test the clusters to ensure that they are stable across different devices, people, and time, in both indoor and outdoor settings.

column3: Reflexive Modes of Knowing in Networks of Collaboration
column9: Emad Khazraee, Susan Gasson
column14: college of information science and technology
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaboration architectures; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: This paper explores tensions between paradigmatic knowledge, based on technology-mediated ontologies and categorizations, and narrative accounts that order emergent knowledge around epistemic objects. We use these modes of knowing to follow the creation, social construction, and acceptance of scientific knowledge based on an ethnographic field study of research groups in the field of Archaeology. We employ actor-network theory to explore the epistemic objects and material practices that affect the acceptance of new theories, explaining how narrative modes of knowing complement the dominant, paradigmatic modes. We conclude that the critical factor in how tensions between the two are resolved lies in amassing a critical mass of epistemic alignment around the emerging theory. Support for the two modes of knowing are both required for innovation in scientific research communities – these two modes must be considered in the design of information and communication systems that aim to advance the collective production of scientific knowledge.

column3: Augmented Reality Triage Training System with Monocular Head-Mounted Display
column9: Yoshiaki Ando, Misaki Hagino, Ken-ichi Okada
column14: Graduate School of Science and Technology
column23: Graduate School of Science and Technology
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Collaboration architectures; Medical and health support
column101: In recent years, the concept of triage in disaster response has attracted wide attention, and the implementation of triage training has become essential. Studies have focused on electronic triage systems that collect and manage information about patients through a network using electronic triage tags, but a training method for such systems has yet to be established. Here we propose an augmented reality (AR) triage training system that uses AR markers and a monocular head-mounted display (HMD) to superimpose dynamic information about patients onto real space. We prepared an application that assists in creating training scenarios, and displays simulated physiological information about patients on the HMD screen. In addition, trainees can reflect on the training by using the output of the training results. Evaluation experiments show that the system is able to create a training scenario rapidly, and to conduct training that reproduces various scenarios.

column3: “Figure Out How to Code with the Hands of Others”: Recognizing Cultural Blind Spots in Global Software Development
column9: Stina Matthiesen, Pernille Bjorn, Lise Petersen
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Distributed/virtual teams; Collaborative software development
column101: We report on an ethnographic study of an outsourcing global software development (GSD) setup between an Indian IT vendor and an IT development division of a Danish bank. We investigate how the local IT development work is shaped by the global setup in GSD and argue that the bank had cultural blind spots toward the changes in Denmark. Three critical issues were neglected due to the cultural blind spots: 1) increased number of interruptions, 2) invisibility of remote colleagues’ work, and 3) the re-definition of boundaries between work and articulation work. The implications of these findings include considerations for how to organize GSD practices and how to prepare the organizational changes that occur when moving from a co-located software development organization to an inter-organizational geographically distributed organization. Also our findings open up discussions about the professional identity of IT developers within GSD, which includes extending the qualifications for IT developers.

column3: Supporting Group Interactions in Museum Visiting
column9: Peter Tolmie, Steve Benford, Chris Greenhalgh, Tom Rodden, Stuart Reeves
column100: User experience/interaction design; Entertainment/games; Other domain-specific support
column101: Ethnographic study in two contrasting museums highlights a widespread but undocumented challenge for CSCW. Visitors’ engagement with exhibits often ends prematurely due to the need to keep up with or attend to fellow group members. We unpack the mechanics of these kinds of phenomena revealing how the behaviours of summoning, pressurizing, herding, sidelining, and rounding up, lead to the responses of following, skimming and digging in. We show how the problem is especially challenging where young children are involved. We explore two ways in which CSCW can help address this challenge: enabling a more fluid association between information and exhibits and helping reconfigure the social nature of visiting.

column3: Enron Corporation: You’re the Boss if People Get Mentioned to You
column9: Apoorv Agarwal, Adinoyi Omuya, Owen Rambow
column100: Social network analysis; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: In this paper we explore and exploit the use of a new type of network, which we call the mention network, for the task of dominance prediction of employees of the Enron corporation given their emails. We analyze the content of emails to extract “who mentions whom to whom” links and show that the network formed using these links out-performs the traditionally used Enron email network. We present a comprehensive set of experiments to conclude that organizational dominance is best predicted by capturing the number of people mentioned to a person i.e. if many more people get mentioned to a per- son then that person is the boss.

column3: How Physicians " Achieve Overview": A Case-based Study in a Hospital Ward
column9: Claus Bossen, Lotte Groth Jensen
column14: Department of Aesthetics and Communication, Arts
column23: Department of Aesthetics and Communication, Arts
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Clinicians’ work in hospitals is safety- and time-critical, and often stressful due to number and complexity of patient cases they must attend to. Therefore, how clinicians gather information about, identify problems and make decisions concerning patients is a crucial concern, a process that can be labelled ‘achieving overview’. In the process, clinicians use various artefacts amongst which medical records are central. Decades of experience is embedded in the structure and use of paper-based records. However, the development of electronic patient records (EPR) will change medical records and their use, including ‘achieving overview’. We conducted an ethnographic study in a hospital ward using paper-based medical records in order to understand how clinicians achieve overview’. Inspired by the approach of exnovation, we elicit the use of paper-based records in order to inform the design of EPRs. We propose five axes which span out the process of achieving overview and describe implications for design of EPRs.

column3: Microblogging During Small Scale Incidents: Detection and Exploration of Incident Related Tweets
column9: Axel Schulz, Petar Ristoski, Immanuel Schweizer, Max Mühlhäuser
column100: Machine Learning and Data Mining; Social network analysis; Other domain-specific support
column101: Microblogs are increasingly gaining attention as information source in emergency management as a lot of valuable situational information is shared, both by citizens and official sources. However, current analyses focus on large scale incidents, with high amount of available information. In contrast, we conduct several studies on every day small scale incidents. The comparably low amount of information shared per event makes this significantly harder. \ 	 \ To assess the possibility of automatically detecting relevant information, we first present the results of a machine learning experiment. With a precision of 82.2%, we are able to detect three types of small scale incidents in microblogs. Second, we conduct an in-depth study of situational features in microblogs. We show that lots of important situational information is microblogged. Also, individual users tend to report faster than official sources. Third, we contribute the first analysis of the correlation between information in microblogs and real-world incidents. Our results indicate that information is shared for more than two thirds of all real-world incidents.

column3: Geospatial Data Visualization in Mobile Shared Workspaces
column9: Eli Hooten, Sean Hayes, Julie Adams
column14: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department
column100: Collaborative visualization; Mobile and embedded devices; User experience/interaction design; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Mobile shared workspaces (MSWs) are software applications that support loosely-coupled cooperative work in the mobile context. MSWs pose several unique design challenges due to the distributed nature of the collaborators and the mobile devices used. Prior MSW research has resulted in the successful development of infrastructure and networking technologies to facilitate reliable mobile collaboration; however, MSW software applications may be improved through developing novel techniques for information visualization and interaction. This paper proposes Feature Sets, a visualization method for digital maps that provides flexible grouping constructs to benefit information visualization, interaction, and collaboration on mobile devices. A user evaluation determined that Feature Sets are superior to Points of Interest, a commonly leveraged method for visualizing data in map-based MSW applications.

column3: From Texts to Trails: Hacking at the Boundaries of Heritage Community
column9: Yong Ming Kow, Jiaqi Nie, Kelvin Cheng, Xavier Roman
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Collaborative software development
column101: Media technologies can radically reorganize work in communities. But how do designers know what to design, that would motivate the community members to use them? In this paper, we research the design of a peer-to-peer production platform—apps, websites, and other front ends—which seeks heritage content from the general public of Singapore. Between September 2012 and May 2013, we performed an ethnographic study within the local heritage community to identify concepts, functionalities, and services of our platform. We participated in the community’s activities, including seminars, trail tours, and workshops. We conducted twelve in-depth interviews with community members, including heritage researchers and curators, and tour guides. We found trails to be well-recognized and widely shared artifacts of overlapping interests among these members. Lastly, we discuss what we call hacking at boundaries as a research endeavor to understand technology design which aims to reconfigure and enhance social collaborations within communities.

column3: Collaboration in-between: The Care Hotel & Challenges of Transitional Care
column9: Erik Grönvall, Claus Bossen
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Medical and health support
column101: The Care Hotel is a municipal healthcare facility where people, typically after a hospital stay, undergo rehabilitation to enable them to live independently at home. Admission, stay, and discharge from the Care Hotel entail numerous coordination activities with a variety of heterogeneous external collaborators, whose involvement may be frequent or occasional. The Care Hotel operates at the junction of its various collaborators and the rehabilitees, and successful rehabilitation requires constant negotiation with external collaborations, such as the general practitioner, relatives, and hospital staff. Hence, work at the Care Hotel can be characterized as ‘collaboration in-between’ which faces the following challenges: stabilizing brittle work arrangements; achieving a comprehensive overview of collaborators; making collaborators’ fields of work transparent to each other; working-out of agreements and differences. Based on a case study, we describe and analyze work at the Care Hotel with a focus on collaboration in-between. We discuss design implications and propose an initial solution.

column3: Good Authors := Good Articles? – How Wikipedia Works
column9: Thomas Wöhner, Sebastian Köhler, Ralf Peters
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Web 2.0 applications particularly benefit from the so called wisdom of the crowd. The question arises to what extent the reputation of participants influences the effectiveness of the wisdom of the crowd. In this paper, we analyze the impact of reputation using the example of Wikipedia. We extend previous research by considering recently introduced reputation metrics and new models for aggregating the reputation values of the authors of a given article. In previous studies a tendentially lower reputation was observed for anonymous authors. Therefore, this paper quantifies the level of participation of anonymous authors in order to evaluate the impact of reputation. In contrast to previous works, our analysis reveals a low relevance of the reputation. The results prove the high importance of the number of authors and therefore, support the open editing model of wiki systems.

column3: Generic Design Principles for Open Production Communities
column9: Pujan Ziaie, Helmut Krcmar
column14: Information Systems, Department of Computer Science
column23: Information Systems, Department of Computer Science
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; User experience/interaction design; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Successful design and development of open production communities as complex socio-technical systems is not a trivial task to be easily accomplished. In such systems, four abstract layers of technology, content, user and community exist that are in constant interaction with each other, with intricate and dynamic natures and interdependencies that vary through time based on contextual as well as individual factors. Despite a large body of literature devoted on this topic, few attempts have been made to conceptualize clear, yet at the same time generic, guidelines and principles to provide a prescriptive approach towards designing production communities. Here we derive a set of design principles based on the characteristics and common patterns of open production communities and the existing pertinent theories. These principles provide a general guideline for community designers to refrain from destructive solutions and help them to aptly select and prioritize features based on the accumulated knowledge in this rather new area of study.

column3: Life Transitions and Online Health Communities:  Reflecting on Adoption, Use, and Disengagement
column9: Michael Massimi, Jackie Bender, Holly Witteman, Osman Ahmed
column100: Medical and health support; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: Online health communities are places where people can come together in order to exchange social support at a particular point in an individual’s life. There are, however, relatively few accounts that look across multiple communities. In this paper, we reflect on research performed in four different online health communities in order to identify patterns in how individuals selectively adopt, use, and disengage from these communities throughout their lives. We argue that users leaving communities is not necessarily a failing of the site’s design or purpose; rather, it is a logical reaction to changing life circumstances. In characterizing this pattern, we contribute a set of implications for design and management that bear consideration by online community designers, developers, moderators, and end-users. Ultimately this may lead to a smoother transition from community to community and ensure that social support needs are being met more consistently in response to changing life circumstances.

column3: Characterizing the Life Cycle of Online News Stories Using Social Media Reactions
column9: Carlos Castillo, Mohammed El-Haddad, Jürgen Pfeffer, Matt Stempeck
column32: Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Other domain-specific support
column101: This paper presents a study of the life cycle of news articles posted online. We describe the interplay between website visitation patterns and social media reactions to the news content. We show that we can use this hybrid observation method to characterize distinct classes of articles. We also find that social media reactions can be used to predict future visitation patterns early and accurately. \  \ We validate our methods using qualitative analysis as well as quantitative analysis on data from a large international news network, for a set of articles generating more than 3,000,000 visits and 200,000 social media reactions. We show that it is possible to model accurately the overall traffic articles will ultimately receive by observing the first ten to twenty minutes of social media reactions.
