Achieving the same prediction accuracy with visits alone would require to wait for three hours of data. We also describe significant improvements on the accuracy of the early prediction of shelf-life for news stories.

column3: A Design Pattern for Representing Workspace Awareness
column9: Miguel Teruel, Elena Navarro, Pascual Gonzalez, Víctor López-Jaquero, Francisco Montero
column15: University of Castilla-La Mancha - LoUISE Research Group
column24: University of Castilla-La Mancha - LoUISE Research Group
column33: University of Castilla-La Mancha - LoUISE Research Group
column42: University of Castilla-La Mancha - LoUISE Research Group
column51: University of Castilla-La Mancha - LoUISE Research Group
column100: Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Collaboration architectures; User experience/interaction design; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: In the same way as it happens when designing a one-user system, designers and developers will probably have to address some design problems that have appeared often previously in some other developments. This kind of recurrent problem can be identified and captured in a design pattern that provides a reusable solution to a common problem. The main aim of this work is to provide a design pattern that can be applied to the design of CSCW applications supporting Workspace Awareness (WA). Hence, this object-oriented pattern answers all WA questions by means of a class structure representing the typical entities and behaviors available in collaborative applications (e.g. users, artifacts, collaborative actions). Moreover, a proof of concept is presented, thus assessing the feasibility of this pattern with a concrete technology, namely C# and Visual Studio 2012.

column3: How to See Values in Social Computing: Methods for Studying Values Dimensions
column9: Katie Shilton, Jes A. Koepfler, Kenneth R. Fleischmann
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Human values play an important role in social computing and the design and use of information technologies. But research on values is challenged by disagreement about indicators and objects of study as researchers distribute their focus across contexts of technology design, adoption, and use. This paper draws upon a framework that clarifies how to see values in social computing research by defining indicators and objects of study. The framework describes values dimensions, comprised of sources and attributes of values in sociotechnical systems. This paper uses the framework to compare how research methods employed in social computing surface values. The framework provides a tool to analyze the strengths and weaknesses of each method for observing values dimensions. By detailing how and where researchers might observe interactions between values and technology design and use, we hope to encourage shared methods and indicators to study values in social computing. This analysis will enable researchers to systematically identify and investigate values in social computing.

column3: Workflow Definition by Cloud Collaboration
column9: Chi Wu-Lee, Gwan-Hwan Hwang
column14: Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering
column23: Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering
column100: Workflow management; Collaboration architectures; Collaborative software development
column101: In this paper we propose a novel workflow definition language for defining workflow in the working model of cloud collaboration. The characteristics are the ability of distributed definition and concurrent revision of a workflow by multiple users from different places in the cloud. Users who participant in the definition of a workflow offer their own requirements of the workflow execution. Each user can selectively contributes to part of the workflow definition. The conflicts between requirements from different users can be detected automatically. A single flow control construct such as AND-join or OR-split can be comprised of requirements from multiple users. We implement a translator of the proposed language so that we can translate requirements collected from multiple users to other workflow definition languages.

column3: Monitoring Email to Predict Team Project Performance and Dynamics
column9: Sean Munson, Karina Kervin, Lionel Robert
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Distributed/virtual teams; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Many managers and mentors for project teams desire more efficient and more effective ways of monitoring and predicting the quality of social relationships and the performance of teams under their purview. Many previous attempts have failed because of the added work they create for team members or team leaders. We build on previous work using linguistic style matching (LSM) as a tool for unobtrusively predicting mutual attraction and performance of teams in a laboratory setting. In our four-month evaluation in a field setting, we were unable to use LSM to predict performance or process. We did find some support for using future-oriented words to predict team performance over time and that shared understanding is an important predictor of final team performance.

column3: Personal Health Technologies in Collaborative Workspaces: Opportunities and Challenges
column9: Laura Pina, Aisling O'Kane, Elizabeth Bales, Gillian Hayes, William Griswold
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: The modernization of the workplace has contributed to an unhealthy sedentary lifestyle. However, personal health technologies to reduce sedentary behavior were not designed with the office in mind. In this research, we explored the design and use of personal health technologies in collaborative work settings. Through interviews, focus groups, collaborative design exercises, and the deployment of a working technology probe, we uncovered four key issues surrounding the challenges of behavior change within offices and the opportunities for technologies to address these issues. Our work demonstrates that although challenging, health technologies in the office can support turning general awareness into actionable knowledge, help people to overcome social stigma associated with behavior change, balance short and long-term work goals and health benefits, and provide appropriate high-quality information. In this paper, we present these results in detail and discuss considerations for the design of personal health technologies used in collaborative workspaces.

column3: Exhaustive and Efficient Search of Puzzles in Operational Transformation
column9: Chengzhyeng Sun, Yi Xu
column100: Concurrency control
column101: Operational Transformation (OT) is a collaboration-enabling technology and has been a technical research topic in CSCW for over two decades. One main challenge in OT research is detecting and resolving puzzles – subtle and characteristic collaborative editing scenarios in which an OT system may fail. After years of extensive search and research, a variety of intricate puzzles have been detected and resolved. However, it remains an open issue whether all puzzles have been discovered. To solve this issue, we set out to devise a verification framework and a software tool, that are able to exhaustively and efficiently cover all possible transformation cases in which puzzles (if any) will manifest themselves. With these tools, we verified OT correctness, made important discoveries and concluded: all puzzles, under basic data and operation models and established transformation properties, have been discovered and resolved. These results have resolved a number of long-standing OT issues and mysteries and significantly contributed to the advancement of OT fundamental knowledge and technological innovation.

column3: Craving, Creating, and Constructing Comfort: Insights and Opportunities for Technology in Hospice
column9: Robert Ferguson, Michael Massimi, Emily Crist, Karyn Moffatt
column42: School of Information Studies, McGill University
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Medical and health support
column101: Hospice is a medical setting for patients with terminal illnesses where active treatment is withdrawn in favor of providing comfort and dignity at the end of life. Providing comfort extends beyond managing physical pain to include social, emotional, spiritual, and environmental aspects of care. Through interviews with 16 family members of past hospice patients, we studied technology’s role in achieving these multifaceted dimensions of comfort. Comfort was an ongoing pursuit, requiring the involvement of diverse stakeholders; communication technologies were selectively chosen in service of this achievement. We provide opportunities and recommendations for technologies in hospice, including the need for varying degrees of richness and symmetry, and for support for life-affirming acts. To our knowledge, this constitutes the first study, in the CSCW and HCI literatures, of communication technology use during the final days of a person’s life, with implications both for hospice and for the end of life more broadly.

column3: Understanding Social Media in Late Life
column9: Alexis Hope, Anne Marie Piper
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: As people age, their social network gets smaller. Online technologies hold great promise for helping older adults maintain social connectedness, yet many older adults resist or participate minimally in the mainstream technologies used by younger members of their social network. We present data from an interview study with 20 people age 71 to 91 that examines  the communication preferences and values of older adults related to social media.  We describe the ways in which older adults communicate with people in their social network, including a few examples of seniors using social media. Older adults engage in social practices that could be supported by online technology, but they rarely use such tools. Seniors articulate many concerns with online social media. Through this analysis we better understand older adults' social communication needs and provide design recommendations for social media to engage people in late life.

column3: From Identity to Mobilization: On-line Pet Advocates in the Aftermath of Hurricane Sandy
column9: Joanne White, Leysia Palen, Kenneth Anderson
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: This study of a Facebook Page founded on 28 October 2012 in anticipation of Hurricane Sandy’s US landfall reveals how on-line pet advocates--a large but loosely organized social movement--transitioned their ad hoc discretionary activities to more cooperative work to assist numerous displaced pets as a result of the dangerous storm. This mixed methods investigation examines how the group organized. It shows how innovations around the organization of visual information--a predominant form of communication in existing non-disaster forms of pet welfare work--were specialized for the disaster case, and gave new meaning to the work of pet advocacy. The paper considers how characteristics of the pet advocate identity were leveraged to articulate work and structure the mission of Page members, thereby mobilizing action.

column3: Towards a Questionnaire for Measuring Affective Benefits and Costs of Communication Technologies
column9: Svetlana Yarosh, Panos Markopoulos, Gregory Abowd
column14: AT&T Research Labs, Jersey City, New Jersey, United States
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: As CSCW creates and investigates technologies for social communication, it is important to understand the emotional benefits and costs of these systems. We propose the Affective Benefits and Costs of Communication Technologies (ABCCT) questionnaire to supplement traditional qualitative methods of understanding communication media. We discuss the pilots of this survey with 45 children and 110 adults measuring the inter-item reliability of this instrument. We present the results of interviews with 14 children and 14 adults, which help confirm that the ABCCT measures the same constructs that may emerge through interview investigations. Finally, we demonstrate that the ABCCT is sensitive enough to discriminate between different communication technologies and has shown promise in some of its early adoption. Though the ABCCT is not without limitations, it may provide a way to compare technologies in field deployments, draw findings across investigations, and quantify the impact of specific design decisions.

column3: Voyant: Generating Structured Feedback on Visual Designs Using a Crowd of Non-Experts
column9: Anbang Xu, Brian Bailey, Shih-Wen Huang
column100: Crowdsourcing; User experience/interaction design
column101: Feedback is a limited resource in design but is critical for helping users iterate toward a desired solution. We present Voyant, a novel system allowing any user performing visual design work to receive structured feedback from a non-expert crowd. Based on results from a formative study, the system generates the elements seen in the design, the order in which the elements are noticed, impressions formed when the design is first viewed, and interpretation of the design relative to guidelines in the domain and the user’s goals. An evaluation of the system was conducted with users and their designs. Users reported the feedback about impressions and interpretation of their goals was most helpful, though the other feedback types were also valued. Users found the visual representations useful for gaining an overview of the feedback and the interactions efficient for exploring details. The cost of generating the feedback was viewed as a fair tradeoff for being able to receive desired feedback without organizing critiques or interrupting peers.

column3: Achieving Convergence in Operational Transformation: Conditions, Mechanisms and Systems
column9: YI XU, Chengzheng Sun
column100: Concurrency control
column101: In this paper, we present a comprehensive and in-depth study on convergence property preservation and avoidance in Operational Transformation (OT) systems. In this study, we discover general and special conditions, trans-formation patterns, and basic mechanisms for avoiding Convergence Property 2 (CP2), and establish the CP2-avoidance correctness of seven major OT systems. Furthermore, we propose improvements to existing systems and design a new OT system with a combination of novel features, which is unique and nonexistent in any existing system. These results represent significant contributions to the advancement of fundament OT knowledge and technology.

column3: Problem Formulation  for Collaborative Problem Solving:  Case Studies in Scaffolded Programming
column9: Sandra Fan, Steven Tanimoto
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; E-Learning and Education
column101: Collaborative problem solving is an important category of cooperative work. Although systems have been developed that bring computational support to collaborative problem solving, they generally do not offer affordances for easy formulation of problems for such collaborative solving. We present a means to formulate problems using a form of scaffolded programming that we have developed and tested. This facility for formulation is part of a problem-solving support system that supports both the formulation and solution processes.  In this paper, we describe the design of the problem-formulation interface, which offers users a straightforward means to formulate problems to be used in the collaborative solving process.  The scaffolded programming involved in problem formulation is a form of end-user programming. We then describe the experience we have gained observing the use of the formulation facility and analyzing the problem formulations that have been created with it.  These cases reveal differing workflows, template structures, and problem types.

column3: LoCo: A Ready-to-Deploy Framework for Powering Next Generation Indoor Location-Driven Experiences
column9: Jacob Biehl, Matthew Cooper, Gerry Filby, Sven Kratz
column100: Location-based and context-aware computing; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Mobile and embedded devices; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: In recent years, there has been an explosion of social and collaborative applications that leverage location to provide users novel and engaging experiences. However, many applications fail to realize their full potential because of limitations in current location technologies. Current frameworks work well outdoors but fare poorly indoors. In this paper we present LoCo, a new framework that can provide highly accurate room-level location. LoCo does not require users to carry specialized location hardware -- it uses radios that are present in contemporary devices combined with a new boosted classification technique.  We provide experiments that show LoCo can achieve accuracy near 98%, a significant improvement over current state-of-the-art Wi-Fi techniques. LoCo is designed to be easily deployed within an environment and leveraged by application developers.  We believe LoCo's high accuracy and accessibility can drive a new wave of location-driven studies and applications.

column3: Twitter as a Navigator for Stranded Commuters during the Great East Japan Earthquake
column9: Hiroko Wilensky
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: During the evening of the Great East Japan Earthquake on March 11, 2011, more than five million commuters were stranded in the metropolitan Tokyo area because the Japan Railroad and other railroad systems ceased their operations. Many commuters walked hours to return home while others struggled to find temporary shelter to stay overnight in the city. The increased use of social media, such as Twitter, was widely reported on Japanese media after the Great East Japan Earthquake. This study is a qualitative investigation of the use of Twitter by stranded commuters and their supporters in the great Tokyo area immediately after the earthquake. This paper describes the possibilities and problems of Twitter use under a fast changing disaster situation and examines if Twitter was an effective navigator for stranded commuters to return home or find shelter.

column3: Do not broadcast your question, Ask an Expert
column9: Cleyton Souza, Jonathas Magalhães, Evandro Costa, Joseana Fechine
column24: university to be filled in later
column25: city to be filled in later
column33: university to be filled in later
column34: city to be filled in later
column42: university to be filled in later
column43: city to be filled in later
column100: Recommender and Filtering Systems; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Essentially social query consists in sharing a question on a social network and waiting for responses. The usual strategy of sharing a public question is inefficient because it does not ensure an answer, either quality or agility. Directing the question to a specific user is a better way to get a right and quick answer. However, choosing this person could be a hard task and by choosing a wrong one we could receive an incorrect answer or the person might just ignore the question. In this paper, we proposed, implemented and evaluated a model based on a multi-criteria approach to find the most suitable user to receive a question on Twitter. We rank expert candidates using the Weight Product Model. One of the main differentials of our model is the use of multi-criteria and that it was built for a social network context. Our technique achieved promising results in predicting the usefulness of real responders answer.

column3: Designing for Presenters at Public Walk-up-and-use Walls
column9: Kai Kuikkaniemi, Vilma Lehtinen, Matti Nelimarkka, Max Vilkki, Jouni Ojala, Antti Ukkonen, Giulio Jacucci
column24: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology HIIT / Aalto University
column42: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology, Aalto University
column51: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology, Aalto University
column60: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology, Aalto University
column100: Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Interactive walk-up-and-use displays are spreading in a variety of settings where presentation situations are common. We contribute by characterizing presentation scenarios and investigating specific design implications for presenters as compared to users who are passers-by. In three studies, we utilize a multitouch screen for information browsing wherein content is accessible through linked spherical physics-modeled widgets we call bubbles. Our first study at an exhibition demonstrated presenters' basic requirements as to content production and widget behavior. In a subsequent lab study, we evaluated a content management system and indicated the need for better managing the content and the screen space through dedicated features. In the third study, we organized a field trial at an exhibition introducing, among other features, a presentation layer as media-presentation support. The three studies confirm the importance of the presentation scenario for public walk-up-and-use screens and point to dedicated design implications for 1) gestures and widget behavior, 2) support in management of presentation territories, and 3) support for content production and management.

column3: Size Matters: Overlooked Factors for Online Communities in MMOs
column9: Nathaniel Poor
column100: Entertainment/games; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Using the full census from the MMO EverQuest II, with over 55,000 guilds and almost 1 million guilded characters, this research addresses the previously unexplored relationship between players, their multiple accounts, their many characters, and guilds of various sizes and levels. Most research avoid how players’ accounts often have more than one character, and the character-account ratio, a new metric, was 3.137 for active guilds. Most guilds are small, many are too small to form a group on their own, but most accounts have characters in large guilds. Character-account ratio varies by guild level and size. Different types of guilds, partially determined by code, provide different resources and user gratifications, suggesting relationships between code and social relations for online communities.

column3: Supporting Engineering Design Communication through a Social Media Tool - Insights from a Formula Student Team
column9: James Gopsill, Hamish McAlpine, Ben Hicks
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social network analysis; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Engineering Design Communication (EDC) in the modern engineering context is highly collaborative, multi-disciplinary and often relates to one or more artefacts associated with the product (such as CAD, calculations and physical prototypes). This results in the need for a method of communication that can deliver the required engineering context, enable multiple-perspectives to be expressed and represent the artefact of interest. It is acknowledged that E-Mail is severely limited in its ability to support EDC but it remains widely used as there are few alternatives. This potentially limits both the recording and sharing of engineering knowledge, and the ability to maintain an awareness of project progress. Therefore, this paper presents some initial insights into the potential of a custom-built Social Media tool (PartBook, Figure 1) to support both engineers' work and engineering project management. This tool has been specifically designed to support EDC and has been deployed in an ongoing study involving a Formula Student Team.

column3: Beyond the Bar: The places where location-based services are used in the city
column9: Frank Bentley, Henriette Cramer, Jörg Müller
column100: Location-based and context-aware computing; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: Mobile services are integrating into the places and routines of daily life. But which types of places afford the use of various services, and how important are these places in our lives? Through several studies we have explored the types of places that are most important to people in their cities, and compare these to the place types where different location-based services are used. We find that places of personal salience are less common in the use of today’s check-in services, but are better represented in location- based storytelling systems. Supported with data from the Storyplace.me service, we suggest that focusing on selective sharing and storytelling can facilitate use at these more personally meaningful places.

column3: From Weight Loss to Weight Maintenance: Challenges and Opportunities in Designing for Weight Management Communities
column9: Jing Wang, Patrick Shih, John Carroll
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Medical and health support
column101: The pervasiveness of online health communities and recent development of tracking technologies provide new affordances for supporting weight management, which is an important and prevalent health issue. To understand the practices and experiences of people managing their weight with such affordances, we interviewed eighteen users from a well-established online peer-to-peer weight management community that provides a calorie tracking tool enabling data sharing. Analysis of the interviews characterizes facilitators and barriers of goal accomplishment, factors affecting community joining and staying, and uses of shared tracking data. Our results highlight that support for weight maintenance was overlooked but is important and beneficial for both individuals’ long-term success of weight management and community development. We identify three challenges, including reframing progress and goals, evolving identities, and integrating shared tracking data and online communities. Based on these observations, we propose design opportunities to leverage tracking data and online communities to support weight management.

column3: Feature the locals: They know the hidden gems
column9: Claudia López, Rosta Farzan
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Word-of-mouth (WOM) is a powerful source of local information, but its availability depends on the number and quality of people’s social ties.  Online local review systems aim to support the potential of local WOM on a much larger scale. However, the popularity of local online reviews force users to make sense of huge amounts of data coming from a large pool of strangers. Drawing on WOM and local attachment literature, we studied which aspects of local reviews on Yelp are the most indicative of its usefulness. Our findings have implications for the design of cues that can better support users in finding useful local reviews.

column3: Designing for Sustainability: Understanding People’s Driving and Errand Habits
column9: Bernhard Firner, Janne Lindqvist
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: Transportation is a major cause of greenhouse gas emissions world-wide and in the United States private passenger vehicles account for 17% of all emissions. Reducing U.S. vehicle emissions faces several hurdles.  First, many U.S. neighborhoods are practically accessible only by car. Second, people, in general, are not good at arranging their activities in a sustainable way and chores that are done separately could be grouped instead. Towards understanding this design space, we conducted semi-structured interviews of 54 participants with diverse age and socio-economic status. We found that changing driving habits would require giving drivers additional information about the temporal and monetary efficiency of their activities and providing tools to identify opportunities for grouping errands.  The majority of participants rated time as their major driving concern, which matches well with the goal of increasing sustainable driving habits.

column3: Exploring the Opportunities and Challenges of Mobile TimeBanking
column9: Kyungsik (Keith) Han, Patrick Shih, Victoria Bellotti, John Carroll
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: Timebanks are organizations that use time as a form of currency to encourage community-based volunteering. Members of the timebanking community provide services to each other in exchange for time credits. Timebanking services and time credits are stored in the timebank’s computer system, which members can access via the Web. In this paper, we introduce mobile timebanking which is an extension to timebanking. Mobile timebanking not only supports conventional timebanking activities but also addresses fine-grain scheduling of opportunistic neighbor-hood service exchange activities. There has been no prior study of mobile timebanking; therefore, we investigate its promise and its challenges. Our five-week user study with 32 participants demonstrates that mobile timebanking might increase the diversity and visibility of service exchanges as well as enabling access to and flexible management of timebanking activities and social communications. It also shows that individual preferences and familiarity influenced the process of timebanking activities.

column3: Connecting Local Heritage to Mobile Tourism
column9: Kyungsik (Keith) Han, Patrick Shih, Mary Beth Rosson, John Carroll
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: Mobile walking tour applications are designed to enhance tour experiences by making digitized content easily accessible to people. Although much research has been conducted to understand technical and social aspects of tour applications, little empirical research has investigated user interactions with such applications, for example exploring user experiences and how users perceive socially generated locational content, or articulating how the mobile tours make a connection to community heritage. To address this, we developed a mobile walking tour application called LSC (anonymized) and conducted a user study with 34 participants. The study results indicate that participants utilize social features as a way of learning local history and interacting with others; participants who have lived in a community longer tend to leave more comments and add more photos; some meaningful places draw particular attention from participants; and LSC represents a digital storytelling, creating digital traces and additional layers of local history information.

column3: Trusted Stranger Networks: Using Social Q&A and Crowdsourcing to Define a New Realm of Digital Volunteerism
column9: Hwajung Hong, Rosa Arriaga
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Crowdsourcing
column101: Trusted Stranger Network (TSN) is a concept that exploits digital volunteers dedicated to answering questions about everyday lives of individuals with special needs. It lies within the junction of social Q&A and crowdsourcing with added facet of requiring the crowd to be trustworthy. Our notion of a TSN transforms existing physical volunteer work structure into a virtual volunteer desk in which people provide rapid and trustworthy advice on everyday situations. With this paper we want to shed light on some of the opportunities and challenges in implementing TSN in the case of supporting special population, in particular individuals with autism.

column3: MyPosition: The Impact of a Public Polling Projection on Civic Participation
column9: Nina Valkanova, Robert Walter, Andrew Vande Moere, Jörg Müller
column23: Quality and Usability Lab Telekom Innovation Laboratories
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; User experience/interaction design
column101: We present the design and evaluation of MyPosition, a public display in the form of a large projection, featuring an interactive polling visualization. MyPosition aims at facilitating the deliberation and comparison of individual opinions on locally relevant topics in an opportunistic and engaging way. We evaluated MyPosition in an in-the-wild study and discovered that the public and engaging nature of the installation was effective in enticing participation and discussion. People submitted their personal opinion instead of playing around with the interactive features. In addition, the identifiability of voters positively impacted the attractiveness of the system at the cost of a lower participation rate. The public nature of the display led to considerable social learning, teaching, nudging and discussion beyond the interaction area in front of the screen.

column3: Exploring the Design Space for Privacy-enhanced Collaborative Tools: An Initial Study
column9: Tom DeHart, Dennis Kafura, Manuel Perez-Quinones, Denis Gracanin, Andrea Kavanaugh
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Collaboration architectures; User experience/interaction design; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: We probed the design space of tools supporting community privacy, by which we mean the desire of a collaborating group to control the dissemination of sensitive information in its possession.  Through consensus the group manages its creation, membership, and actions in exceptional situations. Group members annotate information to control its dissemination. The probe is a realization of a model of community privacy in a prototype email system. User testing of this email system, involving both students and information technology professionals, examined whether the design of the prototype’s interface facilitated the formation of a mental model helpful to users in performing privacy-related tasks,  and the efficacy of the procedure for achieving group consensus. The breakdowns we observed relating to the users’ mental model and the consensus procedure led us to new ideas for the re-design of the user interface and provided valuable insights into developing tools for supporting community privacy. \  \

column3: Understanding Resource Exchange in Online Crowdfunding Platforms
column9: Michael Greenberg, Julie Hui, Elizabeth Gerber
column100: Crowdsourcing; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Online crowdfunding has gained attention among novice entrepreneurs as an effective online platform for funding their ventures. However, a focus on the financial nature of the relationship has obscured the complex interpersonal interactions involving the exchange of non-financial re-sources. Drawing from resource exchange theory, we look at the exchange of resources and the mechanisms that facili-tate this exchange in online crowdfunding. We analyzed 81 popular online crowdfunding platforms to reveal the ex-change of various resources including: money, love, infor-mation, status, goods, and services through mediated, un-mediated, and hybrid structures. Using resource exchange theory as a lens, we examine crowdfunding as a new type of crowdwork platform and explain how resource exchange theory can help the Computer Supported Cooperative Work and Crowdsourcing communities understand and explain new models of exchange in online platforms.

column3: ``You commented your post. What happened?'' Activity Data-Driven Qualitative Research on User Practices in Online Social Networks
column9: Andreas Poller, Petra Ilyes, Andreas Kramm, Laura Kocksch
column15: Fraunhofer Institute for Secure Information Technology SIT
column23: Department of Cultural Anthropology and European Ethnology
column32: Department of Cultural Anthropology and European Ethnology
column41: Department of Cultural Anthropology and European Ethnology
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use; User experience/interaction design; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: Researching user practices in online social networks (OSNs) by observation on-site is difficult to manage. In fact, most empirical studies either employ self-reporting techniques which are considered reliable only to a limited extent, or collect and statistically analyze large data samples which can not account for individual use contexts. To sidestep these shortcomings, we bundle a technical data-gathering technique with a self-reporting technique: we compare activity data on participant's actions collected in situ, and statements from qualitative interviews tailored to the participants. We applied this approach to a 15-participant exploratory study to investigate how Facebook users share content, manage contacts, and use chat and "like" functions. Our approach provides more meaningful, nuanced and context-specific data, providing deeper insights into users' practices, and hence affords better support for software design.

column3: Eliciting Rankings through a Gaming Approach
column9: Yan Cao, William McGill
column14: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column23: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Entertainment/games; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Other domain-specific support
column101: Ranking plays an important role in many dimensions. Traditional approaches to elicit rankings from people such as surveys and interviews are usually time and labor consuming. Users usually need to conduct a large number of pairwise comparisons, presenting a scaling issue. Innovated by the concept of Games With A Purpose, we propose to elicit rankings through a gaming approach. We introduce and describe a casual game in this study. It elicits rankings through a pairwise comparison approach. The fun element of games makes the task more enjoyable and durable. Thus this gaming approach mitigates the scaling issue of pairwise comparisons. An experimental study is conducted to examine the construct validity. The results show that the game-elicited rankings have a high similarity with the data-driven rankings. Also, at the puzzle level, players' performance is significantly better than chance. These findings support the hypothesis that the game provides a valid tool for ranking elicitation.

column3: Sketching Awareness: A Participatory Study to Elicit Designs for Supporting Emergency Medical Teamwork
column9: Diana Kusunoki, Aleksandra Sarcevic, Zhan Zhang, Maria Yala
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design
column101: Prior CSCW research on awareness in clinical settings has mostly focused on higher-level coordination at the inter-team, department, and inter-department levels. In this paper, we offer a perspective on what awareness means within the context of a setting that is different from what has been previously described by looking at collocated ad hoc teams treating critically ill patients with urgent needs. We report findings from four participatory design workshops conducted with emergency medicine clinicians at two regional emergency departments. Workshops were developed to elicit design ideas for information displays that support awareness in emergency medical situations. Through analysis of discussions and clinicians’ sketches of information displays, we identified five features of teamwork that can be used as a foundation for supporting awareness from the perspective of clinicians. Based on these findings, we contribute rich descriptions of five facets of awareness that teams manage during emergency medical situations and discuss them in relation to awareness facets found in the CSCW literature.

column3: Network Neighborhoods, Romantic Relationships, and the Dispersion of Social Ties
column9: Lars Backstrom, Jon Kleinberg
column23: Departments of Computer Science and Information Science
column100: Social network analysis; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: A crucial task in the analysis of on-line social-networking systems is to identify important people --- those linked by strong social ties --- within an individual's network neighborhood, Here we investigate this question for a particular category of strong ties, those involving spouses or romantic partners. We organize our analysis around a basic question: given all the connections among a person's friends, can you recognize his or her romantic partner from the network structure alone? Using data from a large sample of Facebook users, we find this task can be accomplished with high accuracy, but doing so requires the development of a new measure of tie strength that we term `dispersion' --- the extent to which two people's mutual friends are not themselves well-connected. The results offer methods for identifying particular types of structurally significant people in on-line applications, and suggest a potential expansion of existing theories of tie strength.

column3: Textual Determinants of News Headline Sharing on Twitter
column9: Nicholas Diakopoulos, Arkaitz Zubiaga
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: News headlines are written and crafted to capture readers' interest and draw them into a story. But while news outlets attempt to follow the style guidelines they define, little is known about how the form and style of news headlines affects sharing through social networks. Previous research examined the effect of network structure and Twitter-specific features on tweet diffusion. We take a complementary approach focusing instead on investigating grammatical and content factors that enable tweeted headlines to capture reader attention and lead them to spread the news through retweeting. By analyzing the diffusion of tweets from eight major U.S. news outlets over the period of a year, we surface writing patterns found in highly retweeted news headlines, and cast doubt on some of the conventional wisdom for how to write engaging headlines. We find that certain parts of speech, such as verbs, play an important role in catching the attention of readers as do content factors relating to the social deviance of the news story.

column3: Individual Differences shaping Knowledge Workers Interpretation and Uses of Social Media for Informal Knowledge Sharing
column9: Mohammad Hossein Jarrahi, Steve Sawyer
column14: School of Information and Library Science
column15: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: We focus on the differential uses of social media by knowledge workers. The empirical basis of the work is a field study of knowledge sharing practices of knowledge workers from multiple management consulting firms. Findings highlight four characteristics shaping attitudes towards the affordances of social media for knowledge practices and are presented as dichotomies: (1) enthusiasm for technology use (technophiles vs. reluctant adopters), (2) organizational roles (managerial vs. production-focused), (3) age group (Millennials vs. older generations of workers) and, (4) personality dispositions (extroverts vs. introverts). Contrasting attitudes towards social media are outlined in the study based on these dimensions, leading to divergent adoption pathways. Insights from this research offer guidance as to the various trajectories of knowledge worker’s uses of social media to advance their work.

column3: The Dark Side of Q&A: How to Tell When It Goes Wrong?
column9: Tiziano Piccardi, Gregorio Convertino, Massimo Zancanaro, Felipe Ortega, Cedric Archambeau
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Crowdsourcing
column101: Q&A sites have become popular destinations for online users to ask a question and get an answer, or find an existing answer to a similar question. Although these sites are very efficient, globally, we found that there is a significant portion of the questions for which something goes clearly wrong: the user must wait too long or does not get a good answer. In this paper, we characterize this portion of questions, which we call the Dark Side, across eight Q&A sites of the Stack Exchange platform and we describe three sets of predictive models to automatically detect as early as possible if a question is doomed to end up in the Dark Side.

column3: Using Facebook to Investigate How Simulation can Support Anticipating Impact of Configuration Settings on Group Processes
column9: Manoel Pereira, Simone Xavier, Raquel Prates
column100: User experience/interaction design; Social network analysis
column101: Collaborative systems often offer users configuration settings that will allow them to customize aspects of group´s collaboration or access to information. One challenge faced by users is in anticipating how the settings being defined will impact the collaborative and social processes available to group. A known instance of such challenge is represented by Facebook´s privacy setting. In this work, we propose that simulations are necessary to allow users to fully grasp the meaning of such settings. To investigate these issues we have investigated the case of Facebook´s privacy settings.

column3: Standing on the Schemas of Giants: Socially Augmented Information Foraging
column9: Aniket Kittur, Andrew Peters, Abdigani Diriye
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: People spend an enormous amount of time searching for complex information online; for example, consumers researching new purchases or patients learning about their conditions. As they search, people build up rich mental schemas about their target domains; which, if effectively shared, could accelerate learning for others with similar in-terests. In this paper we introduce a novel interface to capture the schemas individuals develop as they gather information online, integrate them across multiple individuals, and surface them for others with similar interests. Through a controlled experiment we show that having access to the others’ schemas while foraging for information helps new users to induce more useful, prototypical, and better-structured schemas than gathering information alone.

column3: Cancer Navigation: Opportunities and Challenges for Facilitating the Breast Cancer Journey
column9: Maia Jacobs, James Clawson, Elizabeth Mynatt
column100: Medical and health support; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Cancer navigation programs help patients overcome emotional, financial, and logistical challenges that are typically not addressed by the medical system. In this paper we examine current practices in a rural cancer navigation organization. Through our work we found five opportunities to support future cancer navigation: resource monitoring, knowledge transfer, case management, long term navigation, and development of best practices. We share current strategies, challenges, and design implications for each opportunity. We also discuss navigation in the broader context of designing technological support for people who directly impact patients’ health but fall outside of the standard health care provider role.

column3: “Lost to the Ether”: Social Media Infrastructuring to Avert Knowledge Silos in a Geographically Distributed Firm
column9: Aditya Johri, Hon Jie Teo
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Computer-Mediated Communication; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: We present findings from a field study that examined knowledge and expertise sharing (KES) practices in a geographically distributed software firm. We found that the firm successfully infrastructured KES using social media through the following mechanisms: (1) aligning use of social media and KES practices from firm inception; (2) supporting continuous tailoring and adaptability of social media for KES; (3) aligning social media use with firm’s product development to enable innovation; and, (4) creating hiring practices that appropriately socialized newcomers into social media and KES practices at the firm. By infrastructuring for KES, the firm was able to create practices that averted knowledge silos common in distributed firms. Our work contributes both to KES and infrastructuring scholarship and has implications for design of work practices.

column3: What You Say and What You Do: Analyzing Stated and Manifested Online Interests
column9: Saiph Savage, Rita Wouhaybi, Saurav Sahay
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: We explore the differences between the interests users state \ in their online profile, and the interests they manifest, via \ their posts and comments to understand how users define themselves and how they behave. We propose a framework that extracts the main themes of interest from users’ posts and then identifies the profile tags relevant to these main themes. \ Subsequently, we categorize all of the posts, comments, and relevant interest tags into the discovered themes to study interest expression patterns in the community and in the user level. We analyze the ontd_political community from Live-Journal using our proposed framework and find that 59% of \ ontd_political’s community members do not have their interest statements aligned with the content they post and share in the community, but all of these users do have stated interests related to the main themes discussed in ontd_political, even when they personally do not contribute to them.

column3: Streaming on Twitch: Shared Experiences of Play Catalyze Intimate Communities
column9: William Hamilton, Oliver Garretson, Andruid Kerne
column15: Interface Ecology Lab @ Texas A&M University
column33: Interface Ecology Lab, Texas A&M University
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Entertainment/games; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Previously, video streaming sites have remained at the fringes of online social media. In the past 2 years, video gaming live streams on sites like Twitch.tv have developed larger viewerships and more truly social media. In conjunction with gameplay, participant interaction gains emphasis. In this paper, we present ethnographic investigation of live streaming of video games on Twitch. \  \ We found that streamers and viewers frequently share their personal lives and form intimate relationships through pro- longed interaction, leading to the formation of open, yet close- knit communities around streams. However, as the popularity of particular streams and streamers reaches a threshold of scale, breakdowns emerge in the fabric of meaningful social experience. We discuss emergent problems and collectively developed stopgap solutions for supporting real-time commu- nication and managing anti-social behavior at large scales. Finally, we present implications for design that must be ad- dressed for live streaming to continue to grow and preserve the intimate social experiences that are its hallmarks.

column3: Books as a Social Technology
column9: Annika Hupfeld, Tom Rodden
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: E-books are on their way to becoming ubiquitous. Whether or not they will eventually replace books or merely complement them, there is a concern that something important might be lost in moving from print to digital books. While there is a wealth of research into the challenges and opportunities of e-reading, there is little research aiming to understand the role of books in everyday life. Rather than speculating on what books are in the digital age, in this paper, we wish to ask what books do. To do so, we conducted a series of in-depth interviews with ten households in the UK to understand everyday uses of books in the home. Our findings suggest that books are not merely reading technologies but a resource for everyday social and personal engagements. We discuss implications of re-framing books as social technologies for the design of e-books.

column3: Articulation Spaces: Bridging the Gap between Formal and Informal Coordination
column9: Alexander Boden, Frank Rosswog, Gunnar Stevens, Volker Wulf
column100: Collaborative software development; Computer-Mediated Communication; Organization/office/workplace support; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: The high complexity of software development makes it necessary to have spaces for formal and informal articulation work. Our research has shown that existing information systems tend to treat these different aspects of coordination separately, resulting in problems of awareness and coordination. In this paper, we present the concept of Articulation Spaces which combines aspects of Coordination Mechanisms and Common Information Spaces (CIS) in order to re-integrate formal and informal aspects of coordination. Based on an implementation in form of a light-weight public display, we evaluate the concept in a medium-sized German software company with regard to its implications for formal and informal forms of coordination. In doing so, we show how Articulation Spaces can serve as an information space for meta-coordination, helping to raise awareness about relevant incidents in the company and facilitate serendipitous knowledge exchange in the sense of a tickets to talk approach. Our findings provide insights into the design of CIS for flexible and coordination-intensive contexts such as software development work.

column3: A Periodic Need-guided Design Approach: Bridging Need-Gap in Enlightenment Hobby Learning
column9: Ye Tao, Fangtian Ying, Guanyun Wang, Yujiu Hong
column15: College of Computer Science and Technology
column24: College of Computer Science and Technology
column33: College of Computer Science and Technology
column42: College of Computer Science and Technology
column100: E-Learning and Education; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: When independent learning is conducted in musical instruments learning, the learning process can be easily interrupted due to expectation gap between children, parents and teachers in each learning phase. This paper presents a periodic need-guided principle for interactive musical instruments design, with specific focus on initial stage in learning for children. A need-identification study was conducted, where subjective needs and objective needs at different stages were identified and utilized to construct a guideline for interactive musical instruments design. By demonstrating the periodic need-guided principle, a prototype was designed and evaluated based upon the guideline to verify the needs identified. The periodic need-guided principle and the design guideline may offer novel interactive educational design for initial learning on musical instruments to provide a dynamic learning procedure and avoid stifling interest in hobby learning by non-subjective reasons.

column3: The role of founders in building online groups
column9: Robert Kraut, Andrew Fiore
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: As a class, online groups are popular, but many die before they become successful.  This research traced the fate of 472,231 new online groups. By the end of a 3-month observation period, 57% of the groups had died, ceasing to post new content. Founders’ human and social capital before the group was formed, the decisions they made when they created the group and their behavior in the group during its first week all predicted group survival. Many of the results suggest that founders create more successful groups if they have more resources (e.g., more online friends) and opportunities for acquiring relevant skills (e.g., more experience with online groups) and are more active in their group.  However, founders who are too controlling seem to present a threat their groups.  Their groups are more likely to fail if they are the only group administrator, if they have ties to all group members and if they added everyone to the group.

column3: Understanding Employee Voice From Social Media
column9: N. Sadat Shami, Jiang Yang, Casey Dugan, Tristan Ratchford, Jamie Rasmussen, Todd Soule, Werner Geyer, Ido Guy, Laura Panc, Yannick Assogba
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Social media can be used to augment traditional surveys in understanding employee voice. In this paper, we introduce Enterprise Social Pulse (ESP) – a tool designed to support analysts whose job involves understanding employee voice. ESP aggregates and analyzes data from internal and external social media sources while respecting employee privacy. It surfaces the data through a user interface that supports organic results and keyword search, data segmentation and filtering, and several analytics and visualization features. An evaluation of ESP was conducted with 19 Human Resources professionals. Results from a survey and interviews with participants revealed the value and willingness to use ESP, but also surfaced challenges around deploying an employee social media listening solution in an organization.

column3: Supervisor-student research meetings: A case study on choice of tools and practices
column9: Hasti Seifi, Helen Halbert, Joanna McGrenere
column23: School of Library, Archival & Information Studies
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; E-Learning and Education; Other domain-specific support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Supervisory meetings are a crucial aspect of graduate studies and have a strong impact on the success of research and supervisor-student relations, yet there is little research on supporting this relationship and even less on understanding the nature of this collaboration and user requirements. Thus, we conducted an exploratory study on tools and practices used by supervisors and students for meetings, for the purpose of making informed design recommendations. Results of a series of five focus groups yielded three themes on: 1) supervisory style diversity, 2) distributed cognition demands, and 3) feedback channel dissonance. Student-supervisor collaboration has many unexplored areas for design and as a first step, our work highlights some potential areas of interest for design and future research.

column3: Structuring and Retrieval in Email Processing
column9: Mateusz Dolata, Nils Jeners, Wolfgang Prinz
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Computer-Mediated Communication; User experience/interaction design; Other domain-specific support
column101: Designing email clients is a challenging task. Users utilize their mailboxes for all kinds of cooperation scenarios. Furthermore, their approaches to interact with the virtual correspondence differ tremendously. This paper reports on a pilot study regarding individual structuring and retrieval strategies. Therefore a survey and extensive, in-depth interviews were conducted. Based on the observations, design requirements regarding structuring paradigms are elicited and motivated.

column3: Using A Culturally Situated Design Tool in Computer Supported Collaborative Network Environment for K-12
column9: Albanie Bolton, Cheryl Seals
column100: E-Learning and Education; Collaborative software development; Entertainment/games
column101: For over 25 years, HCI researchers and developers have been challenged with improving usability of products. More recently, the Computer-Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW) community has focused on developing collaborative systems but even though social interaction was recognized the emphasis was on work. The widespread use of the Internet by millions of diverse users for socializing is a new phenomenon that raises new issues for researchers and developers. Just designing for usability is not enough; we need to understand how technology can support social interaction and design for sociability. Moreover, increasing accessibility to Computer Science and Technology is essential for a discipline that relies on creativity and diverse perspectives. With the educational research community having begun to explore the causes behind the underrepresentation of females and students of color in computing courses, outreach efforts have commenced to overcome these enrollment discrepancies.

column3: Institutional Logics of the EMR and the Problem of ‘Perfect’ but Inaccurate Accounts
column9: Kathleen Pine, Melissa Mazmanian
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Medical and health support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: CSCW has conducted a myriad of work examining the coordinating function of EMR systems, but the accounting function is less understood.  In this paper, we draw on a the theoretical lens of new institutionalism to argue that institutional logics of U.S. healthcare are shaping the work processes embedded within EMR systems, the logic of EMR design itself, and the ways in which key institutional values such as “safety” are achieved and evaluated.  Using ethnographic research in an obstetrical unit, we find that institutional logics of “safety through systems” embedded in the EMR creates a “tight coupling” of coordinating and accounting functions. Such coupling makes it difficult for healthcare workers to effectively engage with the unpredictable and contingent nature of medical work. In working with the EMR they are forced to produce technically perfect but inaccurate accounts of work. This research calls attention to they ways in which institutional logics figure into EMR and the effect of “perfect” but inaccurate accounts on broader institutional environments.

column3: Learnspace Awareness: Applying Design Implications from Large Scale Collaborations to MOOCs
column9: Phil Tietjen, Chris Gamrat, Erika Poole
column32: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; E-Learning and Education; Collaboration architectures; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: A recent New York Times article labeled 2012 “The Year of the MOOC.”  Promising free access to courses from prestigious universities such as Harvard and MIT, many see Massively Open Online Courses (MOOCs) as an exciting new development with the potential to bring disruptive innovation to online learning. At the same time, this attempt to scale learning opportunities to thousands of people has also presented MOOCs with many challenges (e.g., attrition, accreditation, plagiarism). Within CSCW, the concept of “workspace awareness” offers a useful starting point to meet the design needs faced by MOOCs; however, a conceptualization is needed that is more specifically geared towards addressing the unique dynamics of an explicitly learning-oriented space. With this in mind, we introduce a framework called Learnspace Awareness, which leverages features from learning analytics and learning communities, and propose a set of design principles to support learning needs within a MOOC.

column3: The Implication is Maybe To Design: A New Lens for Qualitative Human-Computer Interaction Research
column9: Erika Poole
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: As human-centered computing research extends beyond usability and functionality to solving complicated societal problems, new tools are needed to guide design practice. In this paper, we draw upon behavior models from health psychology, a discipline with a longstanding history of examining complicated issues that are not amenable to simple design-focused solutions. Through use of health behavior models as a lens for interaction design, researchers and designers can more effectively diagnose why it is that people do or do not gravitate toward a given technological creation, and thus target interventions that are more appropriate to the needs and preferences of user groups—regardless of whether these technologies focus on health or another domain. Use of these models complements ethnographic methods, by either framing the sets of questions to ask during a study, or by providing a post-hoc lens for data analysis. To illustrate how these models can be used in practice, we show how the integrated behavior model can provide insight into domestic technology usage practices.

column3: Are you still with me? Interaction Involvement in Dyadic Instant Messaging Conversations
column9: Duyen Nguyen, Susan Fussell
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: This paper explores how participants express and interpret verbal cues of interaction involvement in dyadic conversations via text-based Instant Messaging (IM). We report an experimental study in which we manipulated the participants’ level of involvement using a distraction task. We found that interaction involvement had a positive effect on cognitive and affective processes such as mutual understanding, emotions, and satisfaction of computer-mediated conversations. Moreover, certain verbal cues such as the use of personal pronouns, assent words, cognitive mechanism words, and definite articles were a significant indication of the participants’ level of involvement in an IM conversation. We conclude with our suggestions for improving team collaboration using computer-mediated communication (CMC) tools.

column3: Analysis of Social and Production Activities on GitHub
column9: Yu Wu, Patrick Shih, Jing Wang, John Carroll
column14: College Of Information Sciences and Technology
column23: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column32: College Of Information Sciences and Technology
column41: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Collaborative software development; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Collaboration architectures; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Social activities, such as follow or adding others as friends, are prevalent on social media sites. Many studies consider mutual follow or friendship on social media indicates establishment of social ties. Besides such social activities, GitHub also provides features for users to engage with each other in more effortful work production activities with each other, such as bug reporting and code contribution. In this study, we examined the characteristics and relations of social activities and production related activities. We found that social activities moderated the duration and frequency of production activities on GitHub, and they affected the production activity of the initiators more than those of the recipients.

column3: How Behavioral Modes Affect Cooperation on Social Network Sites
column9: Chun-Cheng Hsu, Yi Chieh Li
column100: Social network analysis; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Collaboration architectures
column101: Social network sites (SNSs) are inextricably linked with students, who engage in social and information-sharing activities. Their personalities in real life may affect their behavior on social media. However, cooperative behaviors through social media were rarely discussed in previous studies, and it is crucial to conduct empirical testing on the evolution of user characteristic. Therefore, this study has two aims: first, to investigate how students cooperate and interact through social networks; second, how personality affects cooperative behavior. Fifty-one students were examined to conduct contextual inquiry by qualitative and quantitative approaches to show the differences between users. Students were divided into six personality types and we discovered that different types of users revealed different characteristics when cooperating in SNSs. Moreover, the personalities of students in real life do not always have corresponding characteristics when using social media. With analyses of user behavior, strategies of social networks design can be improved.

column3: Physiological Measures as Signposts of Affect in Creative, Distributed Collaborations
column9: Andrew Berry, Sean Mitchell, Daniel Perry, Dian Hartono, Cecilia Aragon
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: This study employs a complex systems model of collaborative creativity with distributed affect to interpret multi-modal traces collected from participants collaborating via online chat. We compared two physiological measures related to affect–heart rate variability and electrodermal activity–to the affect participants expressed in chat logs. Then we identified relationships between these traces of affect and the local, global, and contextual dynamics at play within these collaborative groups. Since underlying physiological systems influence affective states, and since affective states play a role in the three levels of small group dynamics, analysis of the affect present in distributed groups provides a link between a physiological and a social psychological understanding of affect.

column3: Social Data Analysis via Commenting on a  Visualization-Oriented News Blog
column9: Jessica Hullman, Nicholas Diakopoulos, Eytan Adar
column15: University of Michigan School of Information
column100: Collaborative visualization; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Recommender and Filtering Systems
column101: Publishing visualizations has become common in many non-research outlets. Discussion and social engagement through online commenting can facilitate collaborative analysis of visual data. Yet much remains to be understood about how people make sense of online data visualization through interactive commenting outside of research prototypes. We present a detailed study of commenting activity around visualizations published on a mainstream news outlet, The Economist’s Graphic Detail blog. We contribute insights into behavior around five different referential anchors to which comments are frequently directed. These results inform the development of an automated classifier that can coarsely yet effectively differentiate comments referencing different types of anchors with an accuracy of 84.8%. A controlled study demonstrates how the most direct application of such a classifier—an interface that surfaces the anchor-based schema—enables significant efficiency gains in the form of lower times to complete a sensemaking task. We conclude with a discussion of the implications of the results for understanding and organizing online commentary, including as input to the design process.

column3: Family Communication and Awareness Routines in Kenya
column9: Erick Oduor, Carman Neustaedter, Tejinder Judge, Kate Hennessy, Serena Hillman, Carolyn Pang
column41: School of Interactive Arts and Technology
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: Family communication and technology design to support it is a widely studied topic; however, we have little knowledge of how families communicate in countries where technology availability and infrastructure is limited. This makes it challenging to design for family communication in developing areas of the world. To this end, we present results from a qualitative study examining the communication patterns of family members that live in rural and urban areas of Kenya, Africa. Our results show that the idea of ‘family’ was different for rural Kenyans compared to urban Kenyans. Mobile phone communication dominated family communication practices where Kenyans had distinct social protocols and routines for exchanging information, timing communication, and being available for calls. These results suggest that future technology designs for communication in countries such as Kenya need to incorporate the unique social customs that already exist around technology usage.

column3: Likes, Hugs, and Comments: Social Support for Moms on ScaryMommy.com and YouBeMom.com
column9: Sarita Schoenebeck
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Home/family/intimacy support; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Moms are one of the fastest growing demographics online. They go online to seek information and resources and offer social support. Despite moms’ heavy use of social media, little is known about how they give feedback and share social support online. We investigate social support in the form of likes, hugs, and comments in two anonymous online mom sites. Using 234,452 posts from ScaryMommy.com Confessions, we show how type of content predicts whether a post will receive microfeedback in the form of a “like” or a “hug.” Using over 53 million comments from YouBeMom.com, we show how type of content correlates to whether a post will receive many comments or no comments. We discuss approaches for providing feedback and social support for moms online and implications for site designers. Building on prior work, we also highlight the distinctive culture of anonymous mom sites and reflect on why moms flock to these particular kinds of sites.

column3: Editing Beyond Articles: Diversity & Dynamics of Teamwork in Open Collaborations
column9: Jonathan Morgan, Michael Gilbert, David McDonald, Mark Zachry
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: We report a study of the English edition of Wikipedia in which we use a mixed-methods approach to understand how participation in specialized workgroups called WikiProjects has changed over the life of Wikipedia. While previous work has analyzed the work of WikiProjects in supporting the creation and maintenance of articles within particular subject domains, the collaborative role of WikiProjects that do not fit this conventional, article-production mold have not been empirically examined. We combine content analysis, interviews and analysis of edit logs to identify and characterize WikiProjects and the work they do. Our analysis suggests that participation in alternative types of projects and activities reflect community concerns and shifts in the community’s conception of valued work over the past six years. We discuss implications for other open collaborations that need flexible, adaptable coordination mechanisms to support a range of content creation, curation and community maintenance activities.

column3: The Influence of Low-context and High-context Cultural Communication Styles in Computer-Mediated Communication
column9: Helen He, Elaine Huang
column14: Dept. of Informatics, People and Computing Lab
column23: People and Computing Lab, Dept. of Informatics
column100: Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: Multicultural teams face many challenges to achieving effective communication. Although Computer-Mediated Communication (CMC) technologies can facilitate communication among culturally diverse team members, differences in culturally-based communication styles affect the use and perception of such technologies, resulting in misunderstandings or tensions. The influence of cultural communication styles within CMC usage is not well-understood, and therefore generally not considered in CMC technology design. To begin to address this issue, we explore the influence of high-context and low-context cultural communication styles on CMC use.  We present a set of CMC practices and interpretations of these practices, derived from a synthesis of communication theory, media richness theory, cultural anthropology findings, previous CMC research, as well as our own study data.  Finally, we propose new avenues of exploration for the CSCW community, with regards to the influence of cultural communication styles on CMC usage.

column3: Crowd Synthesis: Distributed Clustering of Complex Data
column9: Paul André, Aniket Kittur, Steven Dow
column100: Crowdsourcing
column101: Analysts synthesize complex, qualitative data to uncover themes and concepts, but the process is time-consuming, cognitively taxing, and automated techniques show mixed success. Crowdsourcing could help this process through on-demand harnessing of flexible and powerful human cognition, but incurs other challenges including limited attention and expertise. This paper presents three studies in using distributed crowds to `discover' conceptual clusters in complex data sets. Experiment 1 demonstrates the feasibility of using novice crowds with an artificial shapes dataset, comparing pairwise similarity and partial clustering approaches. Experiments 2 and 3 extend this work to challenges in text data: complex, high-dimensional, and ill-structured. To address these challenges we propose a two-stage approach: A) we draw on cognitive theory to assess how re-representing data can shorten and focus on salient dimensions; and B) introduce an iterative clustering approach that provides workers a global overview of data. We discuss performance differences and demonstrate a classification-plus-context approach elicits the most accurate categories at the most useful level of abstraction.

column3: EchoTree: Engaged Conversation when Capabilities are Limited
column9: Andreas Paepcke, Sanjay Kairam
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Collaboration architectures; Collaborative visualization; Crowdsourcing
column101: Speech and motor-impaired individuals using assistive technologies to communicate face a common problem; the inevitable conversational `dead space,' which occurs while the user generates written or artificially-spoken sentences can dramatically reduce conversation quality and partner engagement. To address this problem, we introduce EchoTree, a visualization approach employing predictive language modeling to generate and display candidate utterances, thus allowing  partners to call out guesses about the impaired user's intended conversational direction. By including partners in the process of sentence generation, EchoTree mitigates the dead space problem by (1) engaging partners in a collaborative activity, and (2) in partially reducing the task of typing to that of confirming a word choice guessed by the conversation partner.
