Our implementation is browser-based, making it suitable for face-to-face or remote communication, as multiple parties can view and interact with the same stream of EchoTrees from desktops, tablets, or smartphones. We describe visual and system design choices, and detailed experiments with data sources and language models that informed out current implementation.

column3: Mixing It Up With Social Media in a Political Campaign: Order Effects on Knowledge and Affect
column9: Scott Robertson, Bryan Semaan, Sara Douglas, Misa Maruyama
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Other domain-specific support
column101: Political participation is moving increasingly into computer-mediated environments such as social networking sites (SNSs). However, SNSs exist in a larger information ecology from which people learn about political candidates and issues. This study examined the interaction of political SNSs with other online information sources. Subjects were exposed to political candidates’ Facebook walls, to news articles about the candidates, and to a political speech. The order of exposure was varied and several measures of knowledge and affect were taken. The results show that the order of SNS information influenced subjects’ perceived knowledge, feelings about the candidates, likelihood of voting, and personal affect. We discuss the findings in light of rational and affective aspects of political decision making. \

column3: Impact of Mediating Technologies on Talk and Emotion: Questioning “Commonsense”
column9: Joon Suk Lee, Deborah Tatar
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Much CSCW research predominantly focuses on investigating how distributed, mediated interactions are different from collocated interactions, but rarely looks at how the use of technologies affect collocated people. We argue that the needs for studying the impact of mediating technologies among collocated people are current and large. A situation of seeing the other but not being able to see what captures his/her attention is endemic. In this paper, we investigate collocated triads as they play a collaborative, problem-solving game on laptops, on tablets or on a shared paper. People’s positive emotion rose more when they talked about the complex relationships of the puzzle specifics and added new perspectives to other people’s contributions during the game. People in computer conditions talked less about the specifics on the game board than people in the paper condition, but only people in the laptop condition experienced a significant decrease in positive emotion.

column3: Sounds of Silence: Exploring Contributions to Conversa-tions, Non-Responses and the Impact of Mediating Tech-nologies in Triple Space
column9: Joon Suk Lee, Deborah Tatar
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: We investigate collocated triads as they play a collaborative, problem-solving game using distributed technology on laptops. We examine how different triads attain and maintain mutual understanding in triple-space––when working on a hard problem, with communicating technologies and face-to-face interaction. We present qualitative and quantitative evidence that shows that the notion of good-enoughness is not a group attribute, but rather tied to each dyadic pair. We also discuss and show how groups and individuals can have multiple coexisting current purposes. In addition, we examine how non-response affects group processes in increasingly pervasive “triple space” situations. Our data shows that not all non-responses are the same. Different mediating technologies afford different types of non-responses.

column3: Children’s Exposure to Mobile In-App Advertising: An Analysis of Content Appropriateness
column9: Ying Chen, Sencun Zhu, Heng Xu, Yilu Zhou
column14: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column23: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column32: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column41: Department of Information Systems and Technology Management
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: There is a rising concern among parents that violent and sexual advertisements are shown in the applications (apps) aimed at children. This study is the first to explore the content appropriateness of the in-app advertisements on mobile devices from children’s online safety perspective. We find in-app advertisements are common in the free apps designed for children. Our experimental results show that a large percent of the in-app advertisements carry inappropriate contents for children. Unfortunately, neither mobile platforms nor advertising networks provide maturity policies to restrict the contents of the in-app advertisements. Our findings suggest that these challenges cannot easily be tackled by one entity. Instead, advertisement providers, advertising networks, app developers, and mobile platforms should collaborate in developing policies and mechanisms to monitor the content appropriateness of the in-app advertisements.

column3: Online Kidsteam: Developing an Environment for Geographically Distributed, Intergenerational Participatory Design
column9: Greg Walsh
column100: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Home/family/intimacy support; Distributed/virtual teams; Other domain-specific support
column101: As more children’s technologies are designed to be used with a global audience, new tools need to be created to include more children’s voices in the design process. However, working with those children who are geographically distributed as design partners is difficult because existing technologies either do not support distributed design, or are not child-friendly. In this paper, we describe the design process of an online environment to support geographically distributed, intergenerational participatory design. Within this environment, children can work together despite differences of time zones, geographic location, or availability. The online environment was deployed for eight weeks during the summer and was modified each week throughout that time to better support the participants. Based on the experiences of participants within the environment, we make suggestions for new technologies including user management tools, creative expression tools, and ad hoc team membership.

column3: Negotiating communication availability: Contact or contact not – there is no try
column9: John Tang, Henry Chen
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: While presence and awareness among remote collaborators have been research topics for over 20 years, the current landscape of diverse communication tools and mobile devices creates some new challenges for negotiating availability. We interviewed 16 people about their current practices in negotiating availability among their moderately close contacts across work, home, and mobile contexts. While we expected the interviews to help identify new availability signals to share, we instead found that people chose to explicitly negotiate their availability through lightweight exchanges enabled by mobile texting. We identify the reasons for this approach, and discuss implications for design and further research.

column3: Counting & Coordinating: How people track their personal finances
column9: Joseph 'Jofish' Kaye, Mary McCuistion, Rebecca Gulotta, David Shamma
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: In this paper, we present a study of fourteen residents of the San Francisco Bay Area from a wide variety of economic circumstances and explore how they think about and handle their personal finances. We describe best practices we developed for exploring the sensitive topic of money in qualitative interviews, and then discuss three sets of results. The first is the complex relationship between finances and self-identity, relationships, and family. Second, we discuss the tools and processes people used to keep track of their financial situation. The third set presents how people account for the unknown and unpredictable nature of the future through their financial decisions. We conclude implications for the design of tools to aid people in better managing their money, and discuss the future of studies of money and finance in CSCW.

column3: You’re Happy, I’m Happy: Diffusion of Mood Expression on Twitter
column9: Munmun De Choudhury
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: We study the propagation of expressions of moods from one individual to another in social media. Specifically, we utilize an ensemble of more than 200 moods, and follow their trails of retweets on Twitter. We examine the diffusion of these moods through the characteristics of the author of the retweeted post, of the post, and its linguistic style and topical content. We observe that moods of high valence and low to moderate activation propagate the most. Our findings also indicate that mood-bearing posts from individuals of medium #followers show highest diffusion, instead of elite users. Further, moods in postings with high self-attentional focus, posted by socially interactive women, and with fewer links diffuse the most. Finally, we leverage these characteristics to build a linear regression model that can predict degree of diffusion in a mood-bearing post. The model yields accuracy of 75% showing that user’s attributes as well as post’s language characteristics are key factors driving the diffusion of moods in social media.

column3: A Multi-Perspective Analysis of Hyper-local Online Communities
column9: Rosta Farzan, Claudia López, Di Lu
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: Hyper-local online communities that aim at reaching people living in bounded geographical regions (e.g. neighborhoods and towns) have become widespread among practitioners, and they are becoming increasingly successful. In this paper, we attempt to describe the state of the practice in this niche of online communities, their motivation, their challenges, and opportunities. Our findings show that hyper-local online communities have the potential to significantly contribute to creating stronger communities and well-connected neighborhoods. They can provide an easier and safer way for the community members to communicate with each other and offer the citizen new opportunities to deal with the local issues.  Our observations are inspiring to pursue further research in this field.

column3: The Language that Gets People to Give: Phrases that Predict Success on Kickstarter
column9: Tanushree Mitra, Eric Gilbert
column100: Crowdsourcing; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter—where entrepreneurs and artists look to the internet for funding—have quickly risen to prominence. However, we know very little about the factors that motivate the “crowd” to take projects to their funding goal. In this paper we explore the factors which lead to successfully funding a crowdfunding project. By studying a corpus of 45K crowdfunded projects, and analyzing 9M phrases, we find that the language used in the project pitch is the most important factor—accounting for 58.56% of the variance around successful funding. A closer look at the phrases shows they exhibit general persuasion principles. For example, also receive two reflects the principle of Reciprocity and is one of the top predictors of successful funding. We conclude this paper by announcing the release of the predictive phrases as a public dataset, hoping that our work can enable new features on crowdfunding sites—tools to help both backers and project creators make the best use of their time and money.

column3: Survival of the fittest: Modelling the competition dynamics that shape Facebook posts’ popularity and effectiveness
column9: Jorge Goncalves, Bin Xiao, Yong Liu, Saad Chaudhry, Simo Hosio, Vassilis Kostakos
column15: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Oulu
column23: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column32: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column41: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column50: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column59: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column100: Social network analysis; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: Facebook posts compete for human attention in a zero-sum game. The effectiveness of one post in grabbing the population’s attention comes at the cost of another, due to humans’ finite attention. In a large-scale longitudinal study we investigate what makes Facebook posts popular (seen by many) and effective (commented, liked, or shared by many) in the context of an online community. We model the competition dynamics that shape the fate of Facebook posts using Structural Equation Modelling – independent of their semantics. Our analysis reveals that audience demographics, the timing of posts, and the media type of post are significant factors, and drawing on these we identify important opportunities for developing an effective social media strategy for organisations.

column3: Ensemble: directing creative collaboration through constraints
column9: Joy Kim, Justin Cheng, Michael Bernstein
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Crowdsourcing
column101: Crowds can empower creative work, but structuring that collaboration is a challenge. In story writing, the diverse perspectives of the crowd could support an author’s search for the perfect character, setting, or plot. However, too little structure for the crowd leads to unfocused, sprawling narratives, and too much structure stifles creativity. Motivated by the idea that individual creative leaders and the crowd have complementary creative strengths, we present an approach where a leader directs the high-level vision for a story and articulates creative constraints for the crowd. This approach is manifest in Ensemble, a novel collaborative story-writing platform. In a month-long short story competition, over one hundred volunteer users on the web began more than fifty short stories using Ensemble. Leaders used the platform to direct collaborator work by establishing creative goals, and collaborators contributed meaningful, high-level ideas to stories through targeted suggestions. This work suggests that asymmetric creative contributions may support a broad new class of creative collaborations.

column3: CoPro: A Tangible Programming Tool for Children’s Collaboration
column9: Danli Wang, Yunfeng Qi, Yue Gong, Tingting Wang, Liang He
column15: Institute of Software, Chinese Academy of Sciences
column24: Institute of Software,Chinese Academy of Sciences
column32: Institute of Software,Chinese Academy of Sciences
column33: Institute of Software,Chinese Academy of Sciences
column42: Institute of Software, Chinese Academy of Sciences
column51: Institute of Software, Chinese Academy of Sciences
column100: Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: In this paper, we introduce CoPro, a collaborative tangible programming tool for children aged from 7 to 9. Compared with previous similar tools, CoPro supports children’s collaboration by allowing them to program their own programs in parallel. It consists of two parts: the Hardware and the CoPro Game. In CoPro, cameras are adopted to capture block sequences in real time. The system checks the syntax and semantics and provides real-time feedback. To evaluate how CoPro can support collaboration between children, we conducted a user study with 14 children. The results demonstrated that CoPro is interesting, easy to learn and use. In addition, it not only can support children’s collaboration, but also expose them to basic programming concepts.

column3: Specification and Enforcement of Governance Rules in Software Development
column9: Javier Luis Canovas Izquierdo, Jordi Cabot
column100: Collaborative software development; Collaboration architectures
column101: Any software development project is decomposed into a series of tasks which must be properly prioritized and managed for the success of the project. Unfortunately, the rules governing the tasks (e.g., deciding which ones should be completed first or be part of the next release) are usually implicit or appear scattered in the project documentation or tools (e.g., tracking-systems, forums, etc.). \  \ In this paper we propose to enable the explicit definition and enforcement of governance rules for development tasks. We believe this support provides several important benefits, including improvements in the transparency of the decisionmaking process, traceability (why a decision was made) and the automation of the governance process (e.g. liberating developers from applying the rules manually, avoiding potential inconsistencies). Our approach has been implemented on top of Mylyn, a project management plug-in for Eclipse, which supports most tracking-systems, thus allowing the use of our approach in most development projects.

column3: The Role of Interface Transparency in Facilitating Idea Generation in Groups
column9: Michael Stewart, Deborah Tatar, Steve Harrison
column14: The Center for Human Computer Interaction
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design
column101: Many CSCW applications go to great lengths to maximize transparency by making available participants' actions and respective application states to all others in real-time. Designers might intend to enhance coordination through increased transparency, but what other outcomes might be influenced by these choices? We developed two versions of a CSCW application to support a group idea generation task for collocated groups. One version had diminished transparency in comparison to the other. We studied the effects of this varied transparency on the groups' generativity and collaboration. We found that in modulating transparency there was a trade-off between generativity and collaboration. Groups with diminished transparency felt that their groupmates built on their ideas more, but groups with increased transparency were more generative.

column3: Social Traces: The Impact of Exposing Previous Users’ Characteristics on Social Page Interaction
column9: Charles File, Mor Naaman, Oded Nov, Funda Kivran-Swaine, Raz Schwartz
column33: Polytechnic Institute of New York University
column100: User experience/interaction design; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: This paper presents the results of an experiment studying interaction behavior on a community-driven web page. The experiment manipulated the similarity of a contrived community with each participant, as well as manipulating the presence of cues on the page from which participants might infer that similarity. We term these cues social traces. We examined the effects of social traces on participants’ likelihood to leave a comment. Our results indicate that the presence of social traces can have meaningful impacts on interaction behavior. Contrary to conventional wisdom, however, we found that in certain cases – such as when the user has a good deal of similarity with the community that exists on the social page – the presence of overt social traces can actually decrease interaction likelihood. We discuss further findings that demonstrate the nuances of this effect, particularly with respect to the users’ gender.

column3: Catalyst: Using Activation Thresholds to Trigger Collective Action
column9: Justin Cheng, Michael Bernstein
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Crowdsourcing
column101: The web is a catalyst for drawing people together around shared goals, but many groups never reach critical mass. It can thus be risky to commit effort to a goal: participants arrive only to discover that nobody else came, and organizers devote significant effort to causes that never get off the ground. Crowdfunding lessens this risk by only calling in donations when an effort reaches a collective goal. However, it leaves unsolved the harder problem of mobilizing time and effort. We generalize the concept into activation thresholds, commitments that are conditioned on others’ participation: supporters only need to show up if enough other people commit as well. We present Catalyst, which introduces activation thresholds for on-demand events. For complex coordination needs, Catalyst also includes thresholds for time and role. Catalyst users have organized events including volunteering, on-demand study groups, and mass participation events like a human chess game. Our results suggest that activation thresholds can indeed catalyze a large class of new collective efforts.

column3: Design-Researcher as Therapist: The unexpected  implications of discursive methods in CSCW
column9: Stacy Branham, Steve Harrison
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: The evolving philosophies, methods, and designed artifacts of the CSCW design-researcher are more collaborative and value-active than ever before. It is not uncommon, for example, for researcher and participant to co-construct design solutions, share intimate life stories over design probes, or seek personal fulfillment through reflective technologies. We argue that the types of discourses opened as design-researchers practice their craft constitute "therapeutic communication." That is, they have the power to significantly shape selfhood and refigure participants’ most deeply felt relational bonds. In this paper, we unpack the notion of therapeutic communication through engaging multiple literatures and findings from our study of intimate couple relationships. We conclude by exploring ethical dilemmas presented when we appreciate that the same activities we use in making knowledge and making technology are also in service of making (inter)personal identities.

column3: Interdependencies Between Work Practices in Coordinating Center Enabled Networks (CCENs)
column9: Betsy Rolland, Drew Paine, Charlotte Lee
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Other domain-specific support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Despite recent attention to scientific collaboration, forms of collaboration specifically supported by Coordinating Centers in networked science have remained understudied in CSCW. Coordinating Centers (CCs) are central bodies tasked with the work of coordination and operations management of a multi-site research project. This qualitative, ethnographic study followed two CCs in the field of cancer epidemiology and the networked projects of which they are a part over seven months, through team meeting observations and interviews. From these data, a typology of work practices was developed that encompasses five types of work being done in these scientific networks, here called Coordinating Center Enabled Networks (CCENs). This paper describes the typology and notes the interdependencies between categories, as well as the effect the work practices have on the CCEN’s scientific progress. Finally, we propose an extension of the concept of Articulation Work that encompasses the scope of coordinative work performed in a CCEN.

column3: Analysis of Context Protocols by Conversation Tagging in Multilingual Gaming Simulation
column9: Taishi Nose, Reiko Hishiyama
column14: School of Creative Science and Engineering
column23: School of Creative Science and Engineering
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: Due to globalization, cross-lingual communicating using machine translation has been becoming widespread. However, machine translation results in mistranslations. When collaborating on the Internet, it may be more difficult to effectively communicate with others than face-to-face as it may be difficult to get a handle on the context of the conversation. We analyzed chat data in a machine-translation-mediated multilingual gaming simulation on the Internet. We analyzed the chatting data on the basis of conversation tags that are added by players. We extracted players' action and context protocols in analysis, revealing common communication patterns. We found that mistranslation tends to occur when their conversation are complex, such as containing conversational congestion. This is usually overcome by communicating on common ground after experiencing conversational congestion.

column3: Context Estimation Framework for Real-world Learning from Spatiotemporal Occurrence of Intellectual Activities
column9: Masaya Okada, Masahiro Tada
column100: E-Learning and Education; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: Real-world learning through experience is a typical example of intellectual collaboration in a real-world setting. Formative assessment by constant monitoring of the intellectual achievement of real-world learners is essential for context-aware support, but no assessment methodology has yet been developed. We consider a method to systematically integrate heterogeneous factors of real-world learning: learners' internal situations, their external situations, and their learning field. Then, we propose a framework for systematically estimating the situation of real-world learning. The framework enables us to recognize the sequence of characteristic stay behavior and the associated body posture of a learner, and to estimate the 3D location of his/her interest. The framework enables the estimation of not only the learning topic that a learner is currently examining in a field but also the prospective topics that he/she should learn. Computer-based support with our framework promotes the emergence of new knowledge from intellectual collaboration in the world.

column3: smartPrediction: A Real-time Smartphone-based Fall Risk Prediction and Prevention System
column9: A.K.M. Jahangir Majumder, Ishmat Zerin, Miftah Uddin, Sheikh Ahamed
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining; User experience/interaction design; Home/family/intimacy support; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Medical and health support
column101: The high risk of falls and the substantial increase in the elderly population have recently stimulated scientific research on Smartphone-based fall detection systems. Even though these systems are helpful for fall detection, the best way to reduce the falls and their consequences is to predict and prevent them from happening. To address the issue of fall prevention, in this paper, we propose a fall prediction and prevention system by integrating the sensor data of Smartphones and a SmartShoe. We designed a SmartShoe that contains four pressure sensors with a Wi-Fi communication module to unobtrusively collect data in any environment. By assimilating the SmartShoe and Smartphone sensors data, we performed an extensive set of experiments to evaluate normal and abnormal walking patterns. The system can generate an alert message to warn the user about the high-risk gait patterns and potentially save them from an imminent fall.  We validated our approach using a decision tree with 10-fold cross validation and found 97.2% accuracy in gait abnormality detection.

column3: Avatars as Possessions, Tools, and Opportunities: How Players Value Their Characters in World of Warcraft
column9: Carl Gutwin, Ian Livingston, Regan Mandryk, Max Birk
column100: Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; User experience/interaction design; Entertainment/games
column101: Games characters in games like World of Warcraft have often been considered as a mediated form of self-representation, but recent research suggests that some online characters have less to do with identity. Instead, players appear to treat some of their characters as possessions, with their value arising from qualities such as utility or aesthetics. To better understand the ways that players value their characters in an online environment, we carried out a study of twenty regular World of Warcraft players. We found that players do in fact treat some of their characters as possessions rather than as identities, and we identified several kinds value that characters provide – investment value, representational value, utility, aesthetics, and value as an opportunity for creativity, communication, or sociability. The analytical lens of value provides a new understanding of the ways that players see and appreciate characters in online worlds. Our results can help designers support an aspect of multiplayer games that contributes greatly to player experience.

column3: It Takes an Online Village: A Social Media Ecology of New Mothers
column9: Louise Barkhuus, Elizabeth Bales, Lisa Cowan
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: In this paper we present a qualitative study of how new mothers and soon-to-be mothers utilize online resources, both authoritative and peer sourced, for information and support. We present the results of an interview study conducted with new mothers specifically relating to online information gathering and the seeking of emotional support triggered by the new life stage of motherhood.  We focus particularly on interaction with internet communities. We argue that these  communities can act as valuable social support media, particularly for new mothers and we suggest design guidelines for future support technologies.

column3: Specialization, Homophily, and Gender in a Social Curation Site: Findings from Pinterest
column9: Shuo Chang, Vikas Kumar, Eric Gilbert, Loren Terveen
column100: Social network analysis; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: Pinterest is a popular social curation site where people collect, organize, and share pictures of items. We studied two fundamental issues for such sites: flow of information (via repinning) and patterns of activity that attract followers. We organized our studies around two key factors: the extent to which users specialize in particular topics, and homophily among users. We also considered the existence of differences between female and male users. We found: (a) women and men differed in the types of content they collected and the degree to which they specialized; male Pinterest users were not particularly interested in stereotypically male topics; (b) sharing diverse types of content increases your following, but only up to a certain point; (c) homophily drives repinning: people repin content from other users who share their interests; homophily also affects following, but to a lesser extent. Our findings suggest strategies both for users (e.g., strategies to attract an audience) and maintainers (e.g., content recommendation methods) of social curation sites.

column3: Most Liked, Fewest Friends:  Patterns of Enterprise Social Media Use
column9: Gloria Mark, Ido Guy, Shiri Kremer-Davidson, Michal Jacovi
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Enterprise social media can provide visibility of users’ actions and thus has the potential to reveal insights about users in the organization. In this study we mined large-scale social media use in an enterprise to examine: a) user roles with such broad platforms and b) whether people with large social networks are highly regarded. First, a factor analysis revealed that most variance of social media usage is explained by commenting and ‘liking’ behaviors while other usage can be characterized as patterns of distinct tool usage. These results informed the development of a model showing that network size interacts with other media usage to predict who is highly assessed in the organization. We discovered that the smaller one’s network size in the organization, the more highly assessed they were by colleagues. We explain this inverse relationship as due to friending behavior being highly visible but not yet valued in the organization.

column3: Speech Resource Locators - Sharing Dynamic, User Generated Content and Static Content over Voice through low-end mobiles
column9: Sheetal Agarwal, Jyoti Grover, Priyanka Manwani, Meghna Singh, Arun Kumar
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Collaboration architectures; User experience/interaction design
column101: Sharing of knowledge and collaboration have taken a new meaning with advances in technology since the inception of the Web. We have blogs, instant messengers, mailing lists, twitter and popular social networks such as Facebook and LinkedIn. However, a large section of the society has been largely untouched by Internet so far. People from such underprivileged sections have recently begun to enter and live in the digital world through voice based applications accessible over ordinary telephone calls. However, collaborating with content in telephony voice applications is non trivial. The concept of a shareable hyperlink, a key element that makes popular features of services in web very effective, is not available with telephony voice applications. In this paper, we present Speech Resource Locators (SRLs) – a framework for creating, sharing and accessing links to data and services in such applications. We present the design, describe implemented services and discuss the potential of SRLs to enable much needed communication and collaboration across various sections of underprivileged communities.

column3: PROCID: Bringing Consensus Building to Real-World Distributed Design Discussions
column9: Roshanak Zilouchian Moghaddam, Brian Bailey, Zane Nicholson
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; User experience/interaction design; Collaborative software development
column101: Reaching consensus is a desired but elusive goal in many distributed discussions. A fundamental problem is that the communication interfaces used for the discussions (e.g. Web forums) lack mechanisms for building consensus. In this paper we introduce Procid, a novel interactive system supporting consensus building in distributed design discussions. The key features include (i) a navigation panel for quickly accessing comments with desirable properties; (ii) an idea page that displays the idea proposals, spatially organizes the comments to show their support or opposition to each idea, and shows user-created criteria for evaluating the ideas; and (iii) an algorithm that generates candidates to invite to the discussion by considering criteria important for consensus in the domain. Procid was built as an add-on to the discussion interface in an existing open source software community. An evaluation of Procid in this community shows that users found the primary features of the tool beneficial and perceived it as more effective for consensus building than the discussion interface currently used.

column3: How Social Q&A Sites are Changing Knowledge Sharing in Open Source Software Communities
column9: Bogdan Vasilescu, Alexander Serebrenik, Prem Devanbu, Vladimir Filkov
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaborative software development; Crowdsourcing
column101: Mailing lists have been the preferred means for coordinating development and user support activities in open source software development. With the emergence and popularity growth of social Q&A platforms such as StackExchange, this is beginning to change. Such platforms offer different socio-technical incentives to their participants than mailing lists do, e.g., rich web environments to store and manage content collaboratively, or a place to showcase their expertise more visibly to potential recruiters. However, one of the fundamental differences between StackExchange and mailing lists is gamification, i.e., participants compete to obtain reputation points and badges. Using a case study of R, a popular data analysis software, we investigate how mailing list participation has evolved since the launch of StackExchange. We found that mailing list experts are migrating to StackExchange, and their behavior is influenced by gamification: participants active on both are more active and provide faster answers on StackExchange than on the mailing list, suggesting they are motivated by the game.

column3: Duck, Kamo, Goose: Text and Video Chat Usage by Non-Native Speakers in Multi-party, Multi-linugal Collaboration
column9: Andy Echenique, Naomi Yamashita, Hideaki Kuzuoka
column100: Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: With computer-mediated communication (CMC) tools allowing  collaborations to span across the globe, teams can  incorporate larger groups with greater distances between members. Previous research has identified how communication mediums such as video conferencing and IM chat affect multi-lingual collaborations. When multi-lingual collaborations extend beyond one-on-one interactions, it is unknown how communication mediums address the needs of non-native speaker (NNS) collaborators. To investigate the effect CMC plays in multi-party and multi-lingual collaborations, three person groups  of native and non-native speakers using audio + text (Text) or audio + video (Video) were compared, with each medium being used twice. The NNS's task accuracy dropped significantly in the second Video task. In addition, the NNS's number of common task references increased during the second Text task. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of Text communication for NNSs in multi-party, continued collaborations and give further insight into the challenges NNSs face in multi-lingual, multi-party collaborations.

column3: “Maybe It Was a Joke” - Emotion Rating in Text-Based Communication by Non-Native English Speakers
column9: Ari Hautasaari, Naomi Yamashita
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: Recent literature has largely disproven the notion that emotions cannot be effectively conveyed in text-only media. However, whether non-native speakers can accurately detect emotions in text-based communication has not yet been addressed. This paper introduces an experiment where native (NS) and non-native speakers (NNS) rate the emotional tone of real text-based messages written by native English speaking authors. NNS were less accurate at detecting the emotions in messages compared to NS, especially in the absence of highly positive or negative words. NNS accuracy improved when the English messages were long but reduced when replies to the original messages were included as additional contextual information. Instead of making use of non-verbal cues, such as emoticons in messages and replies, NNS relied on a wide range of objective words and expressions to determine the emotional tone of each message. The results are used to inform the design of supporting tools for multilingual communication and intercultural collaboration.

column3: Promoting User Engagement in Participatory Sensing Applications: The Role of Demographics
column9: Osarieme omokaro, Emmanuel Bello-Ogunu, Amul Adagale, Jamie Payton
column15: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column24: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column33: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column42: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Crowdsourcing
column101: Participatory sensing, in which volunteers use the sensors on \ their smart phones to capture and transmit digital samples of \ the surrounding environment, shows promise for large-scale \ data collection. Recently, researchers have begun to explore \ the use of incentives to motivate participation in these kinds \ of data collection campaigns. This paper presents the results \ of a survey aimed at understanding the use of incentive mechanisms \ in a participatory sensing context, with an explicit focus \ on the role age, race, gender, and education play in these \ types of data collection campaigns. Our results indicate that \ demographics have an impact on how effective incentives are \ for motivating or engaging participants. Understanding the \ influence of demographics on the effectiveness of incentives \ can help developers to create incentives that are tailored for a \ particular participatory sensing application and personalized \ for a user. This work represents a first step to establishing \ design guidelines for participatory sensing incentives.

column3: A Theoretical Model of Mediated Shared Space for Supporting Informal Interaction at a Distance
column9: Thi Lan Truc Nguyen
column100: Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Researchers have developed a variety of technical ways for supporting informal interaction at a distance. However, critical issues regarding awareness support still exist in these systems and this paper examines them. A theoretical model of mediated shared space (Meshed Space) is proposed using spatio-temporal approach in which spatial factors of proximity, visibility, reality, connectivity and sociability, and temporal factors of synchrony and symmetry are used to minimize the critical issues.

column3: Being A Turker
column9: David Martin, Jacki O'Neill, Benjamin Hanrahan, Neha Gupta
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Crowdsourcing is a topic of intense interest in CSCW both as a phenomenon and as a means for conducting research. However, little in-depth, qualitative work has been done to understand crowdworkers, their perspectives and their needs. This research addresses this deficit through a virtual ethnography of Turker Nation forum, a site specifically set up to serve workers (Turkers) who use Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT). We show in detail how Turkers consider they are doing a job of work and orient to AMT as a marketplace. We use this material to illustrate practical and ethical issues surrounding Turkers and the use of AMT.

column3: Understanding Valued Contribution Types in Open Source Design Discussions
column9: Roshanak Zilouchian Moghaddam, Mohsen Vakilian, Brian Bailey, Wai-Tat Fu
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Collaborative software development; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Open source software is a community effort. Participants contribute to the design and development of open source software by writing documentation, submitting code (patches), providing design ideas, etc. However, not all contribution types are valued equally. We report the results of a study in which we used a mixed methods approach to understand the valued contribution types and to examine whether contributors’ roles (designer vs. developer) and their seniority (senior vs. junior members) affect how their contribution is valued. Our analysis revealed that the valued contributions are beyond software development contributions and include social support and collaborative activities. We also found that while junior members usually value developers’ code based contributions, senior members value both designers’ and developers’ contributions. Finally, our analysis indicates that designers’ contributions are valued less often than developers’ contribution. Based on our results, we formulated implications for open source communities who would like to improve the sense of contribution among members with different roles and motivate them to participate.

column3: Collaborative Visual Analysis of Sentiment in Twitter Events
column9: Michael Brooks, John Robinson, Megan Torkildson, Ray Hong, Cecilia Aragon
column23: University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, United States
column100: Collaborative visualization; User experience/interaction design; Social network analysis; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: The widespread adoption of social media generates a vast \ quantity of data that is an increasingly resource for researchers \ across CSCW and many other communities. Collaborative \ visual analytics tools may offer a way for researchers \ to approach large, complex datasets comprised of \ social media content. In this paper, we present TwitterVis, \ a tool enabling multiple researchers to conduct  \ exploratory visual analysis of Twitter datasets,  \ with a focus on emotion around events. We discuss \ an open-ended evaluation of TwitterVis with seven researchers \ interested in Twitter data, to collaboratively explore \ a set of nearly 8 million tweets collected during the 2013 Super \ Bowl. Participants used the tool to identify events of interest \ in the dataset, left comments about questions, hypotheses \ and findings, and used the traces left by other users to prompt \ their own exploration.

column3: Don’t Be Deceived: Dissecting Truthful and Deceptive Reviews
column9: Snehasish Banerjee, Alton Chua
column23: Wee Kim Wee School of Communication and Information
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Crowdsourcing
column101: With the proliferation of user-generated content, users increasingly harness reviews contributed by online peers for decision making. Concurrently, some organizations have fallen into the trap of posting deceptive reviews to promote their products or services. Hence, analyzing differences between truthful and deceptive reviews has become a pressing issue. Though such differences are generally difficult to detect, there could be tell-tale signs in terms of readability, genre and writing style of reviews. This paper thus conducts a linguistic analysis to investigate the extent to which readability, genre and writing style could predict review truthfulness. Drawing data from a publicly available dataset that includes 400 truthful reviews and 400 deceptive reviews for hotels, results indicate that readability and writing style could be significant predictors of review truthfulness. The main findings gleaned from the paper are discussed.

column3: Predicting the Future with a Social Network
column9: Clifton Forlines, Sarah Miller, Leslie Guelcher, Robert Bruzzi
column100: Crowdsourcing
column101: Researchers have long known that aggregate estimations \ built from the individual opinions of a large group of people \ often outperform the estimations of individual experts. This \ phenomenon is generally described as the Wisdom of \ Crowds. In respect to forecasting future events, this \ approach has shown promise. Previous research has \ demonstrated the value of utilizing meta-forecasts \ (forecasts about what others in the group will predict) when \ aggregating. In this paper, we describe an extension to \ meta-forecasting and demonstrate the value of modeling the \ familiarity among a population’s members (its social \ network) and applying this model to forecast aggregation. \ A pair of studies demonstrates the value of taking this \ model into account, and the described technique produces \ aggregate forecast for future events that are significantly \ better than the standard Wisdom of Crowds approach.

column3: Account Sharing in the Context of Networked Hospitality Exchange
column9: Airi Lampinen, Airi Lampinen, Airi Lampinen
column24: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology HIIT / Aalto University
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: This paper examines account sharing in the context of networked hospitality exchange. I discuss the dynamics of account sharing based on a qualitative interview study with multi-person households who offer to host visitors via Couchsurfing.org. Findings reveal that multi-people households that engage in account sharing face several challenges, including presenting multiple people in one profile, coordinating negotiations over access to domestic space, and fairly representing the reputation hosts have accumulated together over time. Amidst the rising rhetoric of a ‘reputation economy’, this paper calls for engaging the inclusions, exclusions, and inequalities that reputation metrics may renew or create, especially if they fail to acknowledge people’s account sharing practices. Furthermore, this paper encourages adopting a design focus beyond individuals in order to cater to users’ goals and needs in maintaining shared accounts and interacting with others through them.

column3: “Eat My Words”: An Empirical Investigation of an Edible Medium for Social Messaging
column9: Jun Wei, Xiaojuan Ma, Shengdong Zhao
column14: NUS Graduate School for Integrative Sciences and Engineering
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Food is more than a means of survival. It is also a form of communication. In this paper, we explored the potential of using food as a social message carrier (a.k.a., food messaging) through a large-scale field study. We conducted the study in an IT company over a period of 20 working days to investigate how people accept, use, and perceive food messaging. We analyzed the characteristics of the 904 collected messages from 343 senders as well as the survey responses and observation notes. Our results suggest strong acceptance for food messaging as an emerging communication medium. This communication method is preferred to use by people with intimate relationship, for expressing socially encouraging content while receiving food messages help to invoke positive emotional reactions. As a first field study on edible social messaging, our findings provide valuable insight into the uniqueness of food as social medium and its potential to promote social bonding.

column3: An Exploration of Communication Media-enabled Knowledge Integration
column9: Dc HONG, cf sha, ym li, chris hong
column14: Shanghai Key Lab of Intelligent Information Processing,School of Computer Science
column33: Shanghai International Wine Exchange Co. Ltd
column41: Shanghai Key Lab of Intelligent Information Processing
column100: Other domain-specific support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaboration architectures; User experience/interaction design
column101: With the tendency of increasing information technology (IT) applications, knowledge integration has emerged as an important research area for both practitioners and researchers, which is conducted by participants in cooperative works. Practically, information and knowledge are transmitted via various communication media in distributed environments and most existing literature examines knowledge integration both from computing and social techniques but ignores the effects of media characteristics. As a complement to previous research, this study proposes a comprehensive theoretical model of knowledge integration (KIM) by incorporating valuable views of media characteristics and social networks (SN) which provides a new prospective for knowledge integration. The mechanism of knowledge integration is explored from a synthesized lens of the uncertainty reduction theory (URT) and the transactive memory systems (TMS). This robust and new model is supported by the investigation of knowledge integration practice on an e-commerce platform of ABC and knowledge integration practice of EFG which can be used to explain the most knowledge integration phenomenon for communication media-enabled cooperative works.

column3: A New User in an Advanced Reputation System: Exploring Behavior on Stack Overflow
column9: Andrew Vargo, Shigeo Matsubara
column14: Graduate School of Informatics, Department of Social Informatics, Ishida and Matsubara Laboratory
column23: Graduate School of Informatics/Social Informatics/Ishida and Matsubara Laboratory
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Questions and Answer (Q&A) forums are important way for crowds to share and disseminate information. A popular way to encourage positive participation is to implement a user driven reputation system. In Stack Overflow, the community has the power to vote and effectively moderate users and contributions. Reputation systems with continuous aggregation of points have a property in that there is an intrinsic advantage to users who have been with the system since inception, making it difficult for new or previously unengaged users to make an impact. However, there are a small number of users who do advance in the reputation system. Clarifying such users’ behavior helps us to understand the mechanisms of the barrier to wider participation. In this study, we look at users who have been able to quickly ascend the reputation pyramid. The analysis shows that high rates of answering and voting have positive correlation with reputation aggregation.

column3: Predicting If and When a Community Will Respond
column9: Jacob Bartel, Prasun Dewan
column100: Recommender and Filtering Systems; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: In post-and-response systems, users often post hoping to receiving responses in a timely manner. Based on when a response will occur, users may want to wait, postpone their work, or perform alternate actions.  We have developed first-cut recommender algorithms that assist the users by predicting if and when a response will occur without assuming anything about the recipients. The main idea in this work is that the response rate of a post in a community thread is correlated with the response rates of previous posts in “similar” threads. To evaluate our work, we have used two public databases: the Newsgroup 20 and the Stack Exchange public data dumps. For Newsgroups (Stack Overflow), we achieved 75.3% (85.2%) accuracy when predicting whether a response will occur and less than 20% (80 %) error predicting the response time. Our results in both cases indicate that our approach, arguably, has practical value by giving a potential poster a sense of scale for response times.

column3: Framework for Designing Social Support Systems for Illness Management
column9: Jina Huh, Andrea Hartzler, David McDonald, Wanda Pratt
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Home/family/intimacy support; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Medical and health support
column101: Social support plays a critical factor in aiding patients’ illness management. Together with the Internet, social support technologies for patients, such as online health communities, blogs, and chatting systems have become widely available for users with various illnesses. However, users’ needs and preferences for social support differ depending on the characteristics of individuals and the illness context. In this paper, we present the social support design framework, which guides social support system development based on needs associated with different illness contexts. We describe in detail the formulation process of the framework using two underlying models—the taxonomy of disease management and the CSCW Time/space model—to aid deeper understanding of specialized needs around social support and how they map to existing CSCW systems. We discuss the potential for our framework to help designers and developers explore how social support systems can address social support needs around illness management. We further discuss how the framework can illuminate design thinking and research.

column3: Groupgarden: Supporting Brainstorming through a Metaphorical Group Mirror
column9: Sarah Tausch, Ismail Kosan, Doris Hausen, Heinrich Hussmann
column100: Collaborative visualization; Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Other domain-specific support
column101: Creative group work is a common method for problem solving and idea generation. Brainstorming is one way to support idea generation in groups. To ensure the productivity of this creativity technique, participants have to observe several rules. Nevertheless, problems such as social loafing, free riding or evaluation apprehension can occur. Additionally, the amount of contributions of group members is often unbalanced. In this paper, we present an approach to support brainstorming rules and to diminish possible problems. We developed a metaphorical group mirror providing feedback about individual as well as group performance. In a user study, we compared brainstorming sessions supported by the feedback of Groupgarden with sessions without any additional support. Results show that the group mirror does effectively support the adherence to particular brainstorming rules. Moreover, participation was more balanced while the total number of ideas did not decrease.

column3: Cross-Cultural Design of Mobile Mathematics Learning Service for South African Schools
column9: Tanja Walsh, Teija Vainio, Riitta Vänskä
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Computer-Mediated Communication; E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; User experience/interaction design; Collaborative software development
column101: In the era of mobile devices and services, researchers in the educational domain have been interested in how to support collaborative learning with mobile technology in both local and global contexts. Recent HCI research in educational domain has particularly focused on how to develop mobile learning services and how to evaluate the learning outcomes. However, learning occurs in a cultural context and the impact of cultural sensitive issues for design of mobile learning needs more attention. We studied mobile mathematics learning- service in a longitudinal research with over 30 South African schools during three years. Our aim was to understand culturally dependent issues which need to be taken into consideration in the design of mobile learning services. We found subjective and objective culturally dependent issues in content, context, infrastructure and technology of mobile learning and therefore, subjects to cross-cultural research. As a conclusion we argue that localization enhances the user experience and therefore support learning.

column3: Make Your Programming Questions Be Answered Quickly: A Content Oriented Study to Technical Q&A Forum
column9: Yi Wang
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: Online programming forums enable programming knowledge sharing across organizational boundaries. Understanding how questions are asked and answered in forums will not only help developers to access the knowledge they need fast but bring important design implications. We report a study of Question and Answer (Q&A) process on MSDN's Visual C# general forum. This study is content-oriented instead of conventional social network analysis to CQA communities. We identified eight topic categories through two-round card sorting. We also explored various content features' influence to Q&A process. A qualitative analysis was performed to identify different life-cycle patterns of questions. These findings highlight the role of content features, and the interaction effects between them and forum phases. Based on these findings, we make a set of suggestions to information seekers on how to make their questions be answered faster, and derive implications for technical forums. To verify our findings, we also conducted a small replication to a Java technical forum and compared the results.

column3: With Stars in Eyes: In Search of Patterns in Users’ Ratings
column9: Alton Chua Y.K., Snehasish Banerjee
column14: Wee Kim Wee School of Communication and Information
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: This paper sheds light on ways users’ rating patterns in hotel review websites differ between independent and chain hotels. To delve deeper, users are classified according to their profiles, namely, business, couple, family, friend and solo while hotels are considered across four geographical regions, namely, America, Asia Pacific, Europe and Middle East-Africa. Data were drawn from TripAdvisor, a popular hotel review website and analyzed quantitatively. Specifically, a 5 (profiles) x 4 (regions) two-way analysis of variance was conducted for independent hotels as well as for chain hotels. The interesting findings were further teased out using a qualitative approach. Results indicate that users’ rating patterns differ significantly between independent and chain hotels across both profiles as well as regions. The paper concludes by highlighting limitations and potential directions for future research.

column3: Civic Engagement on Public Displays –  It's not a Walk in the Park
column9: Simo Hosio, Jorge Goncalves, Vassilis Kostakos, Jukka Riekki
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: As civic participation is declining in western societies, emerging technologies offer novel opportunities for outreach activities. This paper presents a series of incremental studies of interactive public displays to inform and elicit feedback about a local renovation project, with emphasis on civic engagement. Two questions are explored: i) how does the public use and appropriate this technology for civic engagement? and ii) how can the design of feedback mechanisms improve the collected feedback? We describe how users appropriated this technology beyond its original purpose, and show that feedback mechanisms promoting rapid interaction or a sense of community lead to increased participation. Through our study we highlight factors to consider in designing future civic engagement applications for public displays.

column3: Reliable and Unobtrusive Inter-Device Collaboration by Visual Interaction
column9: Rudolf Kajan, István Szentandrási, Adam Herout, Michal Zachariáš
column14: Department of Computer Graphics and Multimedia
column15: Faculty of Information Technology, Brno University of Technology
column24: Faculty of Information Technology, Brno University of Technology
column33: Faculty of Information Technology, Brno University of Technology
column42: Faculty of Information Technology, Brno University of Technology
column100: User experience/interaction design; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Collaboration architectures
column101: We are solving the problem of an on-spot dynamic sharing and collaboration between two devices. Our solution utilizes visual interaction based on an intuitive metaphor: video recording.   \  \ The large screen is mixing a marker field into the natural image contents. The marker field is then detected by the mobile device and the exact screen location is thus recognized. The article is exploring ways how to make the marker field as unobtrusive as possible, while still allowing for a reliable detection and high system responsiveness even on a low-end mobile device.  We created a prototype implementation of the whole system. The experimental results show that our solution provides reliable task migration on a video stream in interactive frame rates (30+ FPS). This substantially outperforms the existing solutions based on natural keypoints. We carried out a user study as well as empirical evaluation tests.  The results indicate that the system is perceived as intuitive, easy to learn and effective in transferring ongoing tasks between devices.

column3: Yumlog: A Social Media to Improve Eating Habits without Conscious Efforts
column9: Tatsuya Fujii, Toshiki Takeuchi, Kyohei Ogawa, Takuji Narumi, Tomohiro Tanikawa, Michitaka Hirose
column15: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, The University of Tokyo
column24: Graduate School of Interdisciplinary Information Studies, The University of Tokyo
column33: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, The University of Tokyo
column42: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, The University of Tokyo
column51: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology, The University of Tokyo
column59: Graduate School of Information Science and Technology
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Mobile and embedded devices; Medical and health support
column101: Having healthy eating habits is an important issue for modern people, but it is difficult in many cases because it requires strong will. \ In this paper, we proposed a social media system for food that enables people to come to eat healthier meals naturally and without conscious efforts. \ Users share their meals with the proposed system, Yumlog, and evaluate the meal's taste and health each other. \ Satisfaction of a user who eats the meal increases by the others' positive evaluations. \ This effect is called Expectation Assimilation in psychology. \ In addition, Yumlog changes others' taste evaluation and health one, and displays the health evaluation as a taste evalution to the user who eats the meal. \ Thus, the user comes to eat foods more that is evaluated as healthy foods, and improves the eating habits without the user's noticing it. \ We showed the potential of the proposed system by user studies.

column3: Software Ecosystem Insight:  Analysis of Software Development as Assemblage
column9: Amber McConahy, James Howison, Jim Herbsleb
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design; Collaborative software development
column101: A fundamental aspect of modern computing is that software is assembled from  components that are written and produced in heterogeneous ways, distributed online, and brought together in different pieces of software. Given the increasing importance of such software ecosystems in domains such as mobile apps, cloud computing, and scientific workflows, there is a compelling need to obtain insight into their processes and dynamics. In this paper, we focus on the scientific software ecosystem, drawing on qualitative data from interviews and workshops to describe information needs at four levels of engagement with software ecosystems: end-user software assemblers, software component producers, software distribution managers, and ecosystem policy-makers. We describe usage data that would go a long way toward fulfilling these needs, and discuss techniques for analyzing and presenting the data, showing illustrative analyses using data obtained from a high performance computing center. We argue that the assembly of artifacts produced by others with little or no direct contact into functional wholes is a key form of CSCW.

column3: House Rules: The Collaborative Nature of Policy in Domestic Networks
column9: Andy Crabtree, Tom Rodden, Peter Tolmie, Richard Mortier, Tom Lodge, Patrick Brundell, Nadia Pantidi
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Home/family/intimacy support; Other domain-specific support
column101: We draw on ethnographic studies to understand the collaborative nature of network policies or rules in domestic settings. We outline the technical nature of network policy in enterprise domains and how this contrasts with the social or collaborative nature of rules in everyday life. We then consider the deployment of network control and policy system interfaces in domestic settings, highlighting the ways in which household members collaboratively exploited these to support network governance. Our results suggest that an important feature of network policy in domestic contexts is that rules about network activity are shaped by and answerable to the moral reasoning that governs domestic life. This reframes our understanding of how rules are oriented to and used in the home and has significant implications for the design of home network policy systems.

column3: Visualizing Interdisciplinarity: Document Clustering Supporting Collaboration in the NASA Astrobiology Institute
column9: Lisa Miller, Rich Gazan, Susanne Still
column100: Machine Learning and Data Mining; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Astrobiology is a new and highly interdisciplinary field encompassing research \ from a diverse array of disciplines including astronomy, physics, biology, chemistry, and geology, presenting challenges of collaboration, coordination and integration for both scientists and funding agencies.  We report on the results of an unsupervised learning (clustering) approach, including a new feature selection method, applied to a corpus of astrobiology-related research \ articles in an attempt to discover emergent research areas, implicit interdisciplinary relationships among diverse astrobiology researchers, and the extent to which published research reflects NASA objectives. Visualizing the clustering output yields insights into actual and potential areas of interdisciplinary collaboration, and creates an artifact that both researchers and administrators can use to discover related work in unfamiliar fields, evaluate large-scale research directions, and create more productive collaborations.

column3: Representing Genocide: Collaboration and the Archiving of Human Rights Media
column9: Abigail Durrant, David Kirk, Stuart Reeves
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Legal/historical/philosophical aspects
column101: Cultural institutions, such as museums, often work with and curate politically and ethically sensitive materials. Increasingly, Internet-enabled, digital technology intersects with these curatorial practices to offer new opportunities for scholarly engagement with the sensitive materials. In this paper we report on a recent study of collaborative archiving practices at the Kigali Genocide Memorial in Rwanda. Through an analysis of our discussions with staff about their work with human rights media, we reflect upon how accounts of the Rwandan genocide are collaboratively captured and represented by this institution to support its humanitarian agenda. In turn, we derive a set of concerns for CSCW support to the archiving of sensitive materials, in particular to human rights media representation in the context of global scholarly networks.

column3: Investigating Groupware Usage Patterns across Meeting Tasks and Roles
column9: Himanshu Verma, Kshitij Sharma, Nan Li, Flaviu Roman, Jan Blom, Patrick Jermann, Pierre Dillenbourg
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Collaboration architectures; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: We present MeetHub - a collaborative environment designed to support content creation and sharing in co-located meetings. MeetHub incorporates a wall-mounted shared workspace synchronized with tablets provided to each member in the group. MeetHub allows interactions with the workspace by equipping each user with a mouse and keyboard as well as a tablet and stylus; thus enabling simultaneous and collective manipulation of shared content. We report an exploratory study to investigate the influence of various meeting tasks and individual roles on the shared knowledge. The results exhibit a significant difference in the usage of various input modes to accomplish diverse content creation activities during tasks. Also, the presence of individual roles has a significant impact on the amount of content shared by a group. Finally, the examination of artifact transitivity highlights some crucial aspects of group dynamics such as strong collaborative coupling.

column3: Sharing the Now:  Applying a Relational Lens to Mobile Facebook Use
column9: Irina Shklovski, Nis Bornoe, Louise Barkhuus, Joseph 'Jofish' Kaye
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: HCI research has explored mobile technologies to support social activity on the go to produce greater feelings of con-nectedness. Much of this has focused on different mobile devices, individual preferences and modes of use. Yet social activity and connectedness are about ongoing enactments of relationships across technologies. Here we introduce the relational approach as a way to include relationships in ad-dition to individual preferences in the design and analysis of mobile communication technologies. We discuss three strategies people use to manage tensions in their relation-ships: selection, segmentation and integration. Our data show that social technologies can destabilize social relations and cause relational tensions, forcing users to renegotiate how they enact these relationships.

column3: The Perception of Others: Inferring Reputation from Social Media in the Enterprise
column9: Michal Jacovi, Ido Guy, Shiri Kremer-Davidson, Sara Porat, Netta Aizenbud-Reshef
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social network analysis; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: The emergence of social media allows people to interact with others all over the world. During interaction, people leave many traces behind that can reveal things about themselves, or about how they perceive others: having many followers may indicate that one is an influencer; forum answers that gain high ranking, are likely to testify for expertise; people who gain high ranking in eCommerce sites are likely to be trustworthy. In this paper, we examine whether public online traces can be used for infering the reputation of a person as perceived by others in relation to trustworthiness, influence, expertise, and impact. We describe a study performed on indicators of reputation that employees leave in a rich organizational social media platform. We compare different indicators, and report the results of an extensive user study with over 500 participants who provided their perception of thousands of others through a set of hypothetical scenarios.

column3: Concurrency Control and Awareness Support for Multi-synchronous Collaborative Editing
column9: Mehdi Ahmed Nacer, Valter Balegas, Nuno Preguica, Pascal Urso
column100: Concurrency control; Collaboration architectures
column101: Collaborative editing tools have become increasingly popular \ in the last decade, with some systems being used by massive  \ numbers of users.  \ While traditionally collaborative editing systems would either  \ target synchronous or asynchronous collaboration settings, \ some recent systems support both types of collaboration, even \ supporting disconnected work. \ In this paper we analyse the limitations of existing systems  \ and propose a data management solution that overcomes such \ limitations. \ The proposed concurrency control algorithm, based on  \ conflict-free data types, builds on the ideas previously developed \ for synchronous collaboration, extending them to support asynchronous  \ collaboration. \ Our solution also includes the necessary information for providing \ comprehensive awareness information to users. \ The evaluation of our algorithm shows that comparing our solution \ with traditional solutions in collaborative editing, the conflict resolution  \ strategy proposed in this paper leads to results closer to the ones  \ expected by users. \

column3: Exploring Family-driven Socio-interactive Care for Children with Language Delay: A Smartphone-supported In-situ Intervention Approach
column9: Inseok Hwang, Chungkuk Yoo, Dongsun Yim, Youngki Lee, Chanyou Hwang, John Kim, Junehwa Song
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Mobile and embedded devices; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: Language delays are developmental problems in childhood not acquiring language as expected in one’s chronological age. Without timely intervention, language delay may act as a lifelong risk factor, e.g., learning disorder, social skill deficits, low socioeconomic status. Speech-language pathologists have highlighted that effective parent participation in everyday parent-child conversation is a key element for remediation of children’s language delays. For effective roles, however, parents need to alter one’s own lifelong-established conversation habits, which requires extensive period of conscious effort and staying alert at every moment. In this paper, we present new opportunities for mobile and social computing to reinforce everyday parent-child conversation, with therapeutic implication in children with language delay. Specifically, we propose TalkBetter, a mobile in-situ intervention service to help parents in daily parent-child conversations, by leveraging real-time meta-linguistic analysis of on-going conversation. Through extensive domain-specific field studies with speech-language pathologists and parents of children with language delays, we report multilateral motivations and implications of TalkBetter, and the system prototyping.

column3: Human Aspects on the Design and Management of Human Computation Workflows
column9: Lesandro Ponciano dos Santos, Francisco Brasileiro, Livia Sampaio, Nazareno Andrade
column100: Workflow management; Collaboration architectures; Crowdsourcing
column101: Human computation is a computing paradigm that allows human beings to execute tasks for which there is still no satisfactory solution even when today's most sophisticated algorithms and silicon-based computing infrastructures are used. Such tasks are usually structured as workflows. In this study, we analyze three dimensions of human computation workflows: quality-of-service requirements, design and management strategies, and human aspects. We review and integrate the contributions of human computation studies in these dimensions. We summarize a set of factors that influence the design and management of these workflows, and we discuss the main strategies that have been proposed to account for these factors. Finally, we put into perspective the main challenges that must be overcome.

column3: Quick and Dirty: Streamlined 3D Scanning in Archaeology
column9: Jarrod Knibbe, Kenton O'Hara, Angeliki Chrysanthi, Mark Marshall, Peter Bennett, Graeme Earl, Shahram Izadi, Mike Fraser
column51: Department of Computer Science, University of Bristol
column100: Other domain-specific support; Mobile and embedded devices; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Capturing data is a key part of archaeological practice, whether for preserving records or to aid interpretation. But the technologies used are complex and expensive, resulting in time-consuming processes associated with their use. These processes force a separation between ongoing interpretive work and capture. Through two field studies we elicit more detail as to what is important about this interpretive work and what might be gained through a closer integration of capture technology with these practices. Drawing on these insights, we go on to present a novel, portable, wireless 3D modeling system that emphasizes ‘quick and dirty’ capture.
