We discuss its design rational in relation to our field observations and evaluate this rationale further by giving the system to archaeological experts to explore in a variety of settings. While our device compromises on the resolution of traditional 3D scanners, its support of interpretation through emphasis on real-time capture, review and manipulability suggests it could be a valuable tool for the future of archaeology.

column3: Being Senior and ICT: a Study of the Adoption and Use of ICT among Seniors in China
column9: Yuling Sun, Xianghua Ding, Tun Lu, Ning Gu
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Home/family/intimacy support; Other domain-specific support
column101: Existing work on seniors and ICT often focuses on seniors as a socially isolated group with physical and cognitive decline. However, this is only part of the story of being senior, and may only represent a view from non-seniors’ perspective, not seniors’. In this paper, drawing on a qualitative study of 17 seniors and their adoption and use of ICT in China, we uncover how seniors themselves address the question of what it means to be a senior, and how their self-identities and values help or hinder their adoption and use of ICT.  This work calls for a number sensitivities when design for seniors: sensitivity to seniors’ self-identities, sensitivity to seniors’ values, and sensitivity to senior’s social ecology.

column3: VidWiki: Using Crowdsourcing to Improve the Legibility of Online Educational Videos
column9: Andrew Cross, Mydhili Bayyapunedi, Dilip Ravindran, Edward Cutrell, William Thies
column100: E-Learning and Education; Crowdsourcing
column101: Videos are becoming an increasingly popular medium for communicating information, especially for online education. Videos are time-consuming to produce and cannot be easily modified after release. As a result, errors or problems with legibility are common. While text-based information platforms like Wikipedia have benefitted enormously from crowdsourced contributions for the creation and improvement of content, the various limitations of video hinder the collaborative editing and improvement of educational videos. To address this issue, we present VidWiki, an online platform that leverages the massive numbers of online students to iteratively improve the presentation quality and content of educational videos. Through the platform, users improve the legibility of handwriting, correct errors, or translate text in videos by overlaying typeset content. We conducted a small user study in which 13 novice users annotated and revised Khan Academy videos. Our conclusion is that the quality of online educational videos could be significantly improved with only a small investment of time on the part of viewers.

column3: Population Stereotype Production and Icon Design for Technology Applications in Middle-of-the-Pyramid Communities
column9: Avijit Sengupta, Peng-Hui Wan, Ting Ting, Klarissa Chang
column100: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design
column101: This study investigates the influence of user factors and referent characteristics on representation types generated using the stereotype production method for designing icons in technology applications. Sixty-eight participants in farming communities were asked to draw images based on sixteen feature referents. Significant statistical differences were found between the types of representations generated for contextual and context-independent referents. Strong correlations were observed between years of formal education and total number of abstract representations produced for both contextual and context-independent referents. However, representation characteristics were not influenced by other user factors such as participants’ experience with mobile phone and years of farming experience. A statistically significant tendency of making concrete representations was observed for both contextual and context-independent referents. These findings provide insights on community members’ involvement in icon design and suggest a consolidated icon design methodology based on population stereotype, particularly for middle-of-the-pyramid communities in developing countries.

column3: The O2 Framework: Joint Design of the Organizational Regulatory Space
column9: João Barata, Paulo Cunha
column100: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaboration architectures; B2B / information systems
column101: We present a framework for the joint design of organizational regulatory spaces (ORS). The framework was developed through action research, integrating the components of context, people, process, information, and IT. The design of the ORS is usually performed by distinct teams, with unconnected viewpoints and tools. Similarly to information systems, there are business experts that defines the goals and rules, while IS experts focus on the support with IT. The ORS design is problematic, and is fragmented. The O2 framework provides a common level of abstraction for the design. The result is a comprehensive and layered map of the ORS. Our Framework has proved to offer an effective representation of the ORS for external auditors and business associations. Internally, we provide organizations with a new tool to design, communicate and improve the regulatory space. Our findings also strengthen the power of metaphors for design and action in CSCW.

column3: User Communities Evolution in Microblogs: A Public Awareness Barometer for Real World Events
column9: Maria Giatsoglou, Despoina Chatzakou, Athena Vakali
column100: Social network analysis; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Social media users' interactions can be captured in a time-evolving weighted network. Such interactions' frequency rates, types, and intensities vary over time and are affected by local real-world events. Community detection has been successfully applied for revealing implicit groups of well-connected entities in various real-world networks. Here, we address the problem of community detection and evolution tracking in users' interaction networks which are formed and evolve around events. We propose a generic framework suitable for: i) modeling users' interactions in social media, ii) identifying evolving communities of users as formed around events, iii) extracting quantitative and qualitative measurements from the communities' evolution timeline, and iv) leveraging the measurements to understand the events' impact. \ We focus our experimentation on the co-evolution of real-world events of different scales along with their associated communities. Two real world case studies based on Twitter user interactions demonstrate the proposed framework's contribution in understanding and capturing associations between communities and events via community features' intra-event and cross-event analysis.

column3: The Communication Patterns of Technical Leaders:  Impact on Product Development Team Performance
column9: Kate Ehrlich, Marcelo Cataldo
column100: Social network analysis; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Recent research has shown that informal communication can have significant impact on product development. However, there is scant research on the effect of technical leaders’ communication despite their importance to the team. Based on a sample of 65 software development teams from two companies we examined the association between technical leaders’ communication structure and the team’s performance. Consistent with past research, we found that a team’s productivity and quality improve when the team communication follows hierarchical and small-world patterns, respectively. However, there was additional improvement in both outcomes when technical leaders shared more information than they gathered, and when they provided more information, on average, than the rest of the team. Our analyses also revealed that technical leaders had limited involvement in the communication structure of low performing teams. In high performing teams, technical leaders exhibited levels of involvement marginally above average suggesting that even though they are important channels of information, they are not necessarily the most "central" individuals in the team's communication structure.

column3: “You can’t block people offline”: Managing risks and attaining self-disclosure goals on Facebook
column9: Jessica Vitak, Jinyoung Kim
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: The present study investigates users’ self-disclosure processes on social network sites by focusing on the perceived goals and risks to making disclosures in these spaces, as well as by identifying a set of disclosure strategies users employ to manage increasingly diverse Friend networks.  Findings from qualitative interviews with 26 American graduate students suggest users’ disclosure goals and risks generally mirror those identified in research in offline settings, although both are influenced to some degree by SNS affordances such as the persistence and visibility of content. While perceived risks may limit sharing information to some degree, users employ a variety of strategies to mitigate these risks and engage with their network. We describe four categories of strategies—which we label network regulation, targeted disclosure, self-censorship, and content regulation—and discuss the implications of these findings for research in the areas of computer-mediated communication, relationship maintenance, and design.

column3: "There are much more Unfiltered Sources" - Facebook and the Mass Media in Tunisia
column9: Marén Schorch, Esma Harbi, David Randall, Kaoru Misaki, Volker Wulf
column51: University of Siegen and Fraunhofer FIT
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design
column101: Facebook played a considerable role during the political uprisings of the ‘Arab Spring’. Together with Al-Jazeera, it was the only reliable source of information for protesters at that time. In this paper, we explore the media landscape in Tunisia two years after the uprising. To this end, we conducted a qualitative investigation (participant observation and interviewing) with young Tunisians. The paper describes how they use Facebook (FB), newspapers and TV for gaining information and for exchange. FB is their primary medium for access to political information. They prefer the variety and diversity of user-generated content, they select information by themselves, discuss among their friends inside FB and with that, co-create meaning and trust. It seems that both the traditional censorship in the national mass media and the revolutionary experience created a unique media landscape among young Tunisians. Facebook still plays a leading role in that landscape.

column3: Social Media Participation and Performance at Work: A Longitudinal Study
column9: N. Sadat Shami, Jeffrey Nichols
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: The use of social media at work is gaining traction. There is evidence to suggest that various benefits accrue from participating in social media. Yet the relationship between using social media at work and employee performance is not clear. We use an ‘affordance approach’ to explain how different forms of social media may predict performance at work. Through a longitudinal study of 80,924 employees of a large global company over the course of 2 years, we find that blog posts and community forum posts were predictors of performance, while internal and external microblogging posts were not. This study provides initial empirical evidence of the relationship between participation in different forms of social media at work and performance.

column3: Transporting Answers to the Enterprise: Signals of Expertise in Social Q&A for Business
column9: Elijah Mayfield, Shimei Pan, Jie Lu, Jennifer Lai
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: The success of internet social question-answering (Q&A) sites has led many businesses to attempt to duplicate this model internally. In such systems, demand for expertise is high, meaning that finding high-quality answers quickly is a top priority. Prior work on expertise discovery, though, has focused on high-traffic public websites like StackExchange. Here, we show that the most predictive metadata features from those public websites do not transfer well to the enterprise. In response, we explore an untapped resource for determining answer quality, based on textual signals of expertise, motivated by work in sociolinguistics. We show that these features add predictive power alone and in addition to features from prior work.

column3: Smart Face: Enhancing Creativity in Video Conference using Real-time Facial Deformation
column9: Naoto Nakazato, Shigeo Yoshida, Sho Sakurai, Takuji Narumi, Tomohiro Tanikawa, Michitaka Hirose
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design; Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing
column101: The purpose of this study is to realize a method for improving social skills by changing the facial appearance of people. In this study, we focus on how to enhance creativity during human interactions, especially in cooperative work situation, such as video conference. Based on the hypothesis that facial appearance of people can affect creativity from that “emotion can affect creativity” and “the appearance of others can affect the emotions”, we suggested a method to affect the creativity by changing the facial appearance in real-time, such as facial expression and facial resemblance. In addition, we tested the effectiveness by building a system to collaborate video conference situation using the proposed method. The user study showed that the proposed method can enhance the creativity.

column3: Web Page Centered Real-time Communication System Based on a Physical Property
column9: Yuhki Shiraishi, Yukiko Kawai, Jianwei Zhang, Toyokazu Akiyama
column23: Faculty of Computer Science and Engineering
column41: Faculty of Computer Science and Engineering
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Collaboration architectures; User experience/interaction design
column101: We have developed a novel real-time communication system that enables ALL users to share information and emotion effectively through ALL Web pages based on a physical property: \ a user can perceive other users browsing the same Web pages through avatars on the Web browser, like a face to face communication in real space. \ In the system, the displayed and communicationable users are optimized by the relationship among them based on the information searching and sharing activities. \ Furthermore, the system also enables users to search not only Web pages but appropriate users by utilizing these activities; \ we construct a new ranking model by combining the real space information (the user activities) with the Web space information (the hyperlinks). \ We also verify the effectiveness of the system by the user study experiments in the condition that we suppose the system works especially well, \ i.e., information retrieval, collaboration tasks, and sharing of feelings.

column3: Mobilizing Network Knowledge with High Throughput Metadata Visualization
column9: B Li
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Distributed/virtual teams; Other domain-specific support
column101: This paper introduces Blanda, a tool to help members of a ecological research network to better identify opportunities for future work based on their existing knowledge. Blanda helps stakeholders identify common and underdeveloped concepts within their own network by using existing stakeholder practices and network structures to aggregate and re-present information from disjoint local and meso scale databases, indexes, bibliographies and other records of research outputs. Previous machine learning approaches, concept discovery approaches, and expert systems have required the user to begin with knowledge about a substantial portion of the field, and attempt to characterize a body of literature from a single statistical perspective only. By contrast, Blanda does not require explicit knowledge about the subject matter of the research, enables each member of the network to frame the literature in their own way, and augments rather than replaces knowledge-finding work by humans. Initial use of Blanda has identified several ecological concepts as candidates for network-wide research.

column3: Collaborating Intelligence Analysts and Surface Use
column9: Judith Brown, Robert Biddle
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Tabletop and Large Wall Displays
column101: We describe a field study of a team of collaborating professional intelligence analysts engaged in a simulated activity in their workplace.  In this field study we investigated the collaborative nature of the event and their use of analog surfaces (notes, posters, post-its and so on) and displays.  Using predominantly activity theory, but also a variety of other models, we applied simple analytic techniques to analyze our notes and photos. We observed that the collaborative nature of the analysts' activity is uneven; stronger in earlier stages, and more between analysts and developers than between analysts. We identify issues in the analyst's current use of analog surfaces and identify potential areas where collaboration could be strengthened by improving collaborative practices and leveraging surface technologies.

column3: Tangible Earth: Tangible Learning Environment for Astronomy Education
column9: Hideaki Kuzuoka, Naomi Yamashita, Yasuyuki Suzuki, Hiroshi Kato, Hideyuki Suzuki, Yoshihiko Kubota
column100: E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Astronomy education is particularly difficult because it requires learners to grasp multiple perspectives of celestial motion and reach a meta-level understanding by combining these perspectives. To enhance the understanding of various astronomy education perspectives, we developed a tangible learning environment called the tangible earth system. In this paper, we report on a case study in which we used our tangible earth system as an educational tool in a collaborative learning environment. Based on Price’s assessment framework, we identified design problems that impede learners from collaboratively understanding celestial concepts. For example, the tangible interface’s physical nature often hindered learners from grasping multiple perspectives and exchanging competent interpretations, misleading them into making incorrect judgments. We propose into our learning environment the introduction of conflicting representations that might spark challenges to faulty reasoning.

column3: Capturing the Mood: Facebook and Face-to-Face  Encounters in the Workplace
column9: Gloria Mark, Mary Czerwinski, Shamsi Iqbal, Paul Johns
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Maintaining positive well-being at the workplace is a growing concern. To gain a deeper understanding of how online and offline social interactions affect people’s mood at work, we examined the influence of both Facebook and face-to-face interaction. 32 participants were observed for five days in their natural work environment. We used a mixed-methods approach: computer logging to capture online behaviors, experience sampling for mood, SenseCam photo capture for interactions, and surveys. Results showed that throughout the day, face-to-face interactions were predictive of positive affect, and Facebook use was negatively correlated with feelings of engagement and challenge. Positive mood changes at the end of the day were predicted by higher Facebook use and higher engagement, whereas negative mood changes were predicted by low engagement. We propose that saliency of events influences the assessment of mood; our results suggest that online and offline interactions offer unique salient cues in a workplace context.

column3: Insights about Perinatal and Postpartum Experiences from Shared Facebook Data
column9: Munmun De Choudhury, Scott Counts, Eric Horvitz, Aaron Hoff
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Social network analysis
column101: The birth of a child is a milestone in the life of parents. We leverage Facebook data shared by 165 new mothers as streams of evidence for characterizing their postnatal experiences. We consider multiple measures including activity, social capital, emotion, and linguistic style in participants’ Facebook data in pre- and postnatal periods. Our study includes detecting and predicting the onset of post-partum depression (PPD). The work complements recent work on detecting and predicting significant postpartum changes in behavior, language, and affect from Twitter data. In contrast to prior studies, we gain access to ground truth on postpartum experiences via self-reports and a common psychometric instrument used to evaluate PPD. We develop a series of statistical models to predict from data available before childbirth a mother’s likelihood of PPD. We corroborate our quantitative findings through interviews with a sample of the participants. We find that increased social isolation and lowered availability of social capital as manifested on Facebook, are the best predictors of PPD in mothers.

column3: Understanding Levels of Virtuality and Coping Strategies in Globally Distributed Software Development Teams
column9: Benjamin Koehne, Chen Zhao
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Computer-Mediated Communication; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Collaborative software development
column101: Distributed software development has become a common work form in industry. Global software development teams collaborate in complex socio-technical environments. Technological infrastructures help to bridge distance gaps and form the basis for distributed software development work. Individuals in distributed work contexts cope with different levels of virtuality in their daily work that affect collaboration in the team. We unpack individual coping strategies employed and developed by individuals in virtual teams. In a long-term study we observed five globally distributed software development teams in a Fortune 500 company. Our results identify coping strategies that evolve around technology appropriacy, cultural spheres, and expressions of individualism. Understanding virtuality as a multi-faceted concept allows us understand individual coping strategies and to present design considerations for collaboration technology used in global software development teams.

column3: Predicting Crowd-based Translation Quality with  Language-independent Feature Vectors
column9: Markus Krause, Michael Rohs
column100: Crowdsourcing; Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: Research over the past years has shown that machine translation results can be enhanced with the help of mono- or bilingual human contributors. Evaluating the quality of a translation remains however a challenge. This paper pro-poses a method to determine the quality of individual translations using a language independent feature vector. The paper demonstrates how different machine learning algorithms can estimate the translation quality using this vector. To illustrate the language independence we applied our method to translations with different source languages. The results show that language independent feature vectors are a feasible solution to predict the quality of a translation and should be investigated in more detail.

column3: The HTP Model: Conceptualizing Web Growth
column9: Ramine Tinati, Leslie Carr, Susan Halford, Catherine Pope
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Legal/historical/philosophical aspects
column101: In this paper we describe a theoretical model that takes into consideration the dynamic and distributed nature of the Web. We take the position that the Web is a product of a diverse collection of activities between humans and technologies, and that it is dynamic and constantly changing shape. Our conceptualization of the Web offers a way to examine and analyze the Web based on three interlinking concepts – heterogeneous networks, translation, and phases (HTP) – essential for representing the interactions, processes, and growth of Web activities. Demonstrating this, we take an emerging but influential Web activity concerned with the practices around Open Government Data, and apply HTP to explain the socio-technical processes underpinning its growth and structure. Based on the lessons learnt we argue that understanding the collection of activities that we label the Web, is essential for revealing the Web’s growth, and critically, how it may evolve in the future.

column3: Beyond the App: Understanding the Fabric of Social Interactions for Ridesharing through Mining Social Networking Sites
column9: Seyed Hadi Mirisaee, Margot Brereton, Paul Roe, Fiona Redhead
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; User experience/interaction design; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: Dynamic ridesharing or carpooling is often formulated as a matching problem of connecting people with an aligned set of transport needs within a reasonable interval of time and space. This problem formulation relegates social connections to being secondary factors. Technology assisted ridesharing applications that put the matching problem first have revealed that they suffer from being unable to address the factor of social comfort, even by adding in friending features or piggybacking on social networking sites. For most people, social context is primary when deciding to rideshare. In this research we aim to understand the fabric of social interactions through which ridesharing happens. We take an online observation approach in order to understand the fabric of social interactions for ridesharing happening in highly subscribed online groups of local residents. These understandings help researchers to identify design challenges and opportunities to support ridesharing in local communities. This paper contributes a fundamental understanding that social interactions and social comfort precede rideshare requests in local communities.

column3: Structuring Collaborative Reflection: A Balance between scripted collaboration and information spaces
column9: Michael Prilla, Thomas Herrmann
column15: Institute for Applied Work Science, Information and Technology Management, Ruhr University of Bochum
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Computer-Mediated Communication; E-Learning and Education; Workflow management
column101: In this paper, we present support for collaborative reflection as a relevant yet neglected field of CSCW. Therefore, it is unclear how the design of this support can tap on the design knowledge available from CSCW research. Based on user studies and prototype evaluations in different workplaces, we describe insights and design challenges for such support, compare them to approaches and paradigms known from CSCW and propose a solution for the design of collaborative reflection support.

column3: Crowds and Critics: How Professional and Amateur Reviews Differ on Metacritic
column9: Alexander Zook, Eric Gilbert
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Both professional and amateur reviews can substantially shape how products fare in the marketplace. Yet, we know little about how these two viewpoints compare. In this paper, we bridge this gap by contrasting professional and amateur reviews within the domain of videogames. Examining nearly 200K reviews from the popular site Metacritic, we find professionals favor phrases describing the broader market, while amateurs emphasize social aspects of playing games. Amateurs skew towards higher scores, but are the primary source of low scores; that is, they show considerably more variance. However, both groups express the same average levels of sentiment. Finally, regressing future videogame sales on reviews, we find that a combination of professional scores, volume of professional reviews, and volume of amateur reviews provides a moderately powerful predictive model for future game sales. This is the first work we know of to systematically contrast professional and amateur reviewers, addressing a question at the heart of many contemporary debates: How do crowds and domain specialists compare?

column3: The FEM wiki social computing model: collaborative input with editorial control for field epidemiologists
column9: Patty Kostkova, Vladimir Prikazsky, Arnold Bosman
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; E-Learning and Education; Collaborative software development; Medical and health support
column101: Specialized professional communities from geographically dispersed social networks need to create and share content through single social platforms, such as wikis. The Field Epidemiological Manual wiki enables online interaction for field epidemiologists around a growing training wiki resource with an active discussion forum.  To take advantage from the social computing enabling epidemiologists tp actively edit the wiki while keeping editorial control, a novel social computing model for wiki collaboration was developed – this supports dual versioning enabling maintenance of expert-reviewed pages in parallel with user-updated versions. \ Further, we developed a user-editable collaborative interface embedding semantic taxonomy in a training wiki platform and generating the semantic navigation hierarchy on the fly.  \ Launched in 2010, FEM wiki is a real world social computing wiki platform supporting field epidemiologists. The success of collaborative features was evaluated by assessing the number and type of changes made by the professional network of epidemiologists over several months.  \

column3: Intercultural Awareness: Cultural and Relational Effects on Gathering Awareness Information
column9: Nanyi Bi, Jeremy Birnholtz, Susan Fussell
column100: Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Computer-Mediated Communication; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Awareness information, information that provides awareness of others’ presence and activities in a workgroup plays a crucial role in computer-supported cooperative work. This paper presents a laboratory experiment that explores the influence of cultural background and familiarity with one’s collaborators on people’s willingness to gather awareness information about others. Our results suggest that members of cultures often considered more relationship-oriented (e.g., China) gathered awareness information less frequently than members of cultures often considered more task-oriented (e.g., the United States). We argue this is because task-oriented cultures legitimize the task-related behaviors, such as awareness information gathering, more so than relationship-oriented cultures. We also examined the effects of awareness checking behaviors on people’s perceptions of themselves and their partner and discuss their implications and directions for future research.

column3: Investigating Shared Situational Awareness at a Swedish trauma centre
column9: Alexander Yngling, Marcus Nilsson, Kristina Groth, Jens Arvei
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; User experience/interaction design
column101: A series of studies was conducted to investigate the level of shared situational awareness within 14 teams (145 participants) working on trauma exercises at a Swedish trauma centre. Data was collected through a validated questionnaire filled in by all participants, and responses have been analysed together with transcriptions of the video recordings made at each ex- ercise. We calculate Fleiss’ kappa, a measure of inter-rater reliability, for the dataset and several subgroups.

column3: Search and Tell: Topic Distributions in Queries and Tweets
column9: Tanushree Mitra, David Shamma, Eric Gilbert
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: What topics are within bounds for search, but out of bounds for Twitter, and vice versa? Where do they overlap? Using a ground-up, empirically-based approach, we compare topics across tweets and search queries. Using a random sample of tweets and queries, we perform a deep content analysis. We find substantial and significant differences on many topics. For example, we observe entertainment, food and sports topics in tweets far more often than we see them among search queries. On the other hand, people routinely query for shopping, yet rarely mention it on Twitter. There is also considerable overlap: we see references to celebrities, health & beauty, travel & recreation, education, gaming and weather as often in tweets as in searches. By identifying where topics converge and diverge, this work bridges a contextual gap between social and search, informing modern systems that combine the two, as well as computer-mediated communication theory.

column3: Swift Shared Identity, Trust, and Performance in  Partially Distributed Teams
column9: Rosalie Ocker, Katherine Hamilton, Starr Roxanne Hiltz, Mary Beth Rosson
column24: College of Information Sciences and Technology, The Pennsylvania State University
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: Information technology teams are often configured as partially distributed teams (PDTs). A PDT consists of two or more subteams that are separated geographically. Although members of a given subteam are co-located, they also collaborate with members of other subteams that are remote. Prior research indicates that both trust and shared team identity are important determinants of team performance.  However, there is little direct empirical evidence of the effect of shared identity on trust, and of trust on shared identity. Findings that do exist are not consistent with theory.  \  \ In a large-scale, longitudinal quasi-experimental field study of partially distributed global teams, we examine the causal relationship between trust and shared identity on PDT performance. A pair of mediation analyses of the data at the team level support the hypothesis that (swift) shared identity leads to trust, and that its continuing rela-tionship with team performance is fully mediated by trust. The alternate model, that trust is mediated by shared iden-tity, was not supported.  \

column3: Digital Mirrors for the Self: An Investigation of Dwelling in Urban Public Spaces
column9: Simo Hosio, richard harper, Vassilis Kostakos, Jorge Goncalves, Jukka Riekki
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Tabletop and Large Wall Displays
column101: The proliferation of computation in our everyday environment enables new types of interaction and communication. Understanding the natural dialogue between users and such technology is crucial to the success of future urban computing deployments. We investigate human dwelling in public spaces using a photography service deployed on a grid of interactive public displays in urban city settings. Through the analysis of user-generated snapshots we show that the service was quickly appropriated beyond its original purpose, resulting in use that differs substantially from those previously documented in photography literature. We reflect on the reasons why the service was appropriated in this way, discuss its role in dwelling, and finally propose the concept of digital mirrors as advancement in the evolution of photography in urban contexts. Ultimately, our findings help ground our understanding of human needs in urban spaces and thus contribute to the design of similar future deployments.

column3: Effectiveness of multicultural case method education system regarding cloud-based multilingual Web services
column9: Kenji Terui, Reiko Hishiyama
column14: School of creative Science and Emgeneering
column23: School of Creative Science and Engineering
column100: E-Learning and Education; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: Case methods have been effective for training managers and administrators mainly in international MBA programs. However, case discussions are generally conducted in a single language environment. This makes it difficult for non-native speakers to contribute to an international class environment. We propose a multilingual case method education system for global classroom, which gives international students the opportunity to share their case discussions in their native language. With our system, international students communicate in their native language through machine translation services in a cloud computing environment. To evaluate the effectiveness of our system, we conducted experiments, in which American, Korean and Japanese students participated, and analyzed the cultural similarities and differences as diversity resulting from computer-mediated case discussions. We found that it is quite possible to conduct case discussions to exchange views with this system. The system has an advantage in determining cultural diversity and encouraging a diverse global perspective.

column3: Enriching the Distressing Reality: Social Media Usage by Chinese Migrant Workers
column9: Jingjing Liu, Alexander Boden, Volker Wulf
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: Based on a field study in Guangdong Province, this paper describes the social media use of Chinese migrant workers in the manufacturing sector. It was found that social media plays a significant role in the lives of young migrant workers who have left their rural hometowns in early adulthood and struggle to survive in the urban centers. They buy expensive IT devices to gain a social reputation, as social media provides opportunities for self-expression; strengthens their self-consciousness; and to a certain extent, influences their world view. For most of the worker in our study, social media has become a very important part of leisure time and entertainment. Moreover, the life in virtual worlds provides them a psychological compensation mechanism to temporarily avoid the pressure of reality.

column3: Managing Political Differences in Social Media
column9: Catherine Grevet, Loren Terveen, Eric Gilbert
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Most people are friends with people like themselves, a concept known as homophily. Exposure to diversity, however, makes us more informed individually and as a society. In this paper, we investigate political disagreements on Facebook to explore the conditions under which diverse opinions can coexist online. Via a mixed methods approach comprising 103 survey responses and 13 interviews, we find that participants who perceive less homophily among their friends engage less on Facebook than those who perceive more. Unfortunately, weak ties are particularly brittle to political disagreements, despite being the ties most likely to offer diversity. Finally, based on our findings we suggest social media design opportunities to bridge across ideological difference: 1) slow down contentious discussions between weak ties; 2) make common ground visible while friends converse; and, 3) let friends interact with data as a strategy to support civil exchanges.

column3: Duography in The Classroom: Collaborative Creative Engagement by Two-sided Mobile Phone Photography
column9: Florian Güldenpfennig, Wolfgang Reitberger, Geraldine Fitzpatrick
column100: E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: Front and back cameras of modern mobile phones can be triggered simultaneously resulting in two opposite-facing pictures. Initial research into this new kind of two-sided photography (we call it ‘duography’) hints at a potentially huge opportunity space. However, there has been no research on this kind of photography so far regarding its potential for (collaborative) creative engagement. In this paper, we investigate this technology in the setting of an art class involving 17 adolescents (16-18 years old) working in groups, and their art teacher, over the course of 12 weeks. We analyse a resulting rich set of two-sided photos to unpack the opportunity space of this novel kind of photography for art education with technology-mediated cooperative artefacts. Thereby we illustrate how duography can mediate collaborative creative engagement during the process of art creation by fostering teamwork as well as after the creation by reflective group discussions.

column3: Increased interdependence can decrease differences: designing so human players treat their human and AI   team-mates the same
column9: Christopher Ong, Kevin McGee
column100: Entertainment/games; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Research indicates that people treat human and AI team-mates differently. Although there has been work on the use of different visual representations to change participant's behavior towards and perception of others, there has been almost no work on how to reduce the difference in how people respond to human and AI team-mates. This paper reports on a study to determine whether changes to the amount of interdependence between team-mates can moderate the difference between how people behave with human and with AI team-mates. A 2x2 (human and AI team-mate; Independent / Interdependent condition) between-subjects experiment was conducted with 60 participants playing a real-time cooperative computer game. The main results are that when team-mates are perceived to have an interdependent relationship, people respond more similarly to human and computer team-mates in terms of behavior towards them and the amount of attention paid. The results suggest that designing to increase player structural interdependence can decrease the difference in how human players treat their human and AI team-mates.

column3: Integrating On-demand Fact-checking with Public Dialogue
column9: Travis Kriplean, Caitlin Bonnar, Alan Borning, Bo Kinney
column15: Computer Science & Engineering, University of Washington
column33: Computer Science & Engineering, University of Washington
column100: Crowdsourcing; Other domain-specific support
column101: Public dialogue plays a key role in democratic society.  Such dialogue often contains factual claims, but participants and readers are left wondering what to believe, particularly when contributions to such dialogue come from a broad spectrum of the public.  We explore the design space for introducing authoritative information into public dialogue, with the goal of supporting constructive rather than confrontational discourse. We also present a specific design and realization of an archetypal socio-technical system of this kind, namely an on-demand fact-checking service integrated into a crowdsourced voters guide powered by deliberating citizens. The fact-checking service was co-designed with and staffed by professional librarians.  Our evaluation examines the service from the perspectives of both users and librarians.

column3: Effect of closeness on picture sharing preference
column9: Auk Kim, Gahgene Gweon
column100: Privacy/access control/trust
column101: Photo sharing activities on social networking sites concern not just the person sharing the information (1st-party) and the person receiving the information (2nd-party), but also the 3rd-party who is in the picture. In our paper, we study the context in which a 3rd-party would be comfortable in allowing his friend (1st-party) to share their photo with a friend of a friend (2nd-party). Our results show that when a closeness between a person and another (2nd-party) is higher, the comfort level of the person for his friend (1st-party) sharing a picture with the 2nd-party is higher, F(5,140)=36.463, p<.001. In addition, when a closeness between a user and his friend (1st-party) is higher, that user’s comfort level on picture sharing for 1st-party with 2nd-party is higher as well, F(4,112)=25.99, p < .001. We also present a model for predicting a user’s comfort level for picture sharing in the results section.

column3: Coordinating Donors on Crowdfunding Websites
column9: Rick Wash, Jacob Solomon
column100: Crowdsourcing; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Crowdfunding websites like Kickstarter, Spot.Us and Donor's Choose seek to fund multiple projects simultaneously by soliciting donations from a large number of donors. These websites also seek to coordinate donations so that each project receives enough money to actually succeed. Each crowdfunding project sets a goal for donations required and a deadline in which to receive them. Crowdfunding site designers must decide what to do with donations to projects that don't reach their goal by the deadline. Some crowdfunding sites use an all-or-nothing return rule in which donations are returned to donors if a project doesn't met its goal. Other sites use a direct donation structure where all donations are kept by the project even if the total is insufficient.  Using a lab experiment that simulates a crowdfunding website, we find that the return rule mechanism leads to a marginal improvement in productivity, but a considerable loss in efficiency. The direct donation model, though, encourages donors to coordinate.

column3: The effects of social cues on privacy behavior: how political worldview makes a difference
column9: Oded Nov, Ofer Arazy
column15: Polytechnic Institute of New York University
column24: Alberta School of Business, University of Alberta
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: We explore the differential effects of privacy-related social cues on users’ decision to disclose personal information online. Specifically, we explore whether signals about the disclosure behavior of others – perceived social disclosure – lead to different privacy choices by users holding opposing political views. Using a simulated online recommender system, we find a positive and diminishing marginal effect of perceived social disclosure on users’ likelihood to disclose personal information. Furthermore, we find that while increased perceived social disclosure has an insignificant effect on the privacy choices of liberals, it has a substantial positive effect on conservatives, raising their likelihood of agreeing to disclose personal information the more they perceive others to do the same.

column3: What’s the Problem? Using Q&A to Elicit Employee Feedback
column9: Jennifer Thom, David Millen, Steven Ross, Dan Gruen
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Gathering employee feedback is an important process in an organization, particularly for idea generation and solution gathering. Participation in online systems that elicit employee feedback can provide reputational benefit for members of an enterprise. As a result, understanding the factors that influence high-rated employee feedback can help employees make more effective suggestions to derive greater reputational benefit from participation. In this paper, we describe a model predicting successful contributions based on activity from a Q&A system specifically designed for eliciting employee feedback and supporting crowdsourced ratings of responses. We then suggest organizational and design implications for systems that elicit employee feedback.

column3: Exploring the Benefits of Portability in a Collaborative Multi-Display Environment
column9: Barrett Ens, Christian Rendl, Florian Perteneder, Pourang Irani, Michael Haller
column24: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
column33: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
column51: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
column100: Collaboration architectures; Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Mobile and embedded devices; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Multi-display environments provide many benefits for group work by connecting displays of various size to form a unified workspace. Personal computers provide users with individual workspace but often confine them to tables or desks. Recent advances, however, have allowed system designers to introduce lightweight technologies such as tablets and even paper to these collaborative environments. We designed a controlled user study to help us better understand the benefits of portable devices in such environments. Our comparative study examines group collaboration in a creative design task under different settings. We look at system configurations using paper, tablets and laptop computers along with a large interactive whiteboard. We observe that access to portable devices benefits group coupling and sharing of content. Our analysis also brings other useful new insights and confirms some results from previous studies in a new environment. We conclude with a set of recommendations that will be useful for designers of future multi-display systems.

column3: A Method for Automatically Detecting Cheating in Competitive mHealth Exergames
column9: Mark Campbell, Tamara Peyton, Erika Poole
column100: Entertainment/games
column101: Mobile games for fitness are an increasing sector in the health research community. Using ‘exergames’ on smartphones, researchers are able to gather data on research subjects’ daily activity levels and activity types and use the data to model new health interventions. However, users frequently game the system, by cheating on their activities in a variety of ways. We identify three such techniques and we review the work done to date around exergame cheat detection. We then outline the use of gait authentication, identification and activity recognition and use of these techniques in a pilot study. Using the results of our pilot study we assert that the techniques we outline for cheating can be thwarted, and the integrity of the research maintained. We argue that building these algorithms into new exergaming data gathering methods will produce more accurate user identification and authentication, resulting in more reliable user activity data for health researchers.

column3: Everyday Dwelling with WhatsApp
column9: Kenton O'Hara, Michael Massimi, richard harper, Simon Rubens, Jessica Morris
column23: Microsoft Research Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: This reports a qualitative study of the use of an instant messaging smartphone application, WhatsApp. It will explain how WhatsApp is used alongside many other messaging media, including Skype and social networking applications like Facebook. This use manifests distinctions in the character of sociability, it will be argued. Those engaged through WhatsApp are physically and socially close, and their pattern of connection phatic. The connections made between users take the form of ‘dwelling’ in Ingold’s sense. The relationship between these and findings of prior studies of IM and SMS are explored as are comparison with other communications such Facebook or via Skype. It will be suggested the forms of sociability here are more formal, though with an equal concern for the display of faithfulness. Implications for the importance of place and diverse forms of social connection in a ‘post social network’ world are discussed.

column3: The Motivations and Experiences of the Mobile Workforce
column9: Rannie Teodoro, Pinar Ozturk, Mor Naaman, Winter Mason
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Crowdsourcing
column101: “Mobile workforce” applications match physical world tasks and willing workers. These systems help conserve resources, streamline courses of action, and increase market efficiency for micro- and mid-level tasks, from verifying the existence of a pothole to walking a neighbor’s dog. This study reports on the motivations and experiences of individuals who regularly complete physical world tasks posted in mobile workforce marketplaces. Data collection included semi-structured interviews with mobile workforce members (workers) of two different services. The analysis revealed the main drivers for participating in a mobile workforce, including desires for monetary compensation and control over schedules and task selection. We also reveal main reasons for task selection, which involve situational factors, convenient physical locations, and task requester profile information. Finally, we discuss the key characteristics of the most worthwhile tasks and offer implications for novel crowdsourcing systems for physical world tasks.

column3: Visualizing Activity Traces to Support Collaborative Literature Searching
column9: kumaripaba Athukorala, Tuukka Ruotsalo, Chao An, Jaakko Peltonen, Aki Reijonen, Giulio Jacucci
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Social Computing and Social Navigation; User experience/interaction design; Other domain-specific support
column101: We investigate how the visualization of activity traces supports collaborative information-seeking. We designed a prototype system that visualizes traces of three types of activities (queries typed, articles bookmarked, and interested keywords) on top of a recently introduced information retrieval system. We conducted a qualitative study with six groups of masters’ students who conducted a collaborative scientific essay writing task for six weeks. We found that the visualization of traces of issued queries and bookmarked articles help the users to better monitor the progress of the collaborators, increase collaboration, and reassure their findings. Traces of interested keywords support sub-topic identification. Furthermore, activity traces of collaborators help the users to learn about the system features. We also found that some users are more concerned about privacy and do not like sharing all of their activities. The findings and the novel collaborative system provide valuable insights and tools into future research on collaborative information-seeking.

column3: Adult Child's Information Fosters Communication by Parent
column9: Nana Hamaguchi, Daisuke Asai, Masahiro Watanabe
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: Parents have difficulty in communicating with their adult children living apart. Much research has focused on this problem and solutions have been proposed that provide parents' information to the children despite the parents' desire to understand their children. \  \ To foster communication by the parent, our proposal takes the unique approach of providing the children's information to the parent. As an initial experiment, we conduct a 15 day field study with three households to identify what information triggers a positive change in the parent's communication behavior and attitude. The results show that the proposal raises the frequency of parent's e-mails and expressions of companionship. A qualitative analysis finds two effects on the parent's mind; the personal information motivates the mother to understand daughter, and daughter's commitment alleviates the mother's fear of one-way communication. \  \ We also discuss the design implications raised by our findings with the goal of improving communication between adult children and their parents.

column3: Is Anybody Out There?: OSS Contributors’ Assessment of Success on GitHub
column9: Nora McDonald, Sean Goggins
column100: Collaborative software development; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: A number of studies have looked at “success” in Open Source Software (OSS) but not at how contributors to those projects measure success. GitHub is a new and uniquely distributed source code management system (DSCM) with features that make participating easier. And while there has been significant migration to GitHub since its introduction, the role played by GitHub in how the success of a project is measured is not well-understood. Survey research was conducted with contributors to five popular projects on GitHub to understand how OSS project members on GitHub measure success. We find that project process measures are considerably more salient than project outcome measures in judging the success of an OSS project. In particular, contributors care most about bugs getting fixed and community feedback as well as receptivity to their contributions and perceived activity/interaction (which they assess based on features of the GitHub platform itself). By contrast, project outcome measures (e.g., the number of downloads) are largely not considered relevant metrics of success.

column3: Staccato Social Support in Mobile Health Applications
column9: Phil Adams, Eric Baumer, Geri Gay
column100: Medical and health support; Social Computing and Social Navigation; User experience/interaction design
column101: Social support plays an important role in health systems. While significant work has explored the role of social support in CMC environments, less attention has been devoted to role of social support in mobile health systems. This paper describes socially supportive messages in VERA, a mobile application for sharing health decisions and behaviors. The short and bursty social interactions in mobile applications afford a particular style of social support, for which we offer the label staccato social support. In comparison to previous work, results indicate that staccato social support is characterized by a greater prevalence of esteem support, which builds respect and confidence; we further note the presence of following up, a positive behavior that contributes to supportive interactions not previously reported in mediated support work. These findings both suggest design recommendations to developers of (mobile) social support systems, and contribute to understanding the role of technologically mediated social support for health.

column3: Agree to Disagree: Election Coverage and Sentiment in the Political Blogosphere
column9: Justin Chung, Jennifer Jones, Gloria Mark, Yiran Wang, Dakuo Wang
column100: Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: Using LDA topic modeling and sentiment analysis, we analyze text from liberal and conservative political blogs in the period bracketing the 2012 US Presidential Election. Rather than reflecting (or at least being mediated by) public opinion polls, the sentiment of political bloggers corresponds with the ever-changing ebb and flow of the electoral horserace. We also find that post polarity is a lagging indicator for electoral polls.

column3: Information Overload or Peer Pressure?:  Using Gamification to Reveal Social and Cognitive Effects in Brainstorming and Convergence
column9: Ali Moradian, Maaz Nasir, Kelly Lyons, Susan Sim, Rock Leung
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Entertainment/games; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Computer-based systems have been designed with a variety of techniques that facilitate group ideation processes and enable companies to harness knowledge within their organizations.  We designed a system to support creative idea processes through brainstorming followed by a convergence activity and extended our system to include game elements. We compared groups using the baseline and extended systems in order to investigate phenomena such as social pressure, input blocking, and cognitive stimulation.  Groups in both conditions were equally satisfied with the process and the system. Groups using the system with game elements produced more ideas than groups using the baseline system and there is an indication that they produced higher-quality ideas. Social comparison appears to dominate input blocking in brainstorming and social comparison may influence the amount of discussion in a convergence task. In this paper, we elaborate on these findings and suggest several areas for future investigation.

column3: So Many Bad Guys, So Little Time: Exploring Crowdsourcing Frameworks for Combating Toxic Players in Online Games
column9: Haewoon Kwak, Seungyeop Han
column100: Entertainment/games; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Exploring negative behavior, called toxic behavior, in online game is one of the key research directions because it is directly connected with gaming experience and user satisfaction. In this work we collect and investigate both over 10 million toxic reports on 1.46 million toxic players and corresponding 1.46 million crowdsourced decisions made in the League of Legends Tribunal.  We crawl data from the three different regions, where are North America, Western Europe, and Korea, for taking cultural differences into account. \ Through the quantitative approach to this huge-scale behavioral traces, we characterize toxic behavior by studying who reports toxic behavior, the subjective perception of toxic playing, the relationship between toxic playing and teamwork, the correlation between endogenous factors and toxic playing, and discriminative linguistic behavior of toxic players.  We then investigate the crowdsourced decisions on toxic reports. We also discover cultural differences in the tendency reporting toxic players and the proportion of being excused in the Tribunal.

column3: Influencing the success of social energy applications: The importance of community connectedness and understanding household dynamics
column9: Tawanna Dillahunt, Jennifer Mankoff
column100: Other domain-specific support; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: An increasing number of researchers are using social techniques such as neighborhood comparison, competition and social engagement, to encourage energy conservation, yet it is unclear when the use of such techniques is successful. We find that researchers have not thoroughly investigated when social engagement techniques can positively affect energy conservation and explore this question in a 4-10 month field deployment of a social-energy monitoring application across 15 households, in two distinct locations. Our results suggest that factors such as opportunities for community interactions and social network structure, which affect social interactions, may be influential in promoting energy efficiency behaviors in social-energy applications. We contribute results that help to explain the types of households and communities in which these techniques may be effective, and explore cases where these techniques failed to engage certain households.

column3: "Real, but Glossy" – Technology and the Practical Pursuit of Magic in Modern Weddings
column9: Michael Massimi, Richard Harper, Abigail Sellen
column100: Home/family/intimacy support
column101: Planning a wedding is arguably one of the most complicated tasks people ever undertake. Despite the commonplace use of technologies in “wedding work,” little research has looked at this from an HCI perspective. Based on an interview study, we illustrate how technology is used to deliver the sought-after fantasy and a practical, yet entertaining, affair. We identify four main ways that technology helps people do this: (a) by allowing much of the practical planning work to become “invisible;” (b) by easing navigation through the delicate rules of family configurations made manifest in the guest list; (c) by helping create a spectacle-like event that adroitly balances excess and realism; and (d) by documenting the wedding in ways that allows re-experiencing the magic after the event. The paper concludes by discussing the implications of this pursuit on social graphs, place, and photography, contributing to the literature on technology and major life events.

column3: Developing a Rural Real-Time Travel Information System: understanding passenger experience during travel-based disruptions
column9: Konstantinos Papangelis, Alan Chamberlain, Nagendra Velaga, Sripada Somayajulu, David Corsar, John Nelson, Mark Beecroft
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design
column101: Individuals living in rural areas are provided with little to no information regarding public transport disruptions. This can result in high levels of travel uncertainty with significant potential impacts upon one’s life. Based on the outcome of 69 interviews and nine focus groups in rural areas in the UK, we explore the passengers’ experience, their behavioural responses, coping strategies and the passengers’ recovery phase. The analysis indicates that a wide range of behavioural responses is evident, extending beyond the choice of route, mode of transport. We identify the two most prevalent ways for mitigating the impacts of disruption; time buffering and the use of kinship networks. Based on this and additional co-design sessions, we design and develop a prototype passenger information system to support the passenger during travel-based disruption. These findings provide a step towards understanding the interplay between technology, passenger experience, disruption, travel, and the interaction of individuals with the transport system in rural areas.

column3: Just because I don’t call, doesn’t mean I don’t care: assessing call logs as a predictor of closeness
column9: Jason Wiese, Jun-Ki Min, Jason Hong, John Zimmerman
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Computer-Mediated Communication; Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: Today’s computer systems lack social sophistication. Many reduce relationships to simply being a friend or not a friend, limiting the set of actions and benefits those systems might provide. We want to address this situation by developing systems that can learn social aspects of relationships including group affiliations, social roles, and closeness. In this study we examine how well communication logs can characterize closeness. Using data from 40 participants, we produced a model that classified closeness into three tiers (low, medium, and high) with 75% accuracy. In an error analysis, we observed that frequent communication and long voice calls are good predictors of being close. However, a lack of communication does not always indicate a lack of closeness. These findings contribute an initial understanding of the capabilities and limitations of using phone logs to capture closeness.

column3: Who you gonna call? Challenges and opportunities for leveraging mobile phone contact list data
column9: Jason Wiese, Jason Hong, John Zimmerman
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: Despite how common contact lists are on mobile phones, little work has been done to understand how people actually use their mobile phone contact lists. This work captures the breadth of anomalies that we observed in the contact lists of 54 participants. Many of these observations are centered on surprising ways that participants name their contacts, for example adding social definitions, including references to companies / services / places, or having the name of a task completed using their phone. These representations make things complex for researchers seeking to use contact lists, but also signify possible opportunities to make inferences about the user, their contact, or the relationship between them. Finally, we offer grounded insights for opportunities to improve and rethink the contact list.

column3: Deep Twitter diving: Exploring Knowledge Communities within Microblogs
column9: Parantapa Bhattacharya, Saptarshi Ghosh, Juhi Kulshrestha, Mainack Mondal, Muhammad Bilal Zafar, Niloy Ganguly, Krishna Gummadi
column33: Max Planck Institute of Software Systems
column42: Max Planck Institute of Software Systems
column51: Max Planck Institute of Software Systems
column69: Max Planck Institute of Software Systems
column100: Social network analysis; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: What is Twitter? Who says What to Whom on Twitter? -- Early studies that investigated these seminal questions suggest that Twitter is by and large a real-time social media platform, where a relatively small number of celebrities, bloggers, and media sources post messages that are consumed by large number of their followers. In this paper, we revisit these questions and argue that the current narrative ignores a long-tail of rich and diverse set of  \ knowledge communities that co-exist in the Twitter network. Twitter knowledge communities span a wide variety of topics ranging from environment and theology to astrophysics and karate. We first propose a methodology for inferring topic-specific knowledge communities within the Twitter network, and then present a detailed characterization of the following and tweeting behaviors of users \ within individual knowledge communities.  We show that our findings have important implications for researchers designing user and content recommendation services on Twitter.

column3: Empirical Investigations on Computer Supported Online Collaborative Learning and Social Practices
column9: Remus Dobrican, Sandro Reis, Denis Zampunieris
column14: Computer Science and Communication Research Unit
column23: Computer Science and Communication Research Unit
column32: Computer Science and Communication Research Unit
column100: E-Learning and Education; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Current Learning Management Systems (LMS) play a very important role in how many people learn nowadays. These systems are used by an increasing number of colleges and universities across the world for online study programs and for distance learning. We consider that current LMS are rather rigid and do not give the end-user the flexibility to explore other opportunities like creating or joining social groups. We have extended the functionalities of Moodle™, with the help of proactive computing, by automatically and dynamically creating communities of practice (CoP) and by developing new graphical elements at the level of the user interface. We conducted experiments from the beginning of the summer semester on our university with more than 1000 users involved. We observed how communities were created, how they evolved over time and what role did they play in facilitating the learning process. Our findings suggest that involving the students in on-line social activity increases their level of participation on Moodle™ while stimulating the entire learning process.

column3: Investigating the Effect of Social Media on Trust Building in Customer-Supplier Relationships
column9: Fabio Calefato, Filippo Lanubile, Nicole Novielli
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: Trust is a concept that has been widely studied in e-commerce since it represents a key issue in building successful customer-supplier relationships. In this sense, social software represents a powerful channel for establishing a direct communication with customers. As a consequence, companies are now investing in social media for building their social digital brand and strengthening relationships with their customers. \  \ In this paper we investigate the role of social media in the process of trust building, with particular attention to the case of small companies. Our findings show that social media contribute to build affective trust more than traditional websites, by fostering the affective commitment of customers.

column3: Teammate Inaccuracy Blindness: When Information Sharing Tools Hinder Collaborative Analysis
column9: Ruogu Kang, Aimee Kane, Sara Kiesler
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Distributed/virtual teams; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Asynchronous collaborative analysis is important in many fields, but information sharing can be a bottleneck. Tools for annotating, organizing, and summarizing information can help, but their value depends on the quality of the shared information. To document this issue, two experiments examined participants’ performance on a complex detective task when they asynchronously received information from teammates. Experiment 1 showed that tools for annotating, organizing, and summarizing a teammate’s information were associated with better performance only when the teammate’s information was of high quality. Tools were associated with poor performance when the teammate’s information was low quality. In Experiment 2, we manipulated information quality. Low quality information conveyed in a report tool misled analysts. A report of high quality from another teammate mitigated this negative effect. The findings point to a phenomenon of teammate inaccuracy blindness. We outline strategies drawn from various literatures for helping collaborators avoid or lessen this effect.

column3: Conflict Management in Collaborative Systems: A Systematic Literature Review
column9: Lira Brasileiro, Tedesco Azevedo
column15: IFPB - Instituto Federal de Educação, Ciência e Tecnologia da Paraíba
column100: Collaboration architectures; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Collaborative software development
column101: This article presents a systematic literature review of conflict management in collaborative systems. This work presents the steps of planning, execution and publication of the results of the systematic review, discussing the main problems tackled in the research over the past decade, as well as pinpointing open avenues of research in the area.

column3: A Dashboard for the Facilitators in an Innovation Platform
column9: Marcos Baez, Gregorio Convertino
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Distributed/virtual teams; Crowdsourcing
column101: We present a design model, algorithms, and a platform for collaborative innovation in which we leverage and extend the functionalities of current Idea Management Systems (IMS), after surveying them. Through the IMS, users in business organizations or local communities can generate, share, judge, refine, and select innovative ideas as part of a grassroots process. In this paper, we survey common functionalities of state-of-the-art IMS, point to shortcomings of these systems such as the lack of adequate support for facilitators and the lack of adequate feedback for regular users about the decision process, and to address these we present the architecture and the design of a platform that includes a dashboard for facilitators as a key differentiator. To the users, the pro- posed platform is also more transparent than conventional IMS. It provides an insight into the idea selection model, thus creating an additional incentive for users to contribute.

column3: Using Annotations in Cross-Cultural Online Group Chats
column9: Na Li, Mary Beth Rosson
column100: Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Computer-Mediated Communication; User experience/interaction design
column101: Cross-cultural communication and collaboration has become increasingly prevalent in organizations and educational systems. In a previous study [1], we found that an imbalance in English proficiency created problems for cross-cultural online chats. When people conversed at different levels of proficiency, turn taking was severely disrupted, causing confusion and loss of discussion points. In this paper, we investigate an enhancement to group chat that we term ‘Instant Annotation’ (IA). We contrasted the use of an IA-enhanced chat tool to a standard chat tool for cross-cultural groups doing a brainstorming and decision task. Results showed that group satisfaction and perceived control of the conversation were enhanced for the participants who used IA. We also found that non-native speakers who used the enhanced tool had the highest agreement with their groups’ final decisions.

column3: Pull Requests & Participation on GitHub
column9: Nora McDonald, Sean Goggins
column100: Collaborative software development; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: We find that GitHub lowers the barrier for participation and collaboration on Open Source Software (OSS) projects primarily by making it possible for users to easily fork code and submit revisions that can be discussed and merged all in the same place. To date, there are no investigations of the code sharing and other virtual organization practices in GitHub projects. In this paper we explicate how GitHub enables new forms of sociotechnical, virtual organization for software engineering work focusing, in particular, on pull requests, a way that code from one developer is contributed back to a GitHub repository publically. Through a mixed methods study of pull request behaviors on GitHub projects we discover practices not reported elsewhere in research on OSS. We find that routine and distributed participation and contribution from new participants and other new practices lead to “democratic” leadership on the projects we examine.

column3: De-Virtualizing Social Events: Understanding the Gap between Online and Offline Participation for Event Calls
column9: Ai-Ju Huang, Hao-Chuan Wang, Chien Wen Yuan
column14: Institute of Information systems and Applications
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: One increasing use of computer-based communication medium is to convene people for initiating or sustaining social events. Although using computer-mediated communication and social network sites like Facebook to promote events is becoming popular, one observation is that online participation of an event does not always translate to offline attendance. In this paper, we report an interview study that looks at how people handle online event invitations, and what affect their online and offline participation. Results show that people’s event participation is shaped by the social perceptions of event nature (e.g., public or private), relationship to others (e.g., strength of connection to other invitees), and the medium used to communicate event information (e.g., targeted invitation via email or spam communication via Facebook event page). By exploring how people come to decide to participate online or offline, the result illuminates the sophisticated nature of the mechanisms that affect participation and provides design implications that can be used to bridge virtual and real attendance.

column3: Collaborative multi-scale selection approach for polygonal modelling
column9: Adrien Girard, Yacine Bellik, Malika Auvray, Mehdi Ammi
