column100: User experience/interaction design; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies
column101: Mutual awareness between users working in collaborative virtual environments is an important factor for efficient collaboration. \ Several studies have reported that haptic feedback improves performance in collaborative tasks. \ However, few researches have tried to evaluate the influence of haptic feedback on mutual awareness, and to link the corresponding measures with the performance and efficiency factors. \ This article presents a haptic collaborative method of interaction dedicated to the dynamic adjustment of selection area.  \ The aim of this method of interaction is to improve the collaborative working efficiency by improving the mutual awareness between the partners. \ To evaluate this method of interaction, we propose an experimental procedure inspired by the field of aviation to measure the effect of the on the awareness.  \ The experimental evaluation compares the proposed collaborative method of selection with a standard approach for selection used in software of polygonal modelling.

column3: Conceptualizing a Target-Oriented Design Model for Incentive Systems in Online Production Communitie
column9: Pujan Ziaie
column14: Information Systems, Department of Computer Science
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Computer-Mediated Communication; Collaboration architectures
column101: Online production communities aim to realize the collective intelligence and leverage the potential creativity, manpower, and knowledge of volunteer users to generate high quality and public content. Designing and implementing apt incentives to sustain participation is still deemed a challenging task for community designers due to the dynamic nature of online communities. In this paper, we review and synthesize the existing body of research pertaining to user participation and incentive systems, and draw from various theories to conceptualize a generalized and target-oriented design model. The result is a design cycle for developing and adopting incentive systems. This novel model addresses user behavior, implicit motivational factors and interdependencies between various incentives with a focus on user desires and motivations. The theorized model can also prove useful to community designers as a knowledge framework and guideline to select and prioritize the best possible incentives in concert with dynamic and multilevel implicit and explicit factors.

column3: Measuring Intention Preservation in  Collaborative Editing
column9: Mehdi Ahmed Nacer, Pascal Urso, François Charoy
column100: Concurrency control; User experience/interaction design
column101: As any system, collaborative editing systems have to ensure user satisfaction on several criteria. Preserving the user intention during the collaboration is considered as the most important criteria and the most difficult to respect. It is even more difficult when concurrent modifications affect the same part of a document. If the result does not satisfy the user, he will have to produce more effort to obtain the intended result. Many algorithms were proposed to control the concurrency of operations but never establish to what degree they preserve intention on real collaboration. \ This paper proposes for the first time, a methodology to measure the effort required to use the result of a given concurrency control algorithm. We employ a large number of open-source development histories to automatically computes this metric and thus to evaluate user intention preservation degree. These histories contains both the concurrent modifications and their merge result as approved by the users. We use our metric to compare and analyze existing collaborative editing algorithms.

column3: Interaction Experience Evaluation based on Mental Effort Measurement with Photoplethysmogram
column9: Yongqiang Lyu, Xin Tong, Xiaomin Luo, Chun Yu, Tianshu Yang, Yu Chen, Yuanchun Shi
column100: User experience/interaction design; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: User experience (UX) is often regarded as the most important criteria for evaluating interaction designs, products and applications. However, the traditional UX measurement models, most of which are emotional models, are often not good at quantitative evaluation. It makes the evaluation results of interactive designs vulnerable to subjective variations. This study proposes a novel photoplethysmogram-based evaluation method for interactive tasks, which measures the invested mental effort through assessing the stress-induced vascular response index (sVRI). The sVRI actually reflects the physiological reaction on the peripheral vasoconstriction to the mental investment while the user is carrying out an interactive task. Experiments on the standard task difficulties and the distinguished interactions for inputting texts show the usability of the sVRI based model for evaluating the UX in a dedicated physiological dimension different from traditional emotional models.

column3: Leveraging the Contributory Potential of User Feedback
column9: Mikhil Masli, Loren Terveen
column100: User experience/interaction design; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Crowdsourcing
column101: Under-contribution is an important problem in online social production communities: important tasks remain undone, and a small minority of participants are active contributors. Indeed, the number of information consumers is often an order of magnitude larger than the number of active contributors. Therefore, converting consumers to contributors is a promising approach to addressing under-contribution. We explored this approach in the context of a geographic wiki and route-planning system for bicyclists. We analyzed several forms of route feedback that users willingly offered, showing that this feedback was rich in useful information. We also demonstrated a technique to extract certain types of this information, which can be used directly to improve the system's route finding capabilities. We believe that our results are applicable to a broad class of online social production systems.

column3: Nothing Succeeds Like Success: Disentangling the Web of Drivers of Success in Online Peer Production Communities
column9: Claudia Müller-Birn, Marcelo Cataldo
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Collaborative software development
column101: Peer production is emerging as a very successful, and even trendsetting, alternative approach to producing digital products. In our article, we examine how participation patterns and socio-technical factors drive the evolution of peer production communities and their success. We utilize a unique data set that comprises over ten years activity of the GNOME community. Our longitudinal analyses reveal that the number of new developers and their permanence in the project are key drivers of success. However, the number of new contributors to mailing lists or project members that performed a dual role (developers and mailing list participants) is detrimental to project success. Our results also show that projects that develop more modular systems and where developers are able to identify and manage their task dependencies are significantly more likely to succeed. Our results shed light on how different patterns of involvement in a peer production community impact success. Moreover, they show the significant and complementary role of participation patterns, coordination patterns and technical design choices.

column3: Shifts in Valence: Online Public Response to Mass Shootings
column9: Emma Spiro, Christopher DuBois, Carter Butts
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Social network analysis
column101: A better understanding of social and behavioral responses to extreme events could inform policy, guide intervention programs, and lessen negative effects on the impacted community. In this research we consider the public response to three mass shootings in the United States. We collect topic-related discussion from Twitter prior to and following each event. Content is scored for affect, enabling us to explore the emotional response of the posting population over time. Results indicate a consistent pattern of increased negative valence followed by a slow return to baseline affect during the immediate post-event period. Deviations are significantly different from baseline affective scores for the examined topics.

column3: On-Body Interfaces: Implications of Location and Touch
column9: Chris Harrison, Haakon Faste
column100: Mobile and embedded devices
column101: Very recently, there has been a perfect storm of technical advances that has culminated in the emergence of a new interaction modality: on-body interfaces. Such systems enable the wearer to use their skin as an input and output platform with interactive graphics. Projects such as Skinput sought to answer the initial and fundamental question: whether or not on-body interfaces were technologically possible. Although considerable technical work remains, we believe it is important to begin shifting the question away from how and what, and towards where and ultimately why. These are the class of questions that inform the design of next generation systems. To better understand and explore this expansive space, we employed a mixed-methods research process involving more than two thousand individuals. This started with high-resolution, but low-detail crowd sourced data. We then combined this with rich, expert interviews, exploring aspects ranging from aesthetics to kinesthetics. The results of this complimentary, structured exploration, point the way towards more comfortable, efficacious, and enjoyable on-body user experiences.

column3: Digitizing People into Numbers: The Role of Data Alignment in Infrastructuring a ‘Unique Identity’ in India
column9: Aditya Johri, Janaki Srinivasan
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Other domain-specific support
column101: We present findings from a qualitative field study of a national e-infrastructuring project currently underway in India. We study how this large and complex infrastructure involved in issuing unique biometric-based identification numbers to the 1.2 billion residents of India was aligned across various stakeholders engaged in the project. We find that the focus on ‘data’ kept the entire infrastructure together and working. However, this narrow focus also made the design team view the people applying for IDs as numbers whose management could be standardized. In reality, the infrastructure encountered people with differing experiences and expectations of state-issued IDs, expectations that had to be managed by agents on the ground. With our focus on the nation state as a site for studying e-infrastructure, we extend the domains in which CSCW research takes place and contribute to the theory of infrastructuring in a context where state-citizen relations are at stake.

column3: Topic Modelling of Blogs to Understanding Quality Concepts Online
column9: Alastair Gill, Francisco Iacobelli, Tobias Blanke
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: Blogs are readily available \ sources of data \ and have been used to understanding sentiment or opinion.  \ However, when \ analysing complex concepts, such as ``quality'', where the meaning is \ often collaboratively constructed and contextual,  it may be necessary to \ resort to  \ human coding. \ In this paper we present a methodology to  \ understand complex concepts, and that captures aspects of the \ contextual---and collaboratively constructed---meaning \ with \ considerably less effort. By using unsupervised topic models along with a small corpus of human labeled data we explore  the different uses of the concept `quality' in a large number of blogs. \ Our methodology is validated against previous research, which agrees that in blogs  \ quality is conceptualised in both  \ an absolute sense (as `excellence') and also in a product-based sense (`value') \ as well as less intuitive uses of the concept.   \ It also allows us to better understand how  \ notions of quality vary by contexts and \ communities.  \

column3: Creepy but Inevitable? Social Networking Approaches Maturity
column9: Hui Zhang, Munmun De Choudhury, Jonathan Grudin
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: The fifth year of a cross-sectional trend study of social networking in a large organization yielded surprises that led to a large-scale interview study. Overall, use is maturing and new concerns have arisen: Experimentation is giving way to mature, routine use. Pressured to show profitability, social networking companies have adapted the search engine revenue model: behavior tracking and targeted advertising. Concerns have shifted from boundary regulation to ways in which information is used, but the benefits of use that is now routine outweigh the concerns.

column3: Should Your MOOC Forum Use a Reputation System?
column9: Derrick Coetzee, Armando Fox, Marti Hearst, Björn Hartmann
column100: E-Learning and Education; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Massive open online courses (MOOCs) rely primarily on discussion forums for interaction among students. In a field experiment with 1101 participants on the edX platform, we introduced a reputation system, which allows students to gather points for making useful posts. We examined the effects of both forums and reputation systems on student course outcomes and student-forum interactions. Results show that use of forums in MOOCs is correlated with better grades and higher retention, and that reputation systems produce faster response times and larger numbers of responses per post, as well as differences in how students ask questions. On the other hand, reputation systems have no significant impact on grades, retention, or the students' subjective sense of community. This suggests that forums are essential for MOOCs, and reputation systems can improve the forum experience, but other techniques are needed to improve student outcomes and community formation. We also contribute a set of guidelines for running field experiments on MOOCs.

column3: Capturing Quality: Retaining provenance for curated volunteer monitoring data
column9: S. Sheppard, Andrea Wiggins, Loren Terveen
column100: Crowdsourcing; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaboration architectures; Workflow management; Distributed/virtual teams; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Other domain-specific support
column101: The “real-world” nature of field-based volunteer monitoring involves unique data management challenges that distinguish it from citizen science projects that rely solely on Internet-mediated interaction. In particular, many data contribution and review practices are often accomplished “offline”, via paper or general purpose software like Excel. This can lead to integration challenges when attempting to implement project-specific ICT with full revision and provenance tracking. In this work, we explore some of the current challenges and \ opportunities in implementing ICT for managing citizen science data. Our two main contributions are: a general outline of the workflow tasks common to field-based data collection, and a novel data model for preserving provenance metadata that allows for ongoing data exchange between disparate technical systems and participant skill levels.

column3: The Impact of Membership Overlap on the Survival of Online Communities
column9: Haiyi Zhu, Robert Kraut, Aniket Kittur
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Online communities play an important role in society. In this study, we study the effects of membership overlap on the survival of online communities. By analyzing the historical data of 5673 Wikia communities, we find that moderate levels of membership overlap are positively associated with the survival of online communities relative to higher or lower levels of membership overlap. Furthermore, we find that it is beneficial for new communities to have shared members who play a central role in other mature communities. These findings provide new insight into an important mechanism underlying successful online communities, contribute to theories of organization science, and provide several actionable steps for the hosts and creators of online communities.

column3: Transnational Migrants and Online Identity Work
column9: Jessica Lingel, Mor Naaman, danah boyd
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: This paper uses qualitative interviews with 26 transnational migrants in New York City to analyze socio-technical practices related to online identity work. We focus specifically on Facebook, where benefits included keeping in touch with friends and family abroad and documenting everyday urban life. At the same time, many participants also reported experiences of fatigue, socio-cultural tensions and concerns about maintaining a sense of personal privacy. These experiences highlight how transnational practices complicate context collapse, where the geographic dispersal of participants’ personal networks renders visible conflicts of “flattened” online networks. Our findings also suggest a kind of technology-enabled code-switching, where transnational migrants leverage technologies to perform identities that alternate between communities, nationalities and geographies. This analysis informs HCI research on complexities of online identity work in terms of shifting social and spatial contexts, and also the extent to which online identity work is a collaborative rather than individual performance.

column3: Mind the Skills Gap: Explaining the Gender Divide in Contributions to Wikipedia
column9: Eszter Hargittai, Aaron Shaw
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: The gender gap in Wikipedia contributions has been widely documented, but has yet to be satisfactorily explained. Women represent an estimated 16% of global Wikipedia editors and 23% of adult Wikipedia editors in the United States. In searching for sources and solutions to this persistent disparity, previous research has focused on analyzing aspects of current contributors and the existing Wikipedia community. Drawing on unique panel survey data with detailed information about both contributors and non-contributors, we examine the role of individuals' background attributes and Internet skills in participating on the site. We find that the gender gap in editing is exacerbated by a similarly significant Internet skills gap. Our results show that by far the most likely contributors are the specific group of high-skilled males, suggesting that future efforts to understand the origins and design solutions for the gender gap must also take Internet skills into account.

column3: Support for Deictic Pointing in CVEs: Still Fragmented After All These Years?
column9: Nelson Wong, Carl Gutwin
column100: Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies
column101: Pointing gestures – particularly deictic references – are ubiquitous in face-to-face communication. However, deictic pointing can be much more difficult in collaborative virtual environments (CVEs) than in everyday life – in some of the earliest CVE studies, researchers found that ‘fragmented interactions’ greatly complicated communication. In the fifteen years since these studies appeared, the technologies used in CVEs have improved substantially. What these advances mean for the problems of fragmentation and deictic gesture, however, is unclear. We conducted an observational study of deictic pointing in a CVE with techniques that may reduce fragmentation: extra-wide and third-person views, precise control over an avatar’s pointing arm, and visual enhancements such as object highlighting and laser pointing. Our study shows that although pointing has come a long way, problems of fragmentation still occur, and that visual and view enhancements can cause new problems for collaboration, even as they solve others. Surprisingly, the visibility of preparatory actions of a gesture remained important, even when augmented pointing techniques were used.

column3: Harnessing Collective Intelligence to Evaluate Crowdfunding Campaigns
column9: Shih-Wen Huang, Huaming Rao, Anbang Xu, Wai-Tat Fu, En-Hsu Yen, Brian Bailey
column100: Crowdsourcing; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: Crowdfunding is a revolutionary way for individuals and small businesses to raise capital from the public. While successful campaigns can raise millions of dollars, it is estiamted that only fewer than half of the campaigns can reach their funding goals. To better understand why a campaign succeeds (or fails), we examined the idea of using crowd workers to evaluate crowdfunding campaigns. We found that, although individual crowd workers are in general not good at predicting whether a campaign will succeed, combining their judgements on different aspects of the campaigns with a sophisticated non-linear machine learning model can predict if a campaign could reach its funding goal with up to 90% accuracy. This is significantly higher than the accuracy achieved by only machine learning techniques (77.5%) or only human judgments (72.5%). This study can serve as a small yet significant first step to developing crowd-computer systems that harness the collective intelligence of crowd workers to evaluate crowdfunding campaigns.

column3: Studying the Structural Fluidity of Virtual Organizations: A Case Study from GitHub
column9: Sean Goggins, Nora McDonald, Giuseppe Valetto, Kelly Blincoe
column33: Drexel University Dept. of Computer Science
column100: Social network analysis; Workflow management; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: This is the first longitudinal study of Virtual Organization (VO) structure and performance on GitHub. We present an in depth ethnomethodological study of interactions in an open source software project, Rails/Rails, in the distributed source code management system, GitHub. We operationalize an index of virtual organization change, which we call structural fluidity. Our index is composed of individual and group measures of leadership and membership in a VO. The case described here builds on insights derived from the deep study of over a dozen projects on GitHub.  We explore comparisons within a single case here in order to develop a concrete, descriptive understanding of how structural fluidity might be operationalized in larger scale studies of software VOs. We close with a discussion that proposes a path for developing more robust structural fluidity indicators, and the role of "flash collaboration" for understanding software VOs.

column3: Planned Obsolescence or Designed Reparability? Infrastructures and Materialities of Breakdown
column9: Daniela Rosner, Morgan Ames
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; User experience/interaction design; Other domain-specific support
column101: This paper tackles issues of design for repair in light of two projects: public sites of facilitated repair in Northern California and the “XO” laptops of One Laptop Per Child (OLPC) in Paraguay. Drawing on 15 months of ethnographic fieldwork, 156 interviews, and archival research, we find that breakdown and repair are not processes that designers can effectively script ahead of time; instead, they emerge in and through everyday practice. Material and socioecomic commitments and constraints shape these practices, surfacing manufacturing limitations, access to repair parts and expertise, and environmental convictions. Repair thus reveals itself as a material and political endeavor embedded in a range of materialities and infrastructures. Our findings point to four emerging concerns for designed reparability in CSCW: the multiple facets of breakdown, the cultural and socioeconomic stakes of repair, the collaborative character of tinkering, and collaborative definitions of worth.

column3: To Share, or Not to Share - An Exploration of Student Information Foraging, Pedagogy, and Opportunities for Collaborative Learning through a Shared Repository
column9: Regina Collins, Harshada Shrivastav, Quentin (Gad) Jones
column100: E-Learning and Education; Computer-Mediated Communication; User experience/interaction design
column101: There is a wealth of information available on the internet, and students actively forage through this information for reasons ranging from entertainment to education.  This paper reports the results of semi-structured interviews exploring why students forage for educational knowledge resources, whether or not they share the resources they find, and how they learn through these types of activities.  Findings suggest that educational information foraging can be classified as either instructor-driven or student-driven, and that students’ decisions to share, or not to share, the outcomes are affected by a number of factors.  This paper argues that the lack of sharing of knowledge resources reveals missed opportunities for collaborative learning; a shared knowledge repository is therefore recommended and design implications for the creation of such a repository are discussed.  New pedagogical activities which would encourage collaborative knowledge building through the use of the shared repository are also explored.

column3: Modular Toolkit of Interface Components for students to efficiently and easily test design concepts
column9: magnus feil, frances tung
column100: User experience/interaction design; E-Learning and Education; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design
column101: This presentation will introduce a toolkit envisioned for design students and educators to explore the principles of interaction design at the intersection of tangible- and screen-based concepts for interaction. \  \ Composed of modular components representing the basic spectrum of interface elements, this toolkit will enable students to prototype by quickly assembling and testing envisioned concepts. \

column3: Adolescent Online Safety: The “Moral” of the Story
column9: Pamela Wisniewski, Mary Beth Rosson, Heng Xu, John Carroll
column14: College of Information Sciences &Technology, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pennsylvania, United States
column32: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column41: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: Adolescence is characterized by heightened risk-taking and independence from parents; these tendencies seem to be magnified by the opportunities afforded through online interactions. We report a qualitative study of 12 parent-adolescent dyads which examines the interplay between parenting behaviors and adolescent moral development.  We show an association between adolescent moral judgment and online behavior, and we illustrate how parenting style and mediation strategies influence the teen’s moral growth and decision making about online behaviors. We also note that parental mediation strategies are moderated by parents’ digital literacy: reduced digital literacy is associated with more restrictive or indulgent strategies, while more digitally competent parents monitor and mediate their teen’s behaviors as they engage online. We also found that experience, not restriction, facilitates the teen’s moral growth.

column3: Designing CSCW System for Assistance of Outdoor Activities of The Elderly
column9: Eeva Leinonen, Anna-Liisa Syrjänen, Kari Kuutti
column100: Collaboration architectures; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Collaborative software development
column101: Appropriate and timely cooperation is an actual challenge for different stakeholders who take care of the elderly in need of assistance in their daily lives. Their number is rising but care-taking resources diminishing, which make the situation difficult for elderly, their relatives, decision-makers and service providers. Assistive technologies can offer new possibilities in organizing the necessary support for the old people. This paper introduces a new mobile augmented tele-guidance navigation concept for outdoor activities of elderly, and shows that it offers a novel approach to organize a support network for the person who needs help. The network is shaped dynamically around the person moving out from his or her apartment. The person is equipped with sensors which recognize the assistance need and alerts the caretakers, who can organize their turns of guiding the person’s activity by the system. We provide a design example contributing to the lack of CSCW cases with assistive technology systems.

column3: Effects of Peripheral Participations in Social Software of Classroom
column9: Fang-Ling Lin
column15: Lunghwa University of Science and Technology
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Social network analysis
column101: This study believes social software has generic aims of peer learning and intends to discover the effects of peripheral participations which strengthen the performance of learning in college classroom. A slideshare-like social software: OpenSlide has been installed for the pedagogy of an operating system course for undergraduates of the information management department. Through the use of slide-exercises and online presentations of learning activities after school, the research examined the interactions by social network analysis. A quasi-experimental study has implemented to investigate the effectiveness of the instructional design by comparing the performance of an experimental class with social software and a control class without social software. Findings have shown that the deployed OpenSlide system with open discussion forum for individual homework constructs a situated learning. And the surface learners acted as peripheral participants and gained progress achievements.

column3: Engaging with Your Friends on Facebook: The Balance between Privacy Protection and Social Connection
column9: Pamela Wisniewski, Emmanuel Bello-Ogunu, Heng Xu, Heather Lipford
column14: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column24: The University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column32: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column42: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; User experience/interaction design; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: Few studies have examined both the benefits and the privacy implications associated with engaging with one’s friends through Social Networking Sites (SNSs). In addition, SNS privacy research tends to focus primarily on self-disclosure privacy, not the interactional privacy concerns related to co-owned information. Through a survey study of 116 Facebook users, we show that engagement with friends through photo tagging and apps has a direct and positive influence on an individual’s Facebook usage and sense of community. However, this effect is tempered by privacy issues associated with personal information disclosed through friends and can serve to reduce overall engagement levels. High levels of privacy concern can decrease engagement with friends through photo tagging, and low levels of perceived effectiveness of Facebook’s privacy policies negatively impact app engagement with friends. Therefore, features that promote direct engagement with one’s friends can be beneficial; yet, designers need to take privacy considerations into account.

column3: The Social Name-Letter Effect on Twitter
column9: Farshad Kooti, Ingmar Weber
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Social network analysis
column101: The Name-Letter Effect, first described by Nuttin in \\cite{nuttin85ejsp}, states that people have a preference for brands, places and even jobs that start with the same letter as their own first name. This effect is commonly explained by ``implicit egotism'' and has become a classic in psychology with more than a hundred articles on the subject. \  \ We use social network data from Twitter to replicate this effect in a new environment. We find limited to no support for NLE on social networks, both for brand and for social links. We do, however, find a very robust same-name effect where, say, Michaels would be more likely to follow other Michaels than Johns. \ This effect also exists in links to celebrities with, e.g., Tom Cruise attracting followership from more than expected Toms.

column3: Am I Normal? Supporting Information Seeking in Complex Chronic Illness Management
column9: Aisling Ann O'Kane, Sun Young Park, Helena Mentis, Ann Blandford, Yunan Chen
column100: Medical and health support; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Mobile and embedded devices; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: With the increased interest in patient-centered health systems putting the onus of responsibility on patients to manage their health data, this paper explores the information seeking practices of two different chronic health populations in their quest to understand their health data. Migraine and diabetes patients and clinicians in the UK and the US were interviewed about their care management practices, and representative online communities were explored to inform a descriptive qualitative study. We found that both chronic conditions require individualized care management plans, which leads to constant questioning what it means to have condition specific symptoms, triggers, and treatments, and attempting to determine their condition is ‘normal.’ Patients seek information about themselves, their medical condition, and what other patients are going through in order to answer these questions, and they can be met with barriers to these sources of information. From these findings, we identify design considerations for personal health informatics systems to support patients’ quests to determine if they are ‘normal.’

column3: O-SNAP: A Collaborative Mobile Search Application that Supports Physical Signaling and In-Person Conversation
column9: Shiri Azenkot, Jaime Teevan, Meredith Morris
column15: Computer Science and Engineering, DUB Group, University of Washington
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Often when people search the web from their smartphones, they do so collaboratively. Although current mobile search tools are designed to support a single user acting alone, in reality people transition between individual and group search, moving closer to group members and sharing their screen while discussing search criteria and results. We present O-SNAP, a mobile application that explicitly supports in-person collaborative search by allowing users to physically signal a willingness to share and facilitating face-to-face search-related communication. While the core application provides traditional mobile search functionality, users rotate their devices to landscape orientation to indicate (to the device and those around them) that they are entering a collaborative mode. We study two uses of the collaborative mode, one where users rate results to create a group list, and another where screens and actions are shared across devices. O-SNAP also implements other features to increase discussion and reduce uncomfortable coordination across searchers. The application highlights how physical proximity can be used to augment collaborative search.

column3: Empowering Online-Offline Interactions in a Free Food Sharing Community
column9: Eva Ganglbauer, Geraldine Fitzpatrick
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social network analysis; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Social networking has a long history of supporting online communities. In this paper we are concerned with a particular type of community that has formed around free food sharing. Foodsharing.de is a platform that enables consumers, farmers, organizations and retailers to offer and collect food. Associated with this is the Foodsharing Facebook group where broader community discussions take place. We report on a qualitative analysis of the Foodsharing Facebook group, with 22.405 likes and 3242 posts and comments, to understand its role in building and sustaining the community. The Facebook group is a place where the individual social and ecological values and economical needs around food sharing can be enacted along local-global and online-offline dimensions. Further community interactions, public relations, and mass media together work to create new social patterns through narratives, pro-active appeals and local community building. We point to the concept of empowerment, on individual, community and organizational levels, as being key to what makes such an activist community work.

column3: Making the Connection between Supportive Government and Needy Citizens: A Case Study with Construction Workers in Urban India
column9: Sheetal Agarwal, Jyoti Grover, Meghna Singh, Jerome White, Arun Kumar
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Several e-governance systems and solutions have been proposed and implemented in the past. These services enhance citizens’ access to government services. However, many of these services still remain  under-utilized as citizens continue to remain unaware due to technological and organizational barriers. \  \ This paper describes a service deployed to enable a supportive government to offer benefits to construction workers employed in burgeoning construction industry of urban India. We report our observations from live operation of this service and insights gained from a user study. The results emphasize that existing channels of communication with citizens are either not enough or not effective. Further, the ecosystem involving government, partners and citizens has several challenges and pitfalls that must be kept in mind while designing programs and services for e-governance.

column3: Tracking serendipitous interactions: How individual cultures shape the office
column9: Chloe Brown, Christos Efstratiou, Ilias Leontiadis, Daniele Quercia, Cecilia Mascolo
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: In many creative work environments, serendipitous interactions between members of different groups may lead to enhanced productivity, collaboration and knowledge dissemination. Two factors that may have an influence on such interactions are cultural differences between individuals in highly multicultural workplaces, and the layout and physical spaces of the workplace itself. In this work, we investigate how these two factors may facilitate or hinder inter-group interactions in the workplace. We analyse traces collected using wearable electronic badges to capture face-to-face interactions and mobility patterns of employees in a research laboratory in the UK. We observe that those who interact with people of different roles tend to come from collectivist and person-oriented cultures comfortable with social hierarchies, and that some locations in particular are more likely to host serendipitous interactions, knowledge that could be used by organisations to enhance communication and productivity.

column3: Relational Maintenance on Social Network Sites: How Facebook Communication Predicts Relational Stability and Change
column9: Victoria Schwanda Sosik, Natalya Bazarova
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Social Network Sites are popular communication tools that help people maintain relationships with their friends, yet there has been little research studying exactly how people use these tools to enact relationship maintenance. This paper analyzes communication between individual friendships on a popular Social Network Site, Facebook, to answer the question of what types of maintenance behaviors enacted on the site predict change or stability of Facebook friendships. Results show that while frequency of communication and certain types of communication (photo tags, photo likes, wall posts, and private messages) predict relationship escalation, enactment of traditional relationship maintenance strategies through the content of Facebook communication does not. These findings contribute to our theoretical understanding of the ways that the functionality of Social Network Sites can help users engage in new types of relationship maintenance.

column3: Enabling the Assembly of Teams: Surface, Deep, and Social Composition using Wiki Profiles
column9: Kathryn Dalrymple, Amy Wax, Leslie DeChurch, Bruce Walker, Noshir Contractor
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social network analysis
column101: Self-assembled teams often have to rely on who they know and first impressions when evaluating potential teammates. A virtual tool can assist self-assembling teams in making informed decisions about possible teammates. The tool can contain information about surface-level, deep-level, and social characteristics. A class self-assembling into teams for a project used a wiki that was populated with self-made profiles of each student to select teammates. The data was analyzed to see if the actual composition of a team’s surface-level, deep-level and social characteristics would predict the likelihood of individuals becoming teammates. Results indicate a strong relationship between preexisting relationships and individuals being teammates. The data also shows those with similar levels of psychological collectivism, a deep-level trait, and similar race, a surface-level trait, to predict individuals being teammates. Implications of the findings and possible future directions are discussed.

column3: The Conversational Routines and Needs of Distance-Separated Grandparents and Young Grandchildren
column9: Azadeh Forghani, Carman Neustaedter
column100: Home/family/intimacy support
column101: A variety of systems have been designed to support communication between distance-separated grandparents and grandchildren. Yet despite this, there are few studies of the actual communication routines and needs of these groups. To address this, we have conducted an interview and diary study that explores the communication practices and needs of distance-separated grandparents and young grandchildren (aged 3-10). Our results describe how these groups communicate over the phone and video chat to share their experiences, tell stories about life, exchange cultural knowledge, and provide parental support.  Yet grandparent-grandchild communication is not without its challenges: grandparents sometimes feel self-conscious, perceive that parents or children will be annoyed if they ask too many questions, and do not want to interfere too much in their grandchildren’s lives. The implication is that designs should attempt to support the conversation routines and needs of grandparents and grandchildren while attempting to mitigate the social challenges.

column3: Engaging in Local Municipal Planning: Examining Citizens’ Role in the Decision-Making Process
column9: Jessica Kropczynski, John Carroll, Guoray Cai
column23: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column32: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design
column101: Democratic civic engagement is a critical component of social life in local communities. This paper uses ethnomethodology to describe civic engagement and decision-making in a community planning context. We draw from our own fieldwork to illustrate citizens’ role as key players in decision making and planners facilitation of deliberative practices associated with presentation of information, surrounding both routine and controversial community planning case settings. Our observations identify key resources and challenges to citizens’ decision-making and deliberation which we encountered in six months of observations of one municipality. Results suggest areas of improvement for facilitated decision-making including: bridging perspectives between citizens and planners, emphasis on consensus building interactions, avoiding staged linear process of planning leading to implementation in support of time for sense-making reflection, and providing mechanisms for recording and archiving to avoid missed opportunities.

column3: Remixers’ Understandings of Fair Use Online
column9: Casey Fiesler, Amy Bruckman
column100: Legal/historical/philosophical aspects; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: How do online content creators make decisions about copyright law? In the course of day-to-day online activities, Internet users are forced to make subtle judgments about one of the most confusing and nuanced areas of law, copyright and fair use. In this study, we conducted semi-structured interviews with eleven content creators who participate in remix and fan creation activities online, to try to probe their legal understandings and attitudes. We found that social norms that emerge among these content creators do not always track to what the law actually says, but are often guided more by ethical concerns. Our participants showed surprisingly similar patterns of understandings and confusions, impacting technology use and interaction online.

column3: Characteristics of Distributed Collaborative Practices and ICT Uses of Social Scientists
column9: Steve Sawyer, Carsten Oesterlund, Jaime Snyder, Matt Willis, Sarika Sharma, Michelle Brown, Doratea Szkolar, Elizabeth Greenberg
column50: create, Syracuse University, Syracuse, New York, United States
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Other domain-specific support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: We focus in this paper on the practices and uses of digital resources of scientists collaborating at a distance. Drawing on a series of semi-structured interviews with scientists currently involved in distributed collaborations provides the empirical basis for our two primary findings. First, we present insights regarding work practices and social dynamics characteristic of these projects. Second, we discuss relationships between distributed scientific collaboration practices and scientists’ uses of common digital tools. These findings suggest that current approaches to cyberinfrastructure (CI) as a means to enhance distributed scientific collaboration may fail to adequately support the level of social negotiation, uses of commercial tools, and the short-lived and craft-like project organization that characterized the practices of social scientists who we interviewed.  Findings suggest that these scientists find shared data practices to be difficult and that most are seeking to balance well-honed personal work practices with a set of temporary practices adopted to support the distributed collaborations in which they are involved.

column3: Understanding the Division of Labour in Software Organizations: A Framework and a Case Study
column9: Jorge Aranda, Adrian Schröter, Christoph Treude, Daniela Damian, Margaret-Anne Storey
column100: Collaborative software development; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Software professionals divide their work by roles, but to date, researchers have not examined nor questioned the nature of these roles, which is a potential source of confusion and dysfunction in software organizations. To address this, we formulate a theoretical framework based on sociological and organizational research, in which roles are defined as sets of expectations placed on the members of the software organization. \  \ The paper also reports on an empirical case study of three software organizations, which was informed and inspired by this framework. We found that roles were inconsistent within and between the organizations, and that role definitions are shaped by institutional, historical, socio-structural, infrastructural, and personal factors. Furthermore, role definitions evolve through organizational growth and through mismatches between expectations and performance. \  \ Our contributions provide software practitioners with a conceptual tool to reason about social structure and organizational design. They also help researchers to frame better studies of division of labour in software groups and to avoid unwarranted abstractions of professional software roles.

column3: Ethnography of Scaling: How to a fit a national research infrastructure in the room
column9: Davd Ribes
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaboration architectures; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Ethnographers have traditionally studied people in particular times and places. However, sociotechnical systems are often long-term enterprises, spanning the globe and serving vast communities. Drawing from three cases of research infrastructure development, this paper demonstrates a methodology in which the ethnographer examines scalar devices: techniques and technologies for knowing and managing large-scale objects. Such devices are enacted in and across concrete times and places; for the ethnographer they are observable as activities of scaling. By examining activities of scaling we can better understand diverse kinds of size and growth within sociotechnical systems.

column3: Collaborative Web Search in Context: A Study of Tool Use in Everyday Tasks
column9: Ryan Kelly, Stephen Payne
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Other domain-specific support
column101: Recent research efforts have led to the creation of a number of systems that provide specialised support for collaborative web search. However, the use of these tools has not been studied outside of the laboratory, and as collaborative search is becoming increasingly commonplace in everyday life, there is a need to understand whether the support provided by collaborative search tools fits with real-world information seeking practices. In the present study, we deployed two collaborative search tools to pairs of searchers with genuine information needs. We report findings from in-depth interviews conducted after participants had used the systems for extended periods of time. Our findings show how system features were used and appropriated in pursuit of collaboration, throwing greater light on the way in which collaborative search is conducted in quotidian settings. We also highlight problematic issues concerning shared search histories. Practical implications of the results are discussed.

column3: Identification in Virtual Teams: Examining the Impacts of Virtuality on Team Identification
column9: Lionel Robert, Sangseok You
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Team identification is an important predictor of team success. As teams become more virtual team identification is expected to become more important. Yet, the dimensions of virtuality such as geographic dispersion, reliance on virtual communication and diversity in team membership can undermine team identification. To better understand the impact of virtuality a study was conducted that examine the effects of geographic dispersion, reliance on virtual communication and perceived differences on team identification. Results indicate that the effects of these dimensions of virtuality on team identification are complex and codependent.

column3: Beyond AMT: An Analysis of Crowd Work Platforms
column9: Donna Vakharia, Matthew Lease
column100: Crowdsourcing; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Workflow management; B2B / information systems
column101: While Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (AMT) helped launch the \ paid crowd work industry eight years ago, many new vendors \ now offer a range of alternative models. Despite this, little \ crowd work research has explored other platforms. Such \ near-exclusive focus risks letting AMT’s particular vagaries \ and limitations overly shape our understanding of crowd work \ and the research questions and directions being pursued. To \ address this, we present a cross-platform content analysis of \ seven crowd work platforms. We begin by reviewing how \ AMT assumptions and limitations have influenced prior research. \ Next, we formulate key criteria for characterizing \ and differentiating crowd work platforms. Our analysis of \ platforms presents contrasts them with AMT, informing both \ methodology of use and directions for future research. Our \ cross-platform analysis represents the only such study by researchers \ for researchers, intended to further enrich the diversity \ of research on crowd work and accelerate progress.

column3: Predicting the Future to Facilitate Content Contribution
column9: Avishay Livne, Eytan Adar
column100: Recommender and Filtering Systems; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: In many user-generated-content sites the rate of content creation is rarely fast enough to fill in knowledge gaps. In such sites editors often hint about where these gaps are. In the case of Wikipedia these hints are called red-links—hyperlinks to stub articles. In our work, we find that stub articles represent a significant portion of unaddressed reader demand. Additionally, we find editors are ill-equipped to identify the red-links that would provide the greatest benefit to visitors. To address this problem, we create a search engine that allows editors to identify pages to which they can contribute their expertise and project their future impact. This requires predicting the future in two ways: 1) anticipating content of uncreated articles and 2) predicting future use. Using the content of existing articles, we speculatively infer the content of and index stub articles. To address the second, we utilize readers click and search behaviors, as well as graph structure to anticipate the importance of these stub pages.

column3: Exploring Theatre of the Oppressed and Media Synchronicity to Supplement Virtual Learning Environments: Experiences with Mados
column9: Pedro Silva, Si Jung Kim
column100: E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Collaboration architectures; User experience/interaction design
column101: This paper explores the application of Media Synchronicity Theory and its potential for translating Critical Pedagogy (specifically Boal’s Theatre of the Oppressed) into a computer-supported collaborative work (CSCW) environment. It introduces the Maquina dos Oprimidos (Mados) prototype, a CSCW supplement to traditional asynchronous learning networks. Mados operates as a role-playing debate game, in which students debate a pre-selected prompt while performing assigned character roles. The study explores the prototype’s potential to affect student’s identification with their assigned character and personal attitude toward the prompt, as well as examining the effect of presence on students’ performances. \  \ The study was performed with 38 8th grade students. Subjects debated a prompt which proposed a banning cell phones from classrooms. Results show that subjects collaboratively constructed solutions that compromised between both positions, while slightly favoring the anti-ban position. Additionally, subjects experienced gains in character identification after participating in the task regardless of assigned character.  \

column3: Sharing Health Successes Online: Theory-Driven Design Strategies for Socially Supportive Technologies
column9: Erika Poole, David McDonald, Eric Hekler
column14: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column32: School of Nutrition and Health Promotion
column100: Medical and health support; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: Do you want to share your successes and victories with health behaviors with your friends and family? What about the kid you went to elementary school with and haven’t seen in decades? Manufacturers of consumer health devices think you might want to do so in order to get social support and accountability from others in achieving behavior change goals. In this paper, we provide guidance from the behavioral sciences on how we might best provide social support mechanisms online, taking into consideration not only the needs of the person asking for support, but also the needs of the people who are candidates for providing support. We present a taxonomy that can more effectively guide the design of social support mechanisms for use in social networking software, mobile health applications, and other technologies used to share health successes.

column3: From Rookie to All-Star: Professional Development in a Graphic Design Social Networking Site
column9: Jennifer Marlow, Laura Dabbish
column24: HCII & Heinz College, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: A plethora of domain-focused social networking sites have emerged and have the potential to change the nature of work as we know it. These sites are dedicated to specific professional activities and are being used both for learning and gaining employment. Little work to date has examined how individuals use social network functionality for professional development in these types of communities. We present a qualitative investigation into how SNS functionality supports two important components of professional activity: skill development and reputation building. We focus on activity within Dribbble, a social network site for graphic designers. Through a series of interviews with novice and experienced Dribbble users who work within and outside of traditional organizations, we identified ways they leverage SNS features for learning and skill development. We find that benefits of the site are dependent on extensive social capital development activities in order to garner attention for posted work. Our results inform the design of online social settings for professional development.

column3: Cultivating Practice, Shepherding Technology Use: Visible and Invisible Work in the Appropriation Process
column9: Pablo-Alejandro Quinones
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Previous work has shown that, potential users are free to interpret technology in any numbers of ways and that the successful appropriation of technology into practice depends heavily on users’ understandings and narratives around the technology’s use. Who drives the successful appropriation process is still ill-defined within the literature. In this paper, we present a case study conducted in a research university, using interviews to understand staff practices and technology appropriation within their work contexts. We found that the successful appropriation of collaborative IT relies on the invisible work conducted by those people within groups who formally or informally aid their colleagues in the successful ‘cultivation’ of practices and sensemaking around technology—people we call shepherds. We draw parallels to other work that suggest the need for similar types of agents and close with a dialog concerning the challenge of establishing shepherding practices within large organizations.

column3: AnnoScape: Use of Live Video Overlay on 3D Data for Distributed Collaborative Review
column9: Austin Lee, Hiroshi Chigira, Sheng Kai Tang, Kojo Acquah, Hiroshi Ishii
column100: User experience/interaction design; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: We present AnnoScape system, a remote collaboration platform that allows geographically distributed users to navigate in the shared virtual 3D scene and to overlay a physical individual desktop workspace image to support individual and collaborative review of the 3D information. Our main contribution is the system design that supports: 1) video overlay techniques in virtual 3D environments to allow distributed users to share the live annotations over the synchronized viewports for the collaborative review; 2) and three types of work modes in relation to how the viewports are coupled. We describe the prototype design and initial experiments to explore AnnoScape’s possibilities through the scenario of having remote collaborators review the 3D data of an existing architectural structure. Our study shows that our system design with video overlay based hand-drawn annotation is advantageous for discussions during 3D data review over a distance.

column3: Collective User Behaviors in News Diffusion across Social Media
column9: Minkyoung Kim
column100: Social network analysis; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Diverse and multiple online social networks are both locally and globally interconnected. This global connectivity is governed by collective user behaviors which have different characteristics between diverse social networks. This study focuses on news diffusion across social media by using \ the Wikipedia Current Events as a news registry. We investigate the ICWSM'11 dataset containing over 386 million documents and analyze collective behaviors of each media type in terms of activity, reactivity, diffusion rate, and heterogeneity of users. Active users in Blog and News media tend to increase the document volume in news diffusion, which is not the case in SNS media. Regarding user reactivity, SNS media exhibit more prompt responses even than News media, while Blog media show more persistent behaviors than the others. In terms of heterogeneity, relative entropy increases as time evolves, which means that different media type users eventually participate in the diffusion in a balanced way.

column3: Trustworthy By Design
column9: Bran Knowles, Mike Harding, Lynne Blair, Nigel Davies, James Hannon, Mark Rouncefield, John Walden
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; User experience/interaction design; Workflow management; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Road maintenance in the UK is characterized by a complex set of workflows and data exchanges with significant levels of mistrust, both between the individual stakeholders – councils, contractors and public - and collectively in the data provided by the systems they use. These issues of trust are accentuated by bid and audit cultures endemic in the industry and the mobile nature of the workforces involved. We are interested in whether (and how) different ways of organizing work – specifically the introduction of technology - might impact on issues of trust. This paper draws on some initial ethnographic findings to design and evaluate a set of software services intended to provide evidence of accuracy and trustworthiness for one particular aspect of road maintenance – road drain or ‘gully’ cleaning.

column3: Beyond End User Content to Collaborative Knowledge Mapping: Interrelations Among Community Social Tools
column9: Tara Matthews, Steve Whittaker, Hernan Badenes, Barton Smith
column24: University of California at Santa Cruz
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Most studies of social tools examine usage of each tool in isolation. Instead, we explore how online communities (a) combine multiple social tools, and (b) use social tools together with external tools. Based on interviews with community leaders and analysis of 128 online community spaces, we explored the combined use of six social software tools—wikis, blogs, forums, social bookmarks, social file repositories, and task-management tools. Our contributions are describing combined technology use by communities and adding to our understanding of online community behaviors: Communities combine social tools to create complex information spaces. When combined, each tool is used for restricted ‘core’ functions. Thus, “social” features are not always leveraged for every tool. Our results suggest that an important overlooked aspect of social media concerns how these different tools can be effectively combined. While most prior work on communities emphasizes end user content, we identify additional important design activities where community leaders curate and combine pre-existing content from multiple tools to serve their community needs.

column3: A Computational Analysis of Agenda Setting and Second-level Agenda Setting
column9: Yeooul Kim, Suin Kim, Alejandro Jaimes, Alice Oh
column100: Machine Learning and Data Mining; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Agenda setting theory explains how media affects its audience. Limitations of traditional media studies about agenda setting include the small set of issues, the costly survey data of public interest, and the expertise needed for categorizing the article frames. In this paper, we propose a computational approach to study agenda setting with a large dataset of online news, approximately 17,000 articles from the website of National Public Radio. Along with the articles, we crawl user comments and social sharing counts. With that data, we automatically extract the major issues with hierarchical Dirichlet processes, a nonparametric probabilistic topic model. Then, we quantify the effects of agenda setting by analyzing the correlation of the user comments and social sharing with the amount of news coverage. Finally, we use sentiment analysis to define and analyze the effects of second-level agenda setting. By using advanced machine learning tools, we demonstrate the potential of detailed and principled analysis of agenda setting from a large set of publicly available data.

column3: Pair Research: Matching People for Collaboration, Learning, and Productivity
column9: Robert Miller, Haoqi Zhang, Eric Gilbert, Elizabeth Gerber
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Distributed/virtual teams; Collaborative software development
column101: To increase productivity, informal learning, and collaborations within and across research groups, we have been experimenting with a new kind of interaction that we call pair research, in which members are paired up weekly to work together on each other’s projects. In this paper, we present a system for making pairings and present results from two deployments. Results show that members used pair research in a wide variety of ways including pair programming, user testing, brainstorming, and data collection and analysis.  Pair research helped members get things done and share their expertise with others. \

column3: How to enable Relationship Building in Tabletop-supported Advisory Settings?
column9: Peter Heinrich, Mehmet Kilic, Felix-Robinson Aschoff, Gerhard Schwabe
column100: Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Financial advisory encounters are important contact points between financial institutions and customers. Recent research showed that these kinds of encounters can successfully be supported with IT-artifacts. Tabletop scenarios, for example, can increase the transparency of the advisory process for the customers. In this line of research, however, we also experienced that the relationship quality as experienced by the customer can suffer severely when IT artifacts are introduced in the advisory scenario. Based on these experiences, we developed guidelines to avoid this effect and implemented them in one of our prototypes. The evaluation reveals that these measures proved to be effective. With the reported study, we seek to enhance our design knowledge on IT-supported advisory scenarios with a special focus on relationship building. In a larger context, we argue that the use of IT during sensitive face-to-face encounters will be of growing significance in the future but is hardly understood, yet. With our generic requirements, design principles and evaluation, we make a contribution in this area.

column3: My Friends Made Me Do It: Predictors of  Facebook Non-use
column9: Eric Baumer, Victoria Schwanda Sosik, Phil Adams
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: This paper examines predictors of non-use of social technology. We analyze a publicly available dataset about Facebook non-use that includes data from 410 respondents. We apply statistical modeling to determine what factors predict both enacted non-use, in terms of a respondent either deactivating or deleting her or his account, as well as considered non-use, in terms of how often a respondent reports considering account deactivation or deletion. Results show that a variety of factors predict increased, or in some cases decreased, likelihood of non-use, including concerns about privacy, the Facebook features a respondent most frequently uses, and whether a respondent knows someone else who left Facebook. These results contribute to our understanding of non-use by examining motivations for, and potential indicators of, social technology non-use. This paper also highlights the sociotechnical ramifications of becoming a non-user and the ways in which non-use is a highly social phenomenon.

column3: Phones and Flu Shots:  Phone Separation Can Activate Attachment Behavior
column9: Stephanie Friedman, Jeff Hancock
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: Given how much time people spend with their mobile phone, is it possible for people to form an emotional attachment to their device? To test this question the present study separated people from their phone while they waited for a flu shot, a potentially anxiety-producing event. According to attachment theory, phone attached individuals should experience separation distress and rate the upcoming flu shot as more painful than unattached individuals. The results supported this prediction: high phone attachment individuals anticipated more pain than low phone attachment individuals when separated from their phone. We also found that high phone attachment individuals were more likely to be younger and to own a smartphone than a regular phone; we found no difference between genders. Our results extend self-reported perceptions of phone attachment by demonstrating that phone separation can activate key attachment behaviors, such as separation distress.

column3: Deliberate Barriers to User Participation on MetaFilter
column9: Hannah Pileggi, Briana Morrison, Amy Bruckman
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: This descriptive study explores deliberate barriers to user participation on the long-lived discussion site Metafilter.com. Metafilter has been in continuous operation since its founding in 1999, and at the time of this writing has around 12,000 active users. While many newer online sites appear eager to eliminate barriers to participation and recruit as many new members as possible, Metafilter charges a $5 fee to join and has a mandatory one-week waiting period before new users are allowed to post. In this paper, we explore both why these barriers were imposed and why some users choose to surmount the barriers to become members. Our data sources include historical documents posted on the site, interviews with eleven site members, an informal user survey, and an interview with the Matt Haughey, the site’s founder and owner. Implications of these design features are discussed.

column3: Designing for Healthcare in Everyday Life: Between Professional Healthcare and Leisure
column9: Erik Grönvall, Morten Kyng, Nervo Verdezoto
column100: Medical and health support; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: In this paper we consider the design of ICT-support for healthcare in everyday life. Increased unsupervised care at home has brought attention to the difficulties encountered when trying to develop healthcare systems for the home. Our work reveals a need to further understand the setting that is being designed for: the private home. When we design for home-based healthcare we need a deep understanding of the home and everyday life healthcare activities to balance inflow of design rationales from healthcare workplaces, like hospitals, and from home-based leisure, like games. To help designers of everyday home-based healthcare, we present and discuss four concerns (why, when, where and control in collaboration) that emerged in our analysis of challenges in three of our projects. In our experience these concerns help designers to focus on aspects where design rationales from healthcare workplaces and leisure respectively are not sufficient and may even point in other directions than what is helpful for home-based healthcare.

column3: Collaborative Science Games for Bioinformatics
column9: Daniel Perry, Aaron Lynch, John Robinson, Karin Hellman, Asmi Joshi, Alyssa-Cyre Oyadomari, Melissa Richtarik, Cecilia Aragon
column32: University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, United States
column100: Entertainment/games; Computer-Mediated Communication; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design
column101: Positive affect has been shown to increase learning performance and retention. While a growing number of serious games have been developed around science and engineering concepts, few are designed with an understanding of the socio-emotional aspects of gameplay. In this paper, we study affect generated during the collaborative design and play of a bioinformatics learning game. We provide insights from a year-long participatory design process with high school students, and discuss the results of an initial user study in a biology classroom. We identify three areas of design focus for emotionally compelling science games: serendipitous experiences, ethics of emotion, and skill transfer. Our research has design implications for creating science-based learning games, as well as more broadly in the design and implementation of other collaborative science learning environments.

column3: GEMS: A Location-Based Game for Supporting Family Storytelling
column9: Jason Procyk, Carman Neustaedter
column100: Location-based and context-aware computing; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: It is now possible to capture geotagged photos and videos and share them with family and friends.  Yet many of the applications for capturing and viewing this information offer little more than maps and simple textual information about a location. We wanted to explore this design space to find new and exciting ways for families to document and share their experiences. We designed a location-based game called GEMS to support telling and sharing stories and to enhance knowledge of place amongst family and friends. The game narrative and mechanics prompt players to reflect on meaningful places from their past and travel to those places to create geolocated digital memory records that capture the personal significance of the places in question. Other players can then visit the locations to collect and view the records. A user study revealed that location can provide a rich foundation for storytelling activities. We learned that location-based storytelling strategies often elicit a sense of discovery through exploration, sharing, and conscious reflection.

column3: Your 'Place' or Mine: How Tables Affect Place in the Classroom Space
column9: Manuel Perez-Quinones, Robert Beaton
column15: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
column24: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
column100: E-Learning and Education; Computer-Mediated Communication; Mobile and embedded devices; User experience/interaction design
column101: In this paper we describe the use of iPads and Nexus devices in the classroom for a full semester. The devices were given to the students with little instructions, other than ‘use them for classwork.’ The classroom was equipped with software that allowed the iPads to share the display in front of the class. We discuss the different forms of collaboration that took place in classroom settings and present our interpretations of such events based on the notion of place and space by Harrison and Dourish. We discuss three types of collaborative places that emerged and present how the tablets were useful in only two of them. We present students assessment of the use of iPads in the classroom and close the paper with implications for future work.

column3: Latitude Hurts, Longitude Kills: Repeated Reciprocity in Spatio-Temporal Distributed Teams
column9: Patrick Wagstrom
column100: Collaborative software development; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Social network analysis
column101: Distributed software development allows firms to leverage cost                                                                                                                                                   \ advantages and to place work near centers of competency. This                                                                                                                                                    \ distribution comes at a cost -- distributed teams face challenges from                                                                                                                                           \ differing cultures, skill levels, and a lack of shared working                                                                                                                                                   \ hours. In this paper we examine an oft-repeated statement about                                                                                                                                                  \ distributed software development ``Latitude hurts, longitude kills''.                                                                                                                                            \ We mine the work item tracker for a large commercial software project                                                                                                                                            \ with a globally distributed development base.
