We examine both the time                                                                                                                                           \ to respond and the propensity of individuals to respond and find that                                                                                                                                            \ while temporal dispersion has a significant negative impact on the                                                                                                                                               \ time to respond, it has little impact on the social network of                                                                                                                                                   \ individuals in the organization. This suggests that rather than                                                                                                                                                  \ looking for partners for round-the-clock development cycles firms may                                                                                                                                            \ be better served by looking for partners in a similar time zone.

column3: Social Structure and Depression in TrevorSpace
column9: Christopher Homan, Naiji Liu, Xin Tu, Megan Lytle, Vincent Silenzio
column23: Department of Biostatistics and Computational Biology
column32: Department of Biostatistics and Computational Biology
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social network analysis
column101: We discover patterns related to depression in the social graph of an online community of lesbian, gay, and bisexual, transgender, and questioning youth. We conducted a small survey on this community, a social networking service called TrevorSpace, and additionally, obtained snapshots of the entire TrevorSpace social graph. We demonstrate that, with high quality survey data on fewer than two hundred community members and the network graph of the entire community (which is completely anonymous except for the survey responses), we can detect statistically significant correlations between a number of graph properties and those TrevorSpace users showing a higher likelihood of depression, according to the Patient Healthcare Questionnaire-9, a standard instrument for estimating depression. Our results suggest that those who are less depressed are more structurally integrated into the TrevorSpace social graph than those with more depression. We believe our techniques may apply to other hard-to-reach online communities where obtaining detailed information about individuals is difficult or expensive, but obtaining the social graph is not.

column3: Different Colors Diffuse Differently: Color and the Spread of Images on Pinterest
column9: Saeideh Bakhshi, Eric Gilbert
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Many lab studies have shown that colors can evoke powerful emotions and impact human behavior. Might these phenomena subtly drive how we act online as well? A key research challenge for image-sharing communities is uncovering the mechanisms by which content spreads through the community. Within this context, we make the leap from color to diffusion: Is it possible there is a link between the two? Drawing on a corpus of 1M images crawled from Pinterest, we find that color subtly but significantly drives how far an image diffuses, even after partially controlling for content quality and network structure. Specifically, orange and red seem to promote diffusion, while green and purple suppress it. As far as we know, this is the first result describing how image features affect diffusion. In addition to speaking to the ongoing research conversation surrounding diffusion, these findings suggest deep future work using more sophisticated computer vision techniques.

column3: The Effect of Leadership Reduction on Activity and Interaction in an Online Game Community
column9: Gregor McEwan, Carl Gutwin
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Entertainment/games
column101: Multi-user web sites are interested in creating virtual communities. Critical to the success of virtual communities is enthusiastic leadership. However, there is little empirical research into how leadership change impacts online communities. In this paper we add to that research. We have been collecting data from an online game site for 1.5 years; during which, the founder/leader dramatically reduced his participation. Consequently, we have data spanning the leadership reduction. Our study – the first we know of investigating changes in online community leadership – revealed a complex picture of how leadership affects community. Overall, the game site activity was not reduced – but we saw a variety of different effects in subgroups within the community. We found the effects of leadership reduction are strongly tied to the dependence of a sub-community on the leader’s activity, and that when other factors draw people to the community, leadership changes do not cause much disruption. Our study provides new understanding for designers who wish to support online communities.

column3: The MyDreamTeam Builder: Enabling the assembly of effective teams
column9: Noshir Contractor, Leslie DeChurch, Yun Huang, Raquel Asencio, Anup Sawant, Toshio Murase
column100: Recommender and Filtering Systems; Social network analysis
column101: Teams are now the fundamental way of accomplishing complex work. Given their prevalence and importance, research on team composition has searched for the ideal composition of individual characteristics that make a good team. However, team composition research tends to ignore the various modalities that teams use to assemble and how this impacts team functioning. Additionally, we argue that research must go beyond basic team composition and explore other factors in team assembly that influence team formation, namely prior relationships. In this study, we present research on predictors of how people choose to assemble and the impact this has on later team functioning.

column3: The Influence of Quid-Pro-Quo on Time-sensitive Crowdsourcing
column9: Anthony Tomasic, Aaron Steinfeld, John Zimmerman, Yun Huang, Robert Kraut
column100: Crowdsourcing; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: While much is known about motivating contributors in \ online communities, there is a need to better understand \ how to motivate crowds to contribute timesensitive \ information. In this study, we explore the impact \ of two quid-pro-quo policies on user contributions. A \ quid-pro-quo policy exchanges contributions from users \ for access to critical information in the system. During a \ large-scale experimental study within a publicly \ deployed, crowdsourced, transit information system, we \ analyzed metrics associated with frequency of \ contribution and commitment to long-term use over a 10- \ month period. Our results confirmed that forced quid-proquo \ led to more contribution, but at a cost of faster \ departure from the study. Implied quid-pro-quo, where a \ participant was simply asked to contribute, but could still \ access community-generated data if they ignored a \ request to help, was largely ineffective and was \ statistically similar to the control condition where no \ request for contribution occurred. Thus crowdsource \ system designers should consider imposing quid-pro-quo \ type policies that concentrate on fewer users, but makes \ them more productive.

column3: To authorize or not authorize: helping users make sense of access policies in organizations
column9: Pooya Jaferian, Hootan Rashtian, Konstantin Beznosov
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Privacy/access control/trust; Other domain-specific support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: This paper addresses the problem of sense making of a complex access policy in an organizational context. We performed two studies to understand and address the problem. In the first study, we explored the access review activity and identified its challenges through a series of semi-structured interviews with security practitioners. Interviews revealed that sense making of access policy requires understanding of the activity context including information about the users, their job, and their access rights, and the history of them. Based on the results of the first study, we modeled access review in the activity theory framework, and used activity theory guidelines to design a new user interface named AuthzMap. We then asked 12 participants with HCI background to perform heuristic evaluation of the interfaces and compared the number and severity of the reported usability problems between three interfaces. Our results show that AuthzMap contained fewer problems than the two existing interfaces and improved the visibility activity context.

column3: A comparison Study: How Do People Communicate Through Social Network?
column9: Ke Ke Cai
column100: Social network analysis
column101: This paper presents a comparison study to identify the communication patterns of people through different social connections. Advances in technology have brought many communication channels for people in daily life, like E-mail, blogs/micro-blog and mobile telecommunication etc. Now and in the future it is going to be critical that people use multiple channels of communication to reach others. The understanding of people's choice to communication channels is becoming quite important. In this paper, we specifically selected two of the most significant channels as the objects for comparison. One is online social network, e.g., Twitter as representative of such networks, and another is mobile telecommunication. The corresponded social network is therefore constructed for each communication channel. Based on it, we implement a series of investigation, including temporal analysis, geographical analysis and topological analysis. Generally, what we have found in this study is that people's communication through different channels shows the differences in various aspects.  \

column3: Creating Interdisciplinary Tangible Interaction Design Practice: A Framework with Material Imagination
column9: Rung-Huei Liang, Wenn-Chieh Tsai
column15: National Taiwan University of Science and Technology
column100: E-Learning and Education; User experience/interaction design
column101: Although tangible interaction has become an interdisciplinary design practice, respective curricula are often designed by educators from different disciplines based on some specific combinations of epistemologies, methodologies, and frameworks. Moreover, it appears that learners from different backgrounds also interpret tangible interaction with their own paradigms. This paper argues that intentionally developing students’ epistemological awareness as well as materializing common imagination from different perspectives will facilitate interdisciplinary collaboration. A tangible interaction curriculum is designed to guide students through a process of building epistemic artifacts for discourse and dialogically criticizing the texture of a tangible interaction design. A set of shared design language, encompassing material, expression, function, and form, enables imaginative while focused communication fluently. Students’ work shows a designerly way as well as an engineering way of knowing in practice and term projects illustrate their articulation for a preferred future through collaborative tangible interaction design.

column3: An Exploration of The Blueprint Model: A Method for Group Decision Making
column9: Jennifer Davidson, Carlos Jensen
column14: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Other domain-specific support
column101: Decisions are made in every corporate team every day. The impact of these decisions is widespread, and a purely emotional decision made early on in a project could severely detriment the ultimate success of a project. We created a visualization tool to aid system-on-a-chip teams to make data-backed decisions about which external intellectual property they should use when planning to design a chip. We then generalize this visualization tool, and entitle it The Blueprint Model. Through a formative investigation, working digital prototype, and a tie to empirical work/theory in visualization and design, The Blueprint Model was developed. The key attributes of The Blueprint Model are interactivity, closeness of mapping, overview+detail, and incorporating a decision-matrix backend. We advocate the use of The Blueprint Model by work groups who are striving to make data-backed decisions about a system that has physical components that can be tied to the real world.

column3: Discovery-Driven Mining of Interesting Patterns in Online Reviews
column9: Min Xie, Shanshan Chen, Pei Li, Naresh Kolloju, Laks Lakshmanan
column100: Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: Mining online user reviews has attracted significant attention from researchers due to \   the huge number of product reviews which can be accessed online. Previous works on \   review mining usually focus on sentiment extraction, on summarizing reviews for a \   product, and on detecting fake reviews. They usually ignore many important facts of the \   review dataset which can only be described using the associated metadata.  In this work, \   we first propose an intuitive cube framework which can facilitate mining the review \   dataset, then we propose an important class of surprising patterns which can be mined \   based on the cube framework. Based on extensive experiments on several real world review \   datasets, we demonstrate the great potential of the proposed surprising patterns which \   can be mined from the dataset.

column3: Remote Social Shopping: Enhancing In-Store Shopping with Social Technologies
column9: Meredith Morris, Kori Inkpen, Gina Venolia
column100: Other domain-specific support; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Crowdsourcing
column101: Consumers shopping in “brick-and-mortar” (non-virtual) stores often use their mobile phones to consult with others about potential purchases. Via a survey (n = 200), we detail current practices in “remote social shopping.” We then consider how emerging social platforms, such as social networking sites and crowd labor markets, could offer rich next-generation remote social shopping experiences. We conducted a field experiment in which shoppers shared photographs of potential purchases via MMS, Facebook, and Mechanical Turk. Paid crowdsourcing, in particular, proved surprisingly useful and influential as a means of augmenting in-store shopping. Based on our findings, we offer design suggestions for next-generation remote social shopping systems.

column3: Properties of Twitter Communication among Teenagers
column9: Gili Rusak
column100: Social network analysis; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: This research identifies unique characteristics of Twitter teenager communities. Data collection codes accessed the Twitter API and analyzed available information from communities of two distinct school districts, ~200 members each. Compared with Twittersphere statistics, the data indicated that teens follow more individuals and reciprocate more friendships than general users. \  Further analysis showed that friendships increase over time and that 50% of a teenager’s followers attend school with him. These results hint that relationships exist both online and offline and are supported by sociology research. Also, Twitter teenager communities are dense with only two degrees of separation. This allows information to flow quickly, making Twitter a news media and a communication tool for adolescents. \  Central users ranked using closeness centrality assist the rapid spread of information. A correlation between number of followers and centrality was found. Many followers and high centrality predict extrovert personalities. Also, the study of homophily of gender showed that females tend to follow more females than males follow males.

column3: Lessons from the Classics: Comparative Case Studies of Open Source Software Peer Review Processes
column9: Jing Wang, Patrick Shih, John Carroll
column100: Collaborative software development; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Recent development of social media enables open source software projects to leverage a larger crowd than they ever accessed, fostering many new projects to emerge and grow. However, as they evolve, projects will face new challenges of engaging contributions and coordinating collaboration, and different projects need to design different socio-technical support to address these challenges. Our study attempts to characterize the differences in collaboration between relatively established open source communities to provide design guidance for emerging open source software projects. We focus our investigation on the core work practices—peer review—of open source software development. By contrasting these processes in Mozilla and Python, we identify their differences of contribution styles, reporting motivations, decision-making processes, division of labor, and uses of tools. We further articulate design implications for OSS projects that are advancing towards their maturity.

column3: “Our Life is the Farm and Farming is Our Life”:  Home-Work Coordination in Organic Farm Families
column9: Gilly Leshed, Maria Håkansson, Joseph 'Jofish' Kaye
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Recent arguments about blurring boundaries between home and work raise issues around coordination of family and work life in everyday activities. In this study, we examine coordination practices in farm families who deliberately interweave home and work. We look at their coordination practices across three dimensions: space, time, and role. In these families, spaces for family and farm work are merged, requiring attention to allocating subspaces on the farm and in the home, with a strong division between indoor and outdoor spaces. Activities follow natural rhythms related to growth and seasons, as well as socially-structured rhythms. Finally, participants play multiple roles simultaneously – farmers, parents, businesspersons – requiring them to allocate responsibilities on the farm based on skills, experiences, preferences, and gender. We conclude by discussing the families’ experiences in the context of home-work split and boundary blurring more generally.

column3: Motivations affecting long-term participation in citizen science projects: A look across three countries
column9: Dana Rotman, Jen Hammock, Jenny Preece, Derek Hansen, Carol Boston, Anne Bowser, Yurong He
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Other domain-specific support
column101: Reliance on volunteer participation for citizen science has become extremely popular in the past decade. Cutting across disciplines, locations, and participation practices, hundreds of thousands of people all over the world are now involved in these studies, and are advancing tasks that scientists cannot accomplish alone. Although existing projects have demonstrated the value of involving volunteers in data collection, few projects have been successful in maintaining volunteers’ continued involvement over long periods of time. Therefore, it is important to understand the temporal nature of volunteers’ motivations and their effect on participation practices, so that effective partnerships between volunteers and scientists can be established. This paper presents case studies of longitudinal participation practices in citizen science in three countries – the United States, India, and Costa Rica. The findings reveal a temporal process of participation, in which initial participation stems in most cases from self-directed motivations. In contrast, long-term participation becomes much more complex and includes both self-directed motivations and collaborative motivations.

column3: Attachment Theory and Facebook Activities
column9: Bumsoo Kang, Sujin Lee, Alejandro Jaimes, Alice Oh
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Social network analysis
column101: Facebook contains a large amount of data which can be used for research on interpersonal behavior patterns. However, there has been almost no research on computationally analyzing Facebook data to predict interpersonal behavior. We begin our inquiry into this problem with attachment theory, which conceptualizes how people form relationships with others. In this paper, we seek to reveal how Facebook users' behavior patterns such as status updates and photo albums are related to attachment style. We describe our dataset of 682 Facebook users, their attachment scale survey results, and their 657,057 posts. We define four key features: social capacity, openness, self-disclosure, and emotional disclosure. By analyzing the two dimensions of attachment, anxiousness and avoidance using the four key features, we find significant correlations between the users' attachment style and their Facebook behaviors. The implication is that a computational analysis of a Facebook user's activities alone can reveal the attachment style of that user without the self-reported survey questionnaire of attachment scale.

column3: YPhone: Bringing Interaction Qualities from Theory to Practice in an Office Context
column9: Wei Liu, Pieter Jan Stappers, Gert Pasman, Jenneke Taal-Fokker
column100: Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; User experience/interaction design; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: With more and more products becoming digital, mobile and networked, paying attention to the qualities of interactions with these products should have is also getting more relevant. While interaction qualities have been addressed in a number of scientific studies, little attention is being paid to their implementation into a real life, everyday context. This paper describes the design and evaluation of a novel office phone, YPhone, which demonstrates the application of a specific set of interaction qualities into the context of office work.

column3: Design Requirements for Interactive Project Maps and the Supporting Information Architecture
column9: Natasa Milic-Frayling, Rachel Jones, Gerard Oleksik, Hans-Christian Jetter
column100: Collaboration architectures; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: A study of a scientific research environment provided an opportunity to explore design requirements for enabling scientists to construct interactive project maps and provide overviews of their work. Through a co-design workshop and a deployment of a technology probe, we explore the support for import, organization, and linking of project resources. Our findings underline the importance of several services that extend the adopted information architectures. The file-based ‘physical’ organization needs to be extended with linked storage to associate individual digital artifacts with multiplicity of their representations used across project maps. The logical organization of digital collections, such as ‘placeless’ information storage, needs to be extended with sophisticated reference resolution service to differentiate between semantic links and access links. The latter reflects the finding that project maps comprise reused content that may be imbedded, linked to, or disconnected from the related digital artifacts. We propose an extendible service-based information architecture that can also enforce diverse content access preferences in a collaborative work environment.

column3: Designing an Interactive Music Stand for Remote Music Tuition
column9: Sam Duffy, Patrick Healey
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; E-Learning and Education; User experience/interaction design; Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing
column101: During the evaluation of an enhanced video conference system for remote music tuition, there was found to be a significant change in interaction between student and tutor, compared to a co-present lesson.  In particular, the fact that the participants no longer shared a music score, but had a separate score in each location, changed the way that they collaborated to maintain lesson flow.  An ethnographic study of one-to-one instrumental lessons suggests that there is an opportunity to create a collaborative interactive space which blends digital artefacts with natural work practice, through the design of a music stand which allows distributed collaboration over a single music score.  This paper highlights some of the differences in interaction observed when the score and participants are separated and proposes a design for an interactive digital music stand for remote music tuition, based on these findings.

column3: Supporting Task Resumption Using Visual Feedback
column9: Yikun Liu, Yuan Jia, Wei Pan, Mark Pfaff
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Workflow management; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: For information workers, maintaining high productivity relies on timely task resumption after interruptions, which are frequent. However, people’s task resumption ability is compromised by disruptive environments and human cognitive limitations. We propose that a helpful intervention is to provide visual feedback about the duration of a suspended task. Results from a controlled study show significantly shorter resumption time by adding visual feedback. Further, using emotionally attachable visual objects in the visualization has the additional benefit of decreasing resumption time without increasing stress. Punishment-oriented persuasion strategies produced faster resumption, but also caused higher stress levels. Combined with other related results, we discuss the implications for design as well directions for future study.

column3: NatureNet: A Model for Crowdsourcing the Design of a Citizen Science Socio-Technical System
column9: Mary Lou Maher, Jenny Preece, Kazjon Grace, Tom Yeh, Carol Boston, Abhijit Pasupuleti
column100: Collaborative software development
column101: Crowdsourcing design has been applied in various areas of graphic design, software design, and product design. This paper draws on those experiences and research in diversity, creativity, and motivation to present a model for crowdsourcing the design of a socio-technical system for a citizen science community. NatureNet is a tabletop device with several client applications available in a nature park setting. Park visitors are encouraged to participate in the design of the tasks and the interaction design as well as collect bio-diversity data. Crowdsourcing design for citizen science of this kind serves two purposes: to increase the motivation to participate and to increase creativity through diversity of design expertise. This paper presents the theory behind our model of crowdsourcing the design of a citizen science socio-technical system, the initial design of NtureNet system, and results from our initial design studies. Our results reinforce our assumptions that crowdsourcing design can introduce more diversity of design ideas and generate enthusiasm for citizen science.

column3: A Study of Positive and Negative Affective Processes in Collaborative Information Seeking
column9: Roberto González-Ibáñez, Chirag Shah
column15: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User experience/interaction design; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Affective processes have long been considered essential in people’s life. Regardless the context, human beings experience different emotions all the time. Despite emotion research conducted in various domains, little is known about the role of affective processes in the information search process, especially when this is carried out in collaboration. This paper presents a study aiming to understand effects, if any, of initial affective processes in collaborative information seeking (CIS). To accomplish this objective, a lab study was conducted. In the study, positive and negative affective states were induced in 135 participants before performing in a precision-oriented search task. Results indicate that positive and negative affective states have short-term implications at the level of information-related behaviors and task perception. Additionally, in collaborative settings, it was found that interactions of participants who start in similar or different affective states have effects in terms of information practices, communication processes, and task perception.

column3: Investigating Impacts of Spatial Configurations for Collaborative Writing
column9: Chirag Shah, Pamela Read, Roberto González-Ibáñez
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Collaboratively seeking and constructing information is becoming an increasingly important activity in our lives. Yet, many important aspects of such common undertakings are still understudied or unclear, including the effect of spatial configuration in information synthesis or writing process. In this paper a lab study is presented that investigates collaborative writing activity as a part of an information seeking project. A total of 60 subjects were used in 30 pairs randomly assigned to one of the three experimental conditions: on a single shared workstation, in the same room with individual computers, and remotely located with text chat. By analyzing the way the collaborative pairs constructed their reports, it was found that those remotely located spent less effort per edit than those in the same room. Separate location discouraged social interactions and boosted the writing efficiency. These differences in various measures across different configurations provide useful guidelines for developing collaborative systems.

column3: Study of Electronic Lab Notebook Design and Practices that Emerged in a Collaborative Scientific Environment
column9: Natasa Milic-Frayling, Rachel Jones, Gerard Oleksik
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Prolific adoption of digital media across scientific fields has led to inevitable transformation of a traditional lab book into an electronic lab notebook (ELN). Research so far has focussed on designing ELN prototypes and learning from their limited deployments. At the same time, a variety of commercially available ELNs have been adopted by industrial and academic laboratories. That provides opportunities for situated research and a deeper understanding of the role that ELNs assumes as an integral part of a scientific environment. In this paper we present a study of ELN design that has emerged as scientists appropriated commercial off-the-shelf note-taking software and adapted it to their work. Through in-situ observations we analysed the interplay between the technology and emerging practices.  Our study revealed a tension that is intrinsic to the digital nature of ELNs: a conflict between the flexibility, fluidity, and low threshold for modifying digital records and the requirement for persistence and consistency. This led to refined requirements and design considerations for ELNs.

column3: Exploring Smartphone Addiction on Campus
column9: Uichin Lee, Yuhwan Kim, Joon-Won Lee, Changhoon Lee, Gahgene Gweon, Junehwa Song, KM Chung, Koji Yatani
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Computer-Mediated Communication; User experience/interaction design
column101: There has been a growing awareness on the negative effects \ of excessive smartphone use or smartphone addiction (e.g., \ conflicts in daily lives). While researchers mostly focused \ on measuring a user’s perceived level of addiction, we find \ that such self-report based psychometric scales are inherently \ limited in explaining what aspects of real usage are pertinent \ to behavioral addiction. After classifying usage motivation \ into social utility (e.g., relationship maintenance) and mood \ management (e.g., information seeking, entertainment, diversion), \ we examine real usage data to deepen our understanding \ on smartphone addiction. Our results show that unlike \ social utility usage, there is a significant relationship between \ mood management usage and smartphone addiction. Finally, \ we discuss the negative impacts of social utility apps such as \ interruption and distraction.

column3: Designing Proximity-Aware Collaborative Interfaces for a Wall-Sized Display
column9: Jakub Dostal, Uta Hinrichs, Per Ola Kristensson, Aaron Quigley
column100: Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Collaborative visualization
column101: In this paper we investigate the potential of proxemic interaction as a means to facilitate collaborative scenarios around large-display information visualisations. With the proliferation of large multi-faceted datasets, a critical question is how to design collaborative environments in which this data can be analysed in an efficient and insightful manner. Exploiting people's movements and distance to the data display and to collaborators, proxemic interaction can potentially support such scenarios in a fluid and seamless way, supporting both tightly coupled collaboration as well as parallel explorations. However, leveraging proxemics in collaborative scenarios is relatively unexplored. We contribute to this area from a technical and a conceptual perspective: (1) We introduce a toolkit that is based on low-cost technology that allows accurate markerless attention-aware tracking of multiple people interacting in front of a display in real-time. (2) We discuss how this toolkit can be applied to support collaborative scenarios around large wall-sized displays.

column3: Drive on My Side of the Road: An Ethnographic Study of Car-Commuters
column9: Nicole Perterer, David Wilfinger, Alexander Meschtscherjakov, Manfred Tscheligi
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Other domain-specific support
column101: Many of us consider time spent on travelling distances from A to B as unproductive and wasteful. In order to design systems that create an enjoyable driving experience, we need a deeper understanding of what people do and want to do while commuting. Current HCI and CSCW researchers put little effort in exploring car-commuters` needs and collaborative aspects of daily commuting. This paper describes an interaction analysis of video and GPS data from 13 journeys recorded in a naturalistic environment to understand some of the drivers’ daily habits and collaborative activities during driving. With our work, we provide suggestions for the design of new social-sensitive and collaborative in-car technologies for commuting, in particular for rush-hour conditions and beyond that enhance an enjoyable driving experience. As a result, we present and discuss three thematic areas: (1) using journey time valuable, (2) smart routing, and (3) “fighting” of daily mileage. Our conclusions provide insights how collaborative in-car technology might support car-commuters` daily collaborative activities such as gaming.

column3: Just Rate It! Gamification as Part of Recommendations
column9: Angelina Ziesemer, Luana Muller, Milene Silveira
column100: User experience/interaction design; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Recommender and Filtering Systems
column101: In attempt to help users in filtering available products, recommender systems are being used by e-commerce systems to try to predict users' preferences and suggest them new products. \ Some recommender system are based in previous ratings and evaluations provided by users to the purchased items. When a new user or a new item is inserted in the recommendation system it can suffer by the so called cold-start problem.  \ However, do you rate the products that you bought? This question and other ones were made to 367 participants by an online survey that aims to identify customer profiles and motivations. Also, we investigated the users engagement in gamified systems and the effects of tangible and intangible rewards in their behavior.  \ This work presents a theoretical framework that provides basis for defining how gamification can be used to encourage ratings and improve user engagement in tasks that benefit user reputation, item reliability and overcome cold-start problem.

column3: TOWARDS A NEW SERIOUS GAME SUPPORTING TEAM COLLABORATION LEARNING
column9: Ikram Bououd, Imed Boughzala
column100: Collaborative software development; E-Learning and Education; Entertainment/games
column101: This paper introduces a new collaborative serious game BestCollab. This game has the distinction of being based on solidarity and collaboration rather than individualism and competition. It puts forward team spirit over the individual one and serves to enhance collaboration skills for players. BestCollab aims to allow teammates to understand the importance of collaboration within a team. This paper positions this game in the space of existing games. Three learning theories have been mobilized in the aim to formulate game objectives, scoring system and rules. The paper related on the game design using a design science approach. The game development follows six main steps of the development of usual software. Finally, we present a collaborative scenario between teammates in the professional context of project management.

column3: You Will Cite This Paper: Structure and Dynamics of Coauthorship, Citation, and Impact within CSCW
column9: Brian Keegan, Dan Horn, Thomas Finholt, Joseph 'Jofish' Kaye
column100: Social network analysis; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: CSCW has stabilized as an interdisciplinary venue for computer, information, cognitive, and social scientists but has also undergone significant changes in its format in recent years. This paper uses methods from social network analysis and bibliometrics to re-examine the structures of CSCW a decade after its last systematic analysis. Using data from the ACM Digital Library, we analyze changes in structures of coauthorship and citation between 1986 and 2013. Statistical models reveal significant but distinct patterns between papers and authors in how brokerage and closure in these networks affects impact as measured by citations and downloads. Specifically, impact is unduly influenced by structural position, such that ideas introduced by those in the core of the CSCW community (e.g., elite researchers) are advantaged over those introduced by peripheral participants (e.g., newcomers).  This finding is examined in the context of recent changes to the CSCW conference that may have the effect of upseting the preference for contributions from the core.

column3: Collaborative Reflection: Technology Integration and Community Building in a Nurse-Managed Clinic
column9: Charlotte Tang, Zoe cheung, Yunan Chen
column24: Weill Cornell Medical College, Cornell University
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: We report how a nurse-managed primary care clinic prepared for an impending Electronic Medical Record (EMR) system. EMR adoption is complex and challenging. It requires not only the system deployment, but also an integration of the system into the reality of patient care practices that includes its social and technological environment. While most previous work focus on the adoption and adaptation of the system after EMR implementation, we found clinicians in our study site engaged in proactive and collaborative reflections in order to identify and address current workflow deficiencies and be better prepared for the upcoming EMR rollout. Doing so not only helped clinicians better understand the operation, but also unexpectedly helped build a stronger and a more cohesive community through reflecting on each other’s work. We argue that collaborative reflection can help enhance the technology readiness of a health organization and its staff, particularly for an EMR system.

column3: Attachment to work groups increases loyalty on Mechanical Turk: Exploring bond- versus identity-based pathways to attachment formation
column9: Yla Tausczik, Laura Dabbish, Robert Kraut
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Computer-Mediated Communication; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Crowdsourcing
column101: Researchers and theorists have proposed that feelings of attachment to subgroups within a larger online community or site can increase users’ loyalty to the site. They have identified two types of attachment to these groups, with distinct causes and consequences. With bond-based attachment, people feel connections to other group members, while with identity-based attachment they feel connections to the group as a whole. In two experiments we show that these feelings of attachment to subgroups do increase commitment to the larger community.  Communication with other people in a subgroup but not simple awareness of them increases attachment to the larger community. By varying how the communication is structured, between dyads or with all group members simultaneously, the experiments show that bond and identity-based attachment have different causes. But the experiments show no evidence that bond and identity attachment have different consequences. We consider both theoretical and methodological reasons why the consequences of bond-based and identity-based attachment are so similar.

column3: Exploring Physical Movement as a Sketching tool in Design education
column9: Helena Tobiasson, Anders Hedman, Jan Gulliksen
column15: Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm SWEDEN
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Research shows that the lack of movement in modern \ society is negative for our health. Can interaction design \ help to remedy this situation? This paper presents an \ explorative case study on considering physical movement \ as a design dimension for product and systems design. In a \ series of workshops thirty students explored how their \ bodies and physical movement could be used as a creative \ component in the design of interactive systems. They \ experienced their tasks through physical movement \ sketching, and reflected on movement as a design \ dimension to inspire new interactive solutions for health \ and well-being.

column3: Situated Action as a Model for Understanding Health Care Provider Workflows
column9: Christopher Schaefbauer, Katie Siek
column100: Medical and health support; Workflow management; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: Although context drives behavior and technology use, we must understand what constitutes context in healthcare. We studied Electronic Health Record (EHR) use in a medium-sized primary care clinic to better understand context within this setting. Despite the complexity of context, we were able to distill characteristics that can be leveraged to provide a better understanding of health care workflows and how to design technologies that support patient care. In our research we found that context often depended the providers’ situation or the patient being examined, which implies that there are two types of context – patient-centric and provider-centric – that affect provider technology use. In past clinical workflow analyses, the CSCW community has tended to assume that all the providers in a healthcare practice use the EHR similarly, however we found individual differences in EHR workflow. We provide a careful analysis of differences among a set of providers using the same EHR and outline archetypes that can improve our ability to design for individual use.

column3: Of Natures and Gamers: Lessons from Designing a Mobile App for Citizen Science
column9: Anne Bowser, Derek Hansen, Jenny Preece, Jen Hammock, Yurong He, Carol Boston, Jocelyn Raphael, Matthew Reid, Ryan Gamett
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Location-based and context-aware computing; Entertainment/games; Crowdsourcing
column101: Increasingly, game elements are being added to citizen sci-ence projects in order to attract new participants. However, the similarities and differences between gamers and citizen scientists are poorly understood, making it hard to design systems that appeal to both groups. This paper examines the similarities and difference between two user groups called “gamers” (i.e., game and technology enthusiasts) and “na-tures” (i.e., citizen scientists and plant enthusiasts) in the context of Floracaching, a new gamified mobile app de-signed to collect plant phenology data. Results are based on 6 co-design sessions conducted with 58 players who used Floracaching prototypes. We identify the most salient moti-vations (discovery, education, nature, social, recognition, and science), describe the most appealing activities for each group, and identify 3 key differences in how they relate to the app: gamers desire more guidance, while natures prefer autonomy; gamers and natures integrate Floracaching into their lives differently; and gamers seek out general chal-lenge while natures prefer to use their domain knowledge.

column3: Perceptions of Presidential Candidates' Personalities in Twitter
column9: Sanmitra Bhattacharya, Padmini Srinivasan, G.R. Boynton
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Social network analysis; Crowdsourcing
column101: Political sentiment-analysis using Twitter has captured wide interest in recent years. In social-media research, opinion on politicians is typically divided into a positive, negative or neutral stance. Our goal is to mine public political opinion at higher resolution. Hence we study opinions related to the personality traits of politicians. Our second goal is to contribute a novel retrieval-based approach for tracking public perception of personality using Gough's Adjective Checklist(ACL) of 110 terms describing key traits. We employ several high-precision search templates built from the ACL and run these on an 18-month span of Twitter-posts on Obama and Romney. We find that perceptions of personality traits vary widely between the two individuals. For example, Romney is perceived as more of an achiever and Obama is perceived as somewhat more friendly. When aggregated into 14 broad personality dimensions we find, for example, Obama rates far higher than Romney on the moderation dimensions and less on the Machiavellian dimension.

column3: Schema-mediated Crowd Idea Generation
column9: Lixiu Yu, Aniket Kittur, Robert Kraut
column100: Crowdsourcing
column101: Contest-oriented crowd innovation sites are prevalent and offer accelerated innovation through a large and diverse pool of participants, but are also highly inefficient and potentially demotivating for participants. We propose a process based on models of analogy and schema induction to promote more effective crowd innovation. This schema induction and idea generation process is amenable to being broken down into capacity-limited chunks that benefit from the diversity of the crowd while mitigating issues such as lack of expertise.  In four experiments we show that: 1) crowds can generate good ideas from schemas; 2) crowd-generated schemas can lead a subsequent crowd to generate good ideas; 3) crowds can generate good schemas from examples; and 4) the steps in the schema-mediated idea generation process can be implemented by multiple crowds. Our results have implications for improving crowd creativity and building systems allowing indirect crowd collaboration.

column3: Mediated Citizenship: Past Conceptualizations, Future Trajectories
column9: Ingrid Erickson, Nassim Jafarinaimi
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Location-based and context-aware computing; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Crowdsourcing
column101: Emerging from a range of recent events and developments, including the widespread usage of social media during US Elections and Arab Spring, is a proliferation of design and research programs focused on technologies that foster civic engagement. Looking closely, however, we observe that digital applications that have emerged from these programs are supportive of a set of distinct, but somewhat limited, set of civic activities. In this paper, we report the preliminary findings from a research study aimed to answer the following queries: What are the common conceptualizations of citizenship that are being considered in design of new technologies? Are the affordances of networking technologies, in general, and mobile devices, in particular, privileging certain forms or conceptions of citizenship? Our analysis is based on a classification of recent mobile technology designs drawn from the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Digital Library, JSTOR and Google Scholar.

column3: Local News Chatter: Augmenting Community News by Aggregating Hyperlocal Microblog Content in a Tag Cloud
column9: Kyungsik (Keith) Han, Patrick Shih, John Carroll
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Crowdsourcing
column101: Being aware of local community information is critical to maintaining civic awareness and engagement. Utilizing technological affordances, such as providing online news and microblogs content, to create and disseminate community information has long been studied. However local community online interactions often fail to exceed the threshold of community perception, and people do not tend to consider microblogs content as a meaningful or informative stream. Local News Chatter (LNC) was designed to address these challenges by augmenting community news and aggregating hyperlocal microblog content. To empirically understand user experiences and design implications of LNC, we ran an exploratory user study with 15 participants. The study results highlight that LNC makes diverse local community information more visible and successfully utilizes microblog content as community-oriented information. It also helps to increase one’s community awareness and shows the potential for encouraging social interaction and engagement.

column3: Mind the Map: The Impact of Culture and Economic Affluence on Crowd-Mapping Behaviours
column9: Giovanni Quattrone, Afra Mashhadi, Licia Capra
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: Crowd-mapping is a form of collaborative work that empowers citizens to collect and share geographic knowledge. OpenStreetMap (OSM) is a successful example of such paradigm, where the goal of building and maintaining an accurate global map of the changing world is being accomplished by means of local contributions made by over 1.2M citizens. While OSM has been subject to many country-specific studies,  the impact of national culture and economic affluence on users' participation  has been so far unexplored. In this work, we systematically study the link between them: we  characterise OSM users in terms of who they are, how they contribute, during what period of time, and across what geographic areas. We find strong correlations between these characteristics and national culture factors (e.g., power distance, individualism, pace of life, self expression), and well as Gross Domestic Product per capita. Based on these findings, we discuss how to design crowd-mapping services that account for cross-cultural differences.

column3: Friending Your Way up the Ladder: Connecting MMOG Behaviors with Offline Leadership
column9: Li Lu, Cuihua Shen, Dmitri Williams
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; Distributed/virtual teams; Entertainment/games
column101: In what ways do the online behaviors of wizards and ogres map to players’ actual leadership status in the offline world? What can we learn from players’ experience in MMOGs to advance our understanding of leadership, especially E-leadership? Part of a larger agenda in the emerging field empirically testing the “mapping” between the online and offline worlds, this study aims to tackle a central issue in E-leadership literature: how technology and technology mediated communications have transformed leadership-diagnostic traits and behaviors. We surveyed over 18,000 players of a popular MMOG and also collected matched behavioral data of a subset of survey respondents over a four-month period. Our results indicate that individuals’ relationship-oriented behaviors in the virtual world are particularly relevant to leadership in voluntary organizations, while their task-oriented behaviors are marginally linked to offline leadership status in voluntary organizations, but not in companies.

column3: “Here I am, now pay me!”: Contextual Integrity and Incentives in Location Sharing
column9: Luke Hutton, Tristan Henderson, Apu Kapadia
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Mobile and embedded devices; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: Location-sharing services such as Foursquare and Facebook are both popular and well-studied in the research literature. Businesses have employed such services to enable mobile and location-aware advertising. More recently, a new class of ‘in- centivised location sharing’ services have arisen, where users are given a direct monetary incentive to share their location with a business or their social network. These incentives may introduce new privacy concerns or violations. \  \ This paper presents the first study of incentivised location sharing. We use Nissenbaum’s framework of contextual in- tegrity to determine whether financial incentive perturbs ex- pectations of location-sharing systems, constituting a risk to privacy. A user study (n=17) shows users are more willing to share personal information with advertisers in exchange for incentives, and that disclosure rates can be mitigated by pro- viding feedback about the flows of information. Our findings indicate that incentivised location sharing may violate con- textual integrity and risk personal privacy.

column3: Media Choices in Emergency Response Management
column9: Sherri Condon, Robinson Jason
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; User experience/interaction design; Social network analysis; Crowdsourcing
column101: The communications of emergency response managers were tracked during simulated catastrophic events at a univerity campus in the Washington, D.C. region. Local, state, and federal response managers interacted with each other and with students using a variety of media in order to investigate the utility of new communication channels for emergency response management. All the participants could interact using a Twitter-like platform and a portal built with Ushahidi crowd-sourcing software. The emergency managers could also use a chat interface that included private instant messaging, telephone, and the county's existing emergency web portal. Their media choices were analyzed along with the functions of their communications, and the patterns that emerged are described and quantified.

column3: Checking In and Hanging Out: A Social Approach to Fitness Interventions for Adolescents
column9: Andrew Miller, Jessica Pater, Elizabeth Mynatt
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Mobile and embedded devices; Medical and health support
column101: Social fitness interventions hold great promise for adolescents, but existing systems tend to focus on exertion interfaces, engaging small cliques, or large-scale competition. We designed a pervasive fitness intervention to test the power of indirect social comparison, collaborative gaming and blended online/offline experience in motivating adolescents to increase their physical activity. We describe a 4-week deployment of our system with 42 US middle school students. Our system—StepStream—improved participants’ attitudes towards physical fitness and increased their sense of social support for fitness. This system represents a new model for school-based physical activity systems, one that lets youth interact with each other around fitness, rather than strictly about fitness, and blends online and offline interaction. We suggest this model as a way to promote and sustain healthy levels of physical activity in adolescents.

column3: The Rise and Fall of Crowd Work Anonymity: Privacy, Regulation, and Ethics on Mechanical Turk
column9: Matthew Lease, Jessica Hullman, Stephen Wolfson, Michael Bernstein, Jeffrey Bigham, Juho Kim, Walter Lasecki
column24: University of Michigan School of Information
column100: Crowdsourcing; Computer-Mediated Communication; Privacy/access control/trust; Legal/historical/philosophical aspects
column101: Many MTurk users were recently surprised to realize that Worker and Requester IDs link to public Amazon profiles. This prompted us to undertake a broad study of the rise and fall of anonymity on MTurk across technological, social, regulatory, and ethical considerations. Our analysis reveals a host of tangled socio-technical issues that fostered and reinforced widespread misconception of anonymity, ultimately resulting in inadvertent exposure of personally identifying information (PII). We discuss the ramifications such exposure has for different crowdsourcing stakeholder groups, potential remedies, and how current patterns of use may change as a result. We identify several general lessons to reduce risk of more such incidents recurring, and we offer relevant recommendations to the different stakeholder groups.

column3: Understanding the Work and Use of Technology in Crowdfunding
column9: Julie Hui, Michael Greenberg, Elizabeth Gerber
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Crowdfunding is an increasingly popular way for entrepreneurs to solicit and acquire resources without having to rely on traditional funding mechanisms such as banks and angel investing. Similar to current research efforts in entrepreneurial and crowd work, we need to better understand how crowdfunding project creators leverage the support of a distributed audience to introduce their project idea into society. We perform a qualitative study of 47 project creators from three popular crowdfunding platforms. Our results suggest that project creators carry out five main types of work—preparing the campaign material, testing the campaign material, publicizing the project, following through with project goals, and contributing back knowledge to the community. In this work, they are challenged to learn new skills, manage publicity, and scale production. Our findings identify specific pain points, technologies used, and opportunities within the crowdfunding process to inform the design of crowdfunding support tools and systems.

column3: Action brokering platforms: Facilitating local engagement with ACTion Alexandria
column9: Derek Hansen, Jes A. Koepfler, Paul Jaeger, John Bertot
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Crowdsourcing
column101: Local communities are turning to new online platforms to help motivate and coordinate local volunteerism and problem solving. Inspired by the American barn raising tradition, ACTion Alexandria is designed to help local residents and service-oriented organizations collectively take action to address pressing local needs. This paper introduces “action brokering” as a new theoretical concept and frames it within a year-long evaluation of ACTion Alexandria. A mixed-method, case study approach was used to understand how social practices, roles, and technologies helped or hindered successful action brokering. Successes were attributed to a competent community manager, institutional support from an existing nonprofit brokering agency, effective use of social media, a synergistic partnership with nonprofits that helped grow each group’s donor network, and emphasis on promoting immediate actions and soliciting ideas for Community Challenges among residents and nonprofit organizations.

column3: The Quantified Us: Levers and Barriers to Sharing Personal Data for Social Good
column9: Masha Safina, Maggee Bond, Kim Erwin
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Privacy/access control/trust; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: How might we transform our personal data into a shared resource for social good? Networked devices and the Internet enable individuals to share increasing amounts of personal data and become active participants in a growing personal information economy. The question we investigate here is how might users share this personal data so as to create new value not only for the individual, but also for communities at large? We call this concept of community-based personal data sharing The Quantified Us. This paper explores the levers and barriers to data sharing among individuals. Specifically, we examine four key issues—control, trust, motivation and value—that emerged from our qualitative user study on self-trackers. Based on findings from this investigation, we propose a new platform model to enable the Quantified Us—one that generates new value from the aggregation and sharing of personal data and in turn supports the growth of communities.

column3: Shared Virtual Desktops
column9: Joona Laukkanen, Joona Laukkanen, Wouter Walmink, Saila Ovaska
column100: Workflow management; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Distributed/virtual teams; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: We propose the concept of shared virtual desktops as a general solution to a number of problems related to remote collaboration and cooperation involving the use of arbitrary computer software. According to the proposed form of desktop sharing design, enabling multiple users independent viewports to an infinite virtual desktop could be used to support computer users in cooperating on a range of scenarios where participants to a desktop sharing session would benefit from being able to work with different applications; establish a shared working context with collaborators; and be able to monitor activities of collaborators. We also report the high-level findings of a proof-of-concept experiment.

column3: Crowdfunding Science: Inviting the Public to Participate
column9: Julie Hui, Amy Laurin, Lauren Tindal, Elizabeth Gerber
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Science research is crucial for the advancement of society. Internet technologies are making it easier for the public to become involved and aware of scientific work, and scientists are becoming increasingly more interested in sharing what they are doing with the public. However, there have been few avenues for the public to become involved in scientific research outside participating in large-scale citizen science projects. In this study, we analyze the recent Internet phenomenon of crowdfunding science. We interviewed 19 scientists in the crowdfunding science community to understand 1) Why are scientists motivated to crowdfund? and 2) How can we design crowdfunding platforms and support tools to help more scientists encourage public support for science projects? We find that scientists are motivated to crowdfund in order to get resources, engage the public, and establish expertise. We conclude with a discussion and design implications on how to encourage more scientists to engage the public in their research through crowdfunding.

column3: Evaluation of a Computer-Assisted Interview for Communicating with Children about Emotions
column9: Katie Atkinson, Phil Jimmieson, Floriana Grasso
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Home/family/intimacy support; Medical and health support
column101: In this paper we provide an overview and evaluation of an implemented system that provides a computer-assisted interview for children and vulnerable adults receiving psychological therapy. The system implements a ``triadic interview'' interaction since it is used as a focus point between the child and the clinician, whose dialogue is mediated by the tool. The tool helps children express their feelings and experiences, by making use of an ``emotion palette'' and a set of sub-tools developed on paper by children and transformed into computer-based depictions. The tool is fully developed and is currently used by a significant number of clinicians worldwide.  Extensive feedback concerning its use in practice provides us with evaluation data that we  report here.  The results indicate that the tool provides a level of support to the end users that improves upon traditional, non computer-based methods of interaction within the therapy setting. \

column3: Geographical and Organizational Distances in Enterprise Crowdfunding
column9: Michael Muller, Werner Geyer, Todd Soule
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Crowdsourcing
column101: We analyze enterprise crowdfunding as a series of opportunities for voluntary or unplanned collaborations. In an enterprise crowdfunding experiment, we study the influence of “distance” on collaborations. Using concepts from Social Identity Theory, we define “distance” in terms of multiple identity facets: of geography, of formal corporate structure, and of less formal group/team working relations. We combine quantitative and self-report data to show how each type of distance has an influence on the likelihood of voluntary collaborations, and we show their “superadditive” combination. We propose new questions for theory, and we consider how our results can lead to new features and technologies to enhance voluntary collaborations in organizations.

column3: Upvoting Hurricane Sandy: Event-Based News Production on a Social News Site, reddit
column9: Alex Leavitt, Joshua Clark
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Crowdsourcing
column101: This paper presents a study of event-based news production in a popular social news site, reddit.com. We use the case study of Hurricane Sandy and reddit’s topical community /r/sandy to examine how a social news platform shapes how and what users produce as relevant news content for an ephemeral event. Through content coding and data analysis, we provide topologies of content and users to describe how levels and types of participation frame news in /r/sandy and contribute to the shifting role that the subreddit plays, from information sharing and citizen journalism to humor and social support. This study also examines how networked gatekeeping structures various dynamics around what kind of information can become relevant in a social news setting. We find that information shared in a social news setting focused more on perspective-based citizen journalism than official news reports. Also, while /r/sandy users were more experienced compared to average reddit users, user experience did not affect the types of content they shared.

column3: Understanding Factors Influencing Review Quality
column9: Saeideh Bakhshi, Partha Kanuparthy
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: People increasingly rely on online recommendation communities to make  \ everyday choices. In order for an online recommendation community to be effective to both users and businesses, it is important to understand what constitutes a high quality review, and how to maximize quality of reviews and member contribution in the community. In this paper, we study Yelp, a large \ online recommendation community to answer these questions. We analyze \ about 230K reviews; and member interaction (votes) with these reviews in the Yelp community. We find several aspects of an online recommendation community that can affect the perceived quality: active and regular members are the highest contributors to good quality recommendations, longer reviews have higher chances of being popular in the community, there are unique features of member contributed content that are perceived as useful, cool or funny by users of the community, and the useful reviews are the early ones on each topic (or business). Our findings have important implications on the design of online recommendation communities.

column3: Reviewing versus Doing: Learning and Performance in Crowd Assessment
column9: Haiyi Zhu, Steven Dow, Robert Kraut, Aniket Kittur
column100: Crowdsourcing; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: In modern crowdsourcing markets, requesters face the challenge of training and managing large transient workforces. Requesters can hire peer workers to review others’ work, but the value may be marginal, especially if the reviewers lack requisite knowledge. Our research explores if and how workers learn and improve their performance in a task do-main by serving as peer reviewers. Further, we investigate whether peer reviewing may be more effective in teams where the reviewers can reach consensus through discussion. An online between-subjects experiment compares the tradeoffs of reviewing versus producing work using three different organization strategies: working individually, working in an interactive team, and aggregating individuals into nominal groups. The results show that workers who review others’ work perform better on subsequent tasks than workers who just produce. We also find that interactive reviewer teams outperform individual reviewers on all quality measures. However, aggregating individual reviewers into nominal groups produces better quality assessments than interactive teams, except in task domains where discussion helps overcome individual misconceptions.

column3: Evaluation of Verbal Communication and Soundscape of a Collaborative Training Simulator
column9: Ebba Thora Hvannberg, Gyda Halldorsdottir, Jan Rudinsky
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Voice communication is vital for collaboration between first responders and commanders during crisis management and its training. To decrease cost, training can take place in a virtual environment instead in a real one. It is non-trivial to build and evaluate a virtual environment for training complex command, where voice communication, often contaminated by sound, is a large part of the context.  To understand the method resources required, this paper presents a case study of a usability evaluation of a training simulator for crisis response. Six employees of an airport fire and rescue squad were asked to carry out collaborative tasks. The evaluation protocol was analyzed for usability problems and mechanics of collaboration. These method resources were assessed and compared. The results show that while traditional usability evaluation and mechanics of collaboration complement each other nicely, additional method resources are needed for analysis of soundscapes and verbal communication in noisy environments.

column3: Help Is on the Way: Patterns of Responses to Resource Requests on Facebook
column9: Cliff Lampe, Rebecca Gray, Andrew Fiore, Nicole Ellison
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: Research suggests that social network sites can facilitate the exchange of requests for assistance, such as seeking recommendations or asking for favors.  Patterns of responsiveness to requests for help are important because they have the potential to affect users’ overall satisfaction with the experience of using SNSs, signal social grooming functions that are an essential part of relationship maintenance, and affect the generation and cultivation of social capital. In this paper, we study a corpus of public status updates posted to Facebook (N=7,466) in order to identify patterns of activity around and linguistic characteristics of status updates that attempt to mobilize resources from the poster’s Facebook network. We find that posts attempting to mobilize help from their network receive more comments than non-mobilization attempts and that those comments were contributed more quickly.  The type of support requested (e.g. a recommendation vs. a favor) also impacted engagement with original posts, ultimately signaling new opportunities for SNSs to support these help-seeking behaviors and social capital conversion.

column3: Self Determination and Long-term Participation in User-Generated Content Communities
column9: Donghee Yvette Wohn, Cliff Lampe
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: While it is known that social factors contribute to participation in online communities, less is known about the underlying psychology explaining long-term engagement.  In Study 1, analysis of in-depth interviews with 30 long-term users of Everything2.com, a 12-year old online community, examined the role of psychological well-being and evolution of motivations over time. Study 2, a survey of 144 Everything2 users, incorporated self-determination theory to test the relationship between basic psychological needs and motivations of users of varying membership length. Results showed that psychological needs and motivations are more complex than the theory suggests; the effect of certain psychological need factors on motivation was moderated by how long a person had been a member of the community. Balance of psychological need fulfillment was a consistent predictor of motivation. Consistent with the theory, social motivation, which had the highest correlation with psychological need fulfillment, was the strongest predictor of membership length.

column3: Awkward Encounters of an “Other” Kind:  Collective Self-Presentation and Face Threat on Facebook
column9: Eden Litt, Erin Spottswood, Jeremy Birnholtz, Jeff Hancock, Madeline Smith, Lindsay Reynolds
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: While we tend to think of self-presentation as a process executed by the self, reputation management on social network sites, like Facebook, is increasingly viewed as a collective endeavor. Information other users share about one another can have significant impact on impression formation, and can sometimes threaten one’s self-presentation goals, making the process challenging. These challenges are further exacerbated because social network sites tend to obscure the audience cues on which the self-presentation process typically depends. However, we know little about the nature of other-generated face threats and the ways that people perceive them. Using an online survey of 150 Facebook users, we report on what users consider to be other-generated face threats and how they feel after experiencing them. Results suggest that many face threats result from a lack of care or misunderstanding of another person’s audience and/or self-presentation goals, or a fear of creating an unwanted association with another Facebook user. Experience of these threats is affected by both individual and situational attributes.

column3: How the Grassroots use Social Media to Discuss Political Candidates
column9: Karissa McKelvey, Joeseph DiGrazia, Fabio Rojas
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social network analysis
column101: Online social networks are an important setting for understanding the intersection of online communities and offline political processes. This paper analyzes the different ways that people discuss elections on Twitter. Using data from a random sample of over 500 million tweets, we examine the differences between users who employ various strategies to talk about U.S. 2010 Congressional candidates. We show that users who simply include the text of a candidate's name exhibit different behaviors than those who use platform-specific mechanisms. Furthermore, candidates' free-text name mentions correlates with their vote tallies, while @mentions and hashtags do not. The findings in this paper suggest that users who use familiar, low-skill free-text strategies reflect the grassroots political sentiment that determines the course of elections. This research has a methodological impact for research investigating the dynamic between online discourse and real-world behavior. We also believe these findings have an impact for building systems that leverage online discourse surrounding elections.

column3: A Cost Efficient Real-Time Vehicle Tracking System
column9: Rohit Minni
column14: School of Information Technology and Engineering
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: The transportation system plays a vital role in today’s world. With the rapid growth in the number of vehicles, the traffic overhead is increasing day by day. People always look for ways to save time while travelling. Due to lack of necessary infrastructure it is difficult to obtain real-time access to a vehicle’s location and its timings in case of public bus transportation systems. Addressing this problem, in this paper I present an innovative methodology to provide real-time updates of the vehicle’s location to users through the use of cost efficient smartphones equipped with Global Positioning System that are widely available in the market. I will present the implementation of the same system for use in various public and private sectors like for real-time bus tracking, taxi tracking, tracking people, tracking fleet of vehicles for logistics and other companies.  I will also present how the data collected can be used for traffic estimation and other applications of implementing the system in vehicles.

column3: Creating and Sharing Records of Massively Multiplayer Online Game Play: Practices and Attitudes
column9: Frank Shipman, Catherine Marshall
column100: Entertainment/games; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: Online games offer multiple ways for players to interact. Recordings of these interactions are being created and used for multiple purposes. Gameplay recordings raise ownership issues similar to those arising from records of other online media.
