This paper presents an analysis of the attitudes and practices of 241 online gamers, 36% of whom reported recording gameplay and 29% of whom reported watching or accessing records of gameplay. A series of scenarios determine what features of the parties involved, the recordings and their use affect perceived rights. Players are more sensitive to the recording and reuse of in-game textual communication than they are to recordings of avatar activity. Particularly negative reactions were elicited by enabling search over textual communication and the inclusion of such communication in advertisements. Players were more skeptical of institutions such as the Library of Congress providing access to such archives than are users of other online media although 50 year embargos on access brought attitudes in line with those for other media.

column3: Social Inﬂuences on Secure Development Tool Adoption
column9: Shundan Xiao, Jim Witschey, Emerson Murphy-Hill
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments
column101: Security tools can help developers build more secure software systems by improving the efficiency of detecting or fixing security vulnerabilities in source code.  \ However, developers do not always use these tools. \ In this paper, we investigate the key social factors that impact developers' adoption decisions, based on a multidisciplinary field of research called diffusion of innovations. \ We conducted 43 one-on-one interviews with professional software developers, and our results suggest a number of ways in which the probability of security tool adoption depends on developers' social environments and on the channels through which information about tools is communicated. \ For example, we found that some developers trust developers with strong reputations on the Internet as much as they trust their colleagues for information about security tools.

column3: Approach a Virtual World with activities for children with speech disorders
column9: Erika Quintero Rivas
column14: Center for Research, Development and Innovation in Information Technology and Communications
column100: Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Social Computing and Social Navigation; User experience/interaction design
column101: In the society often lends more attention to conditions in which endanger the lives of people, however they may suffer not more severe may have a significant impact on the life of them. Speech disorders are an example of this conditions, that if give proper attention on time might mostly be corrected and to avoid in the future other problems that influence the development as a person into society. Taking advantage of the technology has been conceived the idea of creating a virtual world to be used as a resource to supporting the therapies for speech disorders. The aim of this paper is to present advances about 2D virtual world for children with speech disorders. It includes developed as a response to the needs of complement the traditional therapies with specific activities for dyslalia in response to the challenges of use and benefits of virtual world for supporting this affections.

column3: What Do Teens Ask Their Online Social Networks? Social Search Practices among High School Students
column9: Andrea Forte, Michael Dickard, Rachel Magee, Denise Agosto
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: The majority of American teens use social network sites (SNSs) but little is known about how they leverage their online social networks to find information. As part of a larger study on social media and information behaviors, we surveyed 158 high school students to learn about their online question asking and answering practices. We describe which teens are most likely to ask and answer questions, what they ask about, on which sites they ask questions, and how useful they perceive SNSs to be as information sources. When possible, we draw comparisons with findings in the literature about adult populations. We contextualize these findings using early insights from interviews and focus groups with 70 teens and discuss how perceptions of audience, privacy concerns, and self-presentation all play a role in teens use of SNSs to ask and answer questions.

column3: Hybrid Media Consumption: How Tweeting During a Televised Political Debate Influences the Vote Decision
column9: Misa Maruyama, Heather Faucett, Sara Douglas, Scott Robertson, Bryan Semaan
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: An increasing number of people are using microblogs to broadcast their thoughts in real time as they watch televised political events. Microblogging Social Network Sites (SNSs) such as Twitter generate a parallel stream of information and opinion. It is presumed that the additional content enhances the viewing experience. But our experiment explores the validity of this assumption. We studied how tweeting or passively observing Twitter during a debate influenced affect, recall and vote decision. For most measures, participants’ average feeling toward the candidates did not depend on Twitter activity. But Twitter activity did matter in a mock vote. People who tweeted changed their voting choice to reflect the majority sentiment on Twitter. The paper’s contribution is an analysis of the user’s cognitive and affective experience during political deliberation.

column3: Privacy Practices in Collaborative Environments: A Study of Emergency Department Staff
column9: Alison Murphy, Madhu Reddy, Heng Xu
column14: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column32: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Medical and health support
column101: Information privacy research has long focused on the individual. Yet most organizations are highly collaborative where team work is the norm. To examine privacy practices in collaborative settings, we conducted an ethnographic study of a highly collaborative and information-intensive setting – an emergency department (ED). We found that ED staff members used various privacy practices in their daily work. We discuss the tension between work practices and organizational privacy policies, as well as the challenge of assigning accountability for ensuring information privacy of information in these environments.

column3: Speech Therapy Apps: Trust and Evidence in an Online Knowledge-Building Community
column9: Selina Sutton, John Vines, Roisin McNaney, Mary Webster, Patrick Olivier
column100: Medical and health support; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: It is becoming common for mobile touch-screen devices to be used as part of the daily clinical practices of health practitioners. This is particularly so for Speech and Language Therapy (SLT), with a wide variety of apps currently available for use as therapy tools. There is, however, a scarcity of research examining the efficacy of using these technologies in SLT. This has led to the growth of online content, namely blogs, where SLTs share their knowledge and experience of using apps as therapy tools, compiling their own resources through collaborative learning. We analyse the content of these blogs using quantitative and qualitative methods in order to gain insights into SLTs’ appropriation of both apps and blogs. We reflect from our findings current tensions surrounding the use of these technologies—tensions that are pervasive across other health care professions and contexts. We propose three design implications for digital tools to aid this community of practice in their co-operative work.

column3: Fade to Block?: Longitudinal and Retrospective Studies of the Temporal Aspects of Facebook Sharing
column9: Blase Ur, Michelle Mazurek, Manya Sleeper, Lorrie Cranor, Lujo Bauer, Saranga Komanduri, Michael Reiter
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: This paper reports on two studies that investigate empirically how preferences about the audience and emphasis of Facebook posts change over time.  In a 75-participant longitudinal study, participants gave their preferences for up to ten of their Facebook posts in the week they were posted, again one week later, and again one month later. In a 234-participant retrospective study, participants answered questions about the audience and emphasis for posts made in the past week, as well as posts made one year prior.  These studies revealed multiple effects that impact sharing preferences over time: On one hand, participants' desire to have more people see their posts drove many increases in preferred audience size.  On the other, decreasing relevance, even more than concerns about privacy or self-presentation, drove many decreases.  Moreover, participants' predictions about how their preferences would change were poorly correlated with their actual changes in preferences over time, suggesting the need for tools to retrospectively adjust sharing policies.

column3: More Efficient Tagging Systems with Tag Seeding
column9: Vikas Kumar, Daniel Kluver, John Riedl
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; User experience/interaction design; Recommender and Filtering Systems
column101: People in online communities often annotate entities such as movies, music, pictures, and web pages with short phrases or keywords, also known as tags. In this paper we build on prior research that shows that tagging systems tend to stagnate, decreasing the amount of efficiency added over time. We show that although the Film Finder system exhibits the trend of decreasing efficiency over time, the trend can be reversed by interventions for encouraging users to add specific new tag applications into the system, a process known as tag seeding. We find that tag seeding is effective at countering the efficiency loss,and we introduce the Opportunity Gap and Potential algorithms for selecting tags which would most benefit the system as seeds.

column3: From Incredible Audience to Credible Bloggers
column9: Soo Young Rieh, Grace YoungJoo Jeon, Ji Yeon Yang, Cliff Lampe
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: This study examines how expert bloggers’ attention to and interaction with an audience influence their behavior in creating a credible blog. We conducted interviews with 22 expert bloggers who worked on their blogs independently. We found that expert bloggers’ social interaction with their audience influences their motivation to continue blogging and the value that a blog generates. We also identified the blogging practices and behavior to establish and enhance credibility at both the point bloggers create their blog, and as their blogging activities persist over time. We defined blogging credibility as a social process built through the interactions between bloggers and blog readers. Based on the results, practical guidelines for Internet users who want their posts in social media to be perceived to be credible by other users are presented. The findings provide insights for understanding content producers’ perceptions and behavior to improve credibility in user-generated content beyond blogs.  \  \

column3: Towards Channeling Support Where Its Impact is Greater in Online Cancer Communities
column9: MiaoMiao Wen, Yi-Chia Wang, Carolyn Rose
column15: Language Technologies Institute, Carnegie Mellon Univeristy, Pittsburgh
column33: Language Technologies Institute, Carnegie Mellon Univeristy
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Medical and health support
column101: Prior work demonstrates the positive impact of receiving attention on commitment formation in online communities. In this paper, we investigate whether the impact of receiving attention differs depending upon the local circumstances of a participant’s disease, and if so, whether there is room to increase the positive impact of attention offered by participants by channeling it towards users who need it more.  Our analysis is enabled by an automated extraction of cancer events in a user’s history based on their posting history in the forum.  Our analysis demonstrates both that the impact of receiving attention on commitment is greater while a user is experiencing a stressful cancer event and that foreknowledge of the experience of a cancer event is extractable from a user’s posting history on or before an event is experienced 81% of the time.  Furthermore, we demonstrate that users experience an elevated propensity to offer attention related to a cancer event after having experiencing it, which enables principled identification of potential support providers.

column3: Mitigating the Echo Chamber Effect by Visualizing Source Positions on Controversial Topics
column9: Q. Vera Liao, Wai-Tat Fu
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Recommender and Filtering Systems
column101: We examined the effects of visualizing valences (pro/con) and magnitudes (moderate/extreme) of information source positions on controversial topics on the selection and consumption of diverse opinions in online discussions. We found the visualizations had differential impacts on people with varied levels of motivation for accurately learning the topic. Specifically, the visualization promoted selection of sources that were moderately inconsistent with their existing attitudes for people who had high accuracy motives, thus increased their exposure to attitude challenging information; but not for those who had low accuracy motives. The visualization also helped people differentiate between sources with moderate and extreme positions, and increased their agreement with information from the moderately inconsistant sources. By increasing the exposure to attitude challenging information, users with high accuracy motives were also found to learn significantly more about the arguments put forward by the opposite side with the visualization. Implications for designing systems that encourage exposure to diverse information and common ground seeking were discussed.

column3: Framing the Conversation: The Role of Facebook Conversations in Shopping for Eyeglasses
column9: Karim Said, Michele Burton, Amy Hurst, Shaun Kane
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: In this paper we investigate the Warby Parker Facebook page, and explore the ways people formulate questions and conversations as they try to shop for new eyeglass frames. Our research presents insights derived from a sample dataset of over 29,000 Warby Parker Facebook page posts, consisting of photos, comments, and “likes”.  \ Using statistical analyses, and qualitative coding techniques for our subjective data, we explore trends of and motivations for conversations on the Warby Parker Facebook page. We show that contributors produce broad range of content, from artistically edited photo collages to simple one-to-three word comments. In contributing such content, we show that users’ contributions leverage the Warby Parker Facebook page as a platform for creative self-expression, socially driven decision-making, and for simple fun and leisure.  \

column3: GeoTagger: A Collaborative and Participatory Environmental Inquiry System
column9: Jerry Fails, Christopher Loeschorn
column100: E-Learning and Education; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Mobile and embedded devices; Location-based and context-aware computing
column101: This note focuses on the motivation, approach, and the initial prototype implementation of Geotagger: a collaborative participatory environmental inquiry system. We situate the need for such a technology, and discuss related work – much of which is situated in the realm of citizen science. Our work uniquely distinguishes itself from many other citizen science applications in that it supports limited data collection and analysis, with the additional benefit of supporting social interactions and engagement through conversations about observed data. This is accomplished by creating friends and groups which are collaborators in the observational inquiry process.

column3: Evaluating Communication Means in Multidisciplinary Research Networks
column9: Guang Ying Mo, Barry Wellman
column100: Social network analysis; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Diversity rhetoric argues that diversity is beneficial for organizations and is widely accepted by organizations. However, many studies challenged this idea, showing diversity leads to communication difficulties. Using a case study of the GRAND NCE, a Canadian research organization, this article examines the relationship between the cross-boundary design of multidisciplinary projects and communications among researchers. We conducted analyses with a multiple membership multilevel model and social network analysis. That nested the cross-boundary communication within each GRAND member’s networks into the research projects in which they participate. The findings show that disciplinary diversity in research projects is highly associated with email communication across disciplinary boundaries. However, we could not find such an effect on face-to-face communication. Moreover, researchers’ motivations to be involved in multidisciplinary collaborations and their role in the research network are also related to active boundary-spanning communication.

column3: Handoffs and Awareness in Informal Caregiving: Coordination among Multiple Care Participants
column9: Yunan Chen, Karen Cheng, Victor Ngo
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: Informal caregivers, such as family members and friends, Informal caregivers, such as family members and friends, are important for maintaining the health and wellness of the elderly and chronic ill. However, the complexity of informal caregiving has seldom been studied in prior research. In this study, we attempt to answer two main questions -- what makes the coordination of patient care so difficult among multiple informal caregivers, and what are the unique challenges to be considered in designing technologies to facilitate care coordination? To answer these questions, we conducted a qualitative interview study with individuals with caregiving experiences. The findings of the study identified the main challenges faced by caregivers in handling patient-care information, namely: maintaining informational awareness and coordinating informational handoff. From these findings, we identified new considerations that are unique to informal caregiver collaboration, and we outline opportunities for future technologies to support coordination of multiple informal caregivers.

column3: "Blown Out of The Water": Understanding How Collaborative Tools are Changing Technology-Enhanced Learning in Higher Education
column9: Heather Packer, Daniel Smith, Max Van Kleek, Debra Morris, Hugh Davis
column41: Centre for Innovation in Technologies and Education
column50: Centre for Innovation in Technologies and Education
column100: E-Learning and Education
column101: Despite a decade and a half of public and private initiatives driving Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) in higher education in the UK, its adoption has remained inconsistent, variable and generally incomplete across a majority of institutional departments.  In this paper, we present a case-study investigation of one leading research University's TEL deployment, to derive a detailed understanding of the ways TEL strategy has succeeded to support positive learning outcomes, and the ways that it has shifted following pressures driven by the rapid evolution of external collaborative tools and platforms.  This study, conducted as interviews with key TEL stakeholders at the University, allowed us to derive a classification of the primary roles TEL now serves in the University, and potential avenues by which CSCW-related research might contribute solutions to the complex issues that remain.  \

column3: The Notion of “Culture” as a Move toward Closure in Cross-national Software Development Teams
column9: Rasmus Jensen, Bonnie Nardi
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Distributed/virtual teams; Collaborative software development
column101: Studies of distributed software teams report that the main challenges faced are geographical distance, time zone difference, and cultural differences [22]. We conducted an ethnographic study of a distributed software team with members in Denmark and the Philippines. We found that “culture” was invoked by Danish workers to explain failed collaborations, but not by Filipino workers who formulated other explanations and actively resisted cultural explanations. To analyze this asymmetry in asserting culture as an explanation for failure, we use the concept of closure. Metiu, building on Weber [27], defined closure as strategies of exclusion employed by a high-status group to maintain its position relative to a lower status group. Strategies include criticism and lack of interaction to exclude colleagues in other locales [21]. In our study, we observed what we call “moves toward closure,” that is, use of somewhat vague rhetoric about cultural difference directed at achieving closure. We discuss how and why Danish workers moved toward closure, and the responses of Filipino employees.

column3: Counting on Friends: Cues to Trustworthiness in Facebook Profiles
column9: Catalina Toma
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: Social network site profiles are frequently used for social surveillance and relationship initiation. Thus, it is critical to understand how users evaluate one another on the basis of these profiles. The present study examines which profile cues affect perceptions of trustworthiness on Facebook. We draw on uncertainty reduction theory, warranting theory, and hardwired perceptions of facial displays, to identify a set of cues utilized by observers when assessing strangers’ trustworthiness on Facebook. Results show that five profile cues (number of friends, number of tagged photographs, number of “about me” categories filled out, comments received from friends, and smiling photographs) explain a third of the variance in trustworthiness perceptions. Results also show that Facebook users are relatively accurate in assessing how trustworthy they come across to strangers, but that they do not utilize profile cues in these judgments. Theoretical and design implications are discussed.

column3: Twitter ain't Without Frontiers: Economic, Social, and Cultural Boundaries in International Communication
column9: Ruth García-Gavilanes, Yelena Mejova, Daniele Quercia
column100: Social network analysis; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: Has internet breached the barriers of geographic distance and brought about a global communication network? In this study we show that the international Twitter communication landscape is not only still largely predetermined by physical distance, but that it also depends on countries' social, economic, and cultural attributes. We describe a study of an international Twitter mention network of 13 million users across over 100 countries. We show that the Gravity Model, which hypothesizes that the flow between two areas is proportional to their masses (which we approximate using internet penetration) and inversely proportional to the distance between them, is correlated r=0.608 with and somewhat predictive of the international communication flow (Adjusted R2=0.257). However, by supplementing this model with social, economic, and cultural variables, we achieve an Adjusted R2 of 0.794, with income inequality, trade levels and racial intolerance especially impacting communication.

column3: Using Expertise Scores to Motivate Social Learning in the Enterprise
column9: Mercan Topkara, Justin Weisz, Shimei Pan, Jie Lu, Jennifer Lai
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; E-Learning and Education; User experience/interaction design
column101: Expertise assessments are a common part of work in the enterprise, but automated assessments may not be completely accurate when data are incomplete or inaccurate. We explore two dimensions of reporting automated expertise assessments to users: the use of social comparisons and graphical representations showing precise scores versus ranges of scores. In a controlled experiment (N=60), we examined the impact of these dimensions on the perceived accuracy of the assessments, perceived utility of and engagement with the social learning system, and willingness to share expertise across the enterprise. Our findings indicate that the presence of a social comparison increased ratings of system utility and levels of engagement. Precise graphical representations tended to increase feelings of trust in assessments. Participants were willing to share their scores when asked by others or if a culture of sharing existed in the organization.

column3: Exploring the social-technological gap in telesurgery: collaboration within distributed OR teams
column9: Pieter Duysburgh, Shirley Elprama, An Jacobs
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: While its technical feasibility has been illustrated over a decade ago, today, robot-assisted telesurgery is not a part of everyday surgical practice. The thresholds for adoption of telesurgery are mostly seen as technical, legal and financial challenges. However, the aim of this paper is to understand collaboration within OR teams, which seems to be underexposed in research on telesurgery. By means of a proxy-technology assessment, a number of challenges for telesurgery have been identified. These include the unfamiliarity of the remote surgeon with the practices of the local operating room team and the patient. In addition, verbal and non-verbal communication has to be mediated in a telesurgery setting, making it harder for the remote surgeon to have an overview and stay in control during surgery. With this research, we have improved our understanding of the barriers telesurgery faces with regard to collaboration in the operating room.

column3: Mining Collaborative Music Data for Serendipitously Predicting Listening Behavior
column9: Katayoun Farrahi, Peter Knees, Markus Schedl, Maarten Grachten
column42: Austrian Research Institute for Artificial Intelligence
column100: Recommender and Filtering Systems; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Recent trends in music information retrieval and social music computing highlight the importance of personalized retrieval and serendipitous recommendation. We address these problems by presenting an approach to learn topic models from user listening histories on a large-scale. We then assess the quality of these models in a two-fold manner: for clustering of artists according to topics, and for predicting future music listening behavior of Last.fm users. Using Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) with Gibbs sampling, we show that topic models can be beneficially exploited to infer information about both artist similarity (via clustering) and future listening inclination from large amounts of music listening data. \  \ As for clustering, we illustrate that the topics determined by LDA from listening co-occurrence data correspond well to resembling artists, whereas they do not correspond significantly to clusters given by collaborative tags. As for predicting user-specific, serendipitous tracks, we empirically demonstrate that our model is capable of recommending novel tracks to the user which fit his or her actual music taste.

column3: Collaborative Problem Solving Strategies
column9: Yla Tausczik, Aniket Kittur, Robert Kraut
column100: Crowdsourcing; Computer-Mediated Communication; Distributed/virtual teams; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Groups rather than individuals may be better at solving the most complex problems. Yet, strategies to solve difficult interdependent problems in a distributed way have not been exhaustively explored. In this paper, we uncover collaborative strategies that emerge among teams solving new mathematical “micro-problems” online. The results indicate that less typically thought of patterns of collaborative problem solving, such as peer-review of solutions and negotiating the problem, are actually quite common. A better understanding of collaborative strategies can inform the design of tools to support distributed collaboration on complex problems.

column3: What Makes Sports Fans Interactive?: Understanding Mass Interactions in Online Sports Viewing
column9: Minsam Ko, Seungwoo Choi, Juyeong Lee, Yong Jae Jang, Junehwa Song, Uichin Lee
column51: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Nowadays, sports fans can watch sports games at any place using social TV services lively interacting with others via online chatting. In this paper, we deepen our understanding on mass interactions in online sports viewing. With a large-scale chat dataset from Naver Baseball, we perform (1) content analysis to characterize types of mass interactions and (2) a series of regression analyses to identify the key factors which influence the mass interactions. Our content analysis results show that the mass interactions can be categorized into four types, namely expressive monologues, cheers/jeers, opinions/arguments, and questions/answers. We present both quantitative and qualitative features of each category and describe their social implications. Next, our regression analysis results explain the relationship between various factors and the interactions of the mass. In addition, we found that the influence of the factors is different depending on user groups, i.e., active vs. less active users and loyal vs. non-loyal users. Our findings bring practical design implications for online sports TV.

column3: Zombie or not?  Automatic Detection of Fake Followers on Chinese Micro-blogging
column9: Yi Shen, yu jianjun
column14: University of Chinese Academic of Science
column100: Social network analysis; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: Micro-blogging, which has greatly inﬂuenced people’s life, \ is experiencing fantastic success in the worldwide. Howev- \ er, during its rapid development, it has encountered a content \ pollution problem. Various pollution in the micro-blogging \ platforms have hurt the credibility of micro-blogging and \ cause too much negative effect. In this paper, we mainly \ focus on the fake followers (i.e., zombies), which is also a \ kind of pollution in the micro-blogging system. By extract- \ ing the features of zombies in Sina Weibo (a Chinese micro- \ blogging)[weibo.com], we propose a weighted classiﬁer to \ distinguish zombies from the legitimate users. The experi- \ mental results demonstrate that our approach is fairly effec- \ tive. We also present an elaborate analysis of the phenomenon \ of fake followers, then give some inference of the algorithms \ and principles behind them, and ﬁnally provide some sugges- \ tions for the micro-blogging systems and ordinary users to \ deal with the fake followers.

column3: Replication in Ethnography and Interaction Analysis
column9: John Rooksby
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Legal/historical/philosophical aspects; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: This paper draws upon a replication of a classic study (Plans and Situated Actions by Suchman) to discuss methodological issues in CSCW and related fields.  There are often complaints about the lack of replication studies in disciplines related to CSCW (particularly Software Engineering and HCI).  These complaints are usually embedded in wider attempts to install a principled scientific method within these disciplines.  This paper argues naturalistic research, including ethnography and interaction analysis, would also benefit from the kinds of activities advocated in the replication literature.  However, naturalistic approaches are incompatible with the broader scientific visions forwarded by the replication literature.  This paper suggests that attempts to transform HCI, CSCW and Software Engineering into sciences are unhelpful ‘extra steps’ when promoting replication.

column3: Automating Affect Detection in Multilingual Text Chat
column9: Sayer Rippey, Katie Kuksenok, Cecilia Aragon
column100: Machine Learning and Data Mining; Computer-Mediated Communication; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Investigating emotion in chat-based collaborative work is necessary for understanding team dynamics and interactions. Manual annotation can be scaled to larger datasets with experimental machine learning techniques. Recent work has made progress in increasing accuracy even in difficult contexts, like chat rooms, where utterances are short, and slang, abbreviations, misspellings, and lack of grammar are common. However, the increasing prevalence of geographically distributed, multicultural, and multilingual teams presents new challenges to automating affect detection and studying group dynamics based on chat room communication. In this paper, we introduce an adaptation of the statistical affect detection in collaborative chat approach, ALOE, presented at CSCW2013 [2]. This adaptation is intended to help detect affect in French chat while maintaining performance on English. We contribute a catalogue of modifications for using ALOE with French chat logs, as well as a discussion of the implications of automating affect detection across linguistic and cultural boundaries.

column3: Mobilizing the Crowd in India
column9: Aditya Vashistha, Rajan Vaish, Edward Cutrell, William Thies
column100: Crowdsourcing; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Social network analysis
column101: While there has been a surge of interest in mobilizing the crowd to solve large-scale, time-critical challenges, to date such work has not focused on developing countries. In this paper, we describe two experiments to better understand crowd mobilization in low-income contexts. First, we describe a social mobilization contest, the Whodunit Challenge, that required rapid formation of large teams in order to solve a fictional mystery case in India. The contest encompassed 7700 participants in one day and revealed several aspects of crowd mobilization that are distinct from Western contexts. Second, we describe a controlled experiment that compares two financial incentives and their influence on viral spread. As an alternative to a contest, which offers variable payout to each participant, we show that a fixed-payout scheme can be much more viral, spreading from 15 people to over 800 people in a single day. We synthesize our observations into a set of recommendations for effective crowd mobilization, social networking, and viral marketing in the developing world.

column3: Facebook Makes the Heart Grow Fonder: Relationship Maintenance Strategies Among Geographically Dispersed and Communication-Restricted Connections
column9: Jessica Vitak
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: The rise and spread of information and communication technologies has dramatically impacted interpersonal communication and relationship maintenance. These technologies remove temporal and spatial constraints, enabling communication at a distance for low or no physical costs. Research has established that technologies such as email supplement other forms of communication in maintaining relationships, but to what extent do newer technologies—that contain a unique set of affordances—facilitate these processes? Furthermore, do SNS users engage in different practices through the site and obtain different relational benefits based on specific characteristics of the tie? Findings from a survey of adult Facebook users (N=415) indicates that geographically distant Facebook Friends, as well as those who rely on the site as their primary form of communication, engage in relationship maintenance strategies through the site to a greater extent and perceive the site to have a more positive impact on the quality of their relationship.

column3: Computer Supported Collective Action: Patterns, Barriers, and the WeDo Prototype
column9: Aaron Shaw, Haoqi Zhang, Andres Monroy-Hernandez, Sean Munson, Benjamin Mako Hill, Elizabeth Gerber, Peter Kinnaird, Shelly Farnham
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Many have celebrated the Internet’s ability to connect interested individuals and facilitate collective action toward a common goal. In this paper, we define and elaborate the concept of computer supported collective action (CSCA) to describe social computing systems that support collective action. We also characterize five patterns that recur in CSCA, including (1) the identification of a problem; (2) the generation, deliberation, and selection of a goal; (3) coordination and preparation for action; (4) taking action; and (5) assessing, documenting, and following up on actions. We identify design principles for success in each pattern and discuss barriers that lead to common breakdowns when moving from pattern to pattern. We then introduce WeDo, a prototype system aimed at promoting simple end-to-end CSCA. Using our process model, we discuss findings from pilot deployments of the WeDo system which both illustrate the effectiveness of our identified patterns and highlight several failures.

column3: Modeling Search Processes using Hidden States in Task-based Collaborative Exploratory Web Search
column9: Zhen Yue, Shuguang Han, Daqing He
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: In this paper, we modeled collaborative search process using Hidden Markov Model (HMM), which is an automatic technique for analyzing temporal sequential data in search process. We conducted user studies that provided data for collaborative exploratory Web search and individual exploratory Web search under two different tasks. Such data were then used for creating HMM. Our results show that the identified hidden patterns of search process in both individual and collaborative search are compatible with previous studies. Our results also recognize two types of hidden patterns: the search related patterns and sense-making related patterns. While the search related patterns are similar between collaborative and individual Web search, the sense-making related patterns are different. In addition, task difference is a much more critical factor in collaborative search than in individual search. Particularly in collaborative search, we found that the transition from search to sense-making is negatively correlated to search performance whereas the transition from sense-making to search is positively correlated to the search performance.

column3: Collaboration without Coordination? A look at socio-technical factors of success for open source contributions in Github
column9: Kelly Blincoe, Giuseppe Valetto, Sean Goggins
column100: Collaborative software development; Computer-Mediated Communication; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: We explore coordination on GitHub by examining three GitHub projects and contextualize our findings with the culture articulated by project leaders. We perform a categorical analysis of variables that predict successful merges of contributor code on each project. We also examine the role of up front coordination, operationalized through the identification of code contributions that are directly connected to identified issues on a project or discussed prior to submission, in the successful integration of contributed code. Finally, we examine whether or not upfront coordination plays a role in the acceptance of contributions from new members. Our findings suggest that the fluid nature of coordination work on GitHub is both an opportunity for broader participation in OSS projects and a source of unexpected challenges.

column3: Introducing Shared Character Control to Existing Video Games
column9: Anna Loparev, Walter Lasecki, Jeffrey Bigham
column100: Entertainment/games; Collaboration architectures
column101: Many people enjoy the social aspects of gaming, but most \ video games are designed to be played by one person at a \ time. We introduce WeGame, a system that increases the sociability \ of single-player video games by allowing joint colocated \ play. The WeGame mediation framework flexibly \ merges the inputs of multiple players into a single control \ stream before forwarding it to the gaming system in realtime, \ and supports visual overlays to give players feedback \ on the newly-injected social dimensions of the game. Studies \ with more than 50 participants explore the new space enabled \ by WeGame, showing social and preferential effects \ of several archetype mediation strategies. The WeGame approach \ has the potential to improve social aspects of existing \ single-player games, allow novices to learn from experts \ while playing together simultaneously, and improve gaming \ performance.

column3: Dyadic Diversity Attributes on Interactive Tabletop Collaboration, Performance, and Perception
column9: Rong Tang, Elizabeth Quigley
column15: Simmons College, Graduate School of Library and Information Science, Boston
column23: Graduate School of Library and Information Science
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; User experience/interaction design; Collaborative visualization; Location-based and context-aware computing; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Sixty undergraduate students paired up and participated in a usability study of the Library Explorer software on the Microsoft PixelSense Tabletop. Specific investigation was made into the impact of diversity attributes on collaboration style, collaboration quality, task performance, and participants’ perception. Problem solving ideas was coded as suggestions; and examination of suggestions’ non-acceptance revealed interesting patterns regarding gender effects and task performance. Results show that during the collaborative discovery on interactive tabletops, gender and racial diversities, while directly influenced collaboration styles and processes, did not impact team performance. Diversity attributes that directly correlated with team effectiveness included differences in tabletop use experiences, usability ratings, and the frequency of suggestions not being accepted. Findings of the study not only enrich the understanding of the connection between team composition and collaboration styles, but also provide insights on how team members’ suggestion behavior may help capture the nature of collaboration on interactive tabletops.

column3: The Impact of Deviance on Retention in a Multiplayer Game
column9: Kenneth Shores, Yilin He, Kristina Swanenburg, Robert Kraut, John Riedl
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Entertainment/games
column101: Deviant behavior in online systems is a difficult problem to address. Consequences of deviance include driving off users and tarnishing the system’s public image. We present an examination of these concepts in a popular online game, League of Legends. Using a large collection of game records and player-given feedback, we develop a metric, “toxicity,” to identify deviant players. We then look at the effects of interacting with deviant players, including effects on retention. We find that toxic players have several significant predictive patterns, such as playing in more competitive game modes and playing with friends. We also show that toxic players drive away new players, but that experienced players are more resilient to deviant behavior. Based on our findings, we suggest methods to better identify and counteract the negative effects of deviance.

column3: Like or not Like? Analyzing Users’ Sentiments towards Facebook
column9: Honglu Du, Jianqiang Shen, Oliver Brdiczka
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Social network analysis
column101: Recent Pew research found that 27% of Facebook users plan to spend less time on the site this coming year. In this paper, we seek to understand why Facebook users’ attitudes towards Facebook are changing and whether Facebook users’ attitudes towards Facebook could be predicted. The relationship between Facebook users’ sentiment towards Facebook and demographics, Big Five personalities as well as Facebook activities was examined. The results of a hierarchical regression indicated that agreeableness, one of the Big Five personality traits, and the amount of likes users received on Facebook were positively correlated to users’ sentiment towards Facebook. Emotions embedded in users’ posts can also help identify people’s sentiments towards Facebook. Qualitative content analysis revealed that feeling of waste-of-time, too many advertisements, negative peer comparison, weakened cherished relationship and privacy concerns were the main reasons that made users feel negative about Facebook.

column3: Social Security: Combating Device Theft With Community-Based Video Notarization
column9: Alana Libonati, Apu Kapadia, Michael Reiter
column100: User experience/interaction design; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Mobile and embedded devices; Crowdsourcing
column101: People increasingly rely on mobile devices for storing sensitive information and credentials for access to services. Because these devices are vulnerable to theft, security of this data is put at higher risk — once the attacker is in physical possession of the device, recovering these credentials and impersonating the owner of the phone is usually straightforward and hard to defend by purely local means. We introduce the concept of ‘notarization’, a process by which a remote notary verifies the identity of the device user through video chat. We describe the design and implementation of a system that leverages notarization to protect cryptographic keys that the device uses to decrypt device data (e.g., website passwords) or perform signatures in support of client-side TLS, without trusting the notary with these keys. Through a lab-based study with 56 participants, we show that notarization even by strangers is effective for combating device theft.

column3: Understanding Expressions of Loneliness in Social Media
column9: Funda Kivran-Swaine, Jed Brubaker, Mor Naaman
column15: Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: We investigate public expressions of loneliness on Twitter, to improve our understanding of the experience of users that go through perceived social isolation. Using mixed-methods, we first qualitatively extract themes that appear in tweets containing explicit declarations of loneliness. Some themes that surface include temporality, directedness, and the circumstantial contexts of loneliness. We then quantitatively analyze the relationship between the themes, showing, amongst other findings, that tweets that include an explicit call for social connection are significantly more prevalent for non-enduring loneliness experiences . Our findings confirm and can help extend theories of social isolation, and show how these theories are manifested in online communication environments.

column3: Collaboration, Coordination and Control: System Development and Bureaucratic Authority in the Thai Public Sector
column9: Radaphat Chongthammakun, Steven Jackson
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: New computational investments in public sector organizations have been widely cited for their contributions to government service efficiency improvement, cross-agency collaboration and, organizational innovation. But they have also had important and often overlooked effects on relations of organizational authority and control. This paper examines the background, process, and outcome of three recent cases of computerized collaboration support tools in the Thai public sector. We find that such systems have encountered three main tensions that shape and limit their impact (and may be endemic to CSCW deployments in large bureaucratic organizations): tensions between competing demands for centralization and autonomy; tensions between official procedure and the actual practices by which bureaucratic work is accomplished; and tensions stemming from the workarounds, duplications, and system proliferations accompany efforts at organizational standardization. More generally, we argue that investments in new computational infrastructures predicated on collaboration, and coordination must be understood as complex interventions into the basic relations of control that structure and coordinate information power, and authority in complex organizations.

column3: Green Dolphin: Crowd-sourcing the Task of Answering Student Questions
column9: Chulakorn Aritajati, N. Hari Narayanan
column14: Intelligent and Interactive Systems Laboratory Computer Science & Software Engineering Department
column23: Intelligent and Interactive Systems Laboratory Computer Science & Software Engineering Department
column100: E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User experience/interaction design; Crowdsourcing
column101: We present the design of an educational question and answer system, Green Dolphin, and describe a study of its usage and impact in a graduate Computer Science course. Question and answer boards are quite popular on the web. A system called Piazza is in widespread use in the educational domain. One benefit of such a system is that students receive quick responses to their questions from peers. However, seeing teachers’ answers may discourage students from contributing. We implemented a delay in the publication of teachers' answers to encourage student participation. We also implemented a technique to automatically identify "expert" students from their question asking and answering behaviors, and a point-based reward system. We compared Green Dolphin usage with that of Piazza. We found that delaying instructor answers increased students’ participation, the reward system motivated students, and students felt pride in being identified by Green Dolphin as an expert.

column3: Photoportals: Shared References in Space and Time
column9: André Kunert, Alexander Kulik, Stephan Beck, Bernd Froehlich
column100: Collaboration architectures; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; User experience/interaction design; Collaborative visualization; Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing
column101: Photoportals build on photography as a unifying metaphor for reference-based interaction in 3D virtual environments. Virtual photos and videos serve as three-dimensional references to objects, places, moments in time and activities of users. They can be shared among users and serve as portals to the captured information. These portals provide access to intermediate or alternative versions of a scenario and allow the review of recorded task sequences that include life-size representations of the captured users. Photoportals support collaboration among collocated and remote users by providing multiple access points, complementary functionalities and mutual awareness through continuous visual feedback.

column3: Why One Size Can Never Fit All: Evaluating a Novel Overview Visualization for Social Reference Management Systems
column9: Peter Kraker, Sebastian Dennerlein, Dieter Theiler, Dominik Kowald, Kris Jack, Christoph Trattner
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; User experience/interaction design; Crowdsourcing
column101: At the beginning of a study, it is usually quite hard to get an overview of a research field. One needs to work through long lists of search results and their references to build a mental model of the field. Head Start, a novel visualization for social reference management systems, addresses this problem of classic literature search. The interactive system gives an overview of the most important areas in a field, and shows popular publications related to each of these areas. In this paper, we present a qualitative evaluation of the system. We conducted expert interviews with researchers from the domain of Educational Technology. Our results show that the visualization and the underlying concept is received favourably by the experts. Nevertheless, we also observe contradictory statements amongst the participants related to the content and the presentation. Therefore, we conclude that there is no one-size-fits-all approach to overviews of research fields. We discuss ideas of personalization and collaborative editing in order to overcome its weaknesses.

column3: Collaboration Surrounding Beacon Use During Companion Avalanche Rescue
column9: Audrey Desjardins, Carman Neustaedter, Saul Greenberg, Ron Wakkary
column100: Other domain-specific support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: When facing an avalanche, backcountry skiers need to work effectively both individually and as a group to rescue buried victims. If they don’t, death is likely. One of the tools used by each person is a digital beacon that transmits an electromagnetic signal. If buried, others use their beacons to locate victims by searching for their signals, and then dig them out. This study focuses on the collaborative practices of avalanche rescue and the interactions with beacons while backcountry skiing. We conducted interviews with backcountry recreationists and experts, and we observed avalanche rescue scenarios. Our results highlight aspects and challenges of mental representation, trust, distributed cognition, and practice. Implications include simplicity, visibility and practice for future avalanche rescue and training tools, with redesigned beacons serving a key role.

column3: Intrinsic and Extrinsic Incentives in Online Survey Participation: An Experimental Case Study of Interest, Recruitment, and Retention
column9: Andrew Fiore, Coye Cheshire, G.A. Mendelsohn, Lindsay Shaw Taylor
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Online surveys are an important and increasingly pervasive part of the CSCW researcher’s toolkit. However, our understanding of how different approaches to recruitment in online survey research may influence participation rates is incomplete. We present a large-scale field experiment that examines the role of intrinsic and extrinsic incentives in online survey research. We compare the effects of intrinsic incentives in combination with various levels of extrinsic financial incentives on (1) interest in study participation, (2) rate of successful recruitment, (3) retention and quality of participation, and (4) the cost effectiveness of financial incentives. We find that financial incentives yield increased participation in many cases, but the cost is high for the relatively minor gains they provide compared to smaller incentives. Furthermore, we find little benefit and perhaps even some penalty associated with giving financial incentives to participants who were not explicitly recruited into a survey with the promise of money. Implications for recruiting and retaining participants in online survey research are discussed.

column3: Vision Impairment, Social Media and Inclusion: A Three Country Study
column9: Joyojeet Pal, Sidharth Chhabra, Tawfiq Ammari, Ana Maria Huaita Alfaro, Meera Lakshmanan
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Legal/historical/philosophical aspects
column101: This paper presents qualitative research on the use of social media by people with vision impairments in Jordan, Peru, and India. We find that social media is a means of social network expansion by individuals, but also by advocacy and service organizations working on issues related to vision impairment. These narratives of social media use, in particular Facebook, illuminate three key themes. First, we find that existing physical networks provide an important segue into online social networks. Second we find that the online social media are an important means of expanding human networks in ways that were particularly difficult without access to technology. Finally we find that social media provide an important means of accessing the technological assistance and media. The article highlights the role of social media in a climate of economic and social marginalization that people with disabilities often face in regions that lack the infrastructure, legal provisions, and appropriate accessible technology for the inclusion of people with disabilities.

column3: A Comparison of Social, Learning, and Financial  Strategies on Crowd Engagement and Output Quality
column9: Lixiu Yu, Aniket Kittur, Robert Kraut, Paul André
column100: Crowdsourcing
column101: Many crowdsourcing markets are oriented around short-term, one-off, on-demand transactions between employers and workers. There are many potential benefits to extending worker engagement beyond a single task, ranging from building expertise to having a loyal workforce on call. We explore the effects of social, learning, and financial strategies, and their combinations, on increasing worker engagement and output quality. Through three experiments, we show that 1) using these strategies together increased workers’ engagement and the quality of their work; 2) a social strategy was most effective for increasing engagement; 3) a learning strategy was most effective in improving quality. The findings of this paper provide strategies for harnessing the crowd to perform complex tasks, as well as insight into crowd workers’ motivation.

column3: Fast, Functional, and Fitting: Organizing Characteristics of Help-Giving on a Newcomer Online Forum
column9: Hon Teo, Aditya Johri
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: We present findings from a study that examined how help-giving is organized on an online Java programming help forum. Previous studies have demonstrated that in online communities a few experts are able to provide responses to and engage a large number of newcomers. In the face of no overall formal organizing force, how is this expert help organized and to what effect? We found that even though help-giving on online forums is completely voluntary, it self-organizes to provide fast, functional, and fitting help. Our findings show that (1) the most active help-givers gave response promptly (69.0% of first responses within an hour) and were most responsive when help-seeker activity peaked during the day. (2) There was very little duplication of help-giving effort (at an average 2-3 experts responded to any thread), and, (3) the initial responses were also of high quality reducing the need for clarifications and corrections.

column3: Designing the virtual self: How avatar customization and psychological connections influence group collaboration
column9: Rabindra Ratan, Béatrice Hasler
column100: Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; Computer-Mediated Communication; Collaboration architectures; Distributed/virtual teams; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Virtual environments facilitate group collaboration through avatars.  While many studies have examined the effects of avatar attributes on users’ behaviors and attitudes, few have explicitly tested how avatar design avatar design decisions and psychological connections to avatars influence group collaboration.  The present study fills this gap using data from student groups in a collaborative virtual environment.  Avatar customization count was found to relate to more positive group collaboration, as did the extent to which the avatar reflected the user’s personal identity.  Conversely, similarity between the user and avatar’s personality was negatively related to group collaboration satisfaction.  Further, using a face-similar avatar was positively related to the strength of psychological connection to the avatar.  This study suggests that virtual group collaboration environments should be designed to encourage users to focus on designing avatars that reflect the ideal self.

column3: Understanding Information Centrality Metric: A Simulation Approach
column9: Chintan Amrit, Joanne ter Maat
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social network analysis
column101: Identifying the central people in information flow networks is essential to understanding how people communicate and coordinate as well as who controls the information flows in the network. However, the appropriate usage of centrality metrics depends on an understanding of the type of network flow. Networks can vary in the way node-to-node transmission takes place, or in the way a course through the network is taken. This results in different types of information flow processes. When metrics are used for an inappropriate flow process, the result of the metric can be misleading and often incorrect. In this paper we create a simulation of the flow of information in a network, and then we show that the information centrality is suitable for networks where transfer takes places with information flowing through walks rather than paths, trails or geodesics

column3: How Beliefs about the Presence of Machine Translation Impact Multilingual Collaborations
column9: Ge Gao, Bin Xu, Dan Cosley, Susan Fussell
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Traditional communication tools tend to make their presence known, e.g., “when I and my collaborator are using IM to discuss our work, how could we not realize the actual presence of IM?” In the case of machine translation (MT) mediated collaborations, however, the absence or presence of MT is not obvious. English sentences with poor grammar can result from both a partner’s lack of fluency and errors in the MT process. We hypothesize that partners’ attributions about the source of the errors affects their collaboration experience. To test this hypothesis, we conducted a laboratory experiment in which monolingual native English speaking participants collaborated with bilingual native-Mandarin speakers on a map navigation task. Participants were randomly assigned into a 2 (beliefs about MT: absence vs. presence) by 2 (actual mediation of MT: absence vs. presence) experiment design. Beliefs about presence of MT significantly impacted the collaboration experience, opening new opportunities for both research and design around MT-mediated collaborations.

column3: Impact of group norms in eliciting response in a goal driven virtual community.
column9: Sumeet Jain, Tanmay Sinha, Achal Shah, Chandramouli sharma, Carolyn Rose
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Computer-Mediated Communication; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Recommender and Filtering Systems
column101: With the proliferation of social media into our daily lives, online communities have become an important platform for collaborative learning and education. To connect users with varying knowledge levels and increase the net learning throughput, these communities often follow a question-answer based approach. Understanding what drives attention to help-seeking questions can reduce the amount of questions that go unnoticed or remain unanswered by the community. In this paper we discuss an important feature that affects the activity of the community, namely the community norms. We present a machine learning based trigger-driven feedback model that functions by (i) differentiating between help-seeking questions and follow-up posts – i.e. posts that are part of an ongoing discussion, and (ii) a dynamic intervention scheme to help improve question formulation. Our findings show that adhering to the community norms significantly increases the chance of eliciting a response.

column3: Making crowdwork work: Exploring issues in organizational uses of the crowd
column9: Obinna Anya, Melissa Cefkin, Steve Dill, Robert Moore, Robert Kern, Susan Stucky
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Existing definitions of crowdwork center around the unique ways in which work is sourced from the crowd, often emphasizing the kind of work characterized by hyperspecialized, microtask labor. However, real work in organizations is complex and rich, and as crowdsourcing is increasingly used alongside mainstream organizational work, there arise issues along several dimensions that raise social, technological, human-factors and work practice-related challenges. As a result, it seems prudent to explore crowdwork in relation to the nature of work in organizational practice to ascertain the implications of crowdsourcing on organizational structures, human requirements and work efficiency. This paper argues that a more profound reckoning of the nature of work itself and a broader conceptualization of crowdwork that accommodates the inherent complexity of work is needed to address these challenges. Drawing on the field of work practice studies, existing frameworks for crowdwork in the literature, as well as direct feedback from interviews with organizational workers engaging in crowdwork, we explore issues in organizational uses of the crowd.

column3: Effects of Feedback and Working Preference on Novice Citizen Scientists’ Motivation and Contribution
column9: Yurong He, Jennifer Preece, Carol Boston, Anne Bowser, Derek Hansen, Jennifer Hammock, David Jacobs, Dana Rotman
column51: Ira A. Fulton College of Engineering and Technology, Brigham Young University
column100: Other domain-specific support; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Having enough citizens and good data are critical to the citizen science projects. In this study, we adopted a mix method approach to investigate whether we could cultivate novice citizen scientists. To achieve this we investigated two different manipulations: type of formative feedback, and working preference. Task difficulty was a moderator. The results showed that 1) positive corrective guidance has a stronger effect on increasing novice citizen scientists’ motivation and contribution; 2) novice citizen scientists who choose to work in a pair have higher initial motivation; 3) positive corrective guidance works better on improving novice citizen scientists’ contribution, but not for those who choose to work in a pair; 4) the effects of formative feedback is stronger on an easy task, while the effects of working preference is stronger on a difficult task. Based on the results, we suggest design implications for future citizen science projects.

column3: Planet Hunters and Seafloor Explorers: Legitimate Peripheral Participation Through Practice Proxies in Online Citizen Science
column9: Gabriel Mugar, Carsten Oesterlund, Katie Hassman, Kevin Crowston, Corey Jackson
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies
column101: Making the traces of user participation in primary activities visible in online crowdsourced initiatives has been shown to help new users understand the norms of participation but participants do not always have access to others’ work. Through a combination of virtual and trace ethnography we explore how new users in two online citizen science projects engage other traces of activity as a way of compensating. Merging the theory of legitimate peripheral participation with Erickson and Kellogg’s theory of social translucence we introduce the concept of practice proxies; traces of user activities in online environment that act as resources to orient newcomers towards the norms of practice. Our findings suggest that newcomers seek out practice proxies in the social features of the projects that highlight contextualized and specific characteristics of primary work practice.

column3: VideoCafe 2.0 – A Media-Space and Social Media Mashup
column9: Konrad Tollmar, Erik Eliasson, Daniel Turull Torrents
column100: Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: In web development, a mashup is a web application that combines data from multiple sources to create new services. Using this approach we have created a media-space and social media mashup based on an open-source video-communication platform and a social media platform with an open API, i.e. Twitter. The system has been deployed for 6 months in a research organization across 5 European cities. This paper reports some early findings from this pilot deployment. We learned that Twitter interactions were mostly short and about current situation happening around physical spaces. However, despite the bursty form, status updates promote awareness between the remote places as well as initiate casual encounters. We discuss how these results can be used to think about new combinations, i.e. mashups of popular digital media, like video-chats, social media, streamed media, and games to form new media that are noted, used and enjoyed. Another opportunity is to develop research methods to study new forms of communication using hybrid media mashups

column3: Voluntary, Anonymous, Mobile Data Collection to Support Gradual, Collaborative, Web-Based Visualization
column9: Darren Stevenson, Fawaad Ahmad, Eric Struminger
column100: Collaborative visualization; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Crowdsourcing; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: We describe the project FRYOMETRICS, a effort that incorporates distributed data collection via internet-enabled mobile devices to produce a collaborative, gradual, online visualization. The premise of the project is to collect and visualize data from anonymous, voluntary participants corresponding to the number of French fries received in a single Small French Fries order from McDonald’s restaurants across the United States. The eventual end product is an online, interactive, geographic visualization displaying the average number of fries received at each U.S. McDonald’s location based on user submissions. Two project goals include 1) Offer a playful, participatory, and meaningful critique on McDonald’s food practices, mass consumer culture, and the (un)availability of healthy fast food providing individuals a novel means to pause, quantify, and consider their food 2) Provide a test case in participatory, crowdsourced data collection and visualization offering an approach that is simultaneously voluntary, anonymous, mobile, and distributed. Both of these goals combine to support the central proposition of this paper: counting as a subversive activity.

column3: Before All is Said and Done: A Phenomenology of Couples Arguing Through Different Technologies
column9: Deborah Tatar, Samantha Yglesias, Steve Harrison
column100: Home/family/intimacy support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Couples are of interest as constituting an important social structure and also as an exemplar of relationships that involve a commitment to the notion of “we”. Yet couples may and do disagree.  This entails maintaining a balance between potentially divisive elements of discord and potentially confusing (for the discussion) elements of harmony. Furthermore, couples, like everyone else, use technology to communicate. The current work draws heavily on discourse analysis to identify phenomena relevant to understanding how different media provide affordances for different kinds of unfolding discourses of dispute.  The distinction between having an argument and making an argument appears to cross-cut conditions, but people in IM may be less likely to enter into having an argument than f2f couples; people in IM may be less likely to maintain ambiguity in dispute orientation than f2f; users of IM may maintain a lower ratio of reluctance markers to aggravating moves.

column3: Continuous Crowdsourcing
column9: Walter Lasecki, Adam Marcus, Jeffrey Rzeszotarski, Jeffrey Bigham
column100: Crowdsourcing; User experience/interaction design
column101: Crowdsourcing workflows are often based on breaking large tasks into smaller microtasks which are easy for workers to quickly understand and complete because workers have generally been assumed to be new to the task and willing to spend only a few seconds on each job. We describe continuous crowdsourcing, where workers complete longer tasks that have no definite start or end, and can be started or abandoned at a worker's discretion. This approach allows synchronous groups of workers to complete longer-term tasks, while building from experience over time. We introduce AssemblyLine, which allows control over task generation and delivery much in the way a traditional assembly line can be designed and controlled.  The implications of this work extend to traditional microtask work as we characterize the expected performance costs of switching between different kinds of microtasks and introducing delays between microtasks of the same kind.  We show that continuous task delivery can reduce response latency while increasing throughput.

column3: The antecedents of remix
column9: Giorgos Cheliotis, Nan Hu, Jude Yew, Jianhui Huang
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social network analysis; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Reuse of the works of others has become common practice on the Internet and has formed the basis for collaboration in some online communities. However, some works are reused much more frequently than others. In this article, we build a causal model that explains which factors are most salient in determining the likelihood that an author’s work will be reused. Controlling for common factors, such as the work’s popularity, we show that the probability of reuse depends on (a) the degree of derivativity of the work in question, (b) the specific ways in which it derives meaning from other works (intertextuality), (c) the audience’s preferential attachment to authors of high fecundity, and (d) the author’s social embededness in networks of reuse. We use trace data from an online community that was built for the purpose of demonstrating the ability of open sharing and reuse to spur collaboration and innovation in music.

column3: Disconnected States of America: The Time Zone Bubble
column9: Martin Saveski, Daniele Quercia, Amin Mantrach
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Peaks and troughs of temporal activities online tend to be regularly shifted across time zones, and that might impact engagement in big countries like USA. Upon a random sample of 200K news articles and corresponding 41M comments  posted on the Yahoo! News in that country, we confirm that the most informative geographic unit for predicting engagement on articles is not state but time zone: users in the same time zone preferentially engage with each other on the same articles about the same topics, producing what we call "the time zone bubble". It is thus effective to recommend the most popular articles not in the whole USA but in the users' (IP address-derived) time zones, especially to users (the majority) whose past preferences are unknown (cold-start situation).  Interestingly, at state level, topics one reads about are associated with  specific socio-economic conditions and personality traits.

column3: That is what they said, but I doubt so:  News Verification in Chinese social media
column9: Yiran Wang, Gloria Mark
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: In recent years, China has seen a dramatic growth in the use of social media, noticeably for citizen engagement in sharing and discussing current news events. However, due to the an increasing amount of misinformation in China’s social media environment, questioning and verifying suspicious news is becoming extremely important. Our study investigates how people in China recognize and address questionable news items within social media, as well as the agency manifest in individual users’ news verification practices. We found that Chinese social media users in general are more suspicious of the content features, rather than the social features of a news post. Most of our sample reported to have verified news and shared their findings on social media using different ways, indicating a level of agency. We also addressed agency from the perspective of responsibility and gender. Our study provides a new angle to study credibility assessment. It also helps explore new forms of agency exercised in citizen media, situated in a broader authoritarian context.

column3: Designing for the Deluge: Understanding & Supporting the Distributed, Collaborative Work of Crisis Volunteers
column9: Camille Cobb, Ted McCarthy, Kate Starbird, Annuska Perkins
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: As mobile computing and social media grow increasingly popular, they become a potentially valuable source of crisis-related information for situational awareness. It is now widely believed that information gained from social media can contribute knowledge to the official response and help individuals affected by disasters. Consistently, “digital volunteers” and others are coming together to filter and process this data into usable resources, often coordinating their work within distributed, online groups. However, current tools and practices are often unable to keep up with the speed and volume of incoming data in large events. Through contextual interviews with experienced emergency response professionals and digital volunteers, and within the context of an ongoing design effort, this research examines the ad hoc, collaborative practices that have emerged to help process this data and outlines strategies for supporting and leveraging these efforts in future designs.

column3: Understanding Office Energy Consumption from Employee’s Daily Experience
column9: Xiying Wang, Kshitiz Singh, Du Li
column100: User experience/interaction design; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
