column101: While significant attentions have been paid to energy efficiency in households and organizations, relatively little work addresses the collaborative aspects of energy conservation in office buildings. Our smart energy project examines energy consumption in office buildings from employees’ everyday experience. We apply connected technologies as a design lens to understand it. In this project, energy is considered as a networked collaborative system that connects and influences multiple users in a shared office space. At the same time, users' habits, experience, and interactions in the workspace shape the use of energy. From interviews, we learn that energy cost and lack of automations are two main challenges for saving energy at work. Making energy-related information available to employees motivate energy-saving practices at work. Collaboratively saving energy at work is preferable. At the end, we suggest a set of design features for a networked collaborative smart energy system to facilitate energy conservation practices in office buildings.

column3: Technology Opportunities in Urban Planning Review
column9: Rojin Vishkaie, Cand. Phil., Richard Levy, PhD. MCIP, Anthony Tang
column23: University of Calgary, Calgary, Alberta, Canada
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Urban planners play an important role, negotiating plans with developers on behalf of the city and its inhabitants. They also function as shepherds for a developer’s development application, communicating with civic technicians, who ensure adherence to regulations and local bylaws, civic committees and the general public. As a communication proxy between all these different stakeholders, planners often find themselves at the center of miscommunications—often due to assumptions and discussions made over impoverished tools. Our interest in this work was to explore the planning process from the perspective of urban planners—to understand their communication practices, and the challenges they face when working with different stakeholders—with the goal of designing communication technologies to better support these communication activities. We studied 12 urban planners from a major Canadian urban center to inform our perspective, and find that participatory urban planning comprises several functionally different phases—each with different communication and interactive requirements for visual tools to support urban planning.

column3: Polarization in the Political Blogosphere: 2009 - 2012
column9: Stephanie Lee, Sean Munson
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Nearly a decade ago, Adamic & Glance (2005) published a dramatic image of the fragmentation of discussion in the U.S. political blogosphere. Since, several studies have explored the extent to which this fragmentation has persisted over time and measured similar effects in new online spaces, such as Twitter. In this study, we revisit the political blogosphere’s linking patterns. Using a four-year data set of links from U.S. political blog posts, we explore whether political polarization is increasing over time, how fragmentation might change according to contemporary events, and which URLs receive attention from both conservative- and liberal-leaning blogs. We find similar link patterns as previous studies. Over the four years of data, polarization appears to be neither increasing nor decreasing. There may have been some decrease in conservative communication unity, but overall, the American political blogosphere does not appear to have become more fragmented since 2009.

column3: Awareness and Concern about Digital Footprints in Web Applications
column9: Emilee Rader
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: As we surf the web, we leave behind ``digital footprints’’ --- bits of information that are evidence of past behaviors and choices --- that that can be aggregated to infer things about us like our political beliefs, shopping preferences, and personal characteristics. To what extent are we aware that this is happening, and how much does this worry us? Participants in an online experiment were exposed to one of three different scenarios depicting a common, ordinary situation one might encounter while using Facebook or Google. The results provide clues about circumstances under which web-savvy users are aware that this is happening, and whether they are concerned about it. For example, participants were most concerned about unwanted access to private information when exposed to a scenario involving advertisements that related to a sensitive topic presented in the sidebar of a Facebook News Feed, and were least concerned when the scenario was about clicking a Google search result link.

column3: Symp.ly Real-Time Collaboration System
column9: Wei Jia, Stephen Cooper
column100: Collaboration architectures; Concurrency control; Distributed/virtual teams; Collaborative software development
column101: In this paper, we describe a novel real-time collaboration system, Symp.ly that can be utilized both as a group collaboration tool, and as an individual task management tool. Existing productivity software has two main problems. First, they are either only effective for high level milestone and goal setting, or low level individual tasks; no collaboration tool solves both problems. Second, they generally do not provide real-time collaborative syncing with negligible time delay. Symp.ly solves both of these problems by providing an infinitely nestable hierarchical organizational structure, and fully integrated real-time syncing for both text and data structure. We also conducted an empirical study that demonstrated the viability and effectiveness of Symp.ly. We highlight the important features that make a collaboration tool effective in group-based work environments.

column3: The Policy Knot: Re-integrating Policy, Practice and Design in CSCW Studies of Social Computing
column9: Steven Jackson, Tarleton Gillespie, Sandy Payette
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Location-based and context-aware computing; Legal/historical/philosophical aspects
column101: In CSCW and information science research today, the worlds of design, practice and policy are often held separate, speaking to different audiences, venues, and fields of expertise. But many growing areas of CSCW work, including mobile, cloud, and social computing, run into problems at precisely this intersection. This paper presents a model for understanding processes of change and emergence in social computing in which policy, practice, and design show up in the form of complex interdependencies, or knots, which collectively determine the shape, meaning and trajectory of shifting computational forms. We then apply this model to the recent controversy over the location-aware mobile app Girls Around Me, which, when examined with an eye for policy’s interaction with design and users, turns out to be a multi-layered issue involving the intentions app designers, the policies of platforms like Foursquare and Facebook.  Finally, we examine policy negotiations in the case of Google Buzz and the privacy complaint issued in response by the Federal Trade Commission.

column3: Hidden Affinities: Inferring Opportunities for Serendipitous Introductions
column9: Julia Mayer, Chris Markson, Quentin (Gad) Jones
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Location-based and context-aware computing; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Every day people miss out on numerous opportunities to make new connections with interesting people around them. This paper introduces new approaches to identifying opportunities for computer-mediated introductions based on situated social context and social inferences. People’s openness and motivation to meet new people in various places and situations was explored through an interview study. Findings extracted from an analysis of 46 interviews were used to develop a theoretical framework outlining the relationship between current context, openness to meet people, affinity strength, and matching opportunities. We propose several new innovative design concepts for opportunistic social matching systems including contextual rarity, contextual oddity, contextual sociability and skill/attitude matching.

column3: Agency in the Transit Dependent Experience: Resourcefulness, Resilience, and Powerlessness
column9: Emma Rose, Robert Racadio, Travis Martin, Deidre Girard, Joe Sullivan, Beth Kolko
column100: Other domain-specific support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Transportation is a crucial resource that enables access to other resources such as jobs, health care, services, and social capital. In the design of transportation systems, the needs and deep expertise of transit dependent riders, that is, those who do not drive and rely on public transportation, are often overlooked. In this paper, we present results of a design ethnography that investigated the experience of the transit dependent by combining multiple qualitative research methods and Structuration Theory. By conducting research with groups of socially connected people and framing the results that extend the notion of agency found in structuration, we describe the collaborative and social practices of overcoming transportation constraints. Additionally, we identify three framing categories of agency, including resourcefulness, resilience, and powerlessness. Through these categories, we identify opportunities for design of systems and services that could improve the transit experience for transit dependent riders and beyond.

column3: The Role of Collaborative Information Systems in Evidence-Based Clinical Practice
column9: Gabriela Marcu, Sara Kiesler, Anind Dey
column100: Medical and health support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Collaboration among healthcare practitioners requires integrating different evidence to make decisions about a patient. Evidence may include a patient’s data, a practitioner’s experiences with other patients, scientific studies, and established best practices. This process, known as evidence-based clinical practice, has been shown in the literature to be difficult to implement. We investigated collaboration in mental and behavioral health services for children with special needs—-a domain involving large amounts of complex patient data and a range of stakeholders to interpret and act on the data for clinical practice. We found disparate information needs among the stakeholders involved. To meet these needs and support knowledge sharing among these stakeholders, we propose a collaborative information system that represents data appropriately to different stakeholders, and helps stakeholders communicate their interpretations of data and share relevant knowledge based on their varied areas of expertise.

column3: Information Extraction and Manipulation Threats in Crowd-Powered Systems
column9: Walter Lasecki, Jaime Teevan, Ece Kamar
column100: Crowdsourcing; Privacy/access control/trust; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Crowd-powered systems have become a popular way to augment the capabilities of automated systems in real-world settings. Many of these systems rely on human workers to evaluate potentially sensitive data or make important decisions. This puts these systems at risk of unintentionally releasing data or having their outcomes maliciously manipulated. While almost all crowd-powered approaches account for noise in the work of individual workers, few factor in active attacks on the system. We analyze different forms of threats from individuals and groups of workers to extract information from crowd-powered systems and to manipulate outcomes. Via a set of studies performed on Amazon’s Mechanical Turk platform, we demonstrate the viability of these threats. We show that the current system is vulnerable to coordinated attacks on a task based on the requests of another and that a significant portion of Mechanical Turk workers are willing to contribute to an attack. Our findings enable the crowd to continue to play an important part in increasingly critical situations.

column3: To Risk or Not to Risk? Improving Financial Risk Taking of Older Adults by Online Social Information
column9: Chen Zhao, Wai-Tat Fu, Hanzhe Zhang, Henry Been-Lirn Duh, Shengdong Zhao
column100: B2B / information systems; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: An increasingly common online activity of older adults is to manage their retirement savings. A crucial element for better management is the extent to which financial risk taking is rational – whether there is a reasonable balance between expected reward and loss in face of uncertainty. Financial networking websites, utilizing emerging Web 2.0 technologies, have the potential to help risk management by allowing users to learn from others. It is, however, still unclear whether they can help older adults make more rational decisions, especially because older adults are often vulnerable to poor risk management . Using an experiment expanded upon an existing experimental economic task, we investigated how older adults’ investment decisions were affected by social information. We found that both peer and majority information could help older adults make more rational decisions. Furthermore, the more risk-averse an older adult was, the more influential the aggregates of social information became. Design implications of interfaces that harness online social information to improve decision making are discussed.

column3: Data Quality In Purposeful Games
column9: Nathan Prestopnik, Kevin Crowston, Jun Wang
column32: Syracuse University, Syracuse, New York, United States
column100: Crowdsourcing; User experience/interaction design; Entertainment/games
column101: A key problem for crowd-sourced systems is motivating contributions from participants and ensuring the quality of these contributions. Games have been suggested as a motivational approach but there are concerns about data quality, particularly when the data are to be used for scientific research. To address these concerns, we compare the quality of data obtained from two citizen science games, one a “gamified” version of a species classification task and one a fantasy game that used the classification task only as a way to advance in the game play. Surprisingly, though we did observe cheating in the fantasy game, data quality from the two games was not significantly different. As well, the quality of data from short-time contributors was at a usable level. These findings suggest that games can be a useful way to motivate contributions to citizen science projects.

column3: Privacy enhancing video filters through crowdsourcing
column9: Ian Spiro, Chris Bregler
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: We show test subjects processed videos of human gestures then quiz the subjects to see if and when they can identity the people or their body language. Our results show that motion-centric filters, such as frame-differencing and motion dots offer the potential to obscure identity well while minimally impacting the ability to identify certain gestures.

column3: SigSigns: A Non-Intrusive Approach To Enable Communication With The Deaf
column9: Rushil Khurana, Vani Sivasankar, Nikhil Mahajan, Ponnurangam Kumaraguru
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Mobile and embedded devices; User experience/interaction design
column101: A lot of research work has been put in to cure deafness, however \ has met strong resistance from deaf community who see \ the cure as a stigma on their culture. Focus needs to be \ put in towards technologies that improve upon the communication \ medium between the deaf community and the hearing world. \ We present SigSigns which is aimed to bridge the communication  \ gap in scenarios where a short conversation is required.  \ We show an evaluation study of our application which puts forth the \ notion that in a context-aware scenario, SigSigns can be used \ to facilitate short conversations between the deaf individual \ and a person who doesnt understand signs. SigSigns is non-intrusive  \ in nature as no special equipment is required to facilitate \ communication. It runs over a smart phone and thus can be deemed to  \ have a wider reach over other hardware technologies designed for the same purpose.

column3: Yahoo’s indictment of telecommuting: A call for a renewed focus on researching and designing for distributed work
column9: Toni Ferro
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Distributed working has been made viable by the evolution of communications technologies, however, many of the disadvantages of distributed working are social in nature and are difficult to resolve through technical solutions alone. That continued issues with distributed working remain was evidenced earlier this year when Yahoo asked its telecommuting workers to transition back to the workplace. This study uses the understudied phenomenon of coworking to shed new light on the issues of distributed work and calls for a renewed focus on researching and designing for distributed work.

column3: Cursing on Social Media
column9: Wenbo Wang, Lu Chen, Krishnaprasad Thirunarayan, Amit Sheth
column41: Department of Computer Science, Wright State University, Dayton, Ohio, United States
column100: Social network analysis; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Cursing is not uncommon during conversations in the physical world: 0.5% to 0.7% of all the words we speak are curse words, while 1% of all the words are first-person plural pronouns (e.g., we, us, our). On social media, people can instantly chat with friends without face-to-face interaction, and such interaction is usually more public and can be broadly disseminated through highly connected social network. Will these distinctive features of social media lead to a change in people's cursing behavior? In this paper, we examine the characteristics of cursing activity on a popular social media platform -- Twitter, involving the analysis of 51 million tweets and about 22 million users. In particular, we explore a set of questions that have been recognized as crucial for understanding cursing in offline communications by prior studies, including the ubiquity, utility, and contextual dependencies of cursing.

column3: Online Attention Deficit Disorder: Successful Brazilian cities speak local and go global
column9: Carmen Vaca-Ruiz, Daniele Quercia, Luca Aiello, Piero Fraternali
column14: Dip. di Elettronica, Informazione e Bioingegneria (DEIB)
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social network analysis; Location-based and context-aware computing; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Rapid urbanization in developing countries calls for updating socio-economic indicators in a timely fashion. The prohibitive costs of census data collection make that difficult, if not impossible. To avoid allocating resources upon outdated indicators, one could partly update them using digital data. It has been shown that this is possible in developed countries, mainly UK and USA. Here we show that this is the case for Brazil too. We analyze a random sample of a microblogging service popular in that country and accurately predict both city economic capital and social capital. To make these predictions, upon well-established urban sociology theories, we build indexes for the local and global attention attracted by the content produced in a city as well as its efficiency at generating ideas that spread further away in the social graph. We observe that these features effectively signal the well-being of offline communities.

column3: The Impact of Context Collapse Management Strategies on Social Capital in Facebook
column9: Youyang Hou, Cliff Lampe
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: Facebook users encounter challenges managing different online social relationships, which potentially influences the social capital benefits they might experience by interacting with others through the site. In this study, we conducted an online survey of university students to examine factors that differentiated the choices between four social contexts management strategies: default setting, lowest common denominator, friends-only, and segregating friends. The lowest common denominator was the most frequently adopted strategy. Decisions between strategies were associated with user demographics and different motivations to regulate heterogeneous contexts. We also found that network diversity significantly interacted with different ways of regulating context collapse in determining the levels of social capital outcomes. We concluded that the design of SNS privacy regulating systems should consider users’ motivations and preferences, so as to sustain social capital outcomes though interaction with diverse social relations.

column3: Visualizations for Computer Mediated Group Conversations: Exploring the Influences of Aggregated and Articulated Data Visibility on Group Dynamics
column9: Manoj Krishnan, John Espinosa, Karrie Karahalios
column23: computer science/university of illinois at urbana-champaign/social spaces
column24: university of illinois at urbana champaign
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Collaborative visualization; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: Groups are becoming increasingly geographically distributed; and consequently, computer-mediated group conversations are also becoming increasingly distributed. Much research has focused on visualizations that assist computer mediated conversations, and several theories about group conversations and visualizations have been developed. We explore the applicability of Social Translucence Theory, which advocates that individuals in group conversations attempt to conform to the group’s dynamic when individual-level information is made available publicly to the entire group. The theory also states that one of the main reasons behind such behavior is the sense of accountability that accompanies making individual level information public. We present a study designed to investigate whether the effects of Social Translucence theory can coexist with anonymity and if group conformity occurs even without individual level information being made public. We found that user behavior patterns did not exhibit significant differences in the two conditions with different levels of data visibility, which suggests that anonymity and accountability may not be as key a factor in small group conversation.

column3: The Doing of Doing Stuff: How People Coordinate Social Group-Activities
column9: Richard Schuler, Sukeshini Grandhi, Julia Mayer, Steve Ricken, Quentin Jones
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: With the near universal adoption of mobile and social computing technologies in the last decade, it is important to understand if and how these technologies have transformed the group coordination process. In this paper we present a diary study of 36 Millennials that provides an overview of how individuals in today’s technology rich environment perform social group-activity coordination as well as the challenges they face. The findings highlight how people primarily use open-channel communication tools (e.g., text messaging, phone calls, email) to coordinate because the alternatives are seen as either disrupting or curbing the natural conversational processes. While at the same time the use of such tools often results in confusion about who and how people are involved, and what has been decided upon. We interpret these findings through a synthesis of three existing theories and provide implications for the design of technology to support group activity coordination.

column3: Exploring In-situ Privacy Control for Message Pop-up on Smartphones
column9: Chulhong Min, Saumay Pushp, Seungchul Lee, Younghyun Ju, Youngki Lee, Junehwa Song
column32: Department of Computer Science / Network Computing Lab.
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: Today’s smartphones serve as a gateway for online interaction. Due to their casual and instant nature, people use frequent mobile messaging to be connected with others constantly. At the same time, smartphones are being used as a medium for face-to-face interaction as well, e.g., viewing photos and reading articles together. However, such multi-utility of smartphones would incur privacy threats due to push messages, which are delivered anytime even while smartphones are being shared. This breaches privacy isolation across two different social circles in online/face-to-face interactions. In this paper, we propose an ‘in-situ privacy control’ concept and service. It dynamically screens incoming messages in-situ by reflecting user’s situational contexts and preferences. We conduct motivational studies to deeply understand privacy concerns and their key factors. Based on our findings, we develop a working prototype system on Android phones. Through the deployment, we show proof-of-the concept and deliver empirically derived lessons.

column3: SignUP: Mobile Application for Seniors’ Participation and Engagement with Local Community
column9: Young Lee, Shirley Chaysinh, Hiren Mandalia, Crysta Metcalf, Syed Hassan
column100: Mobile and embedded devices; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use; User experience/interaction design; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: In this paper, we describe the development and evaluation of a mobile application prototype, called SignUP, which aims to facilitate seniors’ participation and engagement with their local community. Inspired by findings from the previous ethnographic research, SignUP was designed to offer 1) a range of local event information that is personalized to users’ interest, 2) a simple means for users to gauge their peers’ interest in the events, and 3) various communication means to socialize with their peers around the event. In a month-long field trial with six participants from an art-related interest group, we found that SignUP provided positive support to increase seniors’ engagement in the local events and social connection with existing peers. We present detailed qualitative results from the evaluation study and provide insights on the enhancement of SignUP as a technology to facilitate seniors’ communication and coordination for local event participation.

column3: Exploring the Roles of Analogy in Interdisciplinary Design
column9: Ashok Goel, Ashok Goel, Bryan Wiltgen, Bryan Wiltgen
column100: Other domain-specific support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: In practice, design typically is collaborative and often also interdisciplinary. One would expect cognitive dissonance on design teams, especially interdisciplinary teams.  In theory, analogy is the core of human cognition.  Thus, one would expect analogy to be all over the place in collaborative interdisciplinary design practice.  We describe a study into the roles of analogy in biologically inspired design.  Biologically inspired design is an emerging movement in modern design driven by the need for environmentally sustainable development.  Biologically inspired design is based on analogies from biology to technology, and its practice typically is both collaborative and interdisciplinary.  In this paper, we report on two findings from our research.  First, analogy indeed plays a major role in several tasks such as design concept generation, evaluation, and explanation.  Second, interdisciplinary design teams do have cognitive dissonance because the team members have different mental models.  Analogy plays an important role in persuading team members to change their perspectives on the current problem and thus reduce cognitive dissonance.

column3: A kernel theory of research infrastructure
column9: David Ribes
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaboration architectures; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Infrastructure makes it easier, faster or possible for investigators to study new objects of research. It does so by making available stable resources and services such as data, collaboration tools, sites of sample collection, or calibrated instruments. This paper offers the concept of the kernel of a research infrastructure as a new unit of analysis for investigating the enabling capacities of infrastructure. The kernel is the core resources and services an infrastructure makes available (called the cache), as well as the work, techniques and technologies that go into sustaining that availability (called addressing). By inspecting and comparing the kernel of two long-term scientific enterprises, this paper demonstrates how focusing on the kernel can help explain key qualities of research infrastructure such as flexibility and persistence in the face of dramatic changes to the objects, methods and practice of science.

column3: Visually-integrated collaborative ideation:  Changing the dynamics of creativity in design teams
column9: Lorraine Kisselburgh, Senthil Chandrasegaran, Jeremy Foote, Sriram Karthik Badam, Patricia Gettings, Teis Kristensen, Kylie Peppler, Niklas Elmqvist, Karthik Ramani
column77: School of Electrical and Computer Engineering
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Computer-Mediated Communication; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design
column101: This study examines the dynamics of collaboration and creativity in brainstorming teams. We hypothesize that visually integrated collaborative design environments provide affordances that enhance participation and turn-taking dynamics, leading to stronger elaboration and fluency in ideation, and generating higher quality outcomes of collaboration and creativity. We designed a prototype Visually Integrated Cyber-Enabled Design (VICED) system, and then examined how teams collaborate on a toy design task using the VICED system compared to traditional pencil-and-paper methods. We used real-time sociometric data to measure collaboration dynamics, and the effect of environment on creativity and collaboration outcomes. Findings indicate that the affordances of VICED fundamentally change collaborative dynamics by increasing turn-taking and successful interrupts, as well as participation equity, creating a more collaborative dynamic in design teams. Enhanced turn-taking is indicative of elaboration, an important construct of creativity as well as collaboration. Findings also suggest that VICED affordances positively affect collaboration quality and creative fluency, but not the experience of creative flow.

column3: Social (Media) Graces: making sense of norms in ritual posts
column9: Jennifer Kim, Karrie Karahalios, Michael Twidale
column15: University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social network analysis
column101: Social norms predate technology. In 1922, the visiting card, when left at a home, was evidence to family and other visitors of a visitor’s presence. Emily Post’s book, Etiquette explained these rules. In this paper, we explore norms in social media through a case study of Facebook birthday posts. Participants described their posting behavior through analogies to greeting cards (birthday, Christmas, postcards).  The  tech and social media savvy participants in our study explained and analyzed the subtlety, complexity and nuance of their decisions to send a post, decide what to include in a post, reply to a post, and interpret a birthday post.  While there is currently no explicit book or set of rules on Facebook birthday etiquette, we find distinct patterns of Facebook posting behavior with respect to closeness of relationship.  In particular, we found a greater value placed on posts from connections that were very strong a long time ago.

column3: Examining the Differential Mood Effects of Internet Services: Does Facebook Make Sadder People Sadder?
column9: Galen Panger
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: While a number of recent studies look at the impact of Internet services such as Facebook on the happiness and well-being of users, few if any do so on a comparative basis across social media or other categories of Internet services. Furthermore, many studies examine the main effect of usage on some aspect of well-being, but don’t look at how the experience might be different for people who are happier or perhaps more depressed generally. Are there differential effects in that, for example, some services make happier people happier, and depressed people more depressed? In this study, we contribute a simple comparative survey of the mood impacts of seven Internet services, Google Search, Wikipedia, Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, YouTube and Netflix, and we provide suggestive evidence through self-reports that people with different levels of happiness and depression have different experiences with these services. In particular, Facebook and LinkedIn seem to have the greatest differential effects.

column3: Communicative Bursts and Idea Sharing in Collaborative Engineering Design Processes
column9: Patricia Gettings, Teis Kristensen, Jeremy Foote, Lorraine Kisselburgh, Sriram Karthik Badam, Senthil Chandrasegaran, Karthik Ramani
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Collaborative visualization; Collaborative software development
column101: In this study we examine the dynamics between communicative markers and idea sharing in a collaborative context. We hypothesize that there are identifiable communicative signatures of speech volume and body movement, called bursts, which correlate with one another. Additionally, we posit that increased speech volume and body movement by team members can predict idea sharing. To test these hypotheses, a Visually Integrated Cyber-enabled Design (V-ICED) system is used in conjunction with real-time sociometric data collected via wearable sociometric badges. Our findings support the presence of identifiable bursts indicated by communicative markers and that participant speech volume and movement activity positively correlate with one another. Additionally, the study indicates that alter volume may predict idea sharing, but that alter movement activity does not. Implications for brainstorming in engineering design contexts are discussed.

column3: Reconciling Rhythms: Plans and Temporal Alignment in Collaborative Scientific Work
column9: Stephanie Steinhardt, Steven Jackson
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Distributed/virtual teams; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Collaborative work in large-scale science projects depends on the alignment of multiple and often discordant temporal rhythms. Under such conditions, plans and planning assume a central role and challenge. Plans delineate points of stress between competing rhythms, calling out conflicts that may impact the completion of work. Plans gather and align separate rhythms at scales ranging from the small to the large, mediating between the temporalities embedded in local practices and those emanating from larger institutional levels. And plans establish common baselines of expectation around and against which local choice and action may be calibrated. Through ethnographic field work surrounding a large-scale collaborative ocean science initiative, we identify how plans change rhythms and how rhythms change plans at crucial moments: in the formation of plans (‘plans-in-the-making’) and in their active deployment across distributed worlds of practice (‘plans-in-action’). The temporal alignments detailed here hold implications for CSCW research, design and policy around new infrastructure development in the sciences and other sites of large-scale distributed practice.

column3: Cloudy Forecast: An Exploration of the Factors Underlying Common Repository Use
column9: Charlotte Massey, Thomas Lennig, Steve Whittaker
column33: University of California at Santa Cruz
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaboration architectures
column101: An important barrier to collaboration is the organizational \ bottleneck, where collaborators abandon shared tools \ because they cannot agree common schemes for organizing \ shared information. We conducted a qualitative study of 27 \ participants exploring their collaboration practices. We \ found that they used an average of 4 different collaboration \ tools. We found they were able to overcome the \ organizational bottleneck by combining tools in the form of \ ContentMaps, where participants provide each other with \ explicit task and information structure. They also organized \ information collaboratively using implicit strategies based \ on role and expertise. Both strategies were successful in \ supporting collaborative information access. While we had \ expected successful adoption of collaborative tools to lead \ to abandonment of email, instead we found new uses of \ email in collaboration. We present technical implications \ suggesting how new tools might be better integrated with \ email facilitating these emergent email uses.

column3: CoSMiC: Designing an In-situ Mobile Crowd-sourced Collaborative Application to Find Missing Children
column9: Hyojeong Shin, Taiwoo Park, Bupjae Lee, Seungwoo Kang, Junehwa Song
column24: KAIST(Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
column33: KAIST(Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
column69: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
column100: Collaboration architectures; Location-based and context-aware computing; Crowdsourcing
column101: Finding a missing child is an important problem concerning not only parents but also our society. It is essential and natural to use serendipitous clues from neighbors for finding a missing child. In this paper, we explore a new architecture of crowd collaboration to expedite such a mission-critical process and propose a crowd-sourced cooperative mobile application, CoSMiC that helps parents find a missing child quickly at the very moment of missing. A key idea lies in construction of the location history of a missing kid via crowd participation, thereby leading parents to their kid easily and quickly. To fully harness potential participants who can give helps, we propose the concept of virtual encounter. It enables the collection of enough amount of in-situ observations, which can be crafted to valuable location history for parents. We implement a prototype application and conduct extensive user studies to assess the design of the application and investigate its potential for practical use.

column3: Social Media’s Not Just a Soapbox: How Constituents Lobby Congress via Twitter
column9: Libby Hemphill, Andrew Roback
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Legal/historical/philosophical aspects; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Twitter is increasingly becoming a medium through which constituents can lobby their elected representatives in Congress about issues that matter to them. Past research has focused on how citizens communicate with each other or how members of Congress (MOCs) use social media in general; our research examines how citizens communicate with MOCs. We contribute to existing literature through the careful examination of hundreds of citizen-authored tweets and the development of a categorization scheme to describe common strategies of lobbying on Twitter. Our findings show that contrary to past research that assumed citizens used Twitter as a soapbox, citizens utilize a variety of sophisticated techniques to effect political outcomes.

column3: IdeaToilet: Vitalizing Online Survey on Public Issues Using Posters in Bathroom Stalls
column9: KyoungHee Son, Seoyoung Min, Seungwoo Je
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Location-based and context-aware computing; Crowdsourcing
column101: A place of public toilet is a space of only their privacy is  \ guaranteed. We have confirmed that you have the role of  \ the window that people to express their views to the social  \ problems of the special toilet throughout the experiment. \ We created an online community that allows you to express  \ an opinion on social issues. We, the public relations how to  \ connect by using the QR code to the location of the public  \ rest room, toilet, such as El beta this community. We were  \ able to experimental results, it is confirmed that people to  \ join the most to the toilet. We can be sure that it is a system that is Torureto represent the opinions economic and social issues for people who are  \ most effective in everyday life idea

column3: Go Play Outside: Second Order Game Playing in EVE Online
column9: Bridget Blodgett, Elizabeth Thiry
column100: Entertainment/games; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies
column101: In this paper, we examine the role of second level game playing, including the use of metagaming and emergent game play, as a way for players in MMORPGs to expand their control over the game world. This study used discourse analysis of primary textual documents specifically dealing with a case surrounding the exposure of developer corruption within the EVE Online community to examine the complexity of second level game play within MMORPGs. The analysis of this case is used to explore the role of second level game playing within the EVE Online community, and how this level of play effects individual players’ enjoyment and participation within the EVE Online community.

column3: Automated Decision Support for Human Tasks in a Collaborative System: the Case of Deletion in Wikipedia
column9: Bluma Gelley, Torsten Suel
column100: Collaboration architectures; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Wikipedia’s low barriers to participation have the unintended effect of attracting a large number of articles whose topics do not meet Wikipedia’s inclusion standards. Many are quickly deleted, often causing their creators to stop contributing to the site. We collect and make available several datasets of deleted articles, heretofore inaccessible, and use them to create a model that can predict with high precision whether or not an article will be deleted. We report precision of .986 and recall of .975 in the best case and high precision with lower, but still useful, recall, in the most difficult case. We propose to deploy a system utilizing this model on Wikipedia as a set of decision-support tools to help article creators evaluate and improve their articles before posting, and new article patrollers make more informed decisions about which articles to delete and which to improve.

column3: Let Your Keyboard Smile For You: Happiness Increases Non-Verbal Emotional Cues in Instant Messaging
column9: Afarin Pirzadeh, Mark Pfaff
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: In spite of rapid growth of text-based instant messaging (IM) in very diverse settings, emotion expression in IM has received limited empirical scrutiny, especially inside casual settings. The main focus of this study is how four emotional states (relaxed, angry, happy, sad) influence the type and quantity of emotion-related cues used during informal conversations between friends in IM. Results of the analysis revealed that the happy condition led to more use of nonverbal cues than the other three conditions, including more punctuation, vocal spellings, lexical surrogates, and emoticons. Understanding how users express emotions in IM helps researchers and designers to support the user’s emotional needs, resulting in the improvement of emotional communication strategies in IM.

column3: AskSheet:  Efficient Use of Web Workers to Support Decision Making
column9: Alexander Quinn, Benjamin Bederson
column24: Human-Computer Interaction Lab, University of Maryland
column100: Crowdsourcing; Collaboration architectures; Workflow management; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: The wealth of information and social resources online has empowered individuals and businesses with an unprecedented volume of information to aid in decision making processes. However, this potential is often limited by the labor required to find and process the many details needed for a given decision.  We present AskSheet, a general system that leverages human computation to acquire the inputs to a decision model, which is provided by the user in the form of an arbitrary spreadsheet.  The core innovation of AskSheet is the capability to prioritize the inputs to enable the crowd to focus on the details that impact the end result most.  This can be viewed as an adaptation of individual information seeking behavior to crowds.  The prioritization algorithms use a probabilistic analysis of the spreadsheet formulas to calculate value of information for each of the inputs.  This paper describes the method, the AskSheet system, and our experiences using it.

column3: Elicitation and Consequences of Support in an Online Breast Cancer Support Community
column9: Tatiana Vlahovic, Yi-Chia Wang, Robert Kraut, John Levine
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: We conducted a two-part investigation on Amazon Mechanical Turk of linguistic support processes in a large online breast cancer support community. We first examined how users of the support community use elicitation strategies (question asking and four kinds of self-disclosure) to acquire the social support that they need (emotional and informational support). We then analyzed the consequences (satisfaction) of users receiving or not receiving the social support that they need. We found that three kinds of disclosure elicited emotional support, while question asking discouraged emotional support. Question asking and negative informational disclosure elicited informational support, but negative emotional disclosure discouraged informational support. Users were more satisfied when they asked questions and received informational support, but they were less satisfied when they asked questions and received emotional support. However, users were not more or less satisfied when they self-disclosed and received either kind of social support.

column3: Validity and Reliability of Crowdsourcing Human-Computation Tasks
column9: Maria Menendez, Antonella De Angeli, Fausto Giunchiglia
column100: Crowdsourcing
column101: In recent years, researchers in a variety of domains, and especially in computer science, have eagerly adopted crowdsourcing as a way to perform tasks, which in the past were left to the dedication of research assistants. However, it is not clear how valid and reliable the data gathered through crowdsourcing is. In order to test this, we asked different groups of people to fill out information concerning a Knowledge Base (KB) on Italian monuments. KBs are data repositories which have been traditionally populated, maintained, and fixed by computers and experts. Current approaches to creating KBs are too costly and do not scale. It is therefore important to find alternative methods to create these KBs and crowdsourcing could be an interesting solution if it results in high quality data. Our results indicate that, compared to traditional KB annotators, crowdsourcing was both faster and cheaper and had an acceptable level of validity; however, reliability level depended on the task.

column3: HABLO: Inaudible Acoustic Beacons for Micro-Localization
column9: Sven Kratz, Jacob Biehl
column100: Location-based and context-aware computing; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: We present HABLO, an acoustic beacon system for low-range (< 0.5 m) indoor localization, which remains a difficult task for existing indoor localization technologies. The beacons work in an audio band which is inaudible to humans but can be received by the microphones on consumer devices such as laptops, tablets and smart phones. HABLO is designed to be low-cost, easy to integrate with existing infrastructure using USB connectors and to be usable with unmodified end-user devices. We present a technical description of the software and hardware implementation of our prototype and show the results of an initial feasibility study of our system for a localization application within an office environment.

column3: The challenge of situated and organization learning and identity development in Pro-Am Live Video Broadcasting
column9: Oskar Juhlin, Elin Onnevall, Arvid Engström
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing
column101: ProAm live video producers broadcast events on a regular basis. They are selected for an ethnographic study since their continuous content generation can teach us something of what it takes for amateurs, who currently struggle with utilizing this new media made available through mobile technology, to become proficient users. We learn from media theory that ProAm’s are distinguished from professionals in terms of inherent skills and identities, and have therefore focused on these characteristics. We add to this research by showing on-going challenges that the former faces in their broadcast i.e. how their learning practices, such as through instructions, are situated and related to particular settings. Further, the development of skills and learning was also done as organizations, rather than as individuals. This make visible some efforts needed to become a live video producer user that utilizes this medium on a steady basis. The findings guide design to better support activities contiguous with the set-up of the production, rather than the broadcast per se.

column3: Tangible Interaction with Spoken Content for Growth Markets: A Table-Top System
column9: Saurabh Srivastava, Nitendra Rajput
column100: Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Mobile and embedded devices; User experience/interaction design; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: Tangible interactions have enhanced computer-mediated support for activities such as learning, problem solving, and design. However, most of the tangible user interfaces have been explored in the context of west. We explore how these concepts could be incorporated into households and family life of illiterate populations in growth markets. We report our findings from an evaluation of a multimodal system with combination of gesture and audio from 12 low-literate and 6 literate users. Our results show that such tangible systems are well received by the low literate users and can be implemented to their day to day use cases.

column3: Strategies for Crowdsourcing Visual Design Critique
column9: Kurt Luther, Wei Wu, Amy Pavel, Maneesh Agrawala, Steven Dow, Bjorn Hartmann
column100: Crowdsourcing; E-Learning and Education
column101: Online critique systems have the potential to produce rapid and subjective feedback, thus reducing the time between design iterations. Given practical limitations on the availability of expert critique providers, we explore whether micro-task workers (Amazon turkers) are capable of providing informed design critique. Further, through a between-subjects study (N=133) of three different critique interfaces, we investigate whether we can scaffold turkers to produce results on par with non-turkers. As measured by independent expert reviewers, the study revealed no difference in the quality of critiques produced through the three interfaces. However, the principles-first version where participants select pre-authored statements and then add freeform comments led to more feedback. Those participants also provided overall higher Likert scores when asked whether the interface helped them learn about the critique process, notice issues in the design, and think carefully about the critique. This paper introduces our system CrowdCritter, presents experimental results, and discusses the design space for scaffolding crowd critique for visual design.

column3: To Search or to Ask: The Routing of Information Needs Between Traditional Search Engines and Social Networks
column9: Anne Oeldorf-Hirsch, Brent Hecht, Darren Gergle, Meredith Morris, Jaime Teevan
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: In status message question asking (SMQA), members of social networking sites make use of status messages to express information needs to friends and contacts. We present findings from a laboratory study that examined 82 participants’ SMQA behaviors in the broader context of online information seeking. When given the option of using a search engine and/or a social network, participants leveraged SMQA for 20% of their information needs, most often posing a question in addition to issuing a query. We uncover the motivations behind these routing choices and show how the information need and perceived audience of a given network play important roles. We then demonstrate how information needs and routing decisions are related to participants’ satisfaction, information value and trust of responses and query results. Our findings suggest that search engines may be able to better address up to 20% of information needs by integrating SMQA capabilities into their systems.

column3: Mining Twitter User Connections: Comparing Methods Based on Textual Content Analysis and Social Graphs
column9: Scott Piao, Genovefa Kefalidou, Jon Whittle, Sarah Sharples
column32: School of Computing and Communications, InfoLab21
column100: Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: We investigate the issue of mining new connections among Twitter users by analysing textual content of their tweets. We assume that textual content of tweets can potentially provide complementary information not captured in the Twitter social graphs, and it can possibly be used to detect a wider range of novel connections. We designed an algorithm which combines NLP and Metaphone phonetic algorithm to extract representative vectors of concepts and terms for the users from their tweets, then employ Cosine similarity metric to measure the distance between Twitter users based on the vectors. We evaluated this method in comparison with a Twitter social graph based one for a comparative study. Our evaluation demonstrates that textual content based method can produce results largely complementary to that of social graph based one, and combined together, they can potentially improve social recommendation tools by detecting a wider range of connections in social media space.

column3: Exploring an Augmented Collaborative Design Space Integrating the Familiar
column9: Sheng-Ying Pao
column100: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design
column101: Existing input technologies tend to push private and shared work to be produced on separate platforms, leading to an inefficiency of content generation and communication. We introduce an augmented pen interaction with integrated privacy, accomplished through intuitive gestures. The pen, with its original function as a content generation tool, is now an interface to share instantly with effortless communication and privacy control, thus fostering the creation of shared content. We developed a gesture sensing module compatible with any paper and COTS pens of user’s choosing, leveraging the existing skills of using pen and paper in co-located and remote collaborative environments. This paper describes the design of the system and interaction. This paper also presents the results from a user study, which evaluates the usability and concludes with implications for collaborative design space through familiar tools with integrated privacy.

column3: Socially Mediated Crisis Communication: Considerations for Small Businesses
column9: Kathleen Moore
column14: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: Small businesses increasingly use social media in their daily activities, but when it comes to communicating with stakeholders during a crisis, many lack the necessary resources to properly utilize the new digital medium. Using the sinking of ship the HMS Bounty as context, this paper explores the numerous pitfalls of social media for crisis communication and how recommended practices do not adequately reflect the realities of many small businesses. A discussion of possible design implications follows regarding the partnering social media with small business.

column3: Retweeting Political Sentiments: Polarization and Homogeneity in Twitter from 2012 Presidential Election in South Korea
column9: Ji Sue Lee, Jae-wook Ahn, Hohyon Ryu
column14: School of Library and Information Studies
column100: Social network analysis; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: This research integrates network analysis and content analysis to examine polarization and homogeneity in political communication network from the case of 2012 presidential election in South Korea. The retweeting networks were created from the viral political retweets including names of three presidential candidates for 25 days prior to Election Day. As a sample data, we used and analyzed the top 400 retweets and network properties information. We identified the ideologically segregated two communities (clusters), conservative and liberal, sharing similar sentiments towards the presidential candidates themselves and broader political orientations. Even though the negative sentiments are dominantly shared and circulated within both conservative and liberal communities, the difference on diversity of sentiment codes was detected between two communities. When retweeting tweets between communities, they show the different retweeting pattern in terms of sentiments.

column3: Hexart: Smart Merged Touch Tables
column9: Ahmed Samir, Abdallah Muhammed, Alaa Essam, Esraa Mohammed, Saleh Ahmed, Moustafa Attia, Ayman Atia
column59: HCI LAB, Dep of Computer Science, Faculty of Computers,  Helwan University
column100: Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Collaboration architectures; User experience/interaction design
column101: Group activities face some problems such as loss of time, lack of communication, and inability to efficiently integrate work parts. In this paper we introduce Hexart, a multi-touch tables system that has been designed for helping people in group activities. It introduces two major cooperation concepts, merging and splitting. Merging is a concept of allowing users to merge tables together to form a large multi-touch table and splitting is to allow users to split a table display into some private areas where each user gets a personal private area. Users can interact together through tables or private areas using a sharable public area that is available for all users. Hexart is based on FTIR with a physical hexagon shaped table. The proposed system allows smooth merging of table and sharing hexagon spaces. We have conducted an experiment to measure the user satisfaction and usability of hexagon multi-touch tables.

column3: Prokiwii: A projected portable interface for enriching object scenarios with kinect and Wii remote
column9: Ahmed Raafat, Mohamed Abd-Elaty, Ahmed Hany, Ahmed Rihan, Omar Magdy, Hassan Mazen
column14: HCI LAB, Dep of Computer Science
column15: Faculty of Computers Science,  Helwan University
column23: HCI LAB, Dep of Computer Science
column24: Faculty of Computers Science,  Helwan University
column32: HCI LAB, Dep of Computer Science
column33: Faculty of Computers Science,  Helwan University
column41: HCI LAB, Dep of Computer Science
column42: Faculty of Computers Science,  Helwan University
column50: HCI LAB, Dep of Computer Science
column51: Faculty of Computers Science,  Helwan University
column59: HCI LAB, Dep of Computer Science
column60: Faculty of Computers Science,  Helwan University
column100: User experience/interaction design; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: This paper presents an intuitive interaction technique for everyday objects. We propose a system that allows the user to interact with his everyday objects, and use them to make some scenarios. We enrich the objects with a portable projected interface that is supported by 3d accelerometer in order to build novel user object interaction scenarios. The user can interact with the surface using finger to select and manipulate interface. In addition, the surface can be used to control the projected interface too. We conducted experiment to test the applicability of our proposed system with different applications. Our results show that the proposed system has a lot of potentials to enrich different domains of applications (Montessori cubes, smart goods).

column3: Family Matters: Control and Conflict in Online Family History Production
column9: Heather Willever-Farr, Andrea Forte
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: Findagrave.com and Ancestry.com are sites that support the cooperative creation of public historical resources. These sites of cooperative production have attracted tens of thousands and millions of contributors respectively, yet they embrace content standards, social norms, and models of editorial control that differ radically from the well-studied exemplar of Wikipedia. In this study, we investigated how Ancestry.com and Findagrave.com support production of archival resources through analysis of message boards and interviews with participants. We found that these sites are not only places for building a historical resource, but simultaneously serve as opportunities for public memorialization and familial identity construction. Notably, we found that contributors to these websites embrace the idea of familial oversight of biographical information in order to maintain high standards of quality and they harbor a corresponding skepticism of the open editing practices that have become a hallmark of many open collaboration projects.

column3: When is it ok to use Mobile Devices in Meetings
column9: Robert Bajko, Deborah Fels, Ozgur Turetken
column32: Ted Rogers School of Management, Ryerson University, Torontp, Ontario, Canada
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Mobile and embedded devices; User experience/interaction design
column101: The smartphone is one of the fastest growing mobile devices in North America. As these devices grow in popularity, we have started seeing them appear in private business settings. This paper presents data for a 2012 online survey about mobile device use in business meetings. The major findings from the 255 participants include that the majority of participants feel it is inappropriate to use a laptop for personal use in meetings as well texting personal messages during a meeting. However, they feel that receiving or making work related voice calls and text messages during meetings is accepted. Participants also claimed that iPhones, Blackberrys, feature phones, and iPods are less viewed as being alright to be used in meetings compared to laptops, netbooks, iPads, and desktops.

column3: Approaches to Understand How Partially Distributed Teams Work Together or Separately: a Preliminary Findings from Conceptual Design Teams
column9: Yoon Suk Lee, Kyunghui Oh, Marie Paretti, Nicholas Polys, Brian Kleiner
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Social network analysis; Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing; Distributed/virtual teams; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: In this paper, we propose analysis methods to examine communication patterns of partially distributed conceptual design team members. Three analysis methods were described: (1) examining the frequencies of intra- and inter-sub-group communications, (2) identifying design topics that group members discussed, and (3) conducting network analysis to identify the ties among group members. The data collection, analysis, and the kinds of outcomes that can be produced by each analysis method are explained in the context of conceptual design domain.

column3: Showing the Way: The Implications of an Online Game for Virtual Collaborative Learning and Teaching
column9: Karen Schrier, David Shaenfield
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: In this study, four male participants are observed playing a game, Way, which is an online, synchronous, multiplayer game. In this game, participants cannot use verbal or written communication, and instead must use their avatars to nonverbally teach and learn from each other, solve collaborative tasks, and complete the game’s boards together. Based on an analysis of the four case studies, the researchers identified ten principles that could be used by designers of online virtual collaborative learning and work environments. Providing shared contexts and goals, a constrained set of nonverbal cues and gestures, and a system that values collaborative success, were suggested to enhance collaborative learning and engagement. Perhaps more surprising were that the anonymous nature of the collaboration, and pairing peers that each had limited knowledge, but were learning in tandem, seemed to enhance participant’s trust of each other and their own self-efficacy. These findings have implications for MOOCs and transnational corporations, where collaborators may not share the same language, customs, or culture.

column3: Tactics for Constructing Visions about Electronic Health Records (EHR)
column9: Nina Boulus-Rodje
column100: Medical and health support
column101: The literature about healthcare technologies has been \ expanding rapidly in the past few years. A great number of \ researchers draw upon sociotechnical approaches as well as \ work practice orientation, to unpack the situated and \ emergent practices and complexities. Nonetheless, \ relatively few studies examine critically and empirically the \ discursive processes that surround healthcare technologies. \ This paper analysis the media discourse surrounding \ Electronic Health Record (EHR) initiatives in North \ America. The analysis identifies the different tactics that \ are used in the media discourse. The paper illustrates how \ these tactics are used to showcase EHR initiatives in spite \ of weak empirical evidence. Investigating these conflicting \ visionary discourses is important because they lead to \ inflicted burden on designers and healthcare practitioners \ who are faced with different realities on the ground. \ Furthermore, these visionary discourses have influence on \ technology healthcare policies and design innovations.

column3: Computer-supported collaborative empathy
column9: Karthik Dinakar, Henry Lieberman
column100: Other domain-specific support; Machine Learning and Data Mining
column101: One way that computers can help support \ anonymous collaboration around emotional problems is to \ assure that participants find experiences that are highly relevant \ to their personal issues. This differs from a simple \ information-retrieval goal of finding stories that are merely \ similar in their surface aspects. We study an online community \ supporting distressed teenagers who seek help, mostly \ anonymously. We leverage a novel mixed-initiative machine \ learning technique in order to (1) map the landscape of distressed \ teen issues in this community, and (2) match a user’s \ personal story to relevant stories from the community, reducing \ feelings of isolation, and (3) provide a personalized list of \ external resources which offer specialized help relevant to the \ user’s problem. We report encouraging results from a fourmonth \ live public deployment on a popular youth-culture site \ sponsored by MTV. We also report on how our framework \ was found helpful by professionals in the field of prevention \ science, a branch of psychology concerned with preventing \ psychological problems rather than treating them post-facto.

column3: Search in Social Networks: Designing Models and Algorithms that Maximize the Probability of Influence
column9: Ericsson Marin, Cedric de Carvalho
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Social network analysis
column101: The current entanglement of humans in a huge fabric generated an unprecedented situation for society: the era of connectivity. This connection ability increased the number of people that can be found on social networks, but the tradeoff is the huge amount of people who came to participate in this search process, making it extremely complex. In this paper, grounded in the concepts of Science of Networks and Artificial Intelligence, we construct models and algorithms aiming to produce a search engine to be integrated in environments representative of social networks, such as online social networks. The differential of this mechanism is its ability to evaluate the numerous paths that connect source and target people, opting for the one where the interpersonal influence is maximized, which increases the probability of connecting people involved. In order to simulate its operation, we implement the mechanism in an application which owns results that exceeded original expectations.
